THE PROGRAM WILL FEATURE PARENT EDUCATION, OPEN-ENDED PLAY IN A VARIETY OF DEVELOPMENTALLY APPROPRIATE STYLES (FROM TUMMY TIME TO IMAGINATIVE PLAY), AND IMMERSIVE ART AND MUSIC OFFERINGS. THE MUSEUM WILL DELIVER THE PROGRAM IN A HYBRID ON-SITE/ONLINE MODEL TO REACH AS MANY FAMILIES AS POSSIBLE. THE MUSEUM WILL PROMOTE THE PROGRAM THROUGH COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN EDUCATION, BABY WELLNESS, AND SOCIAL SERVICES.

THE SOUTH ARKANSAS COMMUNITY COLLEGE LIBRARY IN EL DORADO WILL DEVELOP AND DELIVER PROGRAMMING TO UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS TO EASE THEIR TRANSITION FROM THE ISOLATION OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC INTO IN-PERSON SOCIAL ACTIVITY. THE LIBRARY WILL HIRE A PART-TIME COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT SPECIALIST TO CONDUCT OUTREACH IN TARGET COMMUNITIES AND COLLABORATE WITH PARTNERS TO DELIVER PROGRAMMING. COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL INCLUDE THE UNION COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY SYSTEM, THE CALHOUN COUNTY LIBRARY, THE SOUTH ARKANSAS HISTORICAL PRESERVATION SOCIETY, AND THE SOUTH ARKANSAS ARTS CENTER. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL WORK WITH THE COLLEGE'S CENTER FOR WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT AND ADULT EDUCATION CENTER TO PROVIDE RESUME WRITING AND MOCK INTERVIEWING SESSIONS FOR JOB SEEKERS.

THE MYSTIC SEAPORT MUSEUM IN CONNECTICUT WILL REBUILD ITS MARITIME TRADES AND SKILLS PROGRAM TO PRESERVE HERITAGE SKILLS, CRAFTS, AND TRADES AT RISK OF BEING LOST DUE TO COVID-19 PANDEMIC-RELATED STAFFING AND BUDGET CUTS. THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE EXTENSIVE TECHNICAL TRAINING, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND INDEPENDENT RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF TRAINED STAFF WHO CAN PERFORM AND TEACH MARITIME SKILLS. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL HIRE AND TRAIN (OR RETRAIN) FRONTLINE INTERPRETATION STAFF WHO CAN SHARE INCLUSIVE, AUTHENTIC STORIES OF AMERICA'S MARITIME HERITAGE AND ENHANCE VISITORS' EXPERIENCE TO UNDERSTAND THE NATION'S RELATIONSHIP WITH THE SEA.

ASIAN ARTS INITIATIVE WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE INDIGENOUS ARTS AND CULTURE ORGANIZATIONS, WE ARE THE SEEDS AND INDIGENOUS DIRECTION, TO PRODUCE VISUAL ART EXHIBITIONS AND POP-UP PROJECTS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT AT LEAST ONE INDIGENOUS ARTIST-IN-RESIDENCE IN PHILADELPHIA'S CHINATOWN NORTH/CALLOWHILL NEIGHBORHOOD. INDIGENOUS CONSULTANTS WILL BE PAID TO CONTRIBUTE TO A COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD ASSOCIATED WITH THE PROJECT AS WELL AS TO EVALUATE AND PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING ORGANIZATIONAL PRACTICES AND STRATEGIC PROGRAMMING. THE PROGRAM WILL SERVE INDIGENOUS ARTISTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS, ALONG WITH AUDIENCES WHO INTERSECT WITH THE ASIAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY OF ARTISTS, PERFORMERS, YOUTH AND RESIDENTS IN PHILADELPHIA. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, ASIAN ARTS INITIATIVE AND PARTNERS WILL ENCOURAGE ASSET-BASED PRACTICES THAT SERVE AS MODELS FOR CARE IN THE WAKE OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE PORTLAND ART MUSEUM IN OREGON WILL INCREASE ITS WORKFORCE AND PROVIDE STAFF WITH TRAINING TO BETTER SUPPORT PATRONS AS THE MUSEUM REOPENS AND REENGAGES WITH THE COMMUNITY AFTER THE PANDEMIC FORCED ITS CLOSURE. A NEWLY CREATED ROLE OF RECRUITER WILL SUPPORT THE RECRUITMENT PROCESS FOR THE REHIRING OF APPROXIMATELY 30 STAFF POSITIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT INTERVIEW SKILLS TRAINING FOR HIRING TEAMS, EQUITY TRAINING FOR NEW HIRES, AND DE-ESCALATION TRAINING FOR ALL STAFF. RECRUITMENT EFFORTS AND TRAININGS WILL SUPPORT A MORE INCLUSIVE WORK CULTURE THAT IS WELCOMING TO ALL. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT COMMUNITY HEALING AFTER A YEAR OR ISOLATION AND SOCIAL DISTANCING CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY TRAINING STAFF TO SPARK PRODUCTIVE DISCOURSE ON A RANGE OF ISSUES RELEVANT TO VISITORS.

LONGWOOD UNIVERSITY IN FARMVILLE, VIRGINIA, WILL PROMOTE MENTAL HEALTH AND A SENSE OF BELONGING AT LONGWOOD AND IN THE LOCAL PRINCE EDWARD COMMUNITY. THE UNIVERSITY'S JANET D. GREENWOOD LIBRARY, WHICH IS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC, AND THE COUNSELING AND PSYCHOLOGICAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT WILL WORK TOGETHER ON PROGRAMS TO PROMOTE THE COMMUNITY'S WELLBEING. THE LIBRARY WILL HOST PRESENTATIONS FEATURING AUTHORS OF BOOKS ON WELLBEING TOPICS AND WILL ORGANIZE PROGRAMS ABOUT HABITS THAT PROMOTE WELLBEING, SUCH AS KNITTING, GARDENING, AND JOURNALING. PROGRAMS WILL EDUCATE PARTICIPANTS ON SELF-CARE STRATEGIES AND HELP ALLEVIATE ANXIETY THAT MAY BE ASSOCIATED WITH RETURNING TO IN-PERSON ACTIVITIES FOLLOWING MANY MONTHS OF ISOLATION DURING THE PANDEMIC.

THE BARNES FOUNDATION IN PHILADELPHIA WILL FACILITATE A MUSEUM-COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM SUPPORTING A VULNERABLE POPULATION OF EMERGENT ENGLISH LANGUAGE LEARNERS AGES 3-5 AND THEIR FAMILIES FROM SOUTH PHILADELPHIA'S LATINX IMMIGRANT COMMUNITY. THIS PROGRAM IS ESPECIALLY CRITICAL DUE TO DISRUPTIONS IN EARLY CHILDHOOD PROGRAMS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY PARTNER PUENTES DE SALUD AND THE SCHOOL DISTRICT OF PHILADELPHIA'S SOUTHWARK COMMUNITY SCHOOL, EARLY LEARNERS WILL CONNECT WITH ART AT THE BARNES AS A LAUNCHING POINT FOR GAINING BILITERACY SKILLS AND DEVELOPMENTAL READINESS FOR KINDERGARTEN. THIS ENGAGEMENT WILL INCLUDE WEEKLY ONLINE CLASSES LED BY BILINGUAL TEACHING ARTISTS, MONTHLY HOME DELIVERY OF BOOKS AND ART SUPPLY KITS FOR TEACHING UNITS, BI-MONTHLY RECORDED STORY TIMES, AND ROUTINE FAMILY CALLS TO SUPPORT AT-HOME LITERACY STRATEGIES.

THE CADE MUSEUM FOR CREATIVITY AND INVENTION, IN GAINESVILLE, FLORIDA, WILL HIRE AN ADDITIONAL OUTREACH EDUCATOR AND A PARTNERSHIP COORDINATOR TO EXPAND ITS REACH INTO UNDERSERVED RURAL COMMUNITIES USING ITS MOBILE MUSEUM AND LAB. THIS WORK AIMS TO CLOSE MAJOR ACHIEVEMENT GAPS FOR UNDERSERVED STUDENTS WHICH HAVE BEEN EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY PROVIDING CRITICAL STEAM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ARTS, AND MATH) EXPERIENCES THAT FOSTER CREATIVITY AND DEVELOP AN INVENTIVE MINDSET. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH FOUR COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS TO PROVIDE ON-SITE STEAM EXPERIENCES FOR CHILDREN IN EARLY LEARNING PROGRAMS THROUGH MIDDLE SCHOOL. THE MAJORITY OF THESE YOUTH WILL BE FROM TITLE I AND RURAL COMMUNITY SCHOOLS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY. THE MUSEUM WILL EVALUATE THE PROGRAM'S SUCCESS THROUGH BIMONTHLY MEETINGS.

THE UNIVERSITY LIBRARIES AT THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO BOULDER (CU BOULDER) AND THE COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY PUEBLO (CSU PUEBLO) UNIVERSITY LIBRARY WILL PROVIDE TECHNOLOGY ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS AT TWO CAMPUSES TO HELP IMPROVE RETENTION AND STUDENT SUCCESS. THE LIBRARIES WILL PROVIDE LAPTOPS AND HOTSPOTS TO LOW-INCOME STUDENTS AND STUDENTS WHO ARE VETERANS AT THE CU BOULDER AND CSU PUEBLO. EACH INSTITUTION WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY AND STUDENT AFFAIRS DEPARTMENTS TO IMPLEMENT THE PROGRAM. BY PROVIDING PERSONAL COMPUTERS TO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WHO ARE OTHERWISE UNABLE TO AFFORD THEM, THE LIBRARIES WILL ADDRESS THE INEQUITY IN ACCESS TO TECHNOLOGY, AN INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT FACTOR BECAUSE MANY TEXTBOOKS ARE ONLY AVAILABLE IN AN ELECTRONIC FORMAT AND COURSEWORK MUST BE COMPLETED ONLINE. THIS NEED BECAME EVEN MORE EVIDENT DURING THE PANDEMIC, WHEN MANY HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS MOVED TO HYBRID OR FULLY REMOTE LEARNING MODELS.

THE CARNEGIE LIBRARY OF HOMESTEAD IN MUNHALL, PENNSYLVANIA, WILL EXPAND ENGAGEMENT AND INCREASE ACCESS TO LIBRARY RESOURCES FOR COMMUNITIES IN WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA. TO MEET COMMUNITIES' DEMANDS FOR BOTH VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING AND BETTER PREPARE FOR FUTURE SPIKES IN COVID-19, THE LIBRARY WILL CREATE HYBRID VERSIONS OF THE ONLINE PROGRAMS DEVELOPED WHEN THE PANDEMIC MANDATED THE LIBRARY'S CLOSURE. MONTHLY PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE STEAM CLASSES, CLASSES ON HEALTHY COOKING AND GARDENING, AND BOOK CLUBS. FOR THOSE PATRONS WHO CHOOSE TO PARTICIPATE ONLINE, THE LIBRARY WILL DISTRIBUTE TAKE-HOME KITS WITH ALL NECESSARY MATERIALS. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL PROVIDE FREE INTERNET ACCESS AND COMPUTER SERVICES FOR THOSE WHO DO NOT HAVE ACCESS AT HOME.

THE ANN ARBOR HANDS-ON MUSEUM WILL USE ITS TEAM OF HIGHLY TRAINED EDUCATORS AND ITS BACKGROUND AS A LEADER IN DIGITAL AND HANDS-ON LEARNING TO BRING PROGRAMMING AND TARGETED SCHOLARSHIP OPPORTUNITIES TO K-8 STUDENTS IN AND AROUND ST. CLAIR COUNTY, MICHIGAN. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, THE MUSEUM AIMS TO MITIGATE LEARNING LOSS FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY HIRING ADDITIONAL PART-TIME EDUCATION TEAM MEMBERS, WHO WILL CREATE A NEW SERIES OF PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO FOSTER AN INTEREST IN SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, MATHEMATICS, THE ENVIRONMENT, AVIATION, AND AEROSPACE. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR STUDENTS TO ATTEND THE NASA CHALLENGER CENTER, OPENING IN JANUARY 2022 AT ST. CLAIR COUNTY COMMUNITY COLLEGE, WHERE MUSEUM STAFF WILL LEAD STUDENTS THROUGH AN INTENSIVE AND HANDS-ON LEARNING EXPERIENCE FOCUSED ON SPACE EXPLORATION.

LAS VEGAS CLARK COUNTY LIBRARY DISTRICT WILL ENSURE LOCAL STUDENTS HAVE ACCESS TO DIGITAL LIBRARY CONTENT 24/7, THROUGH THE EXISTING PLATFORM THAT SERVES THE FIFTH LARGEST SCHOOL DISTRICT IN THE U.S. FOLLOWING PANDEMIC DISRUPTIONS THAT CLOSED LIBRARIES AND SCHOOLS, THIS PROJECT EMERGED AS A WAY TO PROVIDE GRADE-APPROPRIATE DIGITAL CONTENT TO EVERY STUDENT AUTOMATICALLY WITH NO LIBRARY CARD. IT REPRESENTS A NEW PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CLARK COUNTY SCHOOL DISTRICT AND IS DESIGNED TO REDUCE BARRIERS TO LIBRARY MATERIALS. THE CHALLENGES OF GETTING PARENTS TO SIGN STUDENT LIBRARY CARDS AND CHECK OUT MATERIALS HAVE BEEN SIGNIFICANT, COMPOUNDED BY THE THREE-SHIFT HOSPITALITY ECONOMY. THE PANDEMIC HAD DEVASTATING IMPACTS ON STUDENT PERFORMANCE AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT, BUT SHOULD FURTHER DISRUPTIONS OCCUR THE LIBRARY WILL BE PREPARED TO SERVE STUDENTS WHERE THEY ARE.

FREEDOM'S FRONTIER NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA WILL HIRE EDUCATORS AND HISTORIANS TO RESEARCH, WRITE, AND SECURE PERMISSION TO USE IMAGES FOR FIVE TOURS OF KANSAS AND MISSOURI HISTORICAL SITES WITHIN THE HERITAGE AREA'S 41 COUNTIES FOR INCLUSION IN A MOBILE APPLICATION. TOURS WILL COVER TOPICS AT NATIVE AMERICAN AND AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORIC SITES, AND AT HISTORICAL SITES ASSOCIATED WITH ORDER 11 - THE FIRST KANSAS COLORED INFANTRY, AND THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD. THE TOURS WILL TELL THE DIVERSE HISTORY OF THE AREA, PROVIDE A RESOURCE FOR TEACHERS AND HOMESCHOOLERS, AND PROMOTE HERITAGE TOURISM. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE FREEDOM'S FRONTIER NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA WILL GENERATE CONTENT FOR THE APP TO HELP EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ON THE HISTORY OF THE REGION. PROVIDED IN A DIGITAL FORMAT INFORMED BY PHYSICALLY DISTANT LEARNING DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE APP WILL BE FREE TO DOWNLOAD.

THE MUSEUM OF HISTORY AND INDUSTRY IN SEATTLE WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO IN-PERSON PUBLIC PROGRAMS THROUGH NEW AMERICAN SIGN LANGUAGE INTERPRETATION AND LIVE CAPTIONING SERVICES. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL LAUNCH A PILOT INITIATIVE TO LIVESTREAM SELECT IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING. THROUGH THIS WORK, THE MUSEUM AIMS TO MAKE ITS PUBLIC PROGRAMS MORE ACCESSIBLE TO PEOPLE IN DISABILITY COMMUNITIES WHO HAVE NOT BEEN ABLE TO ENGAGE IN PAST PROGRAMMING, AS WELL AS TO THOSE WHO ARE UNABLE TO VISIT THE MUSEUM'S PHYSICAL SPACE, BOTH DURING THE ONGOING COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND BEYOND. THE MUSEUM WILL CONSIDER REMOTE ATTENDANCE FOR LIVESTREAMED PROGRAMS, DIRECT OBSERVATION OF IN-PERSON AUDIENCES, AND PARTICIPANT SURVEYS TO GAUGE THE IMPACT OF THE INTERPRETATION AND CAPTIONING SERVICES ON ATTENDANCE AND ENGAGEMENT.

WESTMINSTER PUBLIC LIBRARY IN COLORADO PLANS TO BETTER MEET THE NEEDS OF ITS ALREADY UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY, AMPLIFIED BY COVID-19, BY INCREASING ACCESS TO A RANGE OF LIBRARY SERVICES. IT PLANS TO INSTALL TWO LIBRARY HOLDS LOCKERS IN DIFFERENT AREAS OF THE CITY THAT WILL INCLUDE HOTSPOTS, HOMEWORK HELP MATERIALS, AND JOB SKILLS RESOURCES, ASSISTING THOSE WHO LIVE OUTSIDE THE DRIVE TIME BOUNDARIES OF THE LIBRARY'S TWO LOCATIONS OR WORK NON-TRADITIONAL SCHEDULES TO BENEFIT FROM THE LIBRARY'S OFFERINGS. THE COMMUNITY AND THOSE WITHOUT ACCESS TO DIGITAL SERVICES WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED ACCESS TO QUALITY COLLECTIONS, PROGRAMS, AND INTERNET CONNECTIVITY.

MIAMI CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL TRAIN STAFF FROM OTHER LIBRARIES AND MUSEUMS TO CREATE HIGH-QUALITY, MEANINGFUL VIDEOS FOR CHILDREN AGES 8 AND UNDER TO SERVE AUDIENCES WHO WILL CONTINUE TO SEEK RESOURCES AND PROGRAMS ONLINE, A NEED ESTABLISHED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. MUSEUM STAFF WILL IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT AS A FOUR-PART WORKSHOP THAT WILL TEACH OTHER LIBRARY AND MUSEUM PARTICIPANTS HOW THE MARKETING AND MUSEUM EXPERIENCES TEAMS AT MIAMI CHILDREN'S MUSEUM PRODUCED NEARLY 200 VIDEOS THAT GARNERED 100,000 VIEWS. PARTICIPANTS WILL HEAR FIRSTHAND EXPERIENCES, INCLUDING HOW THE MUSEUM PIVOTED TO ONLINE PROGRAMMING WITHIN A WEEK OF THE COVID-19 CLOSURE. PARTICIPANTS ALSO WILL LEARN HOW TO PLAN THEIR OWN ONLINE PROGRAM STRATEGIES.

HISTORIC SARANAC LAKE IN NEW YORK WILL CARRY OUT SEVERAL INITIATIVES TO CATALOG ITS COLLECTIONS, RESPOND TO RESEARCH REQUESTS, AND PREPARE FOR EXPANSION OF THE MUSEUM. THE MUSEUM PRESERVES AND INTERPRETS THE REGION'S HISTORY AS THE BIRTHPLACE OF THE SANATORIUM TREATMENT FOR TUBERCULOSIS IN THE UNITED STATES AND IS A CENTER FOR SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH. DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, IN THE NUMBER OF RESEARCH AND GENEALOGICAL REQUESTS INCREASED DRAMATICALLY, AD DID DONATIONS TO THE COLLECTION. THE MUSEUM WILL REPLACE AND EXPAND A STAFF POSITION LOST DUE TO REDUCTIONS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC TO MANAGE THE INITIATIVES. THIS NEW COLLECTIONS ASSISTANT WILL RESPOND TO RESEARCH/GENEALOGICAL REQUESTS, PROCESS DONATIONS TO THE COLLECTION, AND MANAGE VOLUNTEER-COMPLETED COLLECTIONS PROJECTS. THE ADDITIONAL STAFF SUPPORT WILL INCREASE THE MUSEUM'S ABILITY TO PROPERLY CARE FOR ITS COLLECTIONS AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC.

THE WILD CENTER, A NATURAL HISTORY CENTER IN NEW YORK STATE, WILL CREATE A FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM TO SUPPORT RECOVERY FROM THE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL IMPACTS OF COVID-19 AND ATTRACT YOUNG PEOPLE TO ADIRONDACK PARK, A RURAL, UNDERSERVED REGION OF THE STATE. THE FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM WILL DIVERSIFY THE CENTER'S WORKFORCE TO BETTER REFLECT CHANGING DEMOGRAPHICS, ESPECIALLY AS IT EXPANDS ITS ONLINE EDUCATIONAL OFFERINGS BEYOND THE REGION. THE WILD CENTER WILL RECRUIT, HIRE, AND MENTOR A DIVERSE COHORT OF FELLOWS TO PREPARE THEM TO WORK IN A SCIENCE CENTER OR MUSEUM AND TEACH THEM TO FACILITATE ONLINE PROGRAMMING AT THE CENTER DURING THEIR FELLOWSHIP YEAR. THIS PROGRAM WILL HELP REBUILD THE CENTER'S INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY TO SERVE DIGITAL PRE-K THROUGH 12TH-GRADE AUDIENCES AND FAMILIES, IN ADDITION TO ITS APPROXIMATELY 100,000 ANNUAL ON-SITE VISITORS.

HABITOT CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN BERKELEY, CALIFORNIA, WILL DEVELOP A MOBILE OUTREACH PROGRAM TO EXPAND THE MUSEUM'S ABILITY TO DELIVER PLAY-BASED EXHIBITS AND ENRICHING MAKER, STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH), AND ART EXPERIENCES THAT ENGAGE FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES WHO HAVE BEEN DISCONNECTED FROM ONE ANOTHER DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE A LARGE-CAPACITY VEHICLE; CREATE A MOBILE MAKER ACTIVITY CURRICULUM; IMPLEMENT A FACILITATOR TRAINING; AND ORDER TOOLS, EQUIPMENT, AND SUPPLIES NEEDED FOR ART AND STEM EXPLORATIONS. NEXT, THE MUSEUM WILL PUBLICIZE AND PRESENT 20 FREE COMMUNITY EVENTS TO A MINIMUM OF 2,500 ADULTS AND CHILDREN IN DIVERSE NEIGHBORHOODS, USING ZIP CODE DATA AND SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCY PARTNERSHIPS TO TARGET FAMILIES MOST IMPACTED BY THE PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL MEASURE THE PROGRAM'S SUCCESS THROUGH EXIT FEEDBACK CARDS FROM PARTICIPANTS, OBSERVATIONS, AND TELEPHONE INTERVIEWS WITH SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCY STAFF.

DRAYTON HALL IN CHARLESTON, SOUTH CAROLINA, WILL ENHANCE ITS ABILITY TO BRING MORE COMPLETE, INCLUSIVE, AND CONSISTENT STORIES TO THE VISITING PUBLIC. AS THE COMMUNITY RECOVERS FROM THE PANDEMIC, THE TRUST WILL HIRE TWO NEW FULL-TIME POSITIONS AN INTERPRETER AND ARCHAEOLOGIST TO SUPPORT THE MUSEUM'S RETURN TO FULL OPERATIONS. THE MUSEUM IS DEDICATED TO FOSTERING A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF COLONIAL AMERICA AND THE EVOLUTION OF LIFE IN THE AMERICAN SOUTH. THE NEW STAFF MEMBERS WILL IDENTIFY AND TELL THE STORIES OF THE 18TH AND EARLY 19TH CENTURY ENSLAVED COMMUNITY AT DRAYTON HALL. MUSEUM STAFF ALSO WILL CREATE INCLUSIVE, ENGAGING TOURS THAT SPEAK TO DIFFICULT HISTORIES AND ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF THE PRESENT CRIES FOR RACIAL JUSTICE. THIS INITIATIVE WILL STRENGTHEN THE MUSEUM'S CAPACITY IN THE WAKE OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE BROOMFIELD DEPOT MUSEUM IN COLORADO WILL RESPOND TO COMMUNITY SURVEY FINDINGS IN THE WAKE OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY DEVELOPING A MOBILE EXPERIENCE TO MAKE IT EASIER FOR CITY RESIDENTS TO ENGAGE IN ARTS AND HISTORY. HIGH-LEVEL ACTIVITIES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE ENGAGING WITH THE COMMUNITY; IDENTIFYING POTENTIAL PARTNERS; BUYING AND TESTING A MOBILE STAGE; AND CREATING A PROTOTYPE OF THE MOBILE EXPERIENCE, WHICH WILL INCLUDE POP-UP EXHIBITS, PROGRAMS, AND PERFORMANCES. THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT, THE BROOMFIELD DEPOT MUSEUM AND PROJECT TEAM WILL BE FLEXIBLE AND RESPONSIVE TO COMMUNITY NEEDS. THIS COLLABORATIVE WILL TRACK ATTENDANCE AND THE NUMBER OF EVENTS AND DEVELOP GOALS TO EQUITABLY LOCATE PROGRAMS BY WARD, NEIGHBORHOOD, SCHOOL DISTRICT, AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS.

BOISE ART MUSEUM WILL HIRE 10 NEW INSTRUCTORS AND ONE NEW PROGRAM ASSISTANT TO DIRECTLY SUPPORT RECOVERY FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY REBUILDING THE MUSEUM'S MISSION-DRIVEN ARTS EDUCATION PROGRAMS, INCLUDING A REMOTE ARTS EDUCATION PROGRAM. PRIOR TO THE PANDEMIC, THE MUSEUM'S OFFERINGS REPRESENTED IDAHO'S ONLY VISUAL ARTS EDUCATION PROGRAM FOCUSED ON ORIGINAL ARTWORKS AND PROVEN EDUCATIONAL BEST PRACTICES, INCLUDING INTERACTIVE DISCUSSIONS AND ARTMAKING WITH STUDENTS IN PRESCHOOL THROUGH HIGH SCHOOL. THE REVAMPED PROGRAMS WILL TAKE PLACE IN THE MUSEUM, IN CLASSROOMS, AND VIA THE MUSEUM'S MOBILE APP, PROVIDING TEACHERS MAXIMUM FLEXIBILITY AND THE OPPORTUNITY TO REACH 15,000 STUDENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL TRACK PROGRESS BASED ON PROGRAM ATTENDANCE, TEACHER ADVISORY COMMITTEE FEEDBACK, AND EVALUATION RESULTS FROM STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND THE CURATOR OF EDUCATION.

THE HOUSTON PUBLIC LIBRARY IN TEXAS WILL PRESERVE AND PROMOTE LEGACY ORAL HISTORY RECORDINGS IDENTIFIED AS RELEVANT TO THE HISTORY OF THE CITY. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL COLLECT NEW RECORDINGS THAT DOCUMENT THE IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC ON RACE AND SOCIAL JUSTICE. PRESERVATION EFFORTS FOR EXISTING COLLECTIONS WILL INCLUDE CONVERTING THEM TO MORE STABLE AUDIOVISUAL FORMATS AND MIGRATING THEM TO AN UPDATED PLATFORM THAT IS EASILY ACCESSIBLE ONLINE. THE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND ITS ORAL HISTORY COLLECTION BY GATHERING NEW STORIES THAT TELL THE LIVING HISTORY OF HOUSTON'S PROMINENT AND CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND DOCUMENT THEIR SOCIALLY RELEVANT ACTIONS FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.

THE CITY OF FORT WORTH IN TEXAS WILL PROMOTE DIGITAL INCLUSION AND HELP TO BRIDGE THE DIGITAL DIVIDE FOR ITS RESIDENTS. THE CITY WILL PROVIDE LAPTOP COMPUTERS WITH INTERNET SERVICE FOR USE BY RESIDENTS WHO LACK INTERNET ACCESS OR PERSONAL COMPUTERS AT HOME. THE CITY ALSO WILL COLLECT AND REVIEW PERFORMANCE TRENDS THROUGH MONTHLY STATISTICAL REPORTS, FIND SERVICE ISSUES AND RESOLUTIONS, AND IDENTIFY BEST PRACTICES AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR PROJECT IMPROVEMENT. MORE PEOPLE WILL HAVE ACCESS TO LAPTOPS, THE INTERNET, AND OTHER DIGITAL RESOURCES OFFERED BY THE LIBRARY. THE CITY ANTICIPATES THAT THE HOLD LIST FOR WI-FI DEVICES WILL BE FILLED MORE QUICKLY, REDUCING THE WAITING TIME FOR THE COMMUNITY. THIS PROGRAM WILL PARTICULARLY BENEFIT ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED POPULATIONS AND ADULTS SEEKING WORKFORCE SKILL DEVELOPMENT AND JOB PLACEMENT THAT HAVE BEEN ADVERSELY AFFECTED BY COVID-19.

THE CANTON MUSEUM OF ART IN OHIO WILL CONTINUE AND EXPAND ITS MUSEUM TO GO PROGRAM, WHICH SUCCESSFULLY PIVOTED TO A VIRTUAL EXPERIENCE DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES EDUCATIONAL AND EXPERIENTIAL VISUAL ARTS LEARNING FOR FOURTH AND SIXTH GRADERS, CREATING A LEARNING PLATFORM TO IMPROVE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND WELLBEING THROUGH ARTS IMMERSION. EACH MUSEUM TO GO LESSON INCLUDES A 360-DEGREE VIRTUAL TOUR OF A CURRENT EXHIBIT, ENGAGING ACTIVITIES ON KEY ARTWORKS THAT ARE ALIGNED WITH OHIO'S LEARNING STANDARDS AND SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL LEARNING STANDARDS, AND INTERACTIVE, HANDS-ON ART MAKING EXPERIENCES RELATED TO THE TOUR AND DISCUSSION. THE PROGRAM ALLOWS CLASSROOMS IN ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED AREAS TO MAKE A MUSEUM VISIT.  THE MUSEUM EVALUATES THE PROGRAM PRIMARILY THROUGH SURVEYS AND CONVERSATIONS WITH STAKEHOLDERS AND WILL ADD AN INDEPENDENT PROGRAM ASSESSMENT TO ENHANCE THE PROGRAM'S DATA COLLECTION AND NEEDS ASSESSMENT. THE PROGRAM HELPS STUDENTS ADJUST TO IN-PERSON LEARNING FOLLOWING THE PANDEMIC WHILE REINTEGRATING SCHOOLS WITH THE MUSEUM'S LEARNING RESOURCES.

HOMEWOOD SCIENCE CENTER, LOCATED OUTSIDE CHICAGO, WILL MODIFY TWO PROTOTYPE STEM MUSEUM-BASED ACTIVITY KITS THAT IT DEVELOPED FOR LOCAL SCHOOLS TO SUPPLEMENT LEARNING DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE NEW KITS WILL INCLUDE TEACHER GUIDES, INSTRUCTIONAL VIDEOS, STUDENT WORKSHEETS, AND MATERIALS FOR COMPLETING NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS-SUPPORTED ACTIVITIES. THE CENTER ALSO WILL UPDATE ITS CURRENT FIELD TRIP PRESENTATION AND ACTIVITIES, ALLOWING STUDENTS RECOVERING FROM A YEAR OF DISRUPTED SCHOOLING RESULTING FROM THE PANDEMIC TO PARTICIPATE IN HOMEWOOD SCIENCE CENTER PROGRAMMING IN CLASSROOMS OR AFTERSCHOOL SETTINGS. THE CENTER WILL MEASURE OUTCOMES VIA THE DIMENSIONS OF SUCCESS SURVEY, DEVELOPED WITH SUPPORT FROM THE NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION BY THE PROGRAM IN EDUCATION AFTERSCHOOL AND RESILIENCY.

HIGHLANDER RESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTER IN TENNESSEE WILL EXPAND ITS DIGITAL COLLECTION OF ARCHIVAL MATERIALS DETAILING NEARLY 90 YEARS OF WORK AS A CATALYST FOR GRASSROOTS ORGANIZING AND MOVEMENT BUILDING IN APPALACHIA AND THE SOUTH. BY RECOVERING, DIGITIZING, TRANSLATING, AND ORGANIZING DOCUMENTS, HIGHLANDER WILL CREATE ACCESSIBLE MATERIALS THAT SHARE ITS HISTORY, PEOPLE, PROGRAMS, METHODOLOGIES, AND ROLE IN SOCIAL MOVEMENTS. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC SIGNIFICANTLY SLOWED THIS WORK. FUNDING WILL ALLOW HIGHLANDER TO BOOST ITS PERSONNEL CAPACITY TO MOVE COMPELLING MATERIALS ONLINE IN ADVANCE OF ITS NINETIETH ANNIVERSARY. THESE RESOURCES, INCLUDING RECENT MATERIAL ROOTED IN AND RESPONSIVE TO CURRENT CONDITIONS EXPERIENCED AS A RESULT OF THE PANDEMIC, WILL BROADEN ONLINE ACCESS FOR NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL GRASSROOTS ORGANIZERS, RESEARCHERS, ACADEMICS, AND AUTHORS SEEKING STORIES ABOUT THE HIGHLANDER'S DECADES OF SERVICE.

THE VIZCAYA MUSEUM AND GARDENS WILL INCREASE ITS CAPACITY TO DELIVER PROGRAMS FOR SCHOOLCHILDREN FROM KINDERGARTEN TO 12TH GRADE. AS A DIRECT RESULT OF THE PANDEMIC, THE MUSEUM LOST 71 PERCENT OF ITS TEAM OF LEARNING PROGRAM FACILITATORS DUE TO LAYOFFS, WHO DELIVERED THE MUSEUM'S EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS. THE MUSEUM WILL UPDATE ITS TRAINING CURRICULUM FOR LEARNING PROGRAM FACILITATORS AND ONBOARD A NEW COHORT OF FACILITATORS TO DELIVER SCHOOL PROGRAMMING. IN ADDITION, THE MUSEUM WILL PILOT THREE NEW FIELD TRIP PROGRAMS ON VISUAL ARTS, LITERACY, AND DESIGN AND ENGINEERING, WITH A FOCUS ON STEAM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ARTS, AND MATH). THIS INITIATIVE WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO BEGIN TO RECOVER FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND RESTORE SERVICES TO PRE-PANDEMIC LEVELS.

THE VILLAGE OF GLEN ELLYN IN ILLINOIS WILL BRING ESSENTIAL SERVICES TO THOSE ADVERSELY AFFECTED BY COVID-19, INCLUDING THE WORKING POOR, HOMEBOUND SENIORS, OR OTHER VULNERABLE, MEDICALLY FRAGILE, AND UNDERSERVED INDIVIDUALS TO BETTER MAKE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THE LIBRARY AND THE COMMUNITY. THE LIBRARY WILL PURCHASE A WI-FI-ENABLED OUTREACH VEHICLE TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO TECHNOLOGY IN THE FORM OF HARDWARE, HOTSPOTS, INTERNET CONNECTION, IPADS, LAPTOPS, AND SOFTWARE AT SENIOR CENTERS, SCHOOLS, PARKS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY LOCATIONS. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL FORM AN OUTREACH TEAM TO OFFER HOMEWORK ASSISTANCE AND EDUCATIONAL ENRICHMENT FOR YOUTH, PROVIDE DIGITAL LITERACY INSTRUCTION, ASSIST WITH RESUME BUILDING, AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO JOB TRAINING SERVICES. THE LIBRARY WILL BUILD RELATIONSHIPS IN ORDER TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE NEEDS OF ITS REMOTE MEMBERS AND INCORPORATE THEIR VOICE WITHIN STRATEGIC PLANNING AND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT.

THE JEWISH MUSEUM OF MARYLAND WILL EXPAND ITS REACH IN THE COMMUNITY BY INCREASING DIGITAL SERVICES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A COMMUNICATIONS AND CONTENT COORDINATOR, A NEW STAFF POSITION CREATED TO MEET THE INCREASING DEMAND FOR HYBRID PROGRAMMING THAT INCLUDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR BOTH IN-PERSON AND ONLINE ENGAGEMENT. THE MUSEUM WILL ESTABLISH NEW PROCESSES AND PROCEDURES AND TRAIN STAFF TO SUPPORT AND SUSTAIN A ROBUST ONLINE ENVIRONMENT. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL REDEPLOY ITS ARCHIVE OF PROGRAMMATIC CONTENT RECORDED DURING THE PANDEMIC AND CONDUCT NEW DIGITAL OUTREACH EFFORTS. THE MUSEUM WILL DESIGN ITS PROGRAMMING TO ELIMINATE MANY OF THE GEOGRAPHICAL AND LOGISTICAL BARRIERS THAT LIMIT IN-PERSON PARTICIPATION. THIS INITIATIVE WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO STRENGTHEN STAFF CAPACITIES TO SUPPORT DIGITAL INCLUSION AND THE ONLINE SERVICES REQUIRED AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE PULASKI COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY IN WINAMAC, INDIANA, IS RESPONDING TO COVID-19 BY EXPANDING ITS REACH TO VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON AUDIENCES IN AN INCLUSIVE WAY AND CONTINUING TO PRESENT A DIVERSE RANGE OF PROGRAMS. IN FOUR PUBLIC MEETING SPACES, THE LIBRARY WILL INSTALL PRESENTATION SYSTEMS CONSISTING OF A DISPLAY MONITOR OR PROJECTOR AND OTHER FEATURES. STAFF MEMBERS WILL INVITE OUTSIDE SPEAKERS TO GIVE PRESENTATIONS REMOTELY AND LOCAL GROUPS WILL BE INVITED TO USE THE ROOMS AND PRESENTATION SYSTEMS FOR THEIR MEETINGS AND PROGRAMS. SPEAKERS WILL BE ABLE TO PRESENT TO A MORE DIVERSE RANGE OF PARTICIPANTS, HELPING THEM FEEL MORE KNOWLEDGEABLE, ACCEPTED, AND INCLUDED IN THE COMMUNITY. THE NEW EQUIPMENT WILL ALLOW REMOTE AND IN-PERSON PARTICIPANTS TO SHARE IN THE SAME DISCUSSION NO MATTER WHERE THEY ARE.

OLBRICH BOTANICAL GARDENS IN MADISON, WISCONSIN, WILL BUILD A NEW WEBSITE WITH A CLEAN, MODERN, REFRESHED LOOK AND FEEL AND A REGULARLY UPDATED BLOG AND WILL REFLECT THE BEAUTY AND WORLD-CLASS DESIGN OF THE GARDENS AND CONSERVATORY. THIS WEBSITE WILL BE UP TO DATE WITH CURRENT WEB STANDARDS OF USABILITY AND ACCESSIBILITY, WILL BE EASIER TO MAINTAIN, AND WILL CONNECT VISITORS FASTER AND MORE EASILY TO RESOURCES. FINALLY, THE NEW WEBSITE WILL BUILD STRONGER AWARENESS AMONG VISITORS OF THE PROGRAMS, SERVICES, AND RESOURCES THE CENTER OFFERS BEYOND THE FREE GARDENS, INCLUDING CLASSES, A LIBRARY, A PLANT INFORMATION SERVICE, AND VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS A GROWING DEMAND FOR MULTIMEDIA AND HYBRID LEARNING RESOURCES BY A RAPIDLY DIVERSIFYING AUDIENCE AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

STEPPING STONES MUSEUM FOR CHILDREN IN CONNECTICUT WILL HIRE A MULTIMEDIA DIRECTOR AND CONTINUE TO RETAIN AN AUDIOVISUAL CONSULTANT WHO IS REFINING THE MUSEUM'S VIDEO PRODUCTION PROCESS, THE CENTERPIECE OF A NEW E-COMMUNITY PLATFORM FUNDED BY OTHER SOURCES AND LAUNCHING IN EARLY 2022. THIS WORK WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO DEEPEN ITS EXPERTISE IN CREATING, CURATING, AND PRESENTING DIGITAL MEDIA IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH. THE INDIVIDUALS IN THESE ROLES WILL HELP FRAME AND ADVANCE THE MUSEUM OBJECTIVE TO BETTER PAIR DIGITAL RESOURCES WITH HANDS-ON ACTIVITY KITS AND SUPPORTS, AS WELL AS ESTABLISH A SCHEDULE OF GRADUALLY INCREASING IN-PERSON, ON-SITE EXPERIENCES THAT WILL BE LAUNCHED AFTER NOVEMBER 2021. THE MUSEUM WILL TRACK PROJECT MANAGEMENT MILESTONES AND DELIVERABLES AND WILL EVALUATE MILESTONES USING AN OVERARCHING LOGIC MODEL AND THE RESULTS-BASED ACCOUNTABILITY MODEL MATRIX. THIS INITIATIVE WILL ADDRESS THE COMMUNITY NEED FOR MULTIMEDIA AND HYBRID LEARNING RESOURCES CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE MINNEAPOLIS INSTITUTE OF ART WILL MERGE ITS EXISTING DOCENT AND GUIDE PROGRAMS AND IMPLEMENT A NEW TRAINING PROGRAM FOR VOLUNTEER GUIDES THAT SUPPORTS AUDIENCE-SPECIFIC LEARNING NEEDS, ENHANCES GUIDES' CULTURAL FLUENCY SKILLS, AND IMPLEMENTS NEW TOUR TOPICS. THE MUSEUM AIMS TO DIVERSIFY THE MAKEUP OF ITS GUIDES AND INCLUDE MORE DIVERSITY, EQUITY, ACCESSIBILITY, INCLUSION, AND BELONGING RESOURCES IN ITS PROGRAMS AND SERVICES. INFORMED BY A PROGRAMMATIC PIVOT TO VIRTUAL LEARNING AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE NEW GUIDE PROGRAM WILL SERVE PRE-K THROUGH 12TH-GRADE STUDENTS AND ADULT, UNIVERSITY, AND MULTIGENERATIONAL AUDIENCES THROUGH IN-PERSON OR VIRTUAL TOURS. THE NEW TRAINING WILL HELP GUIDES INCORPORATE GREATER CULTURAL FLUENCY AND RESPONSIVENESS INTO THEIR TOURING USING AN ANTI-RACIST LENS. BY TEACHER REQUEST, THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO INTRODUCE NEW TOUR TOPICS FOR SCHOOL AUDIENCES WHEN IN-PERSON TOURS REOPEN IN 2022, INCLUDING SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL LEARNING, IDENTITY, EMPATHY, AND SOCIAL ACTIVISM.

HARDING FINE ARTS ACADEMY IN OKLAHOMA CITY WILL IMPLEMENT A CURRICULUM TO ENGAGE STUDENTS AND THE COMMUNITY IN POSITIVE PUBLIC DISCOURSE ON SOCIAL AND CRIMINAL JUSTICE REFORM. BEGINNING WITH THE SPRING SEMESTER, STUDENTS WILL READ JUST MERCY: A STORY OF JUSTICE AND REDEMPTION BY BRYAN STEVENSON. THE ACADEMY ALSO WILL DISTRIBUTE FREE COPIES OF THE BOOK TO MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC WHO ARE INTERESTED IN PARTICIPATING IN A BOOK CLUB AND RELATED DISCUSSIONS. HISTORY, GOVERNMENT, AND FINE ARTS CLASSES WILL COVER MATERIAL RELATED TO CRIMINAL AND SOCIAL JUSTICE. THE CURRICULUM WILL CULMINATE WITH A WEEKLONG CONFERENCE THAT WILL INCLUDE A FILM SCREENING, GUEST LECTURER, AND PANEL DISCUSSION WITH COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES. THESE EFFORTS WILL ADDRESS THE EFFECTS OF SOCIAL ISOLATION DUE TO COVID-19 AND PROMOTE COMMUNITY-WIDE HEALING.

THE SOUTH BEND MUSEUM OF ART IN INDIANA WILL HOST AN EXHIBITION ON LEWIS HINE, THE FATHER OF AMERICAN DOCUMENTARY PHOTOGRAPHY. THE EXHIBIT WILL HIGHLIGHT HINE'S FOCUS ON IMMIGRATION, THE DIGNITY OF THE AMERICAN WORKER, AND HOW HINE'S ACTIVISM WAS INSTRUMENTAL IN REFORMING CHILD LABOR LAWS. COMPANION EXHIBITIONS WILL ADDRESS MODERN-DAY IMMIGRATION AND ADVOCACY THROUGH THE ARTS. THE EXHIBITION ALSO WILL INCLUDE A PANEL OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS, SCHOLARS, AND ARTISTS WHO WILL ADDRESS THE TOPICS OF LABOR, IMMIGRATION, AND THE CHANGING NATURE OF WORK. COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL BE INVITED TO DESIGN BANNERS ON THE THEME, WHICH THE MUSEUM WILL HANG DOWNTOWN IN THE SUMMER. THROUGH ON-SITE AND OFF-SITE PROGRAMMING FOR ALL AGES, THE MUSEUM SEEKS TO SPARK DISCUSSION AND ACTION RELATED TO INCLUSION, STEREOTYPING, AND OTHER ISSUES THAT DIVIDE US IN A SAFE ENVIRONMENT THAT FACILITATES HEALING FROM THE SOCIAL ISOLATION CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE LONGMONT MUSEUM IN LONGMONT, COLORADO, SEEKS TO OPEN AN INTERACTIVE EXHIBITION CALLED TIPIS TO TINY HOUSES THAT TAKES AUDIENCES THROUGH THE EVOLUTION OF HOME BUILDING. THE EXHIBIT WILL QUESTION ASSUMPTIONS AROUND HOW PEOPLE USE THEIR RESOURCES AND HOW THEIR DECISIONS IMPACT THE ENVIRONMENT. THE EXHIBIT WILL INVITE AUDIENCES TO LEARN ABOUT ALTERNATIVE CONSTRUCTION METHODS SUCH AS RAMMED EARTH, HEMPCRETE, STRAW BALE, AND EARTHBAG, SHOWING HOW EACH STRUCTURE TELLS A DIFFERENT STORY ABOUT HUMAN INGENUITY AND INVENTIVE, ADAPTIVE RESPONSES. AS SOCIETY MOVES INTO A POST-PANDEMIC WORLD, THE MUSEUM PLANS ON OPENING THIS EXHIBIT IN JUNE 2022 WITH MODIFICATIONS TO MAKE IT SAFE AND ACCESSIBLE FOR ALL VISITORS.

THE WALTER ANDERSON MUSEUM OF ART IN MISSISSIPPI WILL CREATE AN INITIATIVE TO FOSTER HEALING DIALOGUE ABOUT THE REALITIES OF DEATH, MEMORY, AND REBIRTH IN NATURE AND SOCIETY AS THE NATION MOVES TOWARD RECOVERY FROM COVID-19. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH REGIONAL LIBRARIES AND COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP THIS PROJECT, WHICH WILL INCLUDE AN EXHIBITION OF MEMENTO MORI (REMINDERS OF MORTALITY) AND MATERIAL CULTURE FROM THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION AND THAT OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI MUSEUM; AN ORAL HISTORY PROGRAM CAPTURING AND PRESERVING INTERGENERATIONAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS' REFLECTIONS ON DEATH AND REMEMBRANCE; AND A PUBLICATION PLACING ARTWORK FROM THE EXHIBITION IN CONVERSATION WITH COMMUNITY NARRATIVES. THE MUSEUM AND ITS PARTNERS WILL DISTRIBUTE THE PUBLICATION TO LIBRARIES STATEWIDE AS A LASTING LOCAL RECORD OF THIS PERIOD OF RECOVERY AND CATHARSIS.

THE ASHEVILLE ART MUSEUM IN NORTH CAROLINA SEEKS TO REBUILD AND EXPAND CAPACITY AND OUTREACH FOR ITS LEARNING AND ENGAGEMENT PROGRAMS SERVING ALL AGES. THE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND SCHOOL AND TEACHER PROGRAMS, DEEPEN RELATIONSHIPS WITH DIVERSE COMMUNITIES, ENRICH ON-SITE AND VIRTUAL PROGRAMS WITH PARTICIPATION OF ARTISTS AND OTHER EXPERTS, AND SUPPORT THE REINTRODUCTION OF ON-SITE FAMILY PROGRAMS. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL HIRE AN ASSOCIATE TO DEVELOP OR REESTABLISH RELATIONSHIPS WITH SCHOOLS, LIBRARIES, DAY CARE CENTERS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY CENTERS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ACADEMIC AND PROFESSIONAL ENRICHMENT FOR STUDENTS AND EDUCATORS, AS WELL AS OPPORTUNITIES FOR FAMILY AND PEER GROUP BONDING, AS THE LOCAL COMMUNITY RECOVERS FROM THE SOCIAL AND EDUCATIONAL IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROJECT ALSO WILL WORK TO BRIDGE THE CITY'S URBAN AND RURAL DIVIDE THROUGH OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY BUILDING.

TRAVERSE DES SIOUX LIBRARY COOPERATIVE (TDS), A NONPROFIT AND REGIONAL LIBRARY SYSTEM IN MINNESOTA, WILL PROVIDE READERS AGES EIGHT AND UP WITH FICTION AND NONFICTION E-BOOKS TO HELP THEM BOTH ACHIEVE THEIR SCHOOL AND WORK GOALS AS WELL AS ENJOY A FULL AND RICH LIFE IN THIS PERIOD OF PANDEMIC RECOVERY. WHEN THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC STRUCK, TDS EXPERIENCED AN IMMEDIATE INCREASE IN DEMAND FOR E-BOOKS FOR ALL READERS, ESPECIALLY CHILDREN. THE DEMAND HAS STAYED HIGH AND IS VERY LIKELY TO REMAIN HIGH DURING THE PANDEMIC RECOVERY PERIOD, LEVELING OFF AT 125 PERCENT OF THE PRE-PANDEMIC DEMAND. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP TDS MEET THIS HIGH DEMAND AND SUPPORT PANDEMIC RECOVERY BY PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL AND RECREATIONAL BOOKS IN THE FORMAT THE COMMUNITY FINDS USEFUL.

THE FRIENDS FOUNDATION OF THE BIRMINGHAM PUBLIC LIBRARY IN ALABAMA WILL REBUILD COMMUNITY COHESION BY MAKING TECHNOLOGICAL UPGRADES TO SHARED PUBLIC MEETING SPACES. THE LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL ALSO UPGRADE AND EXPAND MEETING FACILITIES AND MEDIA EQUIPMENT USED BY THE PUBLIC. THIS INCLUDES THE INSTALLATION OF GRID ART PANELS, ROOM DIVIDERS, LAPTOPS, AND A NEW AUDIO/VISUAL SOUND SYSTEM. THE UPGRADES WILL TARGET THE SYSTEM'S THREE MOST REQUESTED COMMUNITY SPACES AND ALLOW THEM TO GROW THEIR COMMUNITY PROGRAMS. AT THE SAME TIME, THESE IMPROVEMENTS AIM TO WELCOME BACK THE HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED AND MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES THAT WERE SHUT OUT AT THE BEGINNING OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM OF LOS ANGELES COUNTY, WITH THE LOS ANGELES COUNTY MUSEUM OF ART AND THE BEARS EARS INTER-TRIBAL COALITION AND CO-CURATED BY REPRESENTATIVES OF THE NAVAJO NATION, HOPI TRIBE, PUEBLO OF ZUNI, UTE INDIAN TRIBE OF THE UINTAH AND OURAY RESERVATION, AND UTE MOUNTAIN UTE TRIBE WILL PRODUCE THE TEMPORARY EXHIBITION BEARS EARS: LIVING LAND. THE EXHIBITION WILL BE THE FIRST TO PRESENT THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE BEARS EARS REGION FROM THE PERSPECTIVE OF THESE TRIBES, WHICH CONSIDER THE AREA INTEGRAL TO THEIR WAY OF LIFE. THE EXHIBITION WILL EXPLORE THE INTERSECTION BETWEEN LIVING PEOPLE, THE OBJECTS THEY CREATE, THEIR ANCESTORS, AND THE LAND. THE EXHIBITION WILL SET A NEW STANDARD FOR CO-CURATION BETWEEN NATIVE GROUPS AND MUSEUMS AND PROVIDE NATIVE COMMUNITIES WITH RESOURCES ENHANCING THEIR CAPACITY TO MANAGE AND PROMOTE UNDERSTANDING ABOUT THEIR CULTURAL HERITAGE, AS LOCAL COMMUNITIES RECOVER FROM THE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE MUSICAL INSTRUMENT MUSEUM IN PHOENIX, ARIZONA, WILL EVALUATE AND REFINE THE CONTENT OF ITS MUSIC-BASED RECREATIONAL AND LEISURE ACTIVITIES FOR SENIOR AUDIENCES. THE MUSEUM ORIGINALLY DEVELOPED THE VIDEO MUSIC PROGRAMS IN COLLABORATION WITH THE MUSIC THERAPY PROGRAM AT ARIZONA STATE UNIVERSITY TO ADDRESS SENIORS' SOCIAL ISOLATION DURING THE PANDEMIC. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH COVENANT HEALTH NETWORK, THE MUSEUM WILL ASSESS THIS CONTENT AND DEVELOP A PLAN FOR FUTURE PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION THAT SUPPORTS SENIOR AUDIENCES RECOVERING FROM THE PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL EVALUATE THE VIDEO MUSIC COLLECTIONS AT 40 SENIOR LIVING FACILITIES, WHERE PARTICIPANTS WILL ANSWER QUESTIONS RELATED TO USABILITY, SATISFACTION, AND FUNCTIONALITY. BASED ON THE EVALUATION FINDINGS, THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE ADDITIONAL VIDEO CONTENT TO SUPPORT SENIORS' PSYCHOSOCIAL HEALTH.

THE KING COUNTY LIBRARY SYSTEM IN ISSAQUAH, WASHINGTON, WILL EXPAND INTERNET ACCESS FOR POPULATIONS FOR WHOM BROADBAND AVAILABILITY IS LIMITED AND CONNECTIVITY FEES ARE COST PROHIBITIVE. THE INITIATIVE WILL FOCUS ON FOUR HIGH-NEED COMMUNITIES ACROSS KING COUNTY, NAMELY SENIORS; K-12 STUDENTS; PEOPLE EXPERIENCING HOMELESSNESS; AND ASSET LIMITED, INCOME CONSTRAINED, EMPLOYED (ALICE) HOUSEHOLDS. THE LIBRARY WILL PURCHASE 134 HOTSPOTS AND WILL COVER MONTHLY COSTS OF CONNECTION SERVICES. THE PROJECT WILL HELP CLOSE THE DIGITAL DIVIDE IN THESE COMMUNITIES BY USING MOBILE TECHNOLOGIES TO PROVIDE ACCESS BEYOND THE WALLS OF LIBRARY BUILDINGS. LOANING INTERNET-CONNECTED HARDWARE TO POPULATIONS MOST AFFECTED BY THE PANDEMIC WILL ENABLE THEM TO ACCESS VITAL RESOURCES AND CONNECT TO PATHWAYS THAT CAN HELP DRIVE RECOVERY.

THE INTERNET ARCHIVE'S COVID-19 WEB ARCHIVE WILL BUILD A CENTRALIZED DISCOVERY AND ACCESS POINT FOR HUNDREDS OF COVID-19 DIGITAL COLLECTIONS CREATED BY MORE THAN 200 LIBRARIES FROM OVER 40 U.S. STATES AND SEVERAL OTHER NATIONS. TAKEN TOGETHER, THESE COLLECTIONS INCLUDE OVER 300 MILLION UNIQUE WEB DOCUMENTS, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS, AUDIO AND VIDEO FILES, DATASETS, AND OTHER BORN-DIGITAL RESOURCES TOTALING MORE THAN 90 TERABYTES OF MATERIALS DOCUMENTING THE IMPACT OF THE PANDEMIC ON COMMUNITIES AND RESIDENTS. A PORTAL THAT AGGREGATES THIS CONTENT, PROVIDES SPECIALIZED SEARCH CAPABILITIES, AND PUBLISHES A VARIETY OF OPEN DATASETS WILL ALLOW STUDENTS AND SCHOLARS TO LEARN ABOUT THE HISTORY AND IMPACT OF THE PANDEMIC AT BOTH A NATIONAL AND HYPERLOCAL LEVEL. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO EXTEND FREE ARCHIVING SERVICES TO ADDITIONAL ORGANIZATIONS TO DOCUMENT THE LOCAL IMPACT OF THE PANDEMIC.

THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA'S SPECTRUM DISCOVERY AREA WILL HIRE A DIVERSITY AND INCLUSION PROGRAM MANAGER AND PROVIDE TRAININGS TO STAFF AND PARTNERS TO ESTABLISH AN INCLUSIVE LEARNING ENVIRONMENT FOR ALL IN ITS NEW HOME AT THE MISSOULA PUBLIC LIBRARY. THIS PROJECT RESPONDS TO THE NEED FOR A WELL-TRAINED TEAM TO ENGAGE MISSOULA'S DIVERSE AUDIENCES AND WILL BUILD THE CAPACITY OF SPECTRUM AND ITS PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO SERVE THE PUBLIC, INCLUDING PEOPLE EXPERIENCING HOMELESSNESS, PEOPLE OF COLOR, INDIGENOUS PEOPLE, AND LGBTQ PEOPLE. BY EMBEDDING FREE, EQUITABLE, INCLUSIVE PROGRAMS IN ITS VIBRANT COMMUNITY GATHERING SPACE, SPECTRUM AND ITS PARTNERS WILL SERVE AS A PLACE WHERE PEOPLE OF ALL INCOME LEVELS AND BACKGROUNDS CAN GATHER, LEARN, AND EXPERIENCE STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH) TOGETHER AS COMMUNITIES RECOVER FROM THE EFFECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

HISTORIC GERMANTOWN, A CONSORTIUM OF 18 HISTORICAL SITES AND CULTURAL ATTRACTIONS IN NORTHWEST PHILADELPHIA, WILL HIRE TWO COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT COORDINATORS. THESE INDIVIDUALS WILL BE BASED AT TWO HISTORIC GERMANTOWN MEMBER SITES, STENTON AND CLIVEDEN, TO BUILD CONNECTIONS WITH THE COMMUNITY AND IMPROVE MEMBER SITES' ABILITY TO REACH AUDIENCES DIGITALLY AS THEY RECOVER FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THESE IN-HOUSE STAFF WILL HELP THE HISTORICAL SITES LEARN MORE ABOUT THE NEEDS OF THEIR STAKEHOLDERS OF COLOR (PREVIOUSLY, HISTORIC GERMANTOWN'S MEMBERS RELIED ON CONSULTANTS TO HELP BUILD AND MAINTAIN THESE RELATIONSHIPS). THE NEW STAFF WILL LEARN HOW TO MOVE COMMUNITY INTERACTIONS FROM TRANSACTIONAL TO RELATIONAL, A SHIFT THAT WILL LEAD TO SUSTAINABLE RELATIONSHIPS.

DUPAGE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN NAPERVILLE, ILLINOIS, WILL RESPOND TO DELAYS IN CHILDREN'S ACADEMIC GROWTH DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY CREATING A PROGRAM OF IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL EDUCATIONAL SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ART, AND MATHEMATICS EXPERIENCES FOR CHILDREN AGES 4-12. THE MUSEUM WILL FACILITATE 45- TO 90-MINUTE LEARNING LABS THAT FEATURE ACTIVITIES ALIGNED WITH NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS FOR FIRST THROUGH FOURTH GRADE STUDENTS. EXAMPLES INCLUDE USING CRAFT SUPPLIES TO DESIGN AND BUILD A CREATURE THAT CAN SURVIVE IN ITS NATURAL HABITAT AND BUILDING A BRIDGE TO EXPLORE ENGINEERING CONCEPTS. ACTIVITIES ARE PROVIDED DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS WITHIN TITLE I SCHOOLS AND OTHER CHILDREN WHO FACE BARRIERS TO INFORMAL EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING. THE MUSEUM WILL USE SURVEYS, INTERVIEWS, AND ANECDOTAL EVIDENCE TO MEASURE PROGRESS IN REACHING PROGRAM GOALS AND OBJECTIVES.

THE GARDENS ON SPRING CREEK IN FORT COLLINS, COLORADO, WILL EXPAND THE FREQUENCY, DIVERSITY, AND FOCUS OF HEALTH AND WELLNESS PROGRAMMING TO RESPOND TO INCREASING COMMUNITY DEMAND RELATED TO COVID-19 STRESSORS. THE GARDENS WILL INCORPORATE PROGRAMMING THAT WAS CREATED DURING THE PANDEMIC ON A MORE PERMANENT BASIS AND WILL OFFER ADDITIONAL YOGA CLASSES, A TAI CHI CLASS, AND A GARDEN HOLISTIC WELLNESS CLASS. NEW PROGRAMS WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR THE SPANISH-SPEAKING COMMUNITY, AND SIGNAGE THROUGHOUT THE GARDEN WILL BE UPGRADED TO INCLUDE BOTH ENGLISH AND SPANISH. LOCAL ASSISTED LIVING FACILITIES WILL HOST A GARDENING PROGRAM FOR THE ELDERLY. THE GARDENS WILL HIRE TWO PART-TIME STAFF MEMBERS AND RECRUIT ADDITIONAL VOLUNTEERS TO CARRY OUT THE HEALTH AND WELLNESS PROGRAMS.

LEHIGH UNIVERSITY ART GALLERIES IN BETHLEHEM, PENNSYLVANIA, WILL PROVIDE A FREE TASTE OF ART PROGRAM TO WEAVE TOGETHER CULTURE AND HISTORY. THE PROGRAM WILL PAIR WORKS OF ART FROM THE GALLERIES' PERMANENT COLLECTION WITH RECIPES FROM LOCAL RESTAURANTS TO HIGHLIGHT THE DIVERSE AND ECLECTIC STORIES, CULTURES, VOICES, AND EXPERIENCES THAT MAKE UP THE SOUTHSIDE COMMUNITY OF BETHLEHEM. INTERACTIVE LECTURES, DIY AT-HOME TASTINGS, STORYTELLING, AND DISCUSSION WILL EXPAND AWARENESS OF THE GALLERIES AS A FREE RESOURCE AND CULTURAL HUB, CONNECT LEHIGH UNIVERSITY TO THE LOCAL COMMUNITY, AND BOLSTER POSITIVE SOCIOECONOMIC CHANGE BY SPOTLIGHTING LOCAL RESTAURANTS AND FARMERS MARKETS PARTICULARLY AFFECTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. WHILE MOST PROGRAMS WILL TARGET A GENERAL ADULT AUDIENCE, ONE PROGRAM PER SEMESTER WILL TARGET FAMILIES AND CHILDREN AND ONE WILL BE OFFERED IN SPANISH, FOR A TOTAL OF EIGHT PROGRAMS.

THE ARLINGTON PUBLIC LIBRARY IN TEXAS WILL EXPAND ITS DIGITAL LITERACY OFFERINGS TO SERVE MORE COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND ADDRESS THE WIDENING GAP IN DIGITAL EQUITY AT THE LOCAL LEVEL. WITH MANY STILL STRUGGLING TO FIND OR UPSKILL THEIR JOBS, THESE LIBRARY RESOURCES WILL BE CRITICAL TO POST-PANDEMIC RECOVERY. PATRONS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO COMMUNITY COMPUTER LABS AND LAPTOP CHECKOUT STATIONS. THE LIBRARY WILL PROVIDE CONNECTIVITY THROUGH EXPANDED PUBLIC WI-FI AT ITS SEVEN LOCATIONS, AS WELL AS AT CITY-MAINTAINED WI-FI HOTSPOTS. THE LIBRARY WILL OFFER FREE DIGITAL LITERACY TRAINING, INCLUDING MULTIWEEK, MULTILINGUAL (SPANISH AND ENGLISH) CLASSES AND ONE-TIME WORKSHOPS, IN ADDITION TO JOB TRAINING AND ESL AND GED CLASSES WITH DIGITAL LITERACY COMPONENTS. TRAINED LIBRARY STAFF WILL ASSIST PATRONS WITH LIBRARY COMPUTERS, SOFTWARE, AND INTERNET-RELATED ISSUES.

THE EVERSON MUSEUM OF ART IN SYRACUSE, NEW YORK, WILL UPGRADE ITS DIGITAL INFRASTRUCTURE TO PROVIDE PATRONS WITH ENHANCED ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS AND PROGRAMS. THE PANDEMIC UNDERSCORED THE NEED FOR EXPANDED TECHNOLOGY TO REACH THE GROWING NUMBER OF VIRTUAL VISITORS AND REDUCE BARRIERS TO PARTICIPATION. THE UPGRADED SYSTEMS WILL IMPROVE THE MUSEUM'S EFFICIENCY, SHARING CAPABILITIES, AND DATA SECURITY. UPGRADES WILL INCLUDE TWO NEW SERVERS, CLOUD-BASED TECHNOLOGY, VIDEO PRODUCTION EQUIPMENT, AND COLLECTIONS DATABASE SOFTWARE. THESE COMBINED TECHNOLOGICAL UPGRADES WILL PROVIDE PATRONS WITH DIGITAL ACCESS TO MORE THAN 10,000 OBJECTS IN THE MUSEUM'S PERMANENT COLLECTION. THEY ALSO WILL SUPPORT PATRONS' ACCESS TO A WIDE RANGE OF PROGRAMS AND EVENTS VIA IMPROVED VIDEO STREAMING CAPABILITIES.

THE FARMINGTON PUBLIC LIBRARY IN NEW MEXICO WILL EXPAND COMMUNITY ACCESS TO SAFE, RELIABLE INTERNET, AN ONGOING CHALLENGE THAT HAS BEEN EXACERBATED DURING COVID-19. THE LIBRARY WILL UPGRADE FOUR EXISTING INDOOR WI-FI ACCESS POINTS AND INSTALL FOUR ADDITIONAL OUTDOOR ONES TO PROMOTE 24/7 ACCESS. LIBRARY STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING ON THE NEW SYSTEMS, AND THE LIBRARY WILL PROMOTE AVAILABILITY OF THE NEW ACCESS POINTS. THE EXPANDED ACCESS WILL SERVE USERS FROM THE NAVAJO NATION RESERVATION, CHILDREN, PEOPLE WORKING FROM HOME, AND THE 19 PERCENT OF FARMINGTON'S POPULATION WHO DO NOT HAVE RELIABLE INTERNET ACCESS AT HOME. IN THE SHORT-TERM, THE PROJECT WILL HELP PROVIDE SAFE AND RELIABLE WI-FI WHILE THE LIBRARY BUILDING'S HOURS ARE LIMITED, AND IN THE LONG-TERM, IT WILL HELP POSITION THE LIBRARY AS A COMMUNITY ACCESS HUB.

THE DELAWARE HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL ESTABLISH DELAWARE HISTORY ONLINE, A SET OF VIRTUAL EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES THAT WILL ALLOW THE PUBLIC TO LEARN ABOUT DELAWARE HISTORY FROM ANYWHERE IN THE WORLD. THE PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE COVID CHRONICLES DELAWARE, A COMMUNITY-AUTHORED JOURNAL OF THE GLOBAL PANDEMIC AS EXPERIENCED BY DELAWAREANS; VIDEOS OF MUSEUM OBJECTS, EXHIBITIONS, AND TOURS ALONG WITH EDUCATIONAL PACKETS DESIGNED FOR STUDENTS IN GRADES 3-6; AND A DIGITIZED VERSION OF THE EXHIBITION COLLECTING WILMINGTON: PLACE, PERSPECTIVE AND MEMORY. THE PROJECT AUDIENCE INCLUDES THE GENERAL PUBLIC, AS WELL AS COLLEGE STUDENTS AND CHILDREN IN GRADES 3-12 WHO ARE LEARNING REMOTELY OR PRIORITIZING DIGITAL FIELD TRIPS OVER IN-PERSON EXPERIENCES DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE SOCIETY EXPECTS THERE WILL BE 30,000 PLUS EDUCATIONAL PACKET USERS; 28,000 PLUS VIEWS OF ALL 16 VIDEOS; AND 600 PLUS VIEWS OF THE ONLINE EXHIBITION BY DECEMBER 2022.

THE NEW HAVEN FREE PUBLIC LIBRARY IN CONNECTICUT WILL PROVIDE PATRONS WITH ON-SITE CONSULTATIONS AND CASE MANAGEMENT SERVICES WITH A LICENSED SOCIAL WORKER AT THREE LIBRARY LOCATIONS. TO IMPLEMENT THE PROGRAM, THE LIBRARY WILL BUILD ON ITS SUCCESSFUL 6-YEAR PARTNERSHIP WITH LIBERTY COMMUNITY SERVICES, A LOCAL ORGANIZATION THAT OFFERS SERVICES TO PEOPLE EXPERIENCING HOMELESSNESS WHO ARE LIVING WITH HIV/AIDS, MENTAL ILLNESS, OR ADDICTION. PEOPLE TURN TO THE LIBRARY FOR INFORMATION RELATED TO A RANGE OF BASIC NEEDS. THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES DEALING WITH ISSUES EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, INCLUDING HOMELESSNESS, THE RISK OF HOMELESSNESS, HUNGER, MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES, MEDICAL CONDITIONS, UNEMPLOYMENT, AND UNDEREMPLOYMENT.

THE FORBES HOUSE MUSEUM IN MILTON, MASSACHUSETTS, WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE MILTON PUBLIC LIBRARY, THE MILTON SUBSTANCE ABUSE COALITION, AND THE OPIOID PROJECT TO PRESENT A WORKSHOP AND ART AND STORYTELLING INSTALLATION AT THE LIBRARY. RECOGNIZING THAT THE OPIOID EPIDEMIC HAS WORSENED SINCE THE ONSET OF COVID-19, THE WORKSHOP WILL INCLUDE FIRST RESPONDERS AND PEOPLE WITH A HISTORY OF SUBSTANCE MISUSE. THE PROJECT WILL BE LED BY VISUAL ARTISTS WHO HAVE HELPED PEOPLE RECOVER FROM ADDICTION AND TRAUMA, DESTIGMATIZED ADDICTION, AND FOSTERED CIVIC DISCOURSE. THE PROJECT WILL CORRESPOND TO AN EXHIBITION ON THE FORBES FAMILY'S INVOLVEMENT IN THE 19TH CENTURY OPIUM TRADE AND ITS LONG-TERM IMPACT ON TODAY'S EPIDEMIC.

EXPLORA WILL IMPLEMENT THEIR EMPOWERING TEENS FOR MENTAL HEALTH AT X STUDIO PROJECT. THIS WORK WILL BRING TOGETHER LOCAL TEENS, MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, AND MUSEUM STAFF TO DEVELOP EXPANDED TEEN MENTAL HEALTH PROGRAMS AND RESOURCES, INCREASE MUSEUM STAFF CAPACITY TO SUPPORT TEENS' MENTAL HEALTH, INCREASE TEENS' AWARENESS OF MENTAL HEALTH CAREERS, AND DESIGN A TEEN LOUNGE AT EXPLORA'S NEW X STUDIO. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL LEARN FROM EXPLORA TEENS AND TEENS IN THE MAYOR'S YOUTH ADVISORY COUNCIL ABOUT THEIR CONCERNS, ASPIRATIONS, AND SPECIFIC QUESTIONS RELATED TO MENTAL HEALTH DURING THE EMERGENCE FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. IT ALSO WILL HIRE AND TRAIN STAFF WITH A FOCUS ON SOCIOEMOTIONAL LEARNING AND YOUTH DEVELOPMENT AND GUIDE THE TEENS THROUGH AN EVALUATION OF THEIR PROJECT.

THE ATLANTIC CITY FREE PUBLIC LIBRARY IN NEW JERSEY WILL IMPLEMENT A PROGRAM TO ASSIST FAMILIES AND LOW-INCOME OR UNEMPLOYED RESIDENTS RECOVERING FROM THE PANDEMIC. THE LIBRARY WILL COLLABORATE WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS TO CONNECT RESIDENTS WITH THE SERVICES, PROGRAMS, AND RESOURCES NEEDED TO ACHIEVE A SUSTAINABLE RECOVERY. THE LIBRARY WILL CREATE A DIRECTORY SUMMARIZING AVAILABLE RESOURCES IN THE ATLANTIC CITY REGION AND MAKE IT AVAILABLE ON THE LIBRARY'S WEBSITE, AS WELL AS THROUGH A LIMITED NUMBER OF PRINT COPIES DISTRIBUTED TO PUBLIC ASSISTANCE AGENCIES. THE LIBRARY WILL DEVELOP AND DISTRIBUTE A PRINT BROCHURE PROMOTING THE DIRECTORY.

THE EITELJORG MUSEUM OF AMERICAN INDIANS AND WESTERN ART IN INDIANAPOLIS WILL BUILD INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY TO CARRY OUT EVALUATION WORK THAT WILL PROVIDE EVIDENCE-BASED INFORMATION TO OPTIMIZE VISITOR EXPERIENCES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME MANAGER OF INSTITUTIONAL EVALUATION TO DEVELOP AN INTEGRATED INSTITUTIONAL APPROACH TO AUDIENCE RESEARCH. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL PROVIDE STAFF WITH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING IN EVALUATION METHODS. THE MUSEUM WILL ROLL OUT THE EVALUATION PROJECT, WHICH WILL INFORM ALL OF THE MUSEUM'S FUTURE PROGRAMMING, IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE OPENING OF THE MUSEUM'S NEWLY REIMAGINED AND REINSTALLED NATIVE AMERICAN GALLERY. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC CAUSED DRASTIC CHANGES IN VISITATION. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL LEARN ABOUT NEW VISITATION TRENDS WHILE DEVELOPING A NEW FOCUS ON AUDIENCE RESEARCH AND A VISITOR-CENTERED APPROACH TO EXHIBITS, PROGRAMS, AND EXPERIENCES THROUGH A MUSEUM-WIDE COMMITMENT TO AUDIENCE RESEARCH.

LIBRARY STAFF AT FORDHAM UNIVERSITY WILL COLLECT, PRESERVE, AND SHARE THE RECORD OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AT FORDHAM UNIVERSITY IN THE BRONX. IN REAL TIME: FORDHAM UNIVERSITY'S COVID-19 DIGITAL ARCHIVE IS A FREELY AVAILABLE AND COMPLETELY SEARCHABLE COLLECTION OF SCANNED DOCUMENTS, PROTOCOLS EMAILS, VIDEOS, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTINGS, ORAL HISTORIES, AND OTHER ITEMS WHICH ILLUSTRATE HOW A UNIVERSITY IN THE EPICENTER OF THE CRISIS NAVIGATED THE PRESENT, AND PLANNED FOR THE FUTURE, DURING THE PANDEMIC. LIBRARY BEGAN COLLECTING FOR THE ARCHIVE IN SPRING 2020 AND IMLS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE TEAM'S CAPACITY TO SCAN AND UPLOAD HARD COPY ITEMS THAT PERTAIN TO THE PANDEMIC AS WELL AS TO GREATLY EXPAND THE USE OF VIDEO FOR PERSONAL NARRATIVES AND ORAL HISTORIES. THE ARCHIVE WILL SERVE AS A GUIDE FOR EDUCATORS TO EXAMINE, A COMPREHENSIVE RECORD FOR HISTORIANS TO STUDY, AND A CHRONICLE OF INDIVIDUAL RESPONSES AND NARRATIVES FOR ALL TO CONSIDER.

THE KENTUCKY HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL HOST TRAUMA-INFORMED TRAINING FOR STAFF AND COLLABORATE WITH STATE AND LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO CREATE A TRAVELING DISPLAY, RELATED PROGRAMMING, AND AN ADJACENT COLLECTING OPPORTUNITY TO CAPTURE STORIES AND ENCOURAGE REFLECTION ABOUT THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND CONCURRENT SOCIAL UNREST. THE TRAVELING DISPLAY WILL FEATURE THE KENTUCKY MASKMAKERS' QUILT, CREATED BY A DIVERSE GROUP OF KENTUCKIANS WITH FABRIC THEY HAD USED TO CREATE MASKS IN THE SPRING AND SUMMER OF 2020. THE DISPLAY ALSO WILL INCLUDE FIVE INTERPRETIVE PANELS, A CASE FOR 3-D OBJECTS AND PAPER MATERIALS, AND AN ELECTRONIC INTERACTIVE SHOWCASING A SCRAPBOOK OF THE QUILT'S CONSTRUCTION AND LETTERS FROM KENTUCKY RESIDENTS TO GOVERNOR BESHEAR. THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY AND ITS PARTNERS WILL DEVELOP PROGRAMMING GUIDES, COLLECTING INFORMATION, AND AN OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE IN FACILITATED STORY CIRCLES, OR CONVERSATIONS.

HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY IN TARRYTOWN, NEW YORK, WILL STRENGTHEN ITS INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY AND RESPOND TO TEACHERS' NEEDS FOR ONLINE RESOURCES DURING AND AFTER THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL HIRE INTERPRETIVE STAFF WITH THE DIGITAL STORYTELLING SKILLS NEEDED TO LEAD VIRTUAL PROGRAMS AND TRAIN THEM IN THE ORGANIZATION'S CONTENT ABOUT SLAVERY IN THE COLONIAL NORTH. THE NONPROFIT ALSO WILL TRAIN EXISTING INTERPRETIVE STAFF IN THE DIFFERENCES BETWEEN HISTORIC, SITE-BASED, AND HANDS-ON LEARNING, AS WELL AS FOSTERING ENGAGEMENT IN A REMOTE CLASSROOM SETTING. THIS WORK WILL HELP THE ORGANIZATION CONTINUE TO DEVELOP VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS THAT DELIVER ACCURATE, EMPATHETIC, AND ENGAGING INFORMATION ABOUT THE HISTORY THAT SHAPED THE NATION. THIS PROGRAM WILL SERVE STUDENTS UNABLE TO VISIT HISTORIC SITES BECAUSE OF GEOGRAPHIC OR ECONOMIC CONSTRAINTS, AND WILL MEASURE SUCCESS THROUGH TEACHER SURVEYS, FOCUS GROUP RECOMMENDATIONS, AND STAFF EVALUATION.

THE LOWRY PARK ZOO AND ITS PROGRAMMATIC PARTNERS WILL CREATE THE HYBRID ONLINE AND EXPERIENTIAL PROGRAM, 'WILD WHERE WE LIVE: ONLINE AND EXPERIENTIAL ENRICHMENT FOR EARLY LEARNING SUPPORT.' BASED ON A PREVIOUS PROGRAM 'CHAMPIONS FOR CHILDREN' PILOTED IN 2020, THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER ASSIST FAMILIES IN RECOVERING FROM PANDEMIC-RELATED CHILD LEARNING AND DEVELOPMENT CHALLENGES. INFORMED BY THE NATIONAL 'TALK, READ, SING' INITIATIVE, ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE VIRTUAL STORY TIMES BY PROGRAMMATIC PARTNER HILLSBOROUGH COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY COOPERATIVE WITH EMBEDDED ANIMAL PRESENTATIONS BY THE ZOO; A NATURE ACTIVITY KIT AND ENGLISH/SPANISH GUIDE DELIVERED TO APPROXIMATELY 450 CLIENT FAMILY HOMES; 'TALK, READ, SING' INTERPRETIVE SIGNAGE AT THE ZOO; AND FREE ZOO ADMISSION FOR PARTICIPATING FAMILIES. THIS PROGRAM WILL SERVE FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN FACING SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGES IN PREPARING THEM FOR SCHOOL DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, ESPECIALLY THOSE WITH LIMITED RESOURCES AND LANGUAGE BARRIERS.

THE YORK COUNTY HISTORY CENTER IN PENNSYLVANIA WILL HIRE A COMMUNITY HISTORIAN TO RESEARCH, COLLECT, PRESERVE, AND INTERPRET THE STORIES OF YORK COUNTY'S DIVERSE COMMUNITIES. THE HISTORIAN WILL WORK WITHIN THE COMMUNITY TO DEVELOP RELATIONSHIPS AND SEEK OUT THE STORIES THAT THE COUNTY'S AFRICAN AMERICAN AND HISPANIC COMMUNITIES WANT TO SHARE ABOUT THEIR HISTORY ALONG WITH ARTIFACTS AND IMAGES THAT BEST ILLUSTRATE THESE ACCOUNTS. THE HISTORIAN ALSO WILL MANAGE THE HISTORY CENTER'S SHARE YOUR STORY: COVID-19 INITIATIVE TO COLLECT PANDEMIC-RELATED STORIES FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THE CENTER HOPES THAT THIS WORK WILL IMPROVE ITS COLLECTIONS, WHICH CURRENTLY LACK ADEQUATE REPRESENTATION OF YORK'S RACIAL AND ETHNIC DIVERSITY AND SHOW YOUTH AND FUTURE GENERATIONS THAT PEOPLE FROM ITS DIVERSE COMMUNITIES HAVE MADE SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE HERITAGE, CULTURE, AND ECONOMY OF YORK COUNTY.

THE MUSEUM OF SCIENCE, BOSTON WILL OFFER A FREE SERIES OF INTERACTIVE, SYNCHRONOUS VIRTUAL LEARNING EXPERIENCES THAT INTRODUCES STUDENTS TO STEM TOPICS. THE MUSEUM WILL DESIGN THE PROJECT TO INCREASE THE ACCESSIBILITY AND FLEXIBILITY OF THESE VIRTUAL SYNCHRONOUS PROGRAMS FOR K-12 EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS. IN RESPONSE TO ONGOING SOCIAL DISTANCING RESTRICTIONS DUE TO COVID-19, THE MUSEUM PILOTED THE INITIAL SESSION OF MUSEUM OF SCIENCE AT SCHOOL VIRTUAL PROGRAM IN 2020. CONTINUING INTO THE FUTURE, THE VIRTUAL PROGRAM FOR SCHOOLS AND TEACHERS WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO UTILIZE ACCESSIBLE COMPLEMENTS TO TRADITIONAL ON-SITE PROGRAMS AND CLASSROOM LESSONS.

THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF MEXICAN ART IN CHICAGO WILL ADVANCE DIGITAL INCLUSION FOR PEOPLE WITH AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER AND OTHER INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES BY DESIGNING A BILINGUAL MOBILE APP AND CONTENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM THAT OTHER ORGANIZATIONS CAN AFFORDABLY SCALE AND REPLICATE. THE MUSEUM WILL FORM A CROSS-DEPARTMENTAL ACCESSIBILITY TEAM TO FACILITATE THIS WORK TO SERVE CHILDREN WITH AUTISM AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES WHO HAVE BEEN DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS PROJECT WILL TRAIN MUSEUM STAFF TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITY COMMUNITY, UNDERSTAND THE BARRIERS TO ENGAGEMENT THAT FAMILIES OF PEOPLE WITH AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER AND OTHER INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISORDERS FACE, AND DEVELOP NEW, INCLUSIVE PROCESSES. THE MUSEUM WILL SOLICIT, REVIEW, AND INCORPORATE FEEDBACK FROM PILOT USERS; PROMOTE THE APP; TRACK DOWNLOADS AND USAGE ANALYTICS; AND PUBLISH A HANDBOOK OF BEST PRACTICES FOR OTHER ART ORGANIZATIONS TO USE.

THE CHESAPEAKE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL ADD EDUCATIONAL FEATURES TO EXHIBITS PROMOTING HEALTHY NUTRITION AND ACTIVITY AS WELL AS FACILITATE ON AND OFF-SITE WORKSHOPS. THE PERMANENT ONSITE 'BODY WORKS' EXHIBIT, WHICH SUPPORTS CHILDREN'S PRETEND PLAY IN A MEDICAL OFFICE SETTING, WILL HAVE ADDITIONAL EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND BILINGUAL CONTENT FOR VISITORS TO LEARN MORE ABOUT NUTRITION, EXERCISE, AND DIABETES PREVENTION. NUTRITION WORKSHOPS WILL INTEGRATE PREPARATION AND TASTING OF NUTRITIOUS FOODS, INCLUDING VEGETABLES AND HERBS HARVESTED FROM THE MUSEUM'S GARDEN. PHYSICAL ACTIVITY WORKSHOPS WILL INCORPORATE LARGE MOTOR ACTIVITY THROUGH SHORT HIKES, GROUP GAMES, MULTI-CULTURAL FOLK DANCE, AND OTHER MOVEMENT-BASED ACTIVITIES. SCHOOLS, CHILDCARE CENTERS, AND OTHER ENTITIES PRIMARILY SERVING LOW-INCOME FAMILIES MOST AFFECTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC WILL HAVE WAIVED AND REDUCED FEES TO VISIT CHESAPEAKE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM, OR OPTIONS TO HAVE A HANDS-ON WORKSHOP BROUGHT TO THEIR SITE. THE ADDITION OF SPANISH-SPEAKING STAFF WILL HELP BRIDGE THE LANGUAGE BARRIER FOR SPANISH-SPEAKING FAMILIES PARTICIPATING IN MUSEUM PROGRAMMING.

THE MATTATUCK MUSEUM IN WATERBURY, CONNECTICUT, WILL EXPAND ITS SCHOOL TOUR PROGRAM BY OFFERING TOURS TO STUDENTS IN GRADES 6-8. THE THEMES OF THE PILOT PROGRAM WILL REFLECT THOSE COVERED IN STUDENTS' CURRICULA AND WILL TAKE A PLACE-BASED APPROACH TO EXPLORING ART AND HISTORY. CONTENT FOR THE TOURS WILL COVER THE TIME PERIOD FROM EUROPEAN SETTLEMENT IN NEW ENGLAND TO THE AMERICAN CIVIL WAR. THE TOURS WILL USE HISTORICAL MAPS TO SHOW THE DEVELOPMENT OF WATERBURY. THE TOURS ALSO WILL EXAMINE POPULAR ARTISTIC MOVEMENTS DOCUMENTING THE CHANGING CONNECTICUT LANDSCAPE THROUGH THE YEARS AND ENABLE STUDENTS TO USE THEIR CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS TO ASSESS ARTIST INTENT. IN ADDITION TO TEACHING STUDENTS ABOUT AMERICAN ART AND THE HISTORY OF THE GREATER NAUGATUCK VALLEY REGION, THE PROJECT WILL ALSO HELP WITH THE ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND ACADEMIC RECOVERY FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC IN THE WATERBURY COMMUNITY.

THE CHICAGO BOTANIC GARDEN WILL ADDRESS LEARNING DISPARITIES EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY CONTINUING AND EXPANDING BUDBURST, ITS ONGOING NATIONAL COMMUNITY SCIENCE PROJECT STUDYING PLANT SEASONAL CHANGES AND PLANT-ANIMAL INTERACTIONS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE BOTANIC GARDEN MEETS THE NEEDS OF DIVERSE SPANISH-SPEAKING COMMUNITIES LACKING TRADITIONAL ACCESS TO SCIENTIFIC EDUCATION. BUDBURST BRINGS RESEARCHERS, CONSERVATIONISTS, AND COMMUNITY SCIENTISTS TOGETHER ONLINE IN INDIVIDUAL AND GROUP ACTIVITIES AND IN PERSON THROUGH COMMUNITY EDUCATIONAL EVENTS TO HELP THEM BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW HUMANS IMPACT PLANTS, ANIMALS, AND THE ENVIRONMENT. THE PROGRAM ALSO PROVIDES SCIENCE-BASED CURRICULA FOR STUDENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES. IN ADDITION, BUDBURST WILL EXPAND ITS MILKWEEDS AND MONARCHS PROGRAM, INCREASING CHICAGO'S BIODIVERSITY BY PLANTING POLLINATOR-FRIENDLY COMMUNITY GARDENS AT 23 PARTNER LOCATIONS. THIS PROGRAM WILL PRIORITIZE NEIGHBORHOODS WITH HIGH LATINX POPULATIONS AND WILL MAINTAIN WEB AND MOBILE BILINGUAL ACCESS FOR ITS BUDBURST RESOURCES.

BARTOW COUNTY LIBRARY SYSTEM IN CARTERSVILLE, GEORGIA, IS WORKING TO ATTRACT RESIDENTS BACK TO THE COMMUNITY WING OF ITS MAIN BRANCH BY EXPANDING AND RESTORING ITS TRUSTED PUBLIC SPACE. THE LIBRARY WILL ORDER AND INSTALL MEETING PODS, BOOTHS, AND CONTACTLESS DOORS IN COMMUNITY RESTROOMS, AS WELL AS BUILD MORE PRIVATE SPACES FOR PATRONS TO CONDUCT MEETINGS, JOB INTERVIEWS, AND OTHER SENSITIVE REMOTE ACTIVITIES THAT HAVE GONE VIRTUAL AS A RESULT OF COVID-19. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE PUBLIC'S CONFIDENCE IN THE LIBRARY'S COMMUNITY SPACES, WHICH WILL INCREASE VISITATION. PATRONS WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO MEET, STUDY, AND USE VIDEO CONFERENCE TECHNOLOGY SAFELY AND PRIVATELY.

THE PORT TOWNSEND MARINE SCIENCE CENTER IN WASHINGTON WILL ACQUIRE TECHNOLOGY THAT WILL ENHANCE ITS ABILITY TO REACH MORE PEOPLE, OPERATE MORE EFFICIENTLY, AND PROVIDE A BETTER VISITOR EXPERIENCE. THE MUSEUM WILL UPDATE ITS WEBSITE, MAKING IT EASIER FOR USERS TO NAVIGATE AND FOR STAFF TO KEEP UP TO DATE. IT ALSO PLANS TO UPDATE THE CURRENT POINT OF SALE (POS) SYSTEM IN THE AQUARIUM AND MUSEUM GIFT SHOP AND ADD A NEW POS LOCATION IN DOWNTOWN PORT TOWNSEND, WHICH WILL IMPROVE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE AND CREATE INTERNAL EFFICIENCIES. THE CENTER WILL PURCHASE EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT LIVESTREAMING OF HYBRID PROGRAMS AND WILL TRAIN STAFF ON ITS USE. THESE NEEDS CAME OUT OF THE PANDEMIC AND WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO CONTINUE REACHING SCHOOLCHILDREN, ADULTS, FAMILIES IN THE MIDST OF SOCIAL ISOLATION AND ACADEMIC CHALLENGES.

MARIANNE BECK MEMORIAL LIBRARY IN FLORIDA IS A SMALL RURAL LIBRARY WITH A SINGLE STAFF PERSON, AND THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE ITS CAPACITY TO SERVE THE HOWEY-IN-THE-HILLS COMMUNITY IN THE WAKE OF THE PANDEMIC. BY HIRING AND TRAINING A PART-TIME EMPLOYEE, THE LIBRARY DIRECTOR WILL BE ABLE TO SPEND MORE TIME ON PROGRAM OFFERINGS, BUDGET, AND GENERAL LIBRARY MANAGEMENT. COVID-19 NEGATIVELY IMPACTED THE LIBRARY'S ABILITY TO OFFER NEEDED PROGRAMS AND SERVICES WHEN SEVERAL VOLUNTEERS LEFT FOLLOWING THE PANDEMIC, AND AN ADDITIONAL STAFF PERSON WILL HELP ADDRESS THAT DEFICIT. WITH ADDITIONAL CAPACITY, THE LIBRARY CAN BETTER CARRY OUT ITS COMMITMENT TO SUPPORTING LIFELONG LEARNING FOR COMMUNITY RESIDENTS OF ALL AGES.

IN RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE DETROIT INSTITUTE OF ARTS PIVOTED ITS STUDENT ENGAGEMENT WORK FROM SCHOOL FIELD TRIP EXPERIENCES IN THE MUSEUM TO VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON EXPERIENCES FOR TEACHERS AND STUDENTS. FOR THIS PROJECT, THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE VIDEO CONTENT FOR ONLINE INTERACTION WITH THE COLLECTION AND CONTINUE TO IMPLEMENT VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS. THROUGH THE DIA DELIVERED PROGRAM, THE MUSEUM WILL DISSEMINATE EDUCATION KITS THAT BRING LEARNING EXPERIENCES FROM THE MUSEUM INTO INDIVIDUAL SCHOOLS AND STUDENT HOMES IN KEEPING WITH THE CENTER FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND STATE OF MICHIGAN GUIDELINES FOR PUBLIC GATHERINGS AND SOCIAL DISTANCING. THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE LEARNERS OF ALL AGES, FOCUSING MOSTLY ON K-12 YOUTH IN THE DETROIT METROPOLITAN AREA.

SPARK, A CHILDREN'S MUSEUM LOCATED IN ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA, WILL PROVIDE FREE MONTHLY ADMISSION TO THE COMMUNITY. THE MUSEUM'S INITIATIVE COMES IN RESPONSE TO A SURVEY IN WHICH COMMUNITY MEMBERS EXPRESSED A STRONG NEED FOR FREE ACCESS DUE TO FINANCIAL HARDSHIPS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM, WITH ITS MANY COMMUNITY PARTNERS, HOSTS PROGRAMS RELATED TO CULTURAL CONNECTEDNESS, HEALTH AND WELLBEING, AND STEAM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ARTS, AND MATH). THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE ITS NEW PROGRAMMING AND FREE MONTHLY ADMISSION AVAILABLE TO FAMILIES AND CHILDREN OF ALL AGES, INCLUDING LOW-INCOME AND ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED FAMILIES. THE MUSEUM HOPES TO REACH MORE THAN 3,000 INDIVIDUALS THROUGH THIS EFFORT, WHICH IT WILL TRACK THROUGH ITS ADMISSIONS SOFTWARE.

HISTORIC NEW ENGLAND WILL HIRE A CURATORIAL FELLOW TO ASSIST STAFF IN DEVELOPING A NEW COLLECTING PLAN TO AMPLIFY MARGINALIZED VOICES AND REPRESENT A COMPLETE HISTORY OF THE REGION. TO INFORM THE INSTITUTION'S NEW COLLECTING PLAN, THE FELLOW WILL IDENTIFY COMMUNITY PARTNERS ACROSS THE REGION, WHO WILL BE OFFERED STIPENDS TO PARTICIPATE IN COLLABORATIVE MEETINGS FOCUSED ON DIFFERENT THEMES, INCLUDING INDIGENOUS HISTORY, BLACK HISTORY, AND LGBTQ+ HISTORY. ADDITIONALLY, THE FELLOW WILL RESEARCH MARGINALIZED AND SUPPRESSED STORIES WITHIN THE EXISTING COLLECTIONS; CATALOGUE AND DIGITIZE 'A TIME TO REMEMBER,' HISTORIC NEW ENGLAND'S COVID-19 AND BLACK LIVES MATTER COLLECTING INITIATIVE; AND WRITE BLOG POSTS SHOWCASING STORIES IN THE COLLECTIONS. THIS PROJECT IS PART OF A LARGER ORGANIZATIONAL INITIATIVE, 'RECOVERING NEW ENGLAND'S VOICES,' WHICH RESEARCHES AND SHARES MARGINALIZED AND SUPPRESSED STORIES ACROSS THE REGION.

THE WITTE MUSEUM IN SAN ANTONIO, TEXAS, WILL STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT IN ITS H-E-B BODY ADVENTURE, AN INNOVATIVE MODEL OF COLLABORATIVE MUSEUM-CIVIC ENGAGEMENT THAT PROVIDES ESSENTIAL DATA TO IMPROVE COMMUNITY HEALTH. THE EXHIBITION ANSWERS A COMMUNITY-WIDE CALL FOR SOLUTIONS TO A CHILDHOOD OBESITY EPIDEMIC, USING DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES TO DELIVER HEALTH EDUCATION MESSAGES PLAYFULLY AND POWERFULLY IN A SUPPORTIVE, NONJUDGMENTAL ENVIRONMENT. THE MUSEUM WILL INVIGORATE THE EXHIBITION EXPERIENCE BY REDESIGNING AND UPGRADING THE YOU ARE WHAT YOU DRINK AND SOUTH TEXAS TRAILBLAZE COMPONENTS AND ADDING A VIRTUAL TAG ELEMENT FOCUSED ON HEART HEALTH AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. IN RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS DEFINED BY SAN ANTONIO'S METROPOLITAN HEALTH DISTRICT, THE MUSEUM WILL INTEGRATE VACCINE AWARENESS INTO THE EXHIBITION CONTENT.

THE CAPE COD MUSEUM OF ART IN MASSACHUSETTS WILL HIRE A CONSULTING FIRM TO COMPLETE A MAJOR DIGITIZATION INITIATIVE FOR ITS PERMANENT COLLECTION. THIS WORK WILL MAKE THE PERMANENT COLLECTION ACCESSIBLE WORLDWIDE TO RESEARCHERS, THE PUBLIC, AND PUBLIC PROGRAMMING; IMPROVE INTERNAL MANAGEMENT; AND PRESERVE THE COLLECTION BY REDUCING PHYSICAL HANDLING OF OBJECTS. WITH NO VISITORS ALLOWED IN THE MUSEUM AFTER THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC CLOSED ITS DOORS AND REDUCED ITS PAID STAFF TO ONE PERSON, PROVIDING AN ONLINE EXPERIENCE FOR MEMBERS, MUSEUM SUPPORTERS, AND THE SOCIALLY DISTANCING PUBLIC BECAME A PRIORITY. THANKS TO THIS DIGITIZATION EFFORT, THE MUSEUM WILL BE ABLE TO SHARE ITS COLLECTION INSIDE THE MUSEUM THROUGH INTERACTIVE MEDIA DISPLAYS, OUTSIDE OF THE MUSEUM THROUGH EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, AND WORLDWIDE IN A SEARCHABLE, INTERACTIVE ONLINE FORMAT.

THE JESSAMINE COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY IN NICHOLASVILLE, KENTUCKY, WILL PURCHASE AND EQUIP A COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS PROGRAMMING VEHICLE TO HOST A VARIETY OF OFF-SITE PROGRAMS AND BETTER RESPOND TO SOCIAL DISTANCING NEEDS CREATED BY COVID-19. THE VEHICLE WILL ALLOW OUTREACH AND PROGRAMMING LIBRARIANS TO INTRODUCE NEW WAYS OF HOSTING OUTDOOR PROGRAMS THAT ARE FLEXIBLE, SAFE, AND RESPONSIVE TO THE NEEDS OF PEOPLE WHOSE ACCESS TO AND USE OF THE LIBRARY'S IN-HOUSE OFFERINGS ARE LIMITED. THE VEHICLE WILL INCLUDE A CELLULAR WI-FI CONNECTION, OUTDOOR FURNISHINGS, A PORCH-LIKE AWNING, A SOUND SYSTEM, AND ASSORTED GEAR AND TECHNOLOGIES. THE JESSAMINE COUNTY PANDEMIC STORIES PROJECT WILL BE THE FIRST PROGRAM SERIES, IN WHICH THE LIBRARY WILL COLLECT AND RECORD ORAL HISTORIES AND PERSONAL STORIES OF THE PANDEMIC FROM RESIDENTS REPRESENTING ALL AGES, REGIONS, ETHNICITIES, AND SOCIOECONOMIC BACKGROUNDS.

THE SONOMA COUNTY LIBRARY IN ROHNERT PARK, CALIFORNIA, WILL DISTRIBUTE MOBILE POP-UP NETWORK KITS TO 12 LIBRARY BRANCHES FOR COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROGRAMS. EACH KIT WILL PROVIDE DIGITAL ACCESS FOR UP TO 100 PEOPLE SIMULTANEOUSLY. THE LIBRARY WILL OFFER PROGRAMS IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH AND FOCUS ON PROVIDING INTERNET ACCESS AND TECHNOLOGY INSTRUCTION TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THE LIBRARY WILL COLLABORATE WITH NONPROFIT PARTNERS AT COMMUNITY SITES TO REACH THE MOST VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES, ESPECIALLY THOSE IMPACTED BY FOOD, HOUSING, AND FINANCIAL INSECURITIES. IN A REGION THAT HAS BEEN DEVASTATED BY WILDFIRES THE PAST SEVERAL YEARS, COVID-19 HAS UNDERSCORED THE NEED FOR ONLINE COMMUNITY RESOURCES AND ACCURATE MEDICAL AND EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS INFORMATION.

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN IN NEW YORK CITY WILL RESTORE AN ASSISTANT POSITION TO REBUILD ITS COMMUNITY GREENING OUTREACH PROGRAMS. IN A TYPICAL YEAR, THE GARDEN'S COMMUNITY GREENING OUTREACH PROGRAMS IMPACT AN ESTIMATED 70,000 RESIDENTS. SINCE THE PANDEMIC'S ONSET, THE GARDEN SCALED BACK AND MODIFIED ITS PROGRAMS FOR REMOTE OR SOCIALLY DISTANCED DELIVERY IN LINE WITH EVOLVING PUBLIC HEALTH GUIDELINES. FULLY STAFFED, THESE PROGRAMS ONCE AGAIN WILL HAVE THE CAPACITY TO ENGAGE RESIDENTS IN GARDENING, NATURE APPRECIATION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. FEEDBACK FROM PAST PROGRAM WORKSHOPS, LISTENING CIRCLES, AND CHECK-INS DURING THE PANDEMIC CONSISTENTLY HIGHLIGHTED THAT THESE OUTREACH PROGRAMS CONTRIBUTE TO COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, A KEY DRIVER OF RECOVERY FROM THE COLLECTIVE TRAUMA OF COVID-19. THE ORGANIZATION WILL SURVEY PARTICIPANTS TO EVALUATE PROGRAM SUCCESS.

THE ATHENS REGIONAL LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL INSTALL AUDIO STREAMING OVER WI-FI AND RADIO FREQUENCY ASSISTED LISTENING SYSTEMS (ALS) TO MAKE THEIR PROGRAMS ACCESSIBLE TO THE DEAF AND HARD OF HEARING COMMUNITY. HEARING LOOP TECHNOLOGY WILL BE INSTALLED ACROSS THE SYSTEM'S LIBRARY BUILDINGS TO ENABLE STREAMING AUDIO FOR PUBLIC MEETINGS, CHILDREN'S STORYTIMES, AND COMPUTER COURSES. LIBRARY USERS WILL BE ABLE TO ACCESS THE ALS IN MULTIPLE WAYS, INCLUDING THROUGH AN APP ON THEIR SMARTPHONE OR A LISTENRF DEVICE PROVIDED BY THE LIBRARY. THE ALS INSTALLATION WILL ALLOW FOR EQUITABLE ACCESS TO LIBRARY PROGRAMMING FOR THE 3.4 PERCENT OF THE REGIONAL POPULATION THAT REPORTS HEARING DIFFICULTIES.

THE SOUTH SIOUX CITY PUBLIC LIBRARY WILL ADVANCE DIGITAL INCLUSION AND PANDEMIC RECOVERY BY PROVIDING LIBRARY USERS WITH IMPROVED ACCESS TO COMPUTERS AND TECHNOLOGY SKILLS TRAINING. IN ADDITION TO LOANING HOT SPOTS, TABLETS, AND LAPTOPS, SERVICES WILL INCLUDE ADDITIONAL DATABASES FOR JOBSEEKERS AND STUDENTS, CLASSES ON BASIC COMPUTER SKILLS, AND AN UPGRADED PC RESERVATION SYSTEM. THESE RESOURCES WILL HELP BRIDGE THE DIGITAL DIVIDE IN SOUTH SIOUX CITY, WHERE 24.4 PERCENT OF THE POPULATION DOES NOT HAVE A BROADBAND SUBSCRIPTION. THE LIBRARY'S TECH CENTER WILL ALSO OFFER INSTRUCTIONS IN MULTIPLE LANGUAGES AND PROVIDE LANGUAGE-LEARNING SERVICES, TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE 57 PERCENT OF THE LOCAL POPULATION THAT SPEAKS A LANGUAGE OTHER THAN ENGLISH AT HOME.

THE CAYTON CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL CREATE A PROGRAM TO HELP CLOSE THE 'PLAY DIVIDE' FOR LOW-INCOME CHILDREN, WHICH HAS BEEN EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL BUILD STAFF CAPACITY BY CONDUCTING STAFF-WIDE DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND INCLUSION TRAININGS; IMPLEMENTING A NEW FREE ADMISSION STRUCTURE; AND STRENGTHENING ITS COMMUNITY PROGRAMMING. THIS MUSEUM ALSO WILL PROVIDE 100 FIELD TRIPS FOR KINDERGARTEN TO 3RD-GRADE STUDENTS, WITH A FOCUS ON TITLE 1 SCHOOLS, AND WILL BUILD COMMUNITY-FOCUSED PARTNERSHIPS, NETWORKS, AND ALLIANCES WITH LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS AND SCHOOLS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THE PROGRAM AIMS TO DELIVER OPPORTUNITIES FOR PURPOSEFUL PLAY AND HIGH-QUALITY ARTS EXPERIENCES TO THOUSANDS OF CHILDREN ACROSS LOS ANGELES, BOTH ON-SITE AT THE MUSEUM AND, WHEN TRANSPORTATION IS A BARRIER TO ACCESS, IN LOCAL COMMUNITIES.

THE ALBANY MUSEUM OF ART IN GEORGIA WILL HOST PROGRAMMING TO HELP PHYSICIANS UNDERSTAND ALTERNATIVE VIEWPOINTS AND ENGAGE IN DEEPER EMOTIONAL PROCESSING TO IMPROVE PATIENT CARE. BASED ON ANOTHER PROGRAM IN WHICH PHYSICIAN PARTICIPANTS REPORTED IMPROVED INSIGHT, EMPATHY, AND ABILITY TO REFLECT IN THEIR CLINICAL WORK, THIS INITIATIVE COMBINES THE BALINT METHOD OF 'DOCTOR-PATIENT RELATIONSHIP GROUPS' WITH AN ART ANALYSIS TECHNIQUE CALLED VISUAL THINKING STRATEGIES. SESSIONS WILL BEGIN WITH GROUP MEMBERS EXPLORING A COMPELLING WORK OF ART TO HELP THEM IDENTIFY AND EXAMINE THEIR PERSPECTIVES AND EMOTIONS RELATING TO THE ART. NEXT, A TRAINED FACILITATOR WILL LEAD PARTICIPANTS IN A BALINT SESSION THAT TYPICALLY RELATES TO THE ARTWORK TO EXPLORE THEIR PERCEPTIONS AND EMOTIONS RELATING TO A PATIENT-PHYSICIAN RELATIONSHIP. THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE BIMONTHLY ART EXPERIENCES FOR THESE GROUPS, INCLUDING VISUAL VERBAL JOURNALING, SOUND EXPERIENCES, AND WATERCOLOR WORKSHOPS. THE MUSEUM'S PROGRAMMING WILL SUPPORT THE MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS WHO HAVE CARED FOR THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF SOUTHWEST GEORGIANS THROUGHOUT THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE DAUPHIN COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY IN CENTRAL PENNSYLVANIA WILL RECONFIGURE ITS BRANCHES TO MEET CDC COVID-19 GUIDELINES AND MAINTAIN FULL ACCESS TO LIBRARY SERVICES. THIS AWARD WILL FOCUS ON REDESIGNING THE MADELINE L. OLEWINE MEMORIAL LIBRARY BRANCH IN DOWNTOWN HARRISBURG. UPDATES WILL INCLUDE PHYSICAL ENHANCEMENTS SUCH AS SPECIALIZED CURVED SEATING AND BOOKSHELVES, PHYSICAL BARRIERS, AND STAGGERED COMPUTER STATIONS. CURRENTLY, 63 PERCENT OF THE BRANCH'S PUBLIC-USE COMPUTERS ARE OUT OF SERVICE TO ALLOW FOR SOCIAL DISTANCING. THIS REDESIGN WILL ACCOMMODATE DISTANCING WHILE ALSO MEETING THE INCREASED DEMAND FOR COMPUTER SERVICES BY JOB SEEKERS AND THOSE NEEDING TO ACCESS HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ONLINE. IT WILL ALSO CREATE A SAFER ENVIRONMENT FOR OLDER ADULTS AND THOSE WITH HEALTH CONCERNS TO CONTINUE ACCESSING LIBRARY RESOURCES.

THE BIRTHPLACE OF COUNTRY MUSIC, A MUSEUM IN THE TENNESSEE-VIRGINIA BORDER TOWN OF BRISTOL, WILL PROVIDE TRAINING TO HELP STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS BUILD CAPACITY, ENHANCE THEIR CURRENT EXPERTISE AND CONFIDENCE, GAIN NEW SKILLS, AND ADDRESS CHALLENGES BROUGHT ON BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE TRAINING WILL INCLUDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR CURATORIAL STAFF, ORGANIZATION-WIDE DISASTER AND FIRST AID TRAINING, DOCENT TRAINING, AND CONFERENCE OR AFFINITY GROUP ATTENDANCE. THESE OPPORTUNITIES WILL OFFER STAFF A CHANCE TO LEARN FROM THEIR PEERS AND MAKE USEFUL CONNECTIONS FOR THE FUTURE. THE BIRTHPLACE OF COUNTRY MUSIC SEEKS TO PERPETUATE, PROMOTE, AND CELEBRATE BRISTOL'S RICH MUSICAL HERITAGE; EDUCATE AND ENGAGE AUDIENCES WORLDWIDE REGARDING THE HISTORY, IMPACT, AND LEGACY OF THE 1927 BRISTOL SESSIONS; AND CREATE RECOGNITION, OPPORTUNITIES, AND ECONOMIC BENEFIT FOR ITS LOCAL AND REGIONAL COMMUNITIES.

THE MARYHILL MUSEUM OF ART IN GOLDENDALE, WASHINGTON, WILL DEVELOP AN ONLINE AND IN-PERSON EXHIBITION OF ITS PARTNER PROJECT, 'EXQUISITELY CONNECTED,' FOR WHICH VIRTUAL PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS CREATED ARTWORK THAT WAS DIGITALLY CONNECTED. IN 2020, THE MUSEUM PARTNERED WITH ARTIST MOLLY JOHNSON AND MONMOUTH ARTS OF RED BANK, NJ, TO LAUNCH 'EXQUISITELY CONNECTED,' A NATIONAL VISUAL ART COMMUNITY-BUILDING EXPERIENCE, AS A PARTICIPATORY CREATIVE RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS PROJECT WILL EXHIBIT, DOCUMENT, AND PRESERVE THESE WORKS OF ART THAT HELPED TO CONNECT ARTISTS AND AUDIENCES OF ALL AGES AND ABILITIES DURING A PERIOD OF INTENSE ISOLATION AND ANXIETY. THE MUSEUM WILL ANALYZE THE INFORMATION GENERATED FROM THE PROJECT, AND STAFF WILL PRESENT THEIR FINDINGS AT A PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCE TO HELP OTHER ORGANIZATIONS BETTER ENGAGE IN VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING AND RELATIONSHIP-BUILDING.

THE BAY AREA DISCOVERY MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE ITS MOBILE ENGINEERING LAB PROGRAM, WHICH SERVES SCHOOLS AND LIBRARIES THROUGHOUT THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA. THE MOBILE ENGINEERING LAB PROGRAM DELIVERS RESEARCH-BACKED, HANDS-ON STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH) LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR PRE-K THROUGH 5TH-GRADE STUDENTS THAT ALIGN WITH THE NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS. THIS WORK WILL DIRECTLY RESPOND TO CRITICAL COMMUNITY NEEDS CREATED OR EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, INCLUDING MOBILE AND SOCIALLY DISTANCED CLASSROOMS AND ACCESS TO STEM ENRICHMENT PROGRAMS. DURING THE 2021/2022 SCHOOL YEAR AND SUMMER, THE MUSEUM WILL DELIVER 74 SCHOOL PROGRAMS OF APPROXIMATELY THREE TO FOUR SESSIONS EACH FOR 5,300 PRE-K THROUGH 5TH-GRADE STUDENTS, ALONG WITH 12 LIBRARY AND COMMUNITY PROGRAMS FOR 1,200 CHILDREN. THE PROGRAM WILL PRIORITIZE SERVING TITLE I SCHOOLS AND SCHOOLS WITH THE WIDEST IDENTIFIED ACHIEVEMENT GAPS.

THE CENTER FOR JEWISH HISTORY HAD TO SHIFT ITS PROGRAMS AND OFFERINGS ONLINE DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS CAUSED STAFF AT THE CENTER TO REALIZE THEY NEEDED TO BE MORE ACCESSIBLE TO ITS DIVERSE PATRONS. WHEN THE CENTER REOPENS, IT HOPES TO BE A MORE INCLUSIVE INSTITUTION BY INCREASING ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS ONLINE AND ONSITE PROGRAMS AND SERVICES AND BY INSTALLING A HEARING LOOP IN ITS AUDITORIUM AND AT ALL SERVICE COUNTERS. IT ALSO PLANS TO IMPLEMENT ACCESSIBILITY FEATURES ON ITS WEBSITE, PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY LIVE CAPTIONS FOR A LECTURE SERIES, AND ADD CLOSED CAPTIONS TO ALL RECORDINGS OF PUBLIC PROGRAMS IN ORDER TO BETTER SERVE ALL VISITORS.

CHILDREN'S MUSEUM TUCSON WILL PARTNER WITH TITLE I SCHOOLS, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, AND LIBRARIES TO DELIVER VIRTUAL OUTREACH PROGRAMS WITH ACCOMPANYING HANDS-ON ACTIVITY KITS TO ELEMENTARY STUDENTS THROUGHOUT THE REGION. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC SHARPLY HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES THAT SUPPORT FAMILIES, CHILDREN, AND EDUCATORS IN NON-TRADITIONAL FORMATS AND INFORMAL EDUCATIONAL ENVIRONMENTS. DURING THE PANDEMIC, THE MUSEUM SHIFTED ITS PROGRAMMING TO PROVIDE BILINGUAL STEM, LITERACY AND ARTS-BASED ENGAGEMENT TO ELEMENTARY CLASSROOMS AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS IN AN INTERACTIVE VIRTUAL FORMAT. EDUCATORS MAY SELECT FROM A VARIETY OF LESSON THEMES ALIGNED WITH ARIZONA ACADEMIC STANDARDS. LESSONS ARE LED BY MUSEUM EDUCATORS IN EITHER ENGLISH OR SPANISH LANGUAGE FORMATS AND INCLUDE LIVE VIRTUAL ENGAGEMENT AND HANDS-ON ACTIVITY KITS. DEMAND FOR THIS PROGRAMMING HAS INCREASED, AND THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE MORE THAN 10,000 STUDENTS IN GRADES PRE-K-6 WITH ACCESS TO THESE RESOURCES.

THE WARD MUSEUM OF WILDFOWL ART IN SALISBURY, MARYLAND, WILL PRESENT A 2022 EXHIBIT, GALLERY BOOKLET, VIRTUAL TOUR, IN-PERSON ARTIST TALK, AND COMMUNITY ROUNDTABLE FOCUSED ON A NEW SERIES OF ARTWORK. THE SERIES, CREATED BY LOCAL ARTIST PATRICK HENRY, REFLECTS BLACK EXPERIENCES OF MARYLAND'S EASTERN SHORE. MUSEUM STAFF MEMBERS WILL USE REGIONAL HISTORICAL ARCHIVES AND WORK WITH THE ARTIST, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND REGIONAL DESCENDANTS FEATURED IN PAINTINGS TO INTERPRET THEMES IN THE GALLERY AND CREATE AN ACCOMPANYING BOOKLET. THE MUSEUM WILL OFFER A VIRTUAL TOUR AND MAKE RECORDINGS OF THE IN-PERSON ARTIST TALK AND COMMUNITY ROUNDTABLE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC ONLINE. THE PROJECT WILL OFFER ARTISTIC AND CULTURAL PROGRAMMING IN A PRIMARILY RURAL REGION, AND IN LIGHT OF THE DEVASTATING ECONOMIC IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, ALL IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL EVENTS WILL BE FREE.

ARTSWESTCHESTER, AN ARTS CENTER IN NEW YORK STATE, WILL PARTNER WITH MENTAL HEALTH AND NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO HELP INDIVIDUALS OF ALL AGES THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY MAKE TILES THAT WILL BE WOVEN TOGETHER IN A MURAL AND UNVEILED DURING A COMMUNITY CELEBRATION. THE PROGRAM AIMS TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND COLLABORATION TO OVERCOME THE NEGATIVE EFFECTS THAT THE COMMUNITY HAS SUSTAINED OVER THE COURSE OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE 50 FREE PARTICIPATORY TILE-MAKING AND PAINTING WORKSHOPS LED BY ARTSWESTCHESTER PROFESSIONAL TEACHING ARTISTS AT WESTCHESTER-BASED CULTURAL VENUES, MENTAL HEALTH FACILITIES, AND COMMUNITY SITES. PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS WILL PROVIDE AN ON-SITE THERAPIST AT EACH WORKSHOP TO BE PRESENT FOR IMPROMPTU DISCUSSION, PROVIDE MENTAL HEALTH RESOURCES, AND HELP INDIVIDUALS SEEK FURTHER ASSISTANCE, AS NEEDED.

THE ILLINOIS FIRE SERVICE INSTITUTE LIBRARY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS URBANA-CHAMPAIGN WILL CONDUCT EXPERIENCE-BASED KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT INITIATIVES TO SUPPORT ILLINOIS FIREFIGHTERS. THROUGH TEACHING, RESEARCH, INFORMATION, AND TRAINING BASED ON EVENTS AND LESSONS LEARNED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE LIBRARY HOPES TO INFORM FUTURE FIREFIGHTER TRAINING. THE LIBRARY WILL GATHER ORAL HISTORIES AND REFLECTIONS DOCUMENTING FIREFIGHTERS' PERSONAL EXPERIENCES DURING THE PANDEMIC AND ADD THEM TO IDEALS, THE INSTITUTIONAL REPOSITORY FOR THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL COLLECT IMAGES DOCUMENTING ILLINOIS FIRE DEPARTMENTS' COVID-19 RESPONSE AND ADD THEM TO THE ILLINOIS DIGITAL ARCHIVES. BOTH RESOURCES WILL BE FREELY AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC.

THE DISCOVERY CENTER MUSEUM WILL ENHANCE CLASSROOM LEARNING AND MITIGATE STUDENT LEARNING LOSS DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY DELIVERING A SUITE OF STEM-FOCUSED PROGRAMMING FOR STUDENTS ENROLLED IN AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS AT TEN AT-RISK ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL VISIT EACH SCHOOL TWO TIMES PER MONTH, REACHING APPROXIMATELY 100 STUDENTS IN EACH PROGRAM WITH HANDS-ON, INTERACTIVE STEM ACTIVITIES THAT ENHANCE THEIR CLASSROOM WORK. TO ENGAGE FAMILIES, THE MUSEUM WILL HOST ONE TWO-HOUR FAMILY NIGHT AT EACH ELEMENTARY SCHOOL, OFFERING HANDS-ON, STEM BASED ACTIVITIES TO STUDENTS AND THEIR FAMILY MEMBERS. FINALLY, EACH AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAM WILL MAKE A FREE STEM-FOCUSED FIELD TRIP TO THE MUSEUM WHERE STUDENTS CAN EXTEND THEIR SCIENCE LEARNING. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO SPARK AN INTEREST IN AND BUILD CONFIDENCE WITH STEM TO SUPPORT INCREASED STUDENT ACHIEVEMENT IN THESE SUBJECT AREAS.
