THE POUGHKEEPSIE PUBLIC LIBRARY DISTRICT IN NEW YORK WILL PROVIDE LIBRARY SERVICES AND FREE WI-FI ACCESS TO LOW-INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS AND EXPAND THE REACH OF ITS DIGITAL LITERACY PROGRAMS. THE LIBRARY DISTRICT WILL OPEN A NEW BRANCH LIBRARY AT THE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP CENTER IN THE HEART OF THE UNDERSERVED NORTHSIDE NEIGHBORHOOD, WHERE IT RAN A HOTSPOT DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM DURING THE PANDEMIC. THE BRANCH WILL HAVE A PARTICULAR FOCUS ON EARLY LITERACY AS AN IMPORTANT DEVELOPMENTAL STEP FOR AT-RISK CHILDREN, AND IT WILL PROVIDE FREE WI-FI ACCESS AND DIGITAL LITERACY CLASSES, CONTRIBUTING TO THE COMMUNITY'S ECONOMIC AND EDUCATIONAL VITALITY. THE PROJECT WILL OFFER A MORE PERMANENT SOLUTION TO THE AREA'S DIGITAL DIVIDE AND SUPPORT INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE STILL STRUGGLING TO RECOVER FROM THE IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE INTREPID SEA, AIR AND SPACE MUSEUM, BASED IN NEW YORK CITY, WILL BROADEN OUTREACH FOR ITS LONG-STANDING LEADERSHIP AND SCIENCE PROGRAM FOR GIRLS TO PROVIDE FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES WITH AN ESSENTIAL SUPPORT NETWORK. IN PARTICULAR, THE MUSEUM WILL ENCOURAGE YOUTH FROM LOW-INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS, WHICH HAVE BEEN ESPECIALLY HARD-HIT BY THE EFFECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, TO PURSUE EDUCATION AND CAREERS IN STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH) FIELDS. THE MUSEUM'S FREE YEARLONG PROGRAM INTEGRATES STEM DISCIPLINES INTO REAL-WORLD EXPERIENCES AND APPLICATIONS, INTRODUCES GIRLS TO FEMALE ROLE MODELS ACTIVE IN STEM FIELDS, AND PROVIDES GIRLS WITH SOCIAL AND PROFESSIONAL SUPPORT, INCLUDING NEAR-PEER MENTORS FROM THE PROGRAM'S ALUMNAE NETWORK. THE MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT COMMUNITY OUTREACH AT NEW YORK CITY HOUSING AUTHORITY HOUSING SITES AND DEVELOP INFORMATIONAL RESOURCES THAT ARE WELCOMING, INCLUSIVE, AND CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE TO ENABLE PARENTS AND CAREGIVERS TO ENCOURAGE YOUTH PARTICIPATION.

CLAY COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY SYSTEM IN FLORIDA WILL REIMAGINE ITS FOUR MAKERSPACES TO ADDRESS COVID-19 DISRUPTIONS THAT AFFECTED PARTICIPATION IN COMMUNITY EVENTS, STUDY GROUPS, COLLEGE PREPARATION, AND THE WORKFORCE. WITH DEDICATED PERSONNEL, THESE FORMERLY SELF-DIRECTED CREATION SPACES WILL BE BETTER POSITIONED TO HELP FAMILIES, TEENS, AND STUDENTS NAVIGATE TOOLS FOR 3-D PRINTING, MAKING ART, PODCASTING, AND CONVERTING DIGITAL/AUDIO MATERIALS. THE ROOMS WILL BENEFIT THOSE REENTERING THE WORKFORCE, STARTING A NEW BUSINESS, WORKING ON SCHOOL PROJECTS, OR COLLABORATING WITH OTHER MAKERS IN THE COMMUNITY. THE PROJECT WILL PROMOTE THE LIBRARY'S FREE TOOLS AND SAFE SPACES THAT SUPPORT COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND DIALOG TO FOSTER PANDEMIC RECOVERY.

THE YANKTON COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY'S DAKOTA TERRITORIAL MUSEUM WILL INCREASE DIGITAL ACCESS TO THEIR COLLECTION AND PROGRAMMING FOR THE REGIONAL COMMUNITY. STAFF WILL ADVANCE ONLINE SERVICES TO MAKE THE MUSEUM'S HISTORIC COLLECTION MORE ACCESSIBLE TO RESEARCHERS AND CLASSROOMS, AN ADDITIONAL FULL-TIME STAFF MEMBER WILL BE HIRED TO CREATE AND IMPLEMENT A POST-COVID PROGRAMMING POLICY AND CURRICULUM. THE MUSEUM WILL CONSULT WITH ORGANIZATIONS AND EDUCATORS TO REVIEW EXISTING HISTORICAL SOCIETY EXHIBITIONS TO ASSESS PROGRAMMATIC RELATIONSHIPS TO THEIR CORE CURRICULUM NEEDS AND IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR ORGANIZATIONS TO CREATE PARTNER PROGRAMS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO BUILD COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS AND ALLIANCES WITH REGIONAL SCHOOLS AND NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO FIND WAYS TO WORK TOGETHER TO BETTER SERVE COMMUNITIES POST-COVID.

PENNSYLVANIA MUSEUMS WILL CREATE AN INTERNSHIP PROGRAM FOR INDIVIDUALS FROM DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS TO JOIN THE PIPELINE OF MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS. THIS INITIATIVE WILL IDENTIFY BEST PRACTICES IN INCLUSIVE HIRING FOR MUSEUMS AND HISTORICAL ORGANIZATIONS BY WORKING WITH A HUMAN RESOURCES CONSULTANT OF COLOR TO PROVIDE PAID OPPORTUNITIES FOR A COHORT OF YOUNG PEOPLE OF COLOR FROM COMMUNITIES GREATLY IMPACTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND TRAIN THEM FOR PROFESSIONAL MUSEUM POSITIONS. THROUGH THE INTERNSHIP PROGRAM, PENNSYLVANIA MUSEUMS ALSO WILL FOSTER INCLUSIVE HIRING PRACTICES IN ITS MEMBER MUSEUMS AND ORGANIZATIONS. THE ASSOCIATION WILL SUPERVISE AND ADMINISTER THE INTERNSHIPS AND MEET WITH INTERNS TO GATHER FEEDBACK AND EVALUATE THE EXPERIENCE.

THE LOUISIANA ART AND SCIENCE MUSEUM WILL CREATE NEW DIGITAL TOURS FOR ITS SOLAR SYSTEM GALLERY, ANCIENT EGYPT GALLERY, AND OUR LOUISIANA MAIN ART GALLERY, WHICH WILL BE AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE MUSEUM'S IN-PERSON GUIDED TOUR AND GUIDED EXPLORATION PROGRAMS FOR KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 12TH-GRADE STUDENTS. EACH DIGITAL TOUR WILL FEATURE A GALLERY TOUR GUIDED BY STAFF CONTENT EXPERTS ALONGSIDE COLLABORATING CONTENT EXPERTS, IN ADDITION TO CLOSE-UP INVESTIGATIONS OF RELEVANT OBJECTS FROM THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION. AFTER THE DIGITAL TOUR PRESENTATION, DOCENTS WILL FACILITATE A GUIDED DISCUSSION AND INVESTIGATION OF THE GALLERY, ALONG WITH A HANDS-ON ACTIVITY FOR STUDENTS PARTICIPATING IN GUIDED EXPLORATION PROGRAMS. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL DEVELOP A NEW VOLUNTEER DOCENT PROGRAM. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE MUSEUM'S CAPACITY TO DELIVER INTERPRETATION-DRIVEN, DOCENT-GUIDED PROGRAMS FOR STUDENTS, ESPECIALLY DURING THE MUSEUM'S RECOVERY FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

BUNCOMBE COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARIES IN NORTH CAROLINA WILL WORK WITH LOCAL ARTS AND CULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUAL ARTISTS TO DELIVER ARTS INSTRUCTION TO PEOPLE OF ALL AGES. THE LOCAL CREATIVE ARTS INDUSTRY SUFFERED AS A RESULT OF THE PANDEMIC, AND THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THAT FINANCIAL INSTABILITY AS WELL AS SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL OUTLETS FOR THE COMMUNITY. EVERY OTHER MONTH, LIBRARY STAFF AND LOCAL ARTS ORGANIZATION ADVISORS WILL SELECT AN ARTIST OR CRAFTSPERSON FROM THE COMMUNITY TO SET UP A WORKSPACE IN THE COMMUNITY ARTS ROOM AT THE EAST ASHEVILLE PUBLIC LIBRARY. THE SELECTED ARTISTS WILL ALLOW INDIVIDUALS TO ENTER THEIR WORKSPACE DURING SPECIFIED HOURS TO OBSERVE AND ASK QUESTIONS ABOUT THEIR ARTISTIC PROCESS. EACH ARTIST ALSO WILL PROVIDE AN INTERACTIVE PROGRAM FOR THE COMMUNITY DURING THEIR RESIDENCY.

THE CINCINNATI MUSEUM CENTER (CMC) WILL COMMEMORATE THE 200TH ANNIVERSARY OF JEWISH COMMUNITY LIFE IN THE CITY BY DESIGNING AND PRODUCING A MAJOR EXHIBITION. DEVELOPED IN COLLABORATION WITH JEWISH CINCINNATI BICENTENNIAL, THE EXHIBITION WILL ANCHOR THIS COMMUNITY-WIDE CELEBRATION AND SERVE AS A SAFE, TRUSTED SPACE FOR DIVERSE AUDIENCES TO ENGAGE IN DIALOGUE AND PARTICIPATE IN PROGRAMMING TOGETHER. THE EXHIBITION WILL PROVIDE A SWEEPING HISTORY OF THE CONTRIBUTIONS OF JEWS TO CINCINNATI OVER THE LAST 200 YEARS, INSPIRE FUTURE GENERATIONS TO BE PROUD OF THEIR HERITAGE AND INVITE VISITORS TO CONNECT THEIR PERSONAL EXPERIENCES WITH THOSE OF JEWISH IMMIGRANTS AND MIGRANTS. THE EXHIBIT WILL INVITE EVERYONE IN CINCINNATI, NO MATTER WHAT CULTURE OR FAITH, TO BE PART OF THIS SHARED STORY BY HONORING THE DISTINCT TRADITIONS AND IDENTITIES THAT EACH PERSON CARRIES.

THE WING LUKE MUSEUM OF THE ASIAN PACIFIC AMERICAN EXPERIENCE IN SEATTLE, WASHINGTON, WILL RESUME ITS NEIGHBORHOOD HERITAGE AND FOOD TOURS IN THE CITY’S CHINATOWN-INTERNATIONAL DISTRICT, SUPPORTING SMALL BUSINESSES AND RESIDENTS IN THEIR RECOVERY FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE TOURS, WHICH WILL RUN FROM FEBRUARY THROUGH OCTOBER 2022, WILL FOCUS ON THE HISTORY OF THE NEIGHBORHOOD BUSINESSES AND STORIES OF THE ASIAN PACIFIC AMERICANS WHO OPERATE THEM. PARTICIPANTS WILL MAKE CONNECTIONS TO ASIAN PACIFIC HISTORY AND CULTURE AND WILL ENGAGE IN EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES DESIGNED TO PREVENT FURTHER ANTI-ASIAN RACISM AND ADVANCE RACIAL AND SOCIAL EQUITY.

THE MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME EDUCATION & COMMUNITY COORDINATOR TO FACILITATE ONLINE AND ONSITE PROGRAMMING FOR STUDENTS, TEACHERS, FAMILIES, AND INTERGENERATIONAL AUDIENCES WITH A FOCUS ON BUILDING, SUSTAINING, AND ADVANCING COMMUNITY-BASED INITIATIVES THROUGHOUT THE MUSEUM'S NEIGHBORHOOD OF EAST HARLEM AND ACROSS THE FIVE BOROUGHS OF NEW YORK CITY. THE COORDINATOR ALSO WILL LEAD TRAININGS FOR MUSEUM STAFF TO SUPPORT INCLUSIVE, TRAUMA-INFORMED EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND HELP BUILD PARTNERSHIPS WITH SCHOOLS, CITY AGENCIES, AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THE MUSEUM RECONNECT WITH ITS COMMUNITY FOLLOWING DISRUPTIONS CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND RESPONDS TO THE COMMUNITY'S NEED FOR FREE, ARTS-BASED PROGRAMMING IDENTIFIED DURING THE PANDEMIC.

THE DOWNERS GROVE PUBLIC LIBRARY WILL STRENGTHEN ITS CAPACITY TO RESPOND TO THE DIGITAL NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY QUICKLY, EFFECTIVELY, EFFICIENTLY, AND RESPONSIBLY BY PROVIDING TAKE-HOME LAPTOP KITS TO BORROWERS AND INCREASING ITS WIFI SIGNAL STRENGTH TO REACH BEYOND THE PHYSICAL BUILDING (E.G., PARKING LOT, GARDEN WALK AREA, BENCHES ALONG PUBLIC SIDEWALKS, ETC.). LIBRARY USERS WHO CHECKOUT LAPTOP KITS OR USE THE EXTENDED WIFI OUTSIDE THE BUILDING WILL ALSO HAVE ACCESS TO THE LIBRARY'S REMOTE PRINTING SERVICE, WHICH INCLUDES UP TO 30 PAGES OF FREE BLACK AND WHITE PAGES PER DAY, AND PICK UP THEIR PRINTOUTS DURING NORMAL LIBRARY BUSINESS HOURS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE BETTER SERVICE TO COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHO DO NOT HAVE SWIFT AND READY ACCESS TO THE INTERNET OR TECHNOLOGY TO HELP THEM MEET THEIR VOCATIONAL, EDUCATIONAL, OR RECREATIONAL GOALS AND OBJECTIVES.

THE METROPOLITAN LIBRARY SERVICE AGENCY (MELSA) OF ST. PAUL, MINNESOTA, AND ITS MEMBER LIBRARIES IN EIGHT COUNTIES WILL PILOT COST-PER-CIRCULATION AS AN ADDITIONAL LENDING MODEL FOR E-BOOK AND EAUDIOBOOK PURCHASES FOR THE OVERDRIVE DIGITAL LIBRARY IN RESPONSE TO HIGH DEMAND FOR DIGITAL TITLES DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. COST-PER-CIRCULATION LICENSES WITHIN A LIMITED POOL OF POPULAR TITLES CAN FACILITATE SIMULTANEOUS BORROWING BY AN UNLIMITED NUMBER OF USERS UNTIL A BUDGET CAP IS MET, INCREASING MELSA'S ABILITY TO PROVIDE EQUITABLE ACCESS ACROSS ITS BROAD GROUP OF USERS. MELSA ANTICIPATES THAT THIS PILOT WILL REDUCE THE PERCENTAGE OF THE DIGITAL CONTENT BUDGET DEDICATED TO PURCHASING ADDITIONAL COPIES OF HIGH-HOLD TITLES AND REDUCE THE AVERAGE WAIT PERIOD FOR DIGITAL TITLES. THEY PLAN TO SHARE THE PILOT RESULTS WIDELY AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES TO INFORM THE BROADER INDUSTRY CONVERSATION IN SEARCH OF SUSTAINABLE AND SCALABLE USE MODELS.

BRIC ARTS MEDIA BROOKLYN WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE NEW YORK CITY DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION (DOE) TO PRODUCE ONE BROOKLYN TV, WHICH WILL BRING EDUCATIONAL MEDIA TO MORE THAN 550,000 HOUSEHOLDS IN BROOKLYN. INITIALLY LAUNCHED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC TO PROVIDE STUDENTS AND FAMILIES ACROSS THE CITY WITH REMOTE CURRICULUM AND EDUCATIONAL CONTENT, ONE BROOKLYN TV PROVIDES STUDENTS WITH EDUCATIONAL CONTENT REGARDLESS OF THEIR ACCESS TO THE HIGH-SPEED INTERNET. NOW IN ITS SECOND YEAR, THE PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON CREATING QUALITY EDUCATIONAL VIDEO CONTENT PRODUCED BY TEACHERS AND DOE STAFF AND INCREASING OPPORTUNITIES FOR HANDS-ON YOUTH PARTICIPATION. AN INAUGURAL COHORT OF 20 HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WILL BROADCAST THEIR ORIGINAL MEDIA CONTENT, AS WELL AS CURATE AND ORGANIZE OTHER TELEVISION PROGRAMS FOR BROADCAST. IN RESPONSE TO CONTINUED STUDENT NEEDS, ONE BROOKLYN TV WILL CONTINUE OFFERING AN ACCESSIBLE OPTION TO HYBRID LEARNING AS STUDENTS RETURN TO IN-PERSON INSTRUCTION.

THE MUSEUM OF POP CULTURE IN SEATTLE WILL HIRE THE ARC OF KING COUNTY (THE ARC), A NONPROFIT SERVING PEOPLE WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, TO SPEND 5 MONTHS OBSERVING AND ANALYZING THE MUSEUM'S LIVESTREAMED WORKSHOPS, IN-MUSEUM WORKSHOPS, AND DIGITAL LESSON PLANS. THE ARC WILL RECOMMEND WAYS THE MUSEUM CAN BETTER ENGAGE STUDENTS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, WHO HAVE BEEN ESPECIALLY IMPACTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. MUSEUM STAFF WILL ATTEND TRAININGS BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK AND WILL ENACT THE ARC'S RECOMMENDATIONS, SPENDING 2 MONTHS WITH SELECTED PARTNER SCHOOLS TO PILOT THE ADAPTED PROGRAM CURRICULA. THE ARC WILL REVIEW THE PILOT EVALUATION REPORT SO THAT THE MUSEUM CAN MODIFY AND FINALIZE THE CURRICULUM. FINALLY, MUSEUM EDUCATION STAFF WILL CONDUCT OUTREACH AND MARKETING EFFORTS TO ENGAGE CLASSROOM TEACHERS, NONPROFITS, AND FAMILY GROUPS TO ATTEND THE REVISED PROGRAMS.

THE MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE IN ASTORIA, NEW YORK, WILL INCREASE ITS CAPACITY TO SERVE LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND NATIONAL AUDIENCES BY UPGRADING ITS DIGITAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND EQUIPMENT AND PROVIDING TRAINING FOR STAFF ON HYBRID PROGRAMMING. THE INFRASTRUCTURE UPGRADE WILL SUPPORT DIGITAL MEDIA EDUCATION PROGRAMS THAT FUSE ONLINE AND ON-SITE PROGRAMS. ENHANCED TECHNOLOGY WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF LIVESTREAM PROGRAMMING AND IMPROVE ITS QUALITY. A NEW DIGITAL MEDIA MAKERSPACE LOCATED IN THE MUSEUM'S CORE EXHIBITION AREA WILL INCREASE TECHNOLOGY-BASED EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH. THESE STRATEGIES ARE INTENDED TO ADDRESS THE WIDENING DIGITAL DIVIDE HIGHLIGHTED DURING THE PANDEMIC. BY IMPLEMENTING A HYBRID SYSTEM OF PROGRAMMING, THE MUSEUM WILL INCREASE ITS ABILITY TO CONNECT WITH AUDIENCES BY ENABLING PARTICIPANTS TO ACCESS PROGRAMMATIC AND MEDIA RESOURCES REMOTELY AS WELL AS ON-SITE.

THE ALBANY INSTITUTE OF HISTORY & ART (AIHA) WILL CREATE AN ONLINE RESOURCE OF ONE HUNDRED DIGITIZED ITEMS FROM THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION EXPLORING THE BLACK EXPERIENCE IN ALBANY, NEW YORK, FROM 1650 TO 1877. AIHA'S PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY, CONTEXTUALIZE, DIGITIZE, AND UPLOAD COLLECTION ITEMS HIGHLIGHTING ALBANY'S AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY AS THE FIRST PART OF THE MUCH LARGER ALBANY AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY PROJECT, WHICH SEEKS TO EXPAND THE LIMITED SCHOLARSHIP AND RESEARCH ABOUT AFRICAN AMERICAN LIVES IN ALBANY DURING THIS PERIOD. THE PROJECT PAIRS SEASONED MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS WITH EMERGING MUSEUM AND LIBRARY/ARCHIVES PROFESSIONALS IN A COLLABORATIVE MENTORSHIP MODEL TO GROW THE PIPELINE OF UNDERREPRESENTED PROFESSIONALS IN THE FIELD. THE PROJECT WILL HELP WITH COVID-19 PANDEMIC RECOVERY BY CREATING MORE ONLINE RESOURCES, BUILDING STAFF CAPACITY THROUGH MENTORSHIP, AND ESTABLISHING A FRAMEWORK FOR FUTURE ONLINE PROJECTS.

THE ALPINE PUBLIC LIBRARY IN BREWSTER COUNTY, TEXAS, AIMS TO IMPROVE CHILDHOOD DEVELOPMENT AND OVERCOME SETBACKS RESULTING FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY ENHANCING ITS DIGITAL PLATFORMS AND ONLINE SERVICES AND UPGRADING THE LIBRARY'S DIGITAL LITERACY PROGRAMS. THE LIBRARY, WHICH SERVICES AN AREA OF APPROXIMATELY 6,000 SQUARE MILES, WILL INSTALL INTERACTIVE WHITEBOARDS TO ENHANCE BOTH IN-PERSON AND DISTANCE ACTIVITIES THAT PROMOTE READING AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. THEY ALSO WILL REVITALIZE AND EXPAND THEIR ROBOTICS PROGRAM WITH MORE PROGRAMMABLE ROBOTS, A MAKER SPACE, AND 3D PRINTERS. STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO ACCESS LIBRARY PROGRAMS NO MATTER WHERE THEY LIVE.

AQUINAS COLLEGE IN GRAND RAPIDS, MICHIGAN, WILL CREATE A DIGITAL COLLECTION OF DOCUMENTARY SOURCES AND TANGIBLE OBJECTS THAT REPRESENT THE RESPONSE BY THE COLLEGE AND THE LARGER COMMUNITY TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE COLLECTION WILL INCLUDE 30 ORAL HISTORIES AND PHYSICAL ARTIFACTS COLLECTED FROM COLLEGE STUDENTS, ALUMNI, FACULTY, STAFF, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. A NEW WEBSITE WILL MAKE THE COLLECTION WIDELY ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE AQUINAS' ONLINE PRESENCE AND PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE RESOURCE FOR FUTURE STUDENTS, FACULTY, AND RESEARCHERS SEEKING INFORMATION ON HOW THE COMMUNITY DEALT WITH THIS GLOBAL PANDEMIC.

THE SALEM ART ASSOCIATION WILL HIRE AN EDUCATION DIRECTOR TO DEVELOP PROGRAMS AND FIELD TRIPS THAT WILL ENCOURAGE THE RETURN OF SCHOOL AND FAMILY VISITORS TO ITS BUSH HOUSE MUSEUM FOLLOWING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE EDUCATION DIRECTOR WILL REDESIGN EXISTING FIELD TRIPS FOR FOURTH GRADERS AND DEVELOP NEW FIELD TRIP EXPERIENCES FOR MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THAT CONNECT TO STATE EDUCATION STANDARDS. THE ASSOCIATION WILL POST EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS FOR K-12 STUDENTS ONLINE. WITH SUPPORT FROM LOCAL HISTORIANS AND LEADERS OF UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES, THE MUSEUM WILL REWRITE SCRIPTS THAT ITS GUIDES USE TO CONDUCT TOURS, AS WELL AS EXHIBITION MATERIALS TO INCLUDE THE HISTORY OF SALEM'S DIVERSE, EARLY COMMUNITY. THE ASSOCIATION WILL ALSO DEVELOP TOURS OF DOWNTOWN SALEM THAT REINTERPRET HISTORIC BUILDINGS AND EVENTS IN SALEM'S HISTORY, PROVIDING A BRIDGE TO CURRENT SOCIAL AND RACIAL JUSTICE ISSUES.

THE CONNECTICUT SCIENCE CENTER WILL RESPOND TO A COVID-19 NEED EXPRESSED BY FAMILIES FOR OUTDOOR LEARNING EXPERIENCES BY DEVELOPING FOUR OUTDOOR, STEM-FOCUSED EVENTS AT ITS OUTDOOR PLAZA. EACH EVENT WILL FOCUS ON DIFFERENT AREAS OF SCIENCE AND WILL FEATURE PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL ARTS PERFORMERS, VENDORS, AND PARTNERS, AS WELL AS MUSEUM EDUCATORS WHO WILL LEAD INTERACTIVE SCIENCE DEMONSTRATIONS THAT CONNECT TO NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS. ADDITIONALLY, THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP A PERMANENT OUTDOOR INTERACTIVE EXHIBIT THAT ALLOWS VISITORS TO USE THEIR SHADOW TO TELL THE TIME, ALONG WITH ADDITIONAL CONTENT THAT SUPPORTS CITIZEN SCIENCE ACTIVITIES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL SUPPORT STUDENTS' RECOVERY FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY PROVIDING OUTDOOR STEM EXPERIENCES OUTDOORS THAT HELP THEM CONNECT TO THE LOCAL ENVIRONMENT.

THE SAN DIEGO RAILROAD MUSEUM WILL DIGITIZE AT LEAST 50 PERCENT OF THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION AND RESEARCH LIBRARY CATALOG TO ALLOW THE PUBLIC TO ACCESS INFORMATION AND LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES. AFTER BEING CLOSED FOR 11 MONTHS DURING THE PANDEMIC, THE MUSEUM AIMS TO OPEN DOORS TO GAIN KNOWLEDGE, SHARE PORTIONS OF THE COLLECTION NOT REGULARLY ON VIEW TO THE PUBLIC, AND GET INFORMATION INTO THE HANDS AND HOMES OF THE MUSEUM COMMUNITY, INCLUDING HOBBY AND INDUSTRY EXPERTS, HISTORIANS, RESEARCHERS, SCHOOLS AND STUDENTS OF ALL GRADE LEVELS, ARTS AND CULTURE SUPPORTERS, AND THE PUBLIC IN AND BEYOND SAN DIEGO. THE MUSEUM WILL SURVEY SPECIFIC FOCUS GROUPS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND WHAT MUSEUM STAKEHOLDERS WANT TO SEE. HAVING A COMPREHENSIVE DIGITAL DATABASE FOR THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION AND RESEARCH LIBRARY WILL REINFORCE AND ADVANCE THE MUSEUM'S MISSION BY ENGAGING AUDIENCES WITH A ROBUST ONLINE EXPERIENCE.

THE DISCOVERY CENTER AT MURFREE SPRING IN MURFREESBORO, TENNESSEE, WILL CONDUCT AN AUDIENCE-INFORMED PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVE TO ENSURE THE POST-PANDEMIC RETURN OF A SUPPORTIVE AND ACCESSIBLE MUSEUM ENVIRONMENT FOR CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES AND THEIR FAMILIES. MUSEUM STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING IN DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING PROGRAMS THAT ACCOMMODATE THE NEEDS OF VISITORS WITH VARYING ABILITIES. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL REVITALIZE ITS SPECIAL NEEDS COUNCIL, AN ADVISORY GROUP OF PROFESSIONALS WITH EXPERTISE IN OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY, SPECIAL EDUCATION, AND MUSEUM ACCESSIBILITY, TO SUPPORT PROGRAMMING THAT ENGAGES CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES. THE MUSEUM WILL INFORM ITS PROGRAMMING BY CONDUCTING FOCUS GROUPS WITH CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES AND THEIR FAMILIES.

THE HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL AND TOLERANCE CENTER OF NASSAU COUNTY IN GLEN COVE, NEW YORK, WILL CONDUCT A MULTIFACETED PROGRAM TO BRING PATRONS BACK TO ITS LOUIS POSNER MEMORIAL LIBRARY FOLLOWING A 14-MONTH CLOSURE DUE TO THE PANDEMIC. THE CENTER WILL CREATE AND DISSEMINATE MATERIALS TO PUBLICIZE THE COLLECTION AND WILL IMPLEMENT AN OUTREACH PLAN TARGETED TO LOCAL UNIVERSITIES, PUBLIC SCHOOLS, AND OTHER PUBLIC LIBRARIES. A MONTHLY BOOK GROUP MEETING WILL ENCOURAGE THE LOCAL COMMUNITY TO USE THE LIBRARY'S RESOURCES. AN ONLINE COURSE WILL DRAW ON LIBRARY RESOURCES TO HELP CHILDREN AND GRANDCHILDREN OF HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS RESEARCH THEIR FAMILY HISTORIES.

FRANKLIN PARK CONSERVATORY AND BOTANICAL GARDENS IN OHIO WILL HIRE A COMMUNITY OUTREACH MANAGER TO REVITALIZE THE ORGANIZATION'S OUTREACH PROGRAM TO HELP WITH POST-PANDEMIC COMMUNITY REBUILDING. THIS NEW STAFF MEMBER WILL CULTIVATE NEW PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, INSTITUTIONS, AND OTHER GROUPS WORKING WITH COLUMBUS' UNDERSERVED NEAR EAST SIDE AND SOUTH SIDE NEIGHBORHOODS. FRANKLIN PARK CONSERVATORY AND BOTANICAL GARDENS ALSO WILL PROVIDE 500 FREE YEARLONG MEMBERSHIPS TO ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED FAMILIES IN THE TARGET NEIGHBORHOODS, WRAPAROUND PROGRAMMING TO ENSURE THESE FAMILIES RECEIVE THE MAXIMUM BENEFIT OF THEIR MEMBERSHIP, ON- AND OFF-SITE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING, AND FREE ADMISSION DAYS FOR THE COUNTY. THROUGH THIS EFFORT, THE CONSERVATORY WILL ENSURE ITS PROGRAMS AND RESOURCES ARE DESIGNED TO MEET THE CHANGING NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY, FULFILLING ITS MISSION TO IMPROVE QUALITY OF LIFE AND CONNECT THE COMMUNITY THROUGH EDUCATIONAL, CULTURAL, AND SOCIAL EXPERIENCES INSPIRED BY HORTICULTURE.

THE NATIONAL WOMEN'S HALL OF FAME (NWHF) IN SENECA FALLS, NEW YORK, WILL EXPAND ITS VIRTUAL FORUMS TO ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN DIALOGUE ABOUT PAST, PRESENT, AND FUTURE LEADERS IN WOMEN'S HISTORY. NWHF WILL HOST SIX FORUMS (ONE EVERY OTHER MONTH) HIGHLIGHTING WOMEN'S EQUALITY, WOMEN IN BUSINESS, AND MEDICAL RESEARCHERS WORKING TO ADVANCE WOMEN'S HEALTH. THE FORUMS WILL PLACE SPECIAL FOCUS ON PROVIDING A PLATFORM FOR WOMEN OF COLOR TO SHOWCASE THEIR EXPERTISE. PANEL DISCUSSIONS TARGETED TOWARD GENERATION Z AND MILLENNIALS WILL FOCUS ON CONDUCTING JOB SEARCHES IN THE POST-PANDEMIC ERA. LESSONS LEARNED DURING THE PANDEMIC ABOUT DIGITAL PROGRAMMING WILL ENHANCE THE NWHF'S ABILITY TO EXPAND ITS REACH FAR BEYOND ITS PHYSICAL WALLS AND SUPPORT ITS LONG-TERM GROWTH AND SUSTAINABILITY.

KEARNEY PUBLIC SCHOOLS IN NEBRASKA WILL PROVIDE NONFICTION AND MAKERSPACE/CREATIVE SPACE RESOURCES TO LIBRARIES SERVING 1,134 STUDENTS IN GRADES K-5 AT FOUR PUBLIC ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS IN HIGH POVERTY AREAS. THE NEW RESOURCES WILL HELP STUDENTS RECOVER FROM THE LOST LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES RESULTING FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AS WELL AS DEVELOP COLLABORATION, COMMUNICATION, AND CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS. THE SCHOOL LIBRARIANS WILL RECEIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING AND GIVEN THE TOOLS THEY NEED TO SUPPORT TEACHERS AND STUDENTS IN ACCESSING AND MAKING BEST USE OF THE NEW RESOURCES.

THE PERCUSSIVE ARTS SOCIETY'S RHYTHM! DISCOVERY CENTER (R!DC) IN INDIANAPOLIS WILL IMPLEMENT A SERIES OF LIVE MUSIC AND INTERACTIVE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR FAMILIES AND SCHOOL-AGE YOUTH TO RECONNECT THE COMMUNITY FOLLOWING MONTHS OF ISOLATION DURING THE PANDEMIC. R!DC WILL ORGANIZE TWO LIVE WEEKEND PERFORMANCES AND THREE SUMMER EVENING CONCERTS FEATURING LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND TOURING ARTISTS SHOWCASING A RANGE OF PERCUSSION INSTRUMENTS AND STYLES. INTERACTIVE PROGRAMMING COINCIDING WITH AN UPCOMING VIBRAPHONE EXHIBIT WILL EXPLORE THE DIVERSITY OF VIBRAPHONE ARTISTS ACROSS GENRES. IN ADDITION, R!DC WILL WORK WITH LOCAL NONPROFITS TO REACH RESIDENTS FROM TRADITIONALLY UNDERREPRESENTED AREAS OF THE COMMUNITY AND ENCOURAGE THEIR PARTICIPATION IN UPCOMING PROGRAMS.

THE NEW MEXICO STATE LIBRARY WILL WORK WITH 15 RURAL NEW MEXICO LIBRARIES TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT COMMUNITY-BASED SOCIAL WELLBEING PROJECTS. THE RURAL LIBRARIES WILL RECEIVE MENTORING AND GUIDANCE TO HELP THEM DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDING OF POST PANDEMIC NEEDS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES, USING AN ESTABLISHED SET OF SOCIAL WELLBEING TOOLS FROM AN EARLIER PILOT PROJECT. COMING OUT OF A PANDEMIC, RURAL LIBRARIES AND THE COMMUNITY MEMBERS THEY SERVE FACE THE CHALLENGE OF REESTABLISHING MUTUAL SUPPORT, REBUILDING SOCIAL CONNECTION, AND STRENGTHENING RESILIENCY. THE TOOLS PRIORITIZE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND DIALOGUE, WITH A FOCUS ON REACHING THE ISOLATED AND MARGINALIZED, AS A FOUNDATION FOR TAKING ACTION TO IMPROVE WELLBEING IN THE COMMUNITY. THE LIBRARIES ALSO WILL RECEIVE SMALL SEED GRANTS TO SUPPORT WELLBEING PROJECTS.

THE CHESAPEAKE PUBLIC LIBRARY IN VIRGINIA WILL ADVANCE DIGITAL INCLUSION FOR ITS COMMUNITY AND PROMOTE CONNECTIVITY BY PROVIDING RESIDENTS WITH SAFE AND ACCESSIBLE SPACES TO CONDUCT ACTIVITIES THAT COVID-19 HAS NECESSITATED BY DONE DIGITALLY, FROM TELEHEALTH TO JOB INTERVIEWS TO CONTINUING EDUCATION. AS PART OF 'CONNECT CHESAPEAKE,' THE LIBRARY WILL BUILD THREE PRIVACY BOOTHS THAT WILL BE FREE AND ACCESSIBLE TO ALL MEMBERS. THEY ALSO WILL TRAIN THEIR STAFF IN HIPAA LAWS IN ORDER TO BETTER ASSIST RESIDENTS, AND PARTNER WITH OUTSIDE ORGANIZATIONS TO PROVIDE FURTHER ASSISTANCE. WHILE THESE SERVICES WILL BE AVAILABLE TO ALL, THEY WILL SPECIFICALLY TARGET THE 10 PERCENT OF RESIDENTS WITHOUT RELIABLE INTERNET, PARTICULARLY THOSE WHO LIVE IN BIPOC NEIGHBORHOODS.

THE AMERICAN FOLK ART MUSEUM IN LONG ISLAND, NEW YORK, WILL UPGRADE ITS SOFTWARE AND DATABASE TO MAKE MORE IMAGES OF ART AND ARCHIVAL INFORMATION AVAILABLE ONLINE. DIGITAL CONTENT HAS BEEN AN IMPORTANT ELEMENT OF THE MUSEUM'S WORK FOLLOWING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE NEW SOFTWARE WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO ADD AUDIO, VISUAL, AND OTHER MEDIA FILES TO ITS WEBSITE FOR THE FIRST TIME, INCLUDING ADDING ARCHIVAL PHOTOS, LETTERS, EPHEMERA, AND RECORDINGS TO AN ARTIST'S WEB PAGE TO GIVE A FULLER UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR WORK. THE UPGRADED SOFTWARE WILL BE AVAILABLE TO INDIVIDUALS FROM ANY WEB-CONNECTED DEVICE. THE MUSEUM WILL PRIORITIZE DIGITIZING IMAGES AND ARCHIVES FOR ARTISTS WHO HAVE BEEN HISTORICALLY UNDERREPRESENTED IN THE ART WORLD INCLUDING BLACK, INDIGENOUS, AND OTHER ARTISTS OF COLOR; WOMEN-IDENTIFIED ARTISTS; AND NEURODIVERSE ARTISTS TO MORE ACCURATELY REFLECT THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTIONS.

THE PORT ANGELES FINE ARTS CENTER IN WASHINGTON WILL FILL A GAP IN AFFORDABLE ARTS EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES BY SUPPORTING THE LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICT IN BUILDING CAPACITY FOR ARTS EDUCATION AND ENRICHMENT AND PROVIDING FREE YOUTH PROGRAMMING BEYOND SCHOOL HOURS. THE CENTER WILL HIRE A DIRECTOR OF YOUTH PROGRAMS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT ENRICHMENT PROGRAMS SUCH AS FIELD TRIPS AND AFTER-SCHOOL ACTIVITIES TO HELP YOUNG PEOPLE FIND NEW PATHS FORWARD AS THEY EMERGE FROM A PERIOD OF ISOLATION. THE CENTER SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT GAPS THAT OCCURRED DUE TO THE DROP IN STUDENT ENGAGEMENT THAT THE COUNTRY SAW DURING THE SHIFT TO ONLINE LEARNING BECAUSE THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE MUSEUM OF LIFE AND SCIENCE WILL WORK WITH DURHAM PUBLIC SCHOOLS TO DEVELOP STEM-ORIENTED, NATURE-BASED LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR ELEMENTARY STUDENTS FOR DELIVERY IN NATURAL ENVIRONMENTS AT OR NEAR SCHOOLS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO PRODUCE ASSOCIATED PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS AND FACILITATORS. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC INCREASED AWARENESS OF THE BENEFITS OF OUTDOOR-BASED LEARNING, INCLUDING REDUCED RISK OF VIRAL TRANSMISSION, IMPROVED PHYSICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH, AND SUPPORT OF LEARNING OUTCOMES. LOCAL TEACHERS REPORTED A NEED FOR OUTDOOR-BASED EXPERIENCES AS WELL AS TRAINING TO IMPROVE THEIR SKILLS AND COMFORT TO TEACH IN OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS, INCLUDING THOSE NOT DESIGNED FOR LEARNING. THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP SIX LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR K-5 STUDENTS THAT ALIGN WITH STATE EDUCATION STANDARDS ALONG WITH REUSABLE MATERIALS FOR USE BY PARTICIPATING CLASSES. UP TO 20 TEACHERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, HELPING TO SEED EXPERTISE AT ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY.

HAGEN HISTORY CENTER (HHC) IN ERIE, PENNSYLVANIA, WILL UPGRADE ITS TECHNOLOGY INFRASTRUCTURE TO RESPOND TO THE COMMUNITY'S NEED FOR IMPROVED INTERNET ACCESS, WHICH WAS EXACERBATED DURING THE PANDEMIC. HHC WILL STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND THE REACH OF WIRELESS ACCESS FOR GUESTS AT TWO OF ITS LOCATIONS: THE CAMPUS NEAR DOWNTOWN ERIE WHICH INCLUDES TWO RESTORED HISTORIC HOUSES, A CARRIAGE HOUSE, AND A MODERN ARCHIVES AND EXHIBIT BUILDING, AND AT THE GIRARD CAMPUS, WHICH INCLUDES TWO HISTORIC HOUSES AND FARMLAND. HHC WILL INSTALL ALL-WEATHER OUTDOOR TABLES ON BOTH CAMPUSES TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL WORKSPACE FOR PATRONS' USE WHILE THEY ACCESS THE WI-FI. THE PROJECT WILL RESPOND TO COMMUNITY REQUESTS FOR MORE PROGRAMS AND SERVICES ON THESE TWO PROPERTIES AND WILL MAKE DIGITAL INROADS FOR POPULATIONS THAT CANNOT ALWAYS AFFORD HOME INTERNET ACCESS.

THE LIBRARY SYSTEM OF LANCASTER COUNTY (LSLC), IN PENNSYLVANIA, WILL REINSTATE ITS PROGRAM TO PROVIDE CHILDREN AND HOME-BASED CHILDCARE PROVIDERS WITH ACCESS TO HIGH-QUALITY PRESCHOOL CURRICULUM MATERIALS. LSLC'S BE READY ROVER VAN BREAKS DOWN TRANSPORTATION AND ACCESS BARRIERS BY PROVIDING LIBRARY RESOURCES AND SERVICES DIRECTLY TO HOMES. AN EARLY LITERACY OUTREACH SPECIALIST WILL STOCK THIS BOOKMOBILE WITH LITERACY AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND TRAVEL WITH THE VAN TO PROVIDE CHILDREN'S LESSONS, STORYTIMES, AND CRAFT ACTIVITIES AT HOME-BASED CHILDCARE LOCATIONS AROUND THE COUNTY. IN THE YEAR AHEAD, LSLC PLANS TO INCREASE ITS NUMBER OF VISITS BACK TO PRE-PANDEMIC LEVELS AND DEVELOP STRATEGIES TO INCREASE ITS SERVICE CAPACITY BEYOND THE CURRENT REACH. THIS WORK WILL RESPOND TO PANDEMIC DISRUPTIONS IN THE CHILDCARE PROVIDER SECTOR AND PRIORITIZE CHILDHOOD DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES.

THE WATKINS MUSEUM OF HISTORY IN LAWRENCE, KANSAS, WILL EXPAND DIGITAL ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE AMOUNT AND VARIETY OF COLLECTION MATERIALS AVAILABLE ONLINE, INTRODUCE NEW WAYS TO PRESENT DIGITAL CONTENT, AND EXPAND THE VARIETY OF MUSEUM PLATFORMS THAT MAKE DIGITAL RESOURCES ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC. THIS WORK WILL FOCUS ON PRODUCING AT LEAST 10 NEW OFFERINGS. POTENTIAL EXAMPLES INCLUDE A DIGITAL FINDING AID SO THAT RESEARCHERS CAN BETTER ACCESS CONTENT IN THE LIBERTY PRESS KANSAS LGBTQ MAGAZINE, AN ONLINE EXHIBIT TO MAKE PHOTOS FROM THE HISTORIC 1903 KANSAS RIVER FLOOD ACCESSIBLE IN TIME FOR ITS 120TH ANNIVERSARY, AND A DISTANCE LEARNING LESSON TO INCORPORATE WORLD WAR I PROPAGANDA POSTERS AND LETTERS INTO HISTORY OR LANGUAGE ARTS CURRICULA. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE COMMUNITY NEED FOR MORE DIGITAL ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS THAT WAS EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

MARQUETTE UNIVERSITY RAYNOR MEMORIAL LIBRARIES AND CRISTO REY JESUIT HIGH SCHOOL IN MILWAUKEE, WISCONSIN, WILL PARTNER ON A PILOT FOR A WORK-BASED DIGITAL LITERACY PROGRAM TO ADDRESS GAPS IN EDUCATIONAL ACCESS FOR HISPANIC AND LATINO HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THAT HAVE WIDENED DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. STUDENTS FROM CRISTO REY WILL WORK IN THE LIBRARY'S DIGITAL SCHOLARSHIP LAB ONE DAY EACH WEEK, WHERE THEY WILL IDENTIFY A CHALLENGE CREATED OR AMPLIFIED BY COVID-19 AND DEVELOP A DIGITAL PROJECT TO ADDRESS THAT CHALLENGE. STUDENTS WILL LEARN ABOUT MODES OF DIGITAL COMMUNICATION, DIGITAL CITIZENSHIP, HOW TO CRITICALLY EVALUATE DIGITAL CONTENT, THEIR ROLE AS CREATORS OF INFORMATION, AND INTRODUCTORY SOFTWARE AND CODING. AT THE END OF THE PILOT PROGRAM, MARQUETTE WILL CREATE A SHAREABLE, PEER-REVIEWED BEST PRACTICES MODEL FOR USE BY ACADEMIC LIBRARIES SEEKING TO PARTNER WITH COMMUNITY GROUPS ON DIGITAL LITERACY INITIATIVES.

THE WHALING MUSEUM IN COLD SPRING HARBOR, NEW YORK, WILL RESEARCH, DESIGN, INSTALL, AND EVALUATE A 2-YEAR EXHIBITION EXPLORING AND EXPOUNDING ON THE ROLE OF BLACK MARINERS IN WHALING HISTORY. THE EXHIBIT WILL HIGHLIGHT AND BRING INTO PERSPECTIVE THE SIGNIFICANT BUT MARGINALIZED EXPERIENCES OF WHALING IN AMERICAN HISTORY. THE EXHIBITION WILL CORRESPOND TO PRESENT-DAY ISSUES, PROMOTE DEMOCRATIC VALUES, HIGHLIGHT NEW RESEARCH ABOUT THE EXPERIENCES AND IMPACT OF LOCAL BLACK WHALERS, AND STRENGTHEN THE VISIBILITY OF BLACK PERSPECTIVES ON LONG ISLAND. GEARED TOWARDS UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS ON LONG ISLAND, PARTICULARLY THOSE OF COLOR, WHO HAVE FACED DISPROPORTIONATE IMPACTS OF THE PANDEMIC, THE PROJECT WILL ENCOURAGE AUDIENCES TO FOSTER NEW CONNECTIONS AND GAIN AN UNDERSTANDING OF HOW BLACK SEAMAN PLAYED A ROLE IN THE EVOLUTION OF BLACK COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE.

THE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF ART AND SCIENCE WILL ENGAGE ELEMENTARY STUDENTS IN THE MCALLEN INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT WITH HANDS-ON SCIENCE ACTIVITIES AND PROBLEM-SOLVING, HELPING BRIDGE THE LEARNING GAP CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. PROGRAMS WILL ALIGN WITH STATE EDUCATION STANDARDS AND HELP PREPARE STUDENTS FOR THE STATE SCIENCE EXAM. PREVIOUS SCIENCE PROGRAMMING LED BY THE MUSEUM RESULTED IN STUDENTS' INCREASED INTEREST AND RETENTION OF SCIENCE FACTS, AS INDICATED BY TEACHER EVALUATIONS. THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE EACH STUDENT WITH A VOUCHER TO VISIT THE MUSEUM FREE OF CHARGE AND EXTEND THEIR SCIENCE LEARNING. TEACHERS WILL LEARN ENGAGEMENT AND REFLECTION TECHNIQUES MODELED BY MUSEUM STAFF THAT CAN CONTRIBUTE TO A MORE COLLABORATIVE LEARNING ENVIRONMENT IN THE CLASSROOM. ADDITIONALLY, MUSEUM STAFF WILL PARTICIPATE IN PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING THAT SUPPORTS THEIR DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OF EDUCATION PROGRAMS.

THE MUSEUM OF EAST TENNESSEE HISTORY WILL PARTNER WITH MUSEUM PLANNERS AND WEBSITE DESIGNERS TO CREATE A MORE INCLUSIVE APPROACH TO HISTORY THAT WILL INFORM, UNDERPIN, AND CONTRIBUTE TO AN UPDATED WEBSITE. THE MUSEUM REALIZED ITS ONLINE AND VIRTUAL PRESENCE WAS SIGNIFICANTLY LIMITED AND DID NOT ENCOURAGE CONNECTION, CREATION, OR COMMUNITY BUILDING DURING THE PANDEMIC-RELATED MUSEUM CLOSURES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INITIATE DIALOGUE WITH UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES IN URBAN AND RURAL AREAS, BUILD RELATIONSHIPS, AND CREATE OBJECTIVES FOR BUILDING ONLINE RESOURCES, HYBRID PROGRAMMING, AND MUSEUM EXHIBITS THAT BETTER SUPPORT THE AREA'S DIVERSE AUDIENCES. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED TO REEXAMINE THE TRADITIONAL NARRATIVES AND THE RESOURCES PROVIDED IN THE PAST THAT WAS EXACERBATED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

BIBLIOTECH, A DIGITAL PUBLIC LIBRARY IN SAN ANTONIO, TEXAS, WILL PARTNER WITH LIBRARIES WITHOUT BORDERS US TO EXPAND ITS WASH AND LEARN INITIATIVE, WHICH PROVIDES LITERACY PROGRAMMING AND INFORMATION SERVICES INSIDE LAUNDROMATS AND MAKES LIBRARY SERVICES ACCESSIBLE FOR LOW-INCOME COMMUNITY MEMBERS WITH DEMANDING WORK SCHEDULES. THE INITIATIVE WILL HAVE 63 LAPTOPS AND SERVICE FOR 63 WI-FI HOTSPOTS AVAILABLE FOR ADULT LEARNERS AND YOUTH. BY EXPANDING LAUNDROMAT OFFERINGS TO INCLUDE DISTRIBUTION AND SHARING OF DEVICES, THE FULL ARRAY OF PUBLIC LIBRARY RESOURCES, INCLUDING INTERNET CONNECTIVITY, WILL BE MORE ACCESSIBLE FOR THOSE WHO ARE UNABLE TO TRAVEL TO ONE OF BIBLIOTECH'S THREE MAJOR LIBRARY BRANCHES. THIS PROGRAM SUPPORTS THE LIBRARY'S ONGOING WORK TO ADDRESS THE DIGITAL DIVIDE IN BEXAR COUNTY, WHICH WAS EXACERBATED BY COVID-19, AND TO CREATE A NEW LIBRARY MODEL FOR A POST-PANDEMIC WORLD.

THE RICE COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY'S CORONADO QUIVIRA MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP AN EXHIBITION THAT BUILDS UPON THE MUSEUM'S SOCIAL MEDIA OUTREACH EFFORT INITIATED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND FOCUSED ON REMOTE HISTORIC SITES, SCHOOL BUILDINGS, AND ABANDONED TOWNS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY. THE EXHIBITION WILL FEATURE HISTORIC AND CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHS OF HISTORIC SITES AND WILL INCORPORATE CONTENT PROVIDED BY THE PUBLIC THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA. SINCE MARCH 2020, MOST OF THE MUSEUM'S AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT HAS OCCURRED ONLINE, AND THIS NEW EXHIBITION WILL BUILD UPON THE RELATIONSHIPS DEVELOPED DURING THIS TIME WHILE ENCOURAGING VISITORS TO RETURN TO THE MUSEUM. THE EXHIBITION WILL INCLUDE AN ONLINE COMPONENT AND NEW MUSEUM WEBSITE, ESTABLISHING A FOUNDATION FOR CONTINUED DIGITAL OUTREACH TO LOCAL AND DISTANT ONLINE AUDIENCES.

GREAT EXPLORATIONS CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT AN OUTREACH PROGRAM IN THE MIDTOWN NEIGHBORHOOD OF SOUTH ST. PETERSBURG, FLORIDA, TO TEACH MIDDLE-SCHOOL-AGED YOUTH HOW TO PLANT A GARDEN. MIDTOWN IS AN URBAN FOOD DESERT WITH NO GROCERY STORE IN A THREE-MILE RADIUS THAT HAS FRESH PRODUCE AVAILABLE. THE MUSEUM WILL INCORPORATE STEAM METHODS OF LEARNING, TEACH SMART (SPECIFIC, MEASURABLE, AGREED-UPON, REALISTIC, TIMELY) GOAL SETTING, AND PROVIDE HIGH-SCHOOL-AGED MENTORS TO GUIDE YOUNGER STUDENTS THROUGHOUT THE PROGRAM. GRADUATES OF THE PROGRAM WILL RECEIVE A STARTER GARDEN KIT TO TAKE HOME AND GROW WITH THEIR FAMILY AND TRACK ITS PROGRESS. THE GARDEN AREA WILL REMAIN OPEN AT THE END OF THE PROJECT AS A COMMUNITY GARDEN FOR THE MIDTOWN NEIGHBORHOOD. THE PROJECT WILL HELP WITH RECOVERY FROM THE PANDEMIC BY ADDRESSING THE AREA'S FOOD INSECURITY BY TEACHING STUDENTS HOW TO SUSTAIN THEIR OWN FOOD SOURCE.

THE INDIANA UNIVERSITY MUSEUM OF ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY WILL BROADEN ITS COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT AND SERVICE BY REMOVING BARRIERS AND PROVIDING RESOURCES AND SUPPORT FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS WITH INVISIBLE DISABILITIES SUCH AS AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER, SENSORY PROCESSING DISORDER, ANXIETY, AGORAPHOBIA, AND DEPRESSION. TO REACH THESE GOALS, THE MUSEUM WILL DELIVER PROGRAMMING FOR LEARNERS OF ALL AGES WITH VARYING NEEDS. IN ADDITION, THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE A MULTIFUNCTIONAL WELLNESS ROOM, PROGRAMMING DESIGNED FOR NEURODIVERSE VISITORS, AND GUIDES AND SENSORY MAPS. THROUGH THESE RESOURCES, THE MUSEUM WILL SERVE THOSE WHO MAY BE EXPERIENCING PSYCHOLOGICAL DISORDERS OR CHALLENGES EXACERBATED BY THE EFFECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

KIDSQUEST CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN BELLEVUE, WASHINGTON, WILL EXPAND AND IMPROVE TWO OF ITS EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, LITTLE LABS AND LEARNING KITS, TO SERVE FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN AGES 3-5 IN NEED OF OPPORTUNITIES FOR EDUCATIONAL ENRICHMENT. LITTLE LABS AND LEARNING KITS WILL HELP CLOSE THE LEARNING GAP FOR FAMILIES EMERGING FROM SCREEN-DOMINATED, SOCIALLY ISOLATED PANDEMIC CONDITIONS, WHO ARE IN NEED OF HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES AND MEANINGFUL, PERSONAL INTERACTIONS. LITTLE LABS WILL ENGAGE FAMILIES THROUGH 6-WEEK SESSIONS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH SOUTH KING COUNTY LIBRARIES THAT SERVE LOW-INCOME, MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES. COMMUNITY PARTNERS WILL PROVIDE PARTICIPATING FAMILIES WITH FREE LEARNING KITS THAT INCLUDE MATERIALS FOR HANDS-ON PLAYFUL LEARNING AND MULTILINGUAL CURRICULUM CARDS FOR GUIDED AT-HOME EXPLORATION. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL ADD TWO NEW THEMED KITS AND EXPAND THEIR DISTRIBUTION. THESE PROGRAMS WILL PREPARE PRESCHOOLERS FOR KINDERGARTEN AND ENGAGE PARENTS AND CAREGIVERS IN THEIR CHILDREN'S LEARNING ACTIVITIES.

THE BIOETHICS RESEARCH LIBRARY AT GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY WILL PRESERVE AND MAKE FREELY AVAILABLE OVER 350 HOURS OF RECORDED LECTURES PRESENTED AT THE KENNEDY INSTITUTE OF ETHICS (KIE). THE RECORDINGS ADDRESS THE MAJOR BIOETHICAL CONCERNS OF THE PAST 50 YEARS AND WERE DELIVERED BY KIE SCHOLARS AND OTHER PROMINENT EXPERTS INCLUDING DOCTORS, PHILOSOPHERS, PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICIALS, THEOLOGIANS, AND SCIENTISTS. THE AUDIOVISUAL RECORDINGS ARE CURRENTLY HELD ON A VARIETY OF AT-RISK FORMATS, INCLUDING COMPACT CASSETTES, VHS TAPES, COMPACT DISCS, DVDS, AND QUARTER-INCH OPEN REEL MAGNETIC TAPES. BOTH ANALOG AND DIGITAL FORMATS REQUIRE REFORMATTING AND ENHANCED DESCRIPTIVE METADATA TO ENSURE FUTURE ACCESSIBILITY TO AND DISCOVERY OF THE RECORDINGS. THE LECTURES WILL THEN BE MADE FREELY AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC VIA DIGITAL GEORGETOWN, A UNIFIED PORTAL FOR GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY'S INSTITUTIONAL REPOSITORY AND DIGITAL COLLECTIONS. WE EXPECT THAT THE RECORDINGS WILL BE ESPECIALLY RELEVANT TO THOSE GRAPPLING WITH THE MANY ETHICAL ISSUES THAT HAVE RISEN TO PROMINENCE DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE DISCOVERY MUSEUM IN ACTON, MASSACHUSETTS, WILL DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES AND OUTDOOR PROGRAMS TO RAISE AWARENESS OF THE SHORT- AND LONG-TERM MENTAL HEALTH BENEFITS OF CONNECTING WITH NATURE. WHILE PEOPLE OF ALL AGES AND BACKGROUNDS HAVE EXPERIENCED HEIGHTENED ANXIETY AND DEPRESSION AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, CHILDREN AND PARENTS DISCOVERY MUSEUM'S CORE AUDIENCE ARE AMONG THE HARDEST HIT POPULATIONS, ACCORDING TO BOTH STATE AND NATIONAL DATA. WORKING WITH COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS THAT PROVIDE CLINICAL AND OTHER SERVICES TO FAMILIES, THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP LEARNING EXPERIENCES TO INCREASE PARTICIPANTS' KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE WAYS IN WHICH BEING OUTDOORS CAN DECREASE STRESS AND ANXIETY AND BOOST MOOD. THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE FREE MEMBERSHIPS TO FAMILIES WITH FINANCIAL NEEDS AND DEVELOP NATURE-BASED LEARNING EXPERIENCES TO SUPPORT FAMILIES WHO HAVE CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD THE MUSEUM'S CAPACITY TO PROVIDE NATURE-FOCUSED EXPERIENCES TO ALL VISITORS THROUGH NEW STAFFING, PROGRAMS, AND PARTNERSHIPS.

THE KIDZONE MUSEUM IN TRUCKEE, CALIFORNIA, WILL OFFER HANDS-ON PLAY EXHIBITS AND PROGRAMS TO HELP CHILDREN AGES 0-5 CATCH UP ON DEVELOPMENTAL MILESTONES THEY MAY BE LAGGING BEHIND ON AS A RESULT OF SOCIAL AND LEARNING RESTRICTIONS IMPOSED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE TAHOE TRUCKEE UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT, THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE WEEKLY ART, SCIENCE, AND LITERACY ACTIVITIES THAT HELP CHILDREN GAIN SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL, COGNITIVE, FINE AND SENSORY MOTOR, AND LITERACY SKILLS. THE MUSEUM'S COMMUNITY ADVOCATE WILL COORDINATE MONTHLY MUSEUM ENGAGEMENT ACTIVITIES WITH SOCIAL SERVICE PARTNERS SERVING CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES, ENGLISH-LANGUAGE LEARNERS, AND PEOPLE WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND ABUSE.

THE SAN DIEGO BOTANIC GARDEN IN ENCINITAS, CALIFORNIA, WILL EXPAND ITS PROGRAM OF FREE, REGULARLY SCHEDULED VISITS TO THE GARDEN FOR RACIALLY AND CULTURALLY DIVERSE GROUPS, STUDENTS IN AFTER-SCHOOL CARE, ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED FAMILIES, AND SENIORS. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FIVE SOCIAL SERVICES AGENCIES IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY, THE BOTANIC GARDEN WILL DESIGN INTERACTIVE PROGRAMS THAT MEET THE NEEDS AND INTERESTS OF EACH PARTNER GROUP. THE LATE AFTERNOON PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE INTERACTIVE TALKS WHILE PARTICIPANTS MOVE THROUGH THE 37-ACRE GARDEN, HANDS-ON LEARNING FOCUSED ON GARDENING AND THE ARTS, AND MORE. ACTIVITIES WILL ADDRESS THE EMOTIONAL DISTRESS AND NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON MENTAL HEALTH THAT MANY PEOPLE EXPERIENCED DURING THE PANDEMIC.

THE ANNISTON MUSEUMS AND GARDENS WILL DEVELOP SEVEN OUTDOOR LEARNING HOTSPOTS ON STRATEGIC SITES THROUGHOUT ITS GROUNDS, EACH HIGHLIGHTING A UNIQUE ENVIRONMENTAL SUBJECT, INCLUDING NATIVE AND RARE PLANTS, MICROCLIMATES, BAMBOO AS A RENEWABLE RESOURCE, WATER CONSERVATION, THE BUTTERFLY LIFE CYCLE, BOG GARDENS, AND FOREST ECOLOGY. THE LEARNING HOTSPOTS WILL BE AVAILABLE FREE OF CHARGE TO ANY ONSITE VISITOR AND WILL INCLUDE INTERACTIVE ACTIVITIES AND LINKS TO LEARN MORE THROUGH A QUICK REFERENCE (QR) CODE. THE MUSEUM WILL ENSURE EACH LEARNING HOTSPOT INCLUDES PLANTINGS, INTERACTIVES, AND GRAPHIC SIGNAGE TO SUPPORT THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE. BY PROVIDING A SAFE, OUTDOOR EXPERIENCE, THE MUSEUM IS RESPONDING TO THE PUBLIC'S HESITATION TO VISIT INDOOR MUSEUMS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA STATE MUSEUM WILL REVISE TWO OF ITS GALLERY PROGRAMS, NEBRASKA ECOLOGY AND EXPLORE EVOLUTION, WITH UPDATED CONTENT AND ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES ALIGNED WITH NEBRASKA'S SCIENCE STANDARDS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO UPDATE ITS EXPLORE EVOLUTION VIRTUAL FIELD TRIP AND SCIENCE KIT. THE GALLERY PROGRAMS ARE DEVELOPED FOR LINCOLN PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS WHO REPRESENT A DIVERSE POPULATION AND INCLUDE 70% OF THE SCHOOL-AGE STUDENTS IN THE METRO AREA. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT RURAL SECONDARY SCHOOLS THAT RELY UPON EXPLORE EVOLUTION AS AN IMPORTANT ELEMENT OF THEIR CURRICULUM ON GENETICS, NATURAL SELECTION, AND EVOLUTION. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO AID IN THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC RECOVERY BY PROVIDING STANDARDS ALIGNED PROGRAMS THAT HELP LINCOLN STUDENTS WHO ARE FALLING BEHIND ON STANDARDS DUE TO EDUCATIONAL DISRUPTIONS, WHILE SUPPORTING A RETURN TO MUSEUM FIELD-TRIP OPPORTUNITIES.

THORNWILDE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL IN HEBRON, KENTUCKY, WILL INCREASE THE ABILITY OF ITS LIBRARY AND RELATED ORGANIZATIONS TO DELIVER PROGRAMS AND SERVICES CONTRIBUTING TO POST-PANDEMIC WELLBEING OF FAMILIES, GROUPS, AND INDIVIDUALS OF ALL CULTURAL AND SOCIOECONOMIC BACKGROUNDS. THE SCHOOL WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE COMMUNITY TO INTERACT COLLABORATIVELY AGAIN BY CREATING AND DELIVERING ONLINE AND IN-PERSON EDUCATIONAL, INTERPRETIVE, AND EXPERIENTIAL PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITIONS FOR LEARNERS OF ALL AGES. STORY WALKS WILL GUIDE READERS THROUGH A BOOK WHILE WALKING A PREEXISTING OUTDOOR TRAIL. THE SCHOOL ALSO WILL SET UP A FREE LENDING LIBRARY OUTSIDE, WHERE GENTLY USED BOOKS DONATED BY COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL BE AVAILABLE; AND THORNWILDE ELEMENTARY WILL ORGANIZE TWO COMMUNITY EVENTS TO INTRODUCE PATRONS TO THE LIBRARY'S MAKERSPACE, THROUGH INTERACTIVE ACTIVITIES.

THE HISTORY CENTER OF LAKE FOREST-LAKE BLUFF, IN LAKE FOREST, ILLINOIS, WILL EXPAND ITS PUBLIC ONLINE ACCESS BY DIGITIZING HISTORICAL TEXTS, MAPS, AND PHOTOGRAPH COLLECTIONS AND IMPROVING PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT WITH HISTORICAL DOCUMENTS AND MATERIALS THROUGH ACCESSIBLE ONLINE SEARCH TOOLS. THIS INITIATIVE TO INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY IS FOCUSED ON PROMOTING LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ALL, FOSTERING LIFELONG LEARNING AND CIVIC DISCOURSE, AND EXPANDING THE DIVERSITY OF THE CENTER'S AUDIENCES. THE NIMBLENESS OF THE HISTORY CENTER'S DIGITAL PLATFORM ALLOWED IT TO PRODUCE EXHIBITS ONLINE THROUGHOUT THE PANDEMIC, INCLUDING THE GLOBAL AWARD-WINNING '300 PHOTOS, 30 DAYS: A CANDID LOOK AT COVID-19.'  BY CONTINUING TO CREATE ONLINE CONTENT THAT SERVES RESEARCHERS, EDUCATORS, STUDENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, THE PROJECT WILL RESPOND TO A GROWING APPETITE FOR DIGITALLY ACCESSIBLE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS.

THE WEST VIRGINIA MINE WARS MUSEUM WILL DEEPEN COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS AND SUPPORT CULTURAL TOURISM AS THE AREA RECOVERS FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY PRESERVING THE APARTMENT OF SID HATFIELD (1893-1921), POLICE CHIEF OF MATEWAN AND HERO TO SOUTHERN WEST VIRGINIA'S UNION COAL MINERS. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL DEVELOP A PARTICIPATORY MURAL INSIDE THE STAIRWELL LEADING UP TO HATFIELD'S APARTMENT. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH COALFIELD DEVELOPMENT, A NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION DEDICATED TO REBUILDING APPALACHIA, AND LONGSTANDING PARTNER UNITED MINE WORKERS OF AMERICA LOCAL 1440. OVER THE COURSE OF A YEAR, THE MUSEUM WILL PLAN, LEAD, AND HOST COMMUNITY MEETINGS WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS TO ENVISION, IDENTIFY, AND PRIORITIZE THE MANY POTENTIAL USES FOR THIS SPACE. BASED ON THESE CONVERSATIONS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL GENERATE DESIGN MOCK-UPS AND PROGRAMMING ACTIVITIES AND SEEK FEEDBACK ON THEIR PROPOSAL.

THE PHILADELPHIA MUSEUM OF ART WILL LAUNCH A COMPREHENSIVE AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT INITIATIVE TO BRING PATRONS BACK TO THE MUSEUM FOLLOWING CLOSURES DURING THE PANDEMIC AND TO HELP CONNECT YOUNG VISITORS TO ART. THE MUSEUM WILL PROCEED WITH A SAFE AND GRADUAL RETURN TO IN-PERSON ART KIDS PROGRAMS FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES. THIS INITIATIVE WILL BOTH REBUILD FAMILY AUDIENCES THAT HAD BEEN LOYAL TO THE MUSEUM PRIOR TO THE PANDEMIC AS WELL AS ENGAGE WITH THE PHILADELPHIA COMMUNITY MORE BROADLY. THE MUSEUM WILL ORGANIZE WEEKLY ART-MAKING PROGRAMS AND PLAYDATES FOR FAMILIES, CREATE FAMILY-FRIENDLY GALLERY RESOURCES, DISTRIBUTE ART-MAKING KITS, AND REINSTATE A LARGE-SCALE SUMMER PROGRAM. THE MUSEUM WILL CONDUCT COMMUNITY OUTREACH TO PARTNERS ACROSS THE CITY TO PROMOTE ITS PROGRAMMING AND RESOURCES.

THE GREAT AMERICAN SONGBOOK FOUNDATION (GASF) IN CARMEL, INDIANA, WILL EXPAND AND ENHANCE ITS PERFECT HARMONY PROGRAM, WHICH WILL REACH 7,500 SENIORS THROUGH ONLINE RESOURCES AND VIRTUAL PROGRAMS. ORIGINALLY AN ON-SITE PROGRAM FOUNDED IN 2015, PERFECT HARMONY TRANSFORMED AND GREW DURING THE PANDEMIC TO BE AN ENTIRELY VIRTUAL EXPERIENCE THAT OFFERED CARE PARTNERS AND OLDER ADULTS ROBUST MONTHLY INTERACTIVE AND INFORMATIVE MUSICAL EXPERIENCES THAT HELPED ALLEVIATE LONELINESS AND ISOLATION. GASF WILL ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF THE MONTHLY PERFECT HARMONY RESOURCES BY RECORDING AND EDITING NEW HIGH-QUALITY VIDEOS IN A PROFESSIONAL STUDIO. GASF WILL IMPROVE DATA COLLECTION AND EVALUATION TECHNIQUES TO HELP SUSTAIN THE ONGOING VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING THAT CONTRIBUTES TO WELL-BEING, AS WELL AS CONDUCT ADDITIONAL OUTREACH TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF CAREGIVERS AND SENIORS SERVED.

THE ANCHORAGE MUSEUM IN ALASKA WILL HIRE NEW MUSEUM STAFF AND TRAIN EXISTING STAFF TO DEVELOP COMMUNITY RELATIONSHIPS, PARTNERSHIPS, NETWORKS, AND ALLIANCES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A PROGRAMMATIC STAFF MEMBER TO COLLABORATE WITH AND SUPPORT COMMUNITIES OF COLOR AND LGBTQ COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS A CURATOR TO WORK WITH COMMUNITIES ON CLIMATE CHANGE AND CLIMATE JUSTICE. TO BEST SERVE COMMUNITIES AND PROVIDE LONG-TERM VALUE, THE ANCHORAGE MUSEUM WILL PRIORITIZE ONGOING RELATIONSHIPS WITH DIVERSE COMMUNITIES, RATHER THAN RELYING ON A PROGRAM-BY-PROGRAM OR TRANSACTIONAL MINDSET. THROUGH THIS NEW INITIATIVE, MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A COLLABORATIVE SPIRIT, LEARNING FROM THE INSIGHTS AND LEADERSHIP OF OTHERS TO CREATE TRANSFORMATIVE EXPERIENCES AS THE COMMUNITY RECOVERS FROM THE IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE DON HARRINGTON DISCOVERY CENTER, A SCIENCE CENTER IN AMARILLO, TEXAS, WILL DEVELOP A CULTURALLY RELEVANT AND RESPONSIVE COMMUNITY PROGRAM CELEBRATING SCIENTISTS, PHILOSOPHERS, TECHNOLOGIES, AND THE HISTORY OF SCIENCE FROM COUNTRIES REPRESENTATIVE OF AMARILLO'S REFUGEE COMMUNITIES THROUGH ROTATING EXHIBITS AND COMMUNITY PROGRAMS. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, THE BROADER COMMUNITY WILL LEARN ABOUT THE SCIENTIFIC ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND SOCIETAL IMPACT OF THEIR NEW NEIGHBORS' CULTURES. THIS PROJECT ALSO WILL PROVIDE CULTURALLY RELEVANT STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH) LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO ENGAGE REFUGEE YOUTH AROUND STEM CONCEPTS AND POTENTIAL CAREERS IN STEM AND COMBAT PANDEMIC-RELATED LEARNING LOSS WITHIN THESE COMMUNITIES. FINALLY, THE PROGRAM WILL HELP THE SCIENCE CENTER OVERCOME CHALLENGES ASSOCIATED WITH THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY ATTRACTING MORE VISITORS THROUGH NEW PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITS, INCREASING REVENUE, AND LEVERAGING CONTRIBUTIONS THROUGH PROGRAM SUPPORT AND NEW SPONSORSHIP OPPORTUNITIES.

THE WOOD DALE PUBLIC LIBRARY IN WOOD DALE, ILLINOIS, WILL CREATE OUTDOOR PROGRAMMING THAT ENCOURAGES FAMILIES TO ENGAGE IN WALKING, EXERCISE, AND ACTIVE PLAY. LIBRARIANS WILL CREATE SPECIAL CHALLENGES THAT ENCOURAGE PARTICIPANTS TO EXPLORE THE LIBRARY AND OUTDOOR SPACE. THE LIBRARY WILL DEVELOP AN IMMERSIVE STORY WALK AND NATURE TRAIL FEATURING GRASSY PATHS, NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS, PERENNIAL FLOWERS, AND INTERPRETIVE SIGNAGE, AVAILABLE FOR SELF-EXPLORATION AND GUIDED WALKS. THE CHILDREN'S LIBRARIANS WILL MAINTAIN THE STORY WALK AND CHANGE IT EVERY 90 DAYS. BY CREATING AN OUTDOOR SPACE THAT PROMOTES A VARIETY OF ACTIVITIES, THE LIBRARY WILL ADDRESS THE NEGATIVE HEALTH AND FITNESS EFFECTS THAT CHILDREN AND FAMILIES EXPERIENCED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, WHEN CHILDREN HAD LIMITED ACCESS TO ACTIVE PLAY AND ORGANIZED ACTIVITIES.

ZOO NEW ENGLAND (ZNE) WILL CREATE AN ENGAGEMENT PROGRAM TO BETTER CONNECT WITH AND SERVE RESIDENTS OF SUFFOLK COUNTY, MASSACHUSETTS, WHERE ONE OF ZNE'S CAMPUSES, FRANKLIN PARK ZOO, IS LOCATED. THE INITIATIVE WILL TARGET LOCAL FAMILIES AND SCHOOL-AGE CHILDREN AND TEENS IN UNDERSERVED AREAS, INCLUDING DORCHESTER, ROXBURY, MATTAPAN, AND PARTS OF JAMAICA PLAIN. DURING THE FIRST YEAR OF THIS PROGRAM, ZNE PLANS TO IDENTIFY AT LEAST 150 STAKEHOLDER ORGANIZATIONS AS PARTNERS. IN SUBSEQUENT PHASES, ZNE EXPECTS THESE ORGANIZATIONS WILL BRING 5,000-9,000 COMMUNITY RESIDENTS INTO ZNE FOCUS GROUPS, COMMUNITY ASSET-MAPPING ACTIVITIES, AND PROGRAM SURVEYS. ZNE THEN WILL SOLICIT FEEDBACK FROM THESE RESIDENTS REGARDING ZNE PROGRAM STRATEGIES, PLANNING, AND SUCCESS INDICATORS. FINALLY, ZNE WILL BEGIN PILOT PROGRAMS, SHARING RESULTS AND GATHERING FEEDBACK FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS. BY ENGAGING WITH ITS COMMUNITY, ZNE WILL BE ABLE TO RESPOND TO COMMUNITY NEEDS FOLLOWING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC QUICKLY, EFFECTIVELY, EFFICIENTLY, AND RESPONSIBLY.

THE WOODROW WILSON PRESIDENTIAL LIBRARY WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND RESOURCES THAT FOCUS ON HISTORY AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT FOR LOCAL NONPROFIT SERVICE PROVIDERS, TEACHERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING A DIGITAL EXHIBIT FOCUSED ON HISTORICAL ASPECTS OF LOCAL URBAN RENEWAL AS A STUDY IN CIVIC ENGAGEMENT. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO CREATE AND IMPLEMENT PROGRAMMING ON FINANCIAL LITERACY AND FOOD INSECURITY. THESE PROGRAMS WILL PROVIDE A HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE WHILE ESTABLISHING PARTNERSHIPS WITH NONPROFITS THAT ARE FIGHTING AGAINST POVERTY TODAY. THE MUSEUM WILL DESIGN THE PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS THE COMMUNITY IDENTIFIED CONCERN REGARDING ENSURING STUDENTS REMAIN ENGAGED IN LEARNING BY PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL CONTENT THAT FOSTERS LIFELONG LEARNING AND INCORPORATES DIVERSE PERSPECTIVES AS THE COMMUNITY RECOVERS FROM THE DISRUPTION TO EDUCATION CAUSED BY COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

MEL FISHER MARITIME MUSEUM IN KEY WEST, FLORIDA, WILL HIRE A USER EXPERIENCE/USER INTERFACE EXPERT TO DESIGN A WEBSITE PORTAL TO MAKE IT EASIER TO FIND ITS EIGHT MICROSITES. THIS EXPERT ALSO WILL REDESIGN THE LANDING PAGE FOR THE FLORIDA SLAVE TRADE PORTAL WEBSITE, WITH MUSEUM STAFF REVISING THE CORRESPONDING ONLINE EXHIBIT AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS. IN ADDITION, THE MUSEUM WILL REVISE OR CREATE VIRTUAL EXHIBITS AND ACTIVITY BOOKS FOR ITS EXISTING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM, INITIATE A MARKETING STRATEGY—INCLUDING SOCIAL MEDIA—TO HIGHLIGHT ITS COLLECTIONS, AND SUPPORT STRATEGIC DECISION-MAKING TO INCREASE THE MUSEUM’S ONLINE PRESENCE. FINALLY, THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A GOOGLE ANALYTICS EXPERT TO CREATE CAMPAIGN TRACKING AND USABLE DASHBOARDS. THE MUSEUM WILL TRACK THIS WORK’S PROGRESS USING DATA AND USER SURVEYS. THESE NEW WEB-BASED INITIATIVES WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO ADDRESS THE DESTRUCTIVE EFFECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AS IT CONTINUES TO SERVE ITS COMMUNITY.

THE CHESTER COUNTY HISTORICAL CENTER (CCHC) OF WEST CHESTER, PENNSYLVANIA, WILL VASTLY EXPAND ITS ONLINE COLLECTIONS (INCLUDING LIBRARY AND MUSEUM MATERIALS AND PHOTO ARCHIVES) AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE TO AN UNLIMITED AUDIENCE IN PERPETUITY. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC REVEALED CCHC'S NEED TO UPGRADE ITS SYSTEMS AND IMPROVE ITS CAPACITY FOR ONLINE INTERACTION BETWEEN USERS AND COLLECTIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW CCHC TO EXPAND PART-TIME COLLECTIONS STAFF HOURS AND HIRE A TEMPORARY DIGITAL TECHNICIAN TO SCAN OR PHOTOGRAPH MANUSCRIPTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND ARTIFACTS, AS WELL AS BACK UP THESE FILES. CCHC WILL MAKE THESE ITEMS AVAILABLE ON WEB-BASED PLATFORMS AS COLLECTIONS IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL IMPROVE ITS CUSTOMER SERVICE, EXPAND ITS ABILITY TO PRESERVE COLLECTIONS, AND INCREASE ITS ABILITY TO IMPLEMENT FUTURE DIGITAL PROJECTS.

THE MCWANE SCIENCE CENTER WILL GROW THE MCWANE ACADEMY EDUCATIONAL INITIATIVES FOR THE 2021-2022 SCHOOL YEAR. THESE INITIATIVES INCLUDE DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING SCHOOL-BASED OUTREACH PROGRAMS, VIRTUAL PROGRAMMING, TEACHER WORKSHOPS, AND CLASSROOM RESOURCES. THE MUSEUM WILL USE THE LESSONS LEARNED DURING THE PANDEMIC TO FULLY DEVELOP AN EXPANDED EDUCATIONAL DELIVERY MODEL SECURING DIGITAL PROGRAMMING AS A STAPLE IN ADDITION TO IN-PERSON SERVICES. THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE UNIQUE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO ASSIST THOSE STUDENTS MOST AT-RISK FOR LEARNING GAPS RELATED TO COVID-19 PANDEMIC RELATED CLOSURES AND RESTRICTIONS.

THE HIGHLINE HERITAGE MUSEUM IN BURIEN, WASHINGTON, WILL HIRE AN EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT TO SUPPORT THE DIRECTOR IN ENSURING THE MUSEUM'S LONG-TERM GROWTH AND STABILITY AND CONTINUING VITAL PROGRAMMING THAT BEGAN DURING THE PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM COLLECTS, PRESERVES, AND TELLS THE STORIES OF THE HIGHLINE, A FIVE-CITY REGION MADE UP OF 65 PERCENT MINORITY POPULATIONS. IT IS THE ONLY MUSEUM SPECIFICALLY SERVING THIS GEOGRAPHIC AREA, AND ITS FIRST PERMANENT FACILITY WAS LESS THAN A YEAR OLD WHEN THE PANDEMIC HIT. THE RESULTING CLOSURE HAS TAKEN A TOLL ON THE MUSEUM'S PROGRESS, BUT HIGHLINE HERITAGE MUSEUM IS NOW READY TO MOVE FORWARD AS THE COMMUNITY EMERGES FROM THE MANY MONTHS OF PANDEMIC-RELATED ISOLATION.

THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF DENVER WILL FACILITATE TWO ACCESS INITIATIVES FOR UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS: LOW SENSORY EVENINGS AND MUSEUM2GO KITS. RELAUNCHING THE MUSEUM'S LOW SENSORY EVENINGS WILL PROVIDE QUARTERLY PRIVATE PLAY ACCESS EVENTS FOR FAMILIES OF YOUNG CHILDREN WITH DIVERSE COGNITIVE AND PHYSICAL ABILITIES. THESE FREE EVENTS USE LIMITED CAPACITY AND MODIFIED LIGHTING AND SOUND TO CREATE A WELCOMING AND INCLUSIVE ENVIRONMENT FOR YOUNG CHILDREN WITH DIVERSE COGNITIVE AND PHYSICAL ABILITIES. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH DENVER HUMAN SERVICES, THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL PROVIDE 1,500 MUSEUM2GO KITS TO FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN WHO ARE EXPERIENCING HOMELESSNESS DURING THE ONGOING COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE INTERACTIVE KITS INCLUDE OPEN-ENDED ART SUPPLIES AND MATERIALS TO FACILITATE HANDS-ON LEARNING AND EXPLORATION, AS WELL AS AN ACTIVITY GUIDE WITH ENGAGING, DEVELOPMENTALLY APPROPRIATE ACTIVITIES FOR CHILDREN AGES 8 AND UNDER.

THE DYCKMAN FARMHOUSE MUSEUM ALLIANCE IN NEW YORK CITY WILL HIRE A DIGITAL CONTENT AND PROGRAMS COORDINATOR TO HELP THE MUSEUM CONTINUE RESPONDING TO THE ONGOING COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY EXPANDING ITS ONLINE IMPACT. THIS INDIVIDUAL WILL FILM AND POST LIVESTREAMED AND PRE-RECORDED PROGRAMS, PUBLISH MUSEUM AND EXHIBIT DIGITAL GUIDES, POST UPCOMING EVENTS ON LOCAL MEDIA EVENT CALENDARS, AND CREATE CONTENT ABOUT THE ACTIVE MUSEUM INITIATIVES GROWING UPTOWN (WHICH HELPS COMMUNITY MEMBERS GROW FOOD IN THEIR APARTMENTS) AND TALKING ABOUT RACE MATTERS LECTURE SERIES. THROUGH THIS NEW HIRE'S WORK, THE MUSEUM INTENDS TO INCREASE PROGRAM ATTENDANCE BY 30 PERCENT, INCREASE ITS IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL PROGRAMS BY 20 PERCENT, AND INCREASE ITS COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS BY 20 PERCENT. THE MUSEUM WILL TRACK PROGRESS THROUGH PARTICIPANT SURVEYS AND OTHER MEASURES.

THE GLAZER CHILDREN'S MUSEUM (GCM) IN TAMPA, FLORIDA, WILL IMPLEMENT FOUR ENHANCEMENTS TO ITS DIGITAL PROGRAMMING. FIRST, GCM WILL EXPAND TWO DIGITAL LEARNING PLATFORMS GCM(AT)HOME AND LEARN&PLAY(AT)HOME TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL EDUCATIONAL VIDEOS AND ACTIVITIES TO COMPLEMENT E-LEARNING AND HELP PARENTS FACILITATE PLAY AT HOME. SECOND, GCM WILL ALSO CREATE THREE VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS FOR STUDENTS IN KINDERGARTEN THROUGH GRADE 4 DESIGNED TO SPARK CURIOSITY AND INTEREST IN STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH.) THIRD, GCM WILL EXPAND ITS SOCIAL MEDIA APP TO PROVIDE CONSISTENT AND ENGAGING CONTENT ON TOPICS THAT ALIGN WITH SEASONAL MUSEUM PROGRAMS AND EVENTS. FOURTH, GCM WILL PILOT A VIRTUAL SUMMER READING SERIES. THESE PROGRAMS PROVIDE A MUCH-NEEDED RESPITE FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES WHILE THE COMMUNITY RECOVERS FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

GATEWAY TO SCIENCE CENTER WILL TRAIN ITS STAFF TO MEET THE NEEDS OF UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, PARTICULARLY LOW-INCOME RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, QUICKLY, EFFECTIVELY, EFFICIENTLY, AND RESPONSIBLY. AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, NORTH DAKOTA STUDENTS HAVE EXPERIENCED COVID FATIGUE AND INCREASED DISPARITIES IN LEARNING. STAFF TRAINING WILL FOCUS ON BUILDING SKILLS TO WORK WITH UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. MUSEUM STAFF WILL THEN WORK WITH STAKEHOLDER GROUPS TO DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR COMMUNITY OUTREACH, LEADING TO AN INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF EFFECTIVE STRATEGIES TO ENGAGE STUDENTS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND THE CO-DEVELOPMENT OF INCLUSIVE AND RELEVANT STEM PROGRAMS WITH THOSE COMMUNITIES. IN TURN, STUDENTS AND THEIR LEARNING SUPPORT SYSTEMS ACROSS THE STATE WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED ACCESS TO AND INVESTMENT IN STEM LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES AND INTEGRATION INTO A SUPPORTIVE ECOSYSTEM.

THE VIRGINIA MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS IN RICHMOND WILL FACILITATE A 10-MONTH PROJECT TO EXPAND ITS MUSEUM EDUCATION INTERNSHIP PROGRAM FOLLOWING THE COVID-19 CRISIS. THE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE TRAINING AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR COLLEGE STUDENTS CONSIDERING CAREERS IN MUSEUM EDUCATION, COVERING TOPICS SUCH AS EVALUATION, STUDIO INSTRUCTION, COMMUNITY OUTREACH, AND PUBLIC PROGRAMMING. BUILDING UPON ITS SUCCESSFUL PILOT PROGRAM IN CONSERVATION, THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE 400 HOURS OF HANDS-ON TRAINING TO TEN 3RD- OR 4TH-YEAR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS THROUGH 10-WEEK PAID INTERNSHIPS IN THE MUSEUM'S EDUCATION DEPARTMENT. THE PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON INTEGRATING CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE TEACHING AND NARRATIVES TO ENCOURAGE GREATER DIVERSITY WITHIN THE FIELD. AS THE COUNTRY EMERGES FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE MUSEUM'S INITIATIVE WILL HELP DEVELOP THE NEXT GENERATION OF MUSEUM EDUCATORS.

THE FOUNDATION FOR ADVANCEMENT IN CONSERVATION (FAIC) WILL RESTORE THE CAPACITY OF COLLECTING INSTITUTIONS TO RESPOND AND RECOVER FROM EMERGENCIES FOLLOWING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. FIRST, FAIC WILL DEVELOP A MOBILE APP BASED ON ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND SALVAGE WHEEL. THE APP WILL ESTABLISH A PORTABLE AND EASILY ACCESSIBLE SOURCE OF IMMEDIATELY USABLE INFORMATION IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH FOR EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND SALVAGE AT NO COST TO THE END-USER, EVEN IN PERIODS OF WIDESPREAD POWER OR CELL PHONE OUTAGES. THE PROJECT ALSO WILL REPLENISH THE STOCK OF PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT USED BY NATIONAL HERITAGE RESPONDERS AND LOCAL ALLIANCE FOR RESPONSE TEAMS TO RESPOND TO EMERGENCIES. THESE SUPPLIES, INCLUDING GLOVES AND N95 RESPIRATORS, WERE EXPENDED AT THE BEGINNING OF THE PANDEMIC. REPLENISHING THIS EQUIPMENT WILL ENSURE SAFE AND TIMELY RESPONSES BY VOLUNTEERS TO EMERGENCIES AFFECTING COLLECTING INSTITUTIONS NATIONWIDE.

THE CINCINNATI ART MUSEUM WILL AUGMENT ITS EXISTING DIGITAL CONTENT CREATION FOR MUSEUM PROGRAMS THROUGH TECHNOLOGICAL ENHANCEMENTS AND STAFF TRAINING. THE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND ITS FREE PUBLIC WI-FI TO INCLUDE THE MUSEUM'S OUTDOOR GALLERY AND PROGRAMMING SPACES. MOBILE RECORDING STUDIO CARTS WILL BE BUILT FOR USE IN ALL AREAS OF THE MUSEUM BUILDING AND GROUNDS. STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS WILL RECEIVE THE EQUIPMENT AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT THEY NEED TO CREATE HIGH-QUALITY VIRTUAL AND HYBRID CONTENT. AS INDIVIDUALS CONTINUE TO EXPERIENCE THE IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO CONTINUE TO SERVE DIVERSE AUDIENCES BY DELIVERING NEW PROGRAMMING IN A VARIETY OF FORMATS.

THE DEARBORN HISTORICAL MUSEUM IN MICHIGAN WILL REVITALIZE ITS 1833 COMMANDANT'S QUARTERS TO BETTER INTERPRET THE DIVERSE HISTORY OF THE DEARBORN COMMUNITY. THE MUSEUM WILL RENOVATE DETERIORATING ROOMS AND TRANSITION THE SPACE FROM A HISTORICAL HOUSE TO A TRADITIONAL GALLERY-STYLE MUSEUM. MUSEUM STAFF WILL RESEARCH, DEVELOP, AND INSTALL NEW EDUCATIONAL EXHIBITS FOR SEVEN ROOMS OF THE HOUSE, EACH THEMED AROUND A SPECIFIC ASPECT OF LOCAL HISTORY. TAKEN TOGETHER, THE EXHIBITS WILL PRESENT AN INCLUSIVE AND HOLISTIC VIEW OF DEARBORN'S PAST. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A CONTRACTOR TO DESIGN AND PRINT PROFESSIONAL-QUALITY PANELS FOR THE EXHIBITS. THE RESULTING EXHIBITIONS WILL ALLOW THE DEARBORN HISTORICAL MUSEUM TO BETTER ACHIEVE ITS MISSION WHILE CONTRIBUTING TO THE REVITALIZATION OF THE DEARBORN COMMUNITY FOLLOWING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE PAWLING FREE LIBRARY WILL LICENSE ADDITIONAL EBOOKS AND AUDIOBOOKS FOR LIBRARY USERS OF ALL AGES AND INTERESTS IN ORDER TO MEET THE OVERWHELMING DEMAND THE LIBRARY HAS EXPERIENCED FOR DIGITAL CONTENT IN RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, WHILE ALSO LAYING THE FOUNDATION OF HAVING A BROADER BASE OF RESOURCES LICENSED AND AVAILABLE FOR FUTURE USE. IN ADDITION TO PEOPLE WHO LIVE IN PAWLING, OTHER MEMBERS OF THE MID-HUDSON LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL ALSO BENEFIT FROM THIS ADDITIONAL DIGITAL CONTENT AS WHENEVER NO PAWLING LIBRARY PATRONS ARE BORROWING A TITLE, CARDHOLDERS FROM THE OTHER MEMBER LIBRARIES ARE ABLE TO BORROW IT.

THE PANHANDLE PUBLIC LIBRARY COOPERATIVE SYSTEM (PPLCS), WHICH SERVES FLORIDA'S CALHOUN, HOLMES, AND JACKSON COUNTIES, WILL IMPROVE UPON ITS DIGITAL COLLECTIONS, ADDING MORE ELECTRONIC TITLES AND ADDITIONAL COPIES OF POPULAR E-BOOKS AND OTHER MATERIALS WHEN WAIT TIMES EXCEED NINETY DAYS. PPLCS EXPERIENCED AN EXTREME INCREASE IN DEMAND FOR DIGITAL RESOURCES AFTER SCHOOLS AND LIBRARY BUILDINGS CLOSED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. EVEN AFTER THE LIBRARIES REOPENED IN LATE SUMMER OF 2020, PHYSICAL LIBRARY VISITS WERE SIGNIFICANTLY LOWER THAN THEIR PRE-PANDEMIC LEVELS, WITH USAGE OF THE SYSTEM'S DIGITAL COLLECTIONS CONTINUING TO RISE. ENLARGING PPLCS'S DIGITAL COLLECTIONS, INCLUDING E-BOOKS AND EAUDIOBOOKS, WILL IMPROVE EQUITY BY INCREASING ACCESS TO EDUCATIONAL AND OTHER MATERIALS IN THESE RURAL AND ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES.

THE MARBLES KIDS MUSEUM IN RALEIGH, NORTH CAROLINA, WILL EXPAND ITS FULL CIRCLE ACCESS PROGRAMS TO PROVIDE ENRICHING, HANDS-ON LEARNING FOR UNDERSERVED CHILDREN AND FAMILIES IN WAKE COUNTY MOST IMPACTED BY THE PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL DISTRIBUTE PLAY PASSES TO FULL CIRCLE PARTNER AGENCIES SO FAMILIES CAN VISIT WHENEVER THEIR SCHEDULES ALLOW, AND IT ALSO WILL HOST SPECIAL EVENTS FOR FAMILIES SERVED BY PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO VISIT AS A GROUP DURING EXCLUSIVE HOURS. CAREGIVERS WILL BE INVITED TO ATTEND INFORMATIONAL WORKSHOPS ON TOPICS RELEVANT TO THEIR FAMILIES WHILE CHILDREN ARE ENGAGED IN SUPERVISED PROGRAMMING AND PLAY IN THE MUSEUM'S EXHIBITS. THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE FREE AFTER-HOURS PROGRAMMING FOR CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES AND THEIR FAMILIES.

THE QUEENS BOROUGH PUBLIC LIBRARY (QPL) WILL ENGAGE CHILDREN AND UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS AND CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR LEARNING, CONNECTION, AND ENRICHMENT ONLINE BY PROVIDING MOBILE HOTSPOTS FOR PERSONAL USE TO BORROWERS OF ALL AGES LOCATED IN NEIGHBORHOODS WITH THE LOWEST BROADBAND USE AND WHO CURRENTLY DO NOT HAVE HOUSEHOLD INTERNET ACCESS. THIS AWARD WILL EXPAND THE LIBRARY'S QUEENS CONNECT INITIATIVE TO GIVE MORE QUEENS RESIDENTS RELIABLE INTERNET AND TECHNOLOGY ACCESS AS THEY ARE SEARCHING FOR JOBS, ATTENDING REMOTE CLASSES, ACCESSING TELEHEALTH PROGRAMS, AND CONNECTING WITH FAMILY AND FRIENDS. QPL WILL PARTNER WITH COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS TO REACH NON-LIBRARY USERS AND IMPLEMENT NEW SERVICES THAT TURN PEOPLE INTO LIFELONG LIBRARY SUPPORTERS. THE LIBRARY WILL ALSO HELP TO RAISE AWARENESS OF LOW-COST BROADBAND PLANS AVAILABLE AS PART OF NEW YORK STATE'S EMERGENCY BROADBAND BENEFIT PROGRAM.

THE MIAMI-DADE PUBLIC LIBRARY SYSTEM (MDPLS) WILL IMPROVE ITS ONLINE SERVICES BY INCREASING USER ACCESS TO E-BOOKS AND EAUDIOBOOKS. AT THE ONSET OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, MDPLS EXPERIENCED A SUBSTANTIAL INCREASE IN DEMAND FOR ONLINE SERVICES, E-BOOKS, AND EAUDIOBOOKS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, LIBRARIES WILL ADD NEW ONLINE CONTENT AND PURCHASE ADDITIONAL COPIES OF POPULAR ITEMS, REDUCING WAIT TIMES FOR MATERIALS IN HIGH DEMAND. THEY WILL INCORPORATE PANDEMIC-RELATED CONTENT, SUCH AS CAREER AND READINESS, COPING WITH STRESS AND ANXIETY, MENTAL HEALTH, AND SELF-CARE. THE INITIATIVE WILL WORK IN CONCERT WITH MDPLS'S INTERNET-ENABLED TABLET LENDING PROGRAM, WHICH EXPANDS THE LIBRARY'S REMOTE SERVICES TO THE COMMUNITY. THE TABLETS ARE PRELOADED WITH POPULAR SOCIAL MEDIA AND VIDEOCONFERENCING APPS, AS WELL AS LIBRARY APPS FOR EDUCATIONAL AND RECREATIONAL ENTERTAINMENT SERVICES SUCH AS E-BOOKS, AUDIOBOOKS, MOVIES, AND MUSIC.

THE MINT MUSEUM IN CHARLOTTE, NORTH CAROLINA, WILL HIRE A PART-TIME DIVERSITY, EQUITY, INCLUSION, AND ACCESSIBILITY (DEIA) COORDINATOR. THE NEW COORDINATOR WILL HELP THE DIRECTOR OF HUMAN RESOURCES AND DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY RELATIONS WITH DEIA INITIATIVES PLANNED FOR THE COMING YEARS. THE MUSEUM'S CURRENT DEIA PROGRAM HAS TWO MAIN COMPONENTS: EXTERNAL (INCLUSIVE PUBLIC PROGRAMMING AND PRESENTATION/ACQUISITION OF CULTURALLY AND ETHNICALLY DIVERSE ART/ARTISTS) AND INTERNAL (BOARD AND STAFF TRAINING, ORGANIZATIONAL AND INFRASTRUCTURE CHANGES, CREATIVE POLICIES, AND ACCESS FOR ALL). CURRENT DEIA ACTIVITIES THAT THE COORDINATOR WILL HELP EXPAND INCLUDE MONTHLY PROGRAMS, STUDY AIDS, MEETINGS WITH OTHER DEIA COMMUNITY GROUPS, CONFERENCE PARTICIPATION, AND TRAINING WORKSHOPS. THIS WORK WILL AID THE MUSEUM IN ITS RECOVERY FROM THE IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AS WELL AS STRENGTHEN THE MUSEUM'S COMMITMENT TO PRESENTING THE HIGHEST CALIBER OF PROGRAMMING, OUTREACH, ART EDUCATION, AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT, AND TRANSFORMATIVE EXPERIENCES FOR ITS COMMUNITY.

THE LEWIS GINTER BOTANICAL GARDEN WILL EXPAND ITS POPULAR LENDING SEED LIBRARY, A CIRCULATING COLLECTION OF SEEDS AVAILABLE FOR PEOPLE TO BORROW, PLANT, HARVEST, SAVE, AND RETURN FOR OTHERS TO BORROW. HOME GARDENING INCREASED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC,, DRIVING INTEREST IN THE GARDEN'S PROGRAMMING. THE SEED LIBRARY FUNCTIONS BOTH AS A LENDING SERVICE AND AN EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM, PROVIDING STAFF AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS WITH AN OPPORTUNITY TO EDUCATE PARTICIPANTS THROUGH WORKSHOPS, TALKS, AND LITERATURE ON SEED SAVING METHODS, STARTING FROM SEED, BIODIVERSITY, HISTORY AND TRADITIONS FOR FOOD PRODUCTION AND GARDENING IN VIRGINIA, AND OTHER ALLIED TOPICS. GARDEN STAFF WILL MAKE THE COMMUNITY SEED LIBRARY MOBILE, PROVIDING AN OUTREACH PROGRAM FOR PUBLIC LIBRARIES, SCHOOLS, AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS IN THE CENTRAL VIRGINIA REGION.

THE DUKE UNIVERSITY LEMUR CENTER IN DURHAM, NORTH CAROLINA, WILL HIRE A COLLECTIONS MANAGER TO ACCESSION SPECIMENS, TRACK AND PROCESS LOANS, AND COORDINATE VOLUNTEER EFFORTS. STAFF WILL PARTICIPATE IN TRAINING ON THE USE OF A BIOLOGY DATABASE MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE THAT WILL ALLOW THE CENTER TO SHARE THE CONTENTS OF ITS COLLECTION ONLINE. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR A COLLECTIONS MANAGER AS RESEARCHERS REQUESTED LOANS AND SPECIMEN DETAILS BECAUSE THEY WERE UNABLE TO VISIT THE COLLECTIONS. THE COLLECTIONS MANAGER WILL PARTICIPATE IN CONFERENCES FOCUSED ON PALEONTOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING THE ANNUAL MEETING OF THE SOCIETY FOR THE PRESERVATION OF NATURAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS, AND WILL CREATE A GUIDE DOCUMENTING WORKFLOW THAT WORK-STUDY STUDENTS, VOLUNTEERS, AND FUTURE STAFF CAN USE.

THE WYOMING STATE MUSEUM WILL INCREASE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS BY IMPROVING ITS DIGITAL PLATFORMS AND ONLINE SERVICES, WHICH SAW INCREASED DEMAND DURING THE PANDEMIC. MUSEUM STAFF WILL RECEIVE ADDITIONAL TRAINING TO EXPAND THEIR CAPACITY TO DELIVER ONLINE EDUCATION PROGRAMS. THROUGH A NEW PHOTOGRAMMETRY STUDIO ON-SITE, STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING ON EQUIPMENT AND SOFTWARE THAT PRODUCE 3D SCANS OF COLLECTION ITEMS FOR POSTING ONLINE. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A CURATOR OF DIGITAL ACCESS TO WORK WITH COLLECTIONS STAFF TO CREATE AND DELIVER ONLINE EXHIBITS AND VIRTUAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS. THE NEW POSITION WILL INCREASE THE MUSEUM'S CAPACITY AND ASSOCIATED EDUCATIONAL IMPACT BY AS MUCH AS 66 PERCENT.

THE WALTERS ART MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT AN OUTREACH PROJECT TO RESPOND TO AND ADDRESS THE EDUCATIONAL NEEDS OF STUDENTS IN THE BALTIMORE AREA. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE TWO NEW POSITIONS, A CURRICULUM RESOURCE SPECIALIST AND A SCHOOL PROGRAMS OUTREACH EDUCATOR, CREATE CURRICULUM-ALIGNED PROGRAMS FOR STUDENTS INSPIRED BY THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION, PROVIDE OUTREACH TO EDUCATORS, AND DEVELOP DYNAMIC EVALUATION AND TEACHING PLANS TO ENHANCE THE MUSEUM'S ABILITY TO REACH STUDENTS IN A POST-COVID ENVIRONMENT. THE PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN AND REDEFINE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN SCHOOLS AND THE WALTERS ART MUSEUM TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF STUDENTS AND EDUCATORS IN MARYLAND FOR CURRICULUM-ENHANCING OPPORTUNITIES DURING THE RECOVERY FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE MILWAUKEE PUBLIC LIBRARY IN WISCONSIN WILL IMPLEMENT A PROGRAM TO PROVIDE YOUTH WITH INCREASED COMMUNICATION AND CONFLICT RESOLUTION SKILLS. THE LIBRARY WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME CIRCLE KEEPING CONSULTANT TO LEAD BIWEEKLY YOUTH PROGRAMS AT ALL OF ITS LOCATIONS, GIVING SPECIAL FOCUS TO PROGRAMMING AT THREE BRANCHES LOCATED IN UNDER RESOURCED NEIGHBORHOODS. THE CIRCLE KEEPING PRACTICE DEVELOPS COMMUNITY AND BUILDS RELATIONSHIPS TO CREATE TRUST AND HELP PEOPLE WORK TOGETHER, AND THE CONSULTANT ALSO WILL FACILITATE THE TRAINING OF LIBRARY STAFF IN THIS PRACTICE. THE PROGRAM WILL ADDRESS BEHAVIORAL ISSUES CAUSED BY THE STRESS OF THE PANDEMIC AND HELP THE LIBRARY RESTORE A SENSE OF COMMUNITY IN AN INCREASINGLY DISCONNECTED WORLD.

SANDY SPRING MUSEUM, THE STATE-DESIGNATED REGIONAL FOLKLIFE CENTER OF MONTGOMERY COUNTY, MARYLAND, WILL FUND STAFF TO WORK DIRECTLY WITH FOLK ARTISTS, SHARING RESOURCES TO HELP THEM BUILD THEIR CAPACITY, SUSTAIN THEIR FOLK TRADITIONS, AND FOSTER SOCIAL COHESION IN THE CHALLENGING SOCIOECONOMIC CLIMATE OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE WORK IT BEGAN IN 2014 TO PROVIDE RESOURCES FOR ACTIVITIES DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED BY ARTISTS, AS WELL AS GIVE ARTISTS A PUBLIC VENUE FOR SHARING THEIR ART. THE COLLABORATING FOLK ARTISTS ARE ALMOST EXCLUSIVELY IMMIGRANTS, PEOPLE OF COLOR, AND MEMBERS OF UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, AND NONE HAVE PAID STAFF OR THEIR OWN FACILITY. THE SANDY SPRING MUSEUM PROGRAM ALLOWS THESE ARTISTS TO SHARE THEIR CULTURAL CONTRIBUTIONS WITH AUDIENCES WHO WOULD NOT OTHERWISE HAVE ACCESS TO THEM, FOSTER CROSS-CULTURAL RELATIONSHIPS, AND INCREASE THE MUSEUM'S IMPACT IN THE COMMUNITY.

THE BUFFALO & ERIE COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY IN NEW YORK WILL PROVIDE EQUIPMENT AND RESOURCES TO EXPAND COMMUNITY ACCESS TO THE INTERNET, THE DISPARITIES OF WHICH WERE EVEN MORE EVIDENT DURING THE PANDEMIC. LAPTOPS AND WI-FI HOTSPOTS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE FOR PATRONS AT 16 PUBLIC LIBRARIES IN URBAN, SUBURBAN, AND RURAL AREAS. THE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE THESE RESOURCES FREE OF CHARGE TO COMMUNITIES WHERE THERE ARE INFRASTRUCTURAL AND FINANCIAL BARRIERS PREVENTING COMPUTER AND INTERNET ACCESS. ADULTS AND CHILDREN WILL BE ABLE TO RESERVE AND BORROW LAPTOPS AND HOTSPOTS FOR A PREDETERMINED LENGTH OF TIME. THE LIBRARY WILL PROMOTE THE PROGRAM THROUGH ITS COMMUNITY PARTNERS, LOCAL SCHOOLS, AND COMMUNITY CENTERS, AS WELL AS THROUGH OUTREACH BY NEIGHBORHOOD BRANCH LIBRARIES.

THE TUSKEGEE HISTORY CENTER IN ALABAMA WILL PRODUCE NEW ON- AND OFF-SITE INTERACTIVE PROGRAMS TO EDUCATE MORE PEOPLE ON THE FACTS OF THE TUSKEGEE SYPHILIS STUDY AND EXAMINE THE ISSUES OF MISTRUST THAT AROSE FROM THE STUDY. THE CENTER WILL DESIGN PROGRAMS FOR HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS AND ANYONE SEEKING A GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF MINORITY HEALTHCARE INEQUITIES. THE CENTER WILL LAUNCH A TOUR TO HIGHLIGHT PLACES ASSOCIATED WITH THE STUDY, INCLUDING SITES WHERE MEN WERE RECRUITED TO PARTICIPATE. THE PROGRAM WILL GENERATE GREATER AWARENESS OF THE STUDY FACTS AND INCREASE SENSITIVITY ABOUT MINORITY HEALTHCARE DISPARITIES, AS WELL AS ADDRESS SOME OF MISTRUST CONNECTED WITH THE RELUCTANCE ON THE PART OF SOME AFRICAN AMERICANS TO PARTICIPATE IN CAMPAIGNS ADDRESSING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE SARASOTA ART MUSEUM IN FLORIDA WILL EXPAND DIGITAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR K-12 STUDENTS. THE MUSEUM, ESTABLISHED BY RINGLING COLLEGE OF ART AND DESIGN TO STRENGTHEN EDUCATIONAL AND CULTURAL OFFERINGS IN THE GULF COAST COMMUNITY, WILL CREATE VIRTUAL TOURS OF FOUR EXHIBITIONS ALONG WITH AGE-APPROPRIATE RELATED CURRICULAR LESSONS FOR CLASSROOM USE. FOR THOSE SCHOOLS THAT DO NOT HAVE BROADBAND CAPABILITY, THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE TOURS AND LESSONS AVAILABLE VIA PORTABLE DRIVES. INITIALLY, THE MUSEUM WILL TARGET TITLE I AND CHARTER SCHOOLS. FEATURED EXHIBITIONS FROM NATIONALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY RENOWNED MULTICULTURAL ARTISTS WILL SPAN A SPECTRUM OF DIVERSE ETHNIC, SOCIAL, AND GEOGRAPHIC PERSPECTIVES. THESE PROGRAMS ADDRESS AN IDENTIFIED K-12 COMMUNITY NEED FOR VIRTUAL ARTS ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES CREATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE WAHLUKE SCHOOL DISTRICT PROJECT WILL HELP BRIDGE EQUITY GAPS IN LITERACY EXPERIENCED BY RURAL, LOW-INCOME, HISPANIC STUDENTS THAT WERE FURTHER EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. ACCESS TO BOOKS WAS ALREADY A CHALLENGE FOR FAMILIES WHEN SCHOOL AND PUBLIC LIBRARY CLOSURES MADE ACCESS TO MATERIALS NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE FOR ALMOST A YEAR. WITH THIS PROJECT, PHYSICAL AND DIGITAL BOOKS WILL BE PURCHASED FOR LIBRARIES AT THREE ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS AND A JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL. MAKERSPACES WITHIN THE LIBRARIES WILL INVITE STUDENTS TO USE KNOWLEDGE GAINED THROUGH THE USE OF TECHNOLOGY DURING THE PANDEMIC TO DEMONSTRATE LITERACY AND BUILD LEARNING AGENCY AND SELF-EFFICACY. STUDENT ARTIFACTS OF LEARNING CREATED IN THE MAKERSPACE WILL BE SHARED ON NEW LIBRARY WEBSITES TO HELP CONNECT THEM TO LEARNING SPACES OUTSIDE THE SCHOOL WHERE THEY HAVE SPENT A GOOD PART OF THE LAST YEAR. THESE BEST PRACTICES, AMONG OTHERS, WILL CONTRIBUTE TO PROGRESS IN READING ACHIEVEMENT AND SUCCESSFUL RECOVERY FROM INTERRUPTIONS TO EDUCATION DURING THE PANDEMIC.

THE GEORGIA O'KEEFFE MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT A PROJECT TO REBUILD THE MUSEUM'S CAPACITY TO DELIVER CULTURALLY-RELEVANT EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCES FOR CHILDREN AND ADULTS IN SANTA FE AND NORTHERN NEW MEXICO. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HIRING A FULL-TIME COMMUNITY EDUCATOR, RELAUNCHING THE 4TH GRADE VISIT PROGRAM, DEEPENING THE ARTS EDUCATION PARTNERSHIP WITH MILAGRO MIDDLE SCHOOL, LAUNCHING A TEACHER ADVISORY GROUP, IMPLEMENTING COMMUNITY-BASED BILINGUAL (SPANISH AND ENGLISH) PROGRAMS, REENGAGING A LIBRARY PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM TO UTILIZE NEIGHBORHOOD LIBRARIES AS VENUES FOR LEARNING PROGRAMS, AND PLANNING AND DEVELOPING A MOBILE ART TRUCK THAT WILL BRING EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES AND ENRICHMENT OPPORTUNITIES OUT INTO THE COMMUNITY. ACCESS TO ART AND CREATIVE SELF-EXPRESSION WILL HELP INDIVIDUALS FIND MEANING, PURPOSE, AND JOY WHILE HELPING TO BUILD A MORE CONNECTED AND SUPPORTIVE COMMUNITY AS IT REBUILDS AFTER THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE BIG HEAVY WORLD FOUNDATION WILL ADDRESS PANDEMIC IMPACTS ON ITS MUSIC COMMUNITY BY REVITALIZING INTEREST AND PARTICIPATION IN LOCAL CULTURAL HERITAGE. THE FOUNDATION WILL EXPAND ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION OF ITS VERMONT MUSIC MUSEUM, SHOWCASING THE STATE'S DIVERSE MUSIC HERITAGE AND BRING ITS ARTIFACTS, EXHIBITS, AND MUSIC ARCHIVE CATALOGUE ONLINE, PROVIDING ACCESS TO AUDIENCES IN THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AND BEYOND. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL INCREASE ON-SITE DOCENT AND VOLUNTEER HOURS, EXPANDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO PARTICIPATE IN THE MUSEUM'S RESEARCH, PRESERVATION, DEVELOPMENT, AND OUTREACH WORK. THE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND COMMUNITY INTERNET ACCESS THROUGH A WORKSTATION AND PUBLIC HOT SPOT TO SUPPORT NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS TO INTERACT WITH ARTISTS IN EDUCATIONAL AND REAL-TIME COLLABORATIVE PERFORMANCE EVENTS.

THE JOURNEY MUSEUM IN RAPID CITY, SOUTH DAKOTA WILL PARTNER WITH THE RAPID CITY PUBLIC LIBRARY TO DEVELOP THE 'REMEMBERING, HONORING, AND MOVING FORWARD AFTER THE 1972 BLACK HILLS FLOOD' PROJECT. THIS DIGITAL CURATION, ORAL HISTORY, AND EXHIBIT (VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON) PROJECT TELLS THE STORY OF THE 1972 FLOOD THAT WILL INCLUDE MULTIPLE PERSPECTIVES LOOKING BEYOND MOURNING AND HEROISM TO FULLY EXAMINE THE IMPACT OF THE EVENT. THIS PROJECT WILL INCORPORATE THE PREVIOUSLY EXCLUDED NATIVE AMERICAN PERSPECTIVE TO ADDRESS HOW THEY WERE DISPROPORTIONALLY AFFECTED BY THE FLOOD AND WILL ATTEMPT TO CORRECT INACCURATELY RECORDED DEATH RATES IN THE NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUNITY - RATES THAT WERE PREVIOUSLY MISREPORTED AND UNDERREPRESENTED. THE PROJECT IS INTENDED TO HELP RAPID CITY RECOVER FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY CREATING A NEW PAID POSITION WHILE INCLUDING THE REGION'S NATIVE AMERICAN VOICES, WHO ARE ALSO DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED BY THE PANDEMIC. THE PROJECT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED WHILE RAPID CITY CONSIDERS HOW IT WILL TRACK AND INCLUDE THE NATIVE AMERICAN EXPERIENCE OF THE PANDEMIC.

THE BURKE WILL EXPAND ITS INTERPRETIVE STAFF PROGRAM TO ENABLE VISITORS TO EASILY UNDERSTAND WHAT THEY ARE SEEING AT THE MUSEUM AND HAVE THEIR QUESTIONS ANSWERED IN A TIMELY AND ENGAGING MANNER. INTERPRETATION FLOOR STAFF STATIONED NEAR HIGH-VISIBILITY LOCATIONS IN THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE PATRONS BY EXPLAINING WHAT IS HAPPENING IN THOSE SPACES AND ANSWERING QUESTIONS ABOUT THE WORK ON VIEW. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL EXPAND ITS ARTIST STUDIO, WHICH PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIGENOUS ARTISTS TO SHARE THEIR WORK, ARTISTIC PRACTICES, AND CULTURAL TRADITIONS WITH A BROADER COMMUNITY. THE PROJECT WILL REVIVE THE MUSEUM'S NEW APPROACH TO COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, WHICH WAS INTERRUPTED BY COVID-19, AND WHICH WILL CONTINUE TO CONNECT PEOPLE IN THIS TIME OF PANDEMIC RECOVERY.

THE BURCHFIELD PENNEY ART CENTER IN BUFFALO, NEW YORK, WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME SOCIAL MEDIA AND DIGITAL CONTENT SPECIALIST TO MANAGE THE CENTER'S WEBSITE, SOCIAL MEDIA CHANNELS, EMAILS, AND DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS AND MARKETING BUYS TO MEET AUDIENCE NEEDS THROUGH A HYBRID MODEL OF ON-SITE AND ONLINE PROGRAMMING DURING THE ONGOING COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS NEW HIRE WILL WORK WITH THE CENTER'S CURATORIAL, EDUCATIONAL, AND PUBLIC PROGRAM DEPARTMENTS TO PLAN AND CREATE CONTENT, INCLUDING EVALUATING THE CENTER'S WORK AGAINST ITS DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND INCLUSION VISION AND GOALS. THE CENTER SERVES THE EIGHT COUNTIES OF WESTERN NEW YORK AND HAS STRONG TIES TO THE BUFFALO COMMUNITY. THE CENTER IS GATHERING DATA TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND LEVERAGE POTENTIAL OPPORTUNITIES WITH BROADER LOCAL, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL AUDIENCES.

THE CONTEMPORARY ART MUSEUM ST. LOUIS WILL IMPLEMENT THE COLLECTIVE IMPACT PROJECT BRINGING ARTISTS, ORGANIZATIONS, AND RESIDENTS FROM SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES TOGETHER TO CREATE COLLABORATIVE WORKS OF ART THAT RAISE AWARENESS AROUND COMPLEX SOCIAL ISSUES. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH CREATIVE REACTION LAB, A LOCAL NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION SERVING PEOPLE OF COLOR, THE MUSEUM WILL ORGANIZE EXHIBITIONS AND PUBLIC PROGRAMS SHOWCASING THE COMMUNITY-CREATED ARTWORK.
