TO ENSURE THE MUSEUM REMAINS A WELCOME AND OPEN RESOURCE FOR ALL, STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING IN ANTI-RACISM AND TRAUMA-AWARE PRACTICES. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO OVERCOME THE IMPACT OF STRESS CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC THROUGH TRAUMA-AWARE, HEALING ART PROJECTS THAT RESPOND TO COMMUNITY NEEDS.

THE VISUAL ARTS CENTER OF NEW JERSEY IN SUMMIT WILL PARTNER WITH ELIZABETH PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICT TO ADDRESS STUDENTS' NEEDS, INCLUDING THOSE CREATED AND EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, AND HELP WITH ITS PANDEMIC RECOVERY. ALTHOUGH THE SCHOOL DISTRICT IS PLANNING TO HOLD IN-PERSON CLASSES THIS SCHOOL YEAR, THE STUDENTS ARE STILL RECOVERING FROM THE EMOTIONAL IMPACTS OF THE PANDEMIC AND LOSS OF IN-PERSON LEARNING SINCE MARCH 2020. SINCE 2009, THE CENTER HAS HOSTED THE ARTS ALIVE INITIATIVE, BRINGING HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS FROM THOMAS JEFFERSON ARTS ACADEMY TO THE CENTER FOR AN IN-DEPTH, SEQUENTIAL LEARNING ARTS EDUCATION PROGRAM THAT EXPANDS STUDENTS' KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF CONTEMPORARY ART. BECAUSE OF A POSSIBLE RESTRICTION TO FIELD TRIPS THIS SCHOOL YEAR DUE TO THE PANDEMIC, THE CENTER WILL CONTINUE ADAPTING ITS EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING TO THE STUDENTS' NEEDS.

THE MICHILIMACKINAC HISTORICAL SOCIETY IN ST. IGNACE, MICHIGAN, WILL PLAN AND IMPLEMENT THE COLLECTIONS ACCESS AND ARTIFACT-CENTERED HUMANITIES EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING INITIATIVE. THE SOCIETY'S PROGRAMMING ATTRACTS VISITORS AND CONTRIBUTES FINANCIALLY TO THE REGION, BUT IT WAS NOT ABLE TO OPEN IN 2020 DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, A NEW SLATE OF PROGRAMMING WILL EXPAND DIGITAL ACCESS TO THE SOCIETY'S COLLECTION, DEVELOP AND DELIVER EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING CONNECTED TO THE MICHILIMACKINAC AREA, AND PRESERVE AND PROTECT ITS COLLECTION, SUPPORTING THE SOCIETY'S REENGAGEMENT WITH ITS VISITORS FOLLOWING THE PANDEMIC. THE PROPOSED INITIATIVE INCLUDES UPGRADING THE SOCIETY'S DATABASE SUBSCRIPTION AND MOVING TO A CLOUD-BASED PLATFORM TO EXPAND ONLINE ACCESS TO THE ORGANIZATION'S COLLECTION OF ARTIFACTS, WHICH WILL ALLOW THE ORGANIZATION TO CURATE ONLINE EXHIBITS.

THE BELEN PUBLIC LIBRARY IN BELEN, NEW MEXICO, WILL CREATE PUBLIC PROGRAMMING TO ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN SELF-IMPROVEMENT OPPORTUNITIES AS TOOLS FOR RECOVERY FROM COVID-19 PANDEMIC EXPERIENCES. THE LIBRARY WILL CREATE EDUCATIONAL AND INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMMING TO ADDRESS NEEDS ACROSS AGE GROUPS AND SOCIAL, CULTURAL, AND ETHNIC DEMOGRAPHICS. ORGANIZED PROGRAMMING WILL INCLUDE WEEKLY FAMILY YOGA FOR MIND AND BODY HEALTH CLASSES AND BIWEEKLY SOCIALS TARGETED AT TEENS. TO SUPPORT THOSE WHOSE EMPLOYMENT WAS IMPACTED BY THE PANDEMIC, THE LIBRARY WILL OFFER A PROGRAM ON JOB OPPORTUNITIES IN THE POST-COVID ECONOMY, FOLLOWED BY BIWEEKLY OPEN LABS ON RESUME WRITING AND HOW TO SUBMIT JOB APPLICATIONS ONLINE. THE LIBRARY WILL ORGANIZE A COMMUNITY EVENT TO CREATE A PANDEMIC TIME CAPSULE AND A COMMUNITY-BASED MUSEUM EXHIBIT WITH COVID-19 MEMORIES AND EPHEMERA, CONTEXTUALIZED WITH INFORMATION AND OBJECTS FROM THE 1917 FLU EPIDEMIC.

THE NEW CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN SAN DIEGO, CALIFORNIA, WILL REIMAGINE AND REINTRODUCE ITS SCHOOL VISITS PROGRAM FOR PRE-K/ELEMENTARY STUDENTS AND HEAD START GROUPS. ALTHOUGH VIRTUAL TOURS WERE A TEMPORARY PIVOT DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, POSITIVE REVIEWS AND AN ONGOING DEMAND FOR REMOTE OPTIONS LED THE MUSEUM TO PLAN NEW VIDEOS AND ACTIVITIES THAT SUPPORT THE YOUNGEST LEARNERS WHO WERE MOST AFFECTED BY LEARNING LOSS DURING THE PANDEMIC. THE NEW CHILDREN'S MUSEUM SCHOOL VISIT EXPERIENCE WILL BUILD ON ITS INQUIRY-BASED, ON-SITE TOURS THAT EXPLORE THE MUSEUM'S ART INSTALLATIONS AND INCLUDE HANDS-ON ART MAKING. UPDATES WILL INCLUDE VIRTUAL TOURS, ENGLISH/SPANISH ACTIVITY BOOKLETS, AND ART KITS AND DIGITAL ART PACKETS FOR SCHOOLS, WHICH PROVED HUGELY SUCCESSFUL WHEN PILOTED DURING THE PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL EXPAND PROGRAMMING FOR PRE-K AUDIENCES WITH NEW ONLINE AND ON-SITE OPTIONS AND WILL PROVIDE FREE ACCESS FOR STUDENTS FROM TITLE I SCHOOLS AND HEAD START PROGRAMS.

THE WALKER ART CENTER IN MINNEAPOLIS, MINNESOTA, WILL ADVANCE NEW STRATEGIES TO RESPOND TO CHALLENGES SCHOOLS FACE AS THEY NAVIGATE IN-PERSON, OFFSITE, AND VIRTUAL NEEDS FOR LEARNING, ENSURING CONTINUED ACCESS TO ARTS RESOURCES DURING RECOVERY FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL RESTRUCTURE AND BUILD ITS EDUCATOR STAFF, DEVELOP NEW VIRTUAL AND HYBRID OFFERINGS, AND ENHANCE DIGITAL FORMATS THAT ALIGN WITH THE MUSEUM’S FIELD TRIP AND TOUR CURRICULUM. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL PROMOTE AND SHOWCASE THE DIVERSITY OF ITS LEARNING EXPERIENCES AVAILABLE TO SCHOOLS. THE PROJECT IS AIMED PRIMARILY AT K–12 STUDENTS IN THE TWIN CITIES AND AT RURAL SCHOOLS WITHOUT EASY ACCESS TO ARTS PROGRAMMING. THE MUSEUM WILL USE OBSERVATION CHECKLISTS AND TEACHER SURVEYS, AMONG OTHER TOOLS, TO ASSESS ITS WORK.

THE STUDIO MUSEUM IN HARLEM WILL DEVELOP THE THOMAS J. PRICE EXHIBITION, WITNESS, AND THE 2021-22 SEASON OF INHARLEM COMMUNITY-BASED COLLABORATIVE PROGRAMMING. THE MUSEUM WILL DEEPEN ITS ROOTS IN THE COMMUNITY THROUGH INHARLEM BY PROVIDING ARTS-BASED PROGRAMMING FOR FAMILIES, TEENS, AND ADULTS THROUGH BOTH DIGITAL AND IN-PERSON INITIATIVES THAT OPERATE WITH THE HELP OF LOCAL NYC LIBRARIES, PARKS, COMMUNITY CENTERS AND PUBLIC SCHOOLS. THE INHARLEM EXHIBITION THOMAS J. PRICE: WITNESS INVOLVES ERECTING A NINE-FOOT BRONZE FIGURE SITED WITHIN HARLEM'S MARCUS GARVEY PARK THAT ADDRESSES BLACK MASCULINITY, STEREOTYPES AND SHARED DIASPORIC EXPERIENCES AND WILL BE THE U.K. ARTIST'S FIRST EVER U.S. MUSEUM SOLO EXHIBITION. THE MUSEUM WILL ENGAGE ITS RESILIENT COMMUNITIES VIA INHARLEM PROGRAMMING AND AID IN RECOVERY AS THEY OVERCOME THE DEVASTATING EFFECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC TOGETHER.

THE MUSEUM OF THE EARTH WILL DEVELOP THE HERE ON EARTH COMPONENT OF EARTH(AT)HOME ONLINE, AN OPEN EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE PLATFORM THAT WILL PROVIDE HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS WITH REGIONALLY CONTEXTUALIZED GEOSCIENCE CONTENT AND CAREER PATH GUIDANCE THAT THEY CAN INTEGRATE INTO THEIR LESSONS AND CLASSROOMS. HERE ON EARTH WILL INCREASE AWARENESS OF EARTH SCIENCE AMONG HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, INCREASE AWARENESS OF GEOSCIENCE CAREERS, AND HELP DIVERSIFY THE GEOSCIENCES WORKFORCE. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH HIGH SCHOOL SCIENCE PROGRAMS, NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUMS, AND NATIONAL PUBLIC PARKS AROUND THE COUNTRY TO CONNECT EXISTING PRI EARTH SCIENCE LEARNING RESOURCES WITH A WIDER NATIONAL COMMUNITY OF HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS. THIS ONLINE LEARNING RESOURCE FOR TEACHERS SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE WEAKNESS AND LIMITATIONS IN AVAILABLE ONLINE LEARNING RESOURCES EXPOSED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE LA VETA REGIONAL LIBRARY DISTRICT IN COLORADO WILL EXPAND THE WAYS IN WHICH IT ENGAGES WITH ISOLATED, RURAL MOUNTAIN COMMUNITIES AS THEY EMERGE FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC WITH DEMOGRAPHIC SHIFTS AND CHANGING NEEDS, BROUGHT ABOUT BY FAR-REACHING ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL CHANGES. THE LIBRARY WILL CREATE A COMMUNITY COORDINATOR POSITION TO BUILD AND STRENGTHEN ITS COMMUNITY AND INTERGOVERNMENTAL PARTNERSHIPS. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL HIRE A COMMUNITY NEEDS ANALYST TO DESIGN, DELIVER, AND ANALYZE A COMMUNITY NEEDS ASSESSMENT. THE LIBRARY WILL USE THE ASSESSMENT TO DESIGN PROGRAMS AND ALLOCATE RESOURCES TO BEST SERVE PATRONS AND SUPPORT THEIR POST-PANDEMIC RECOVERY.

WOODLAND PARK ZOO WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A PAID INTERNSHIP PROGRAM WITH THE CITY OF SEATTLE TO HOST INTERNS PARTICIPATING IN SEATTLE PROMISE, A PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES PUBLIC SCHOOL GRADUATES UP TO TWO YEARS OF FREE TUITION AT ONE OF THREE SEATTLE COMMUNITY COLLEGE CAMPUSES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN PAID WORK EXPERIENCE FOR YOUTH WHO HAVE BEEN DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED BY UNEMPLOYMENT DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC; LIKEWISE, IT WILL STRENGTHEN THE ZOO'S CAPACITY TO DELIVER A PAID INTERNSHIP PROGRAM INTO THE FUTURE. THE PILOT PROJECT WILL PROVIDE EIGHT SEATTLE PROMISE STUDENTS WITH AN 8-WEEK PAID INTERNSHIP EXPERIENCE. THE ZOO WILL PROVIDE TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO ITS STAFF TO PREPARE MEANINGFUL INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES AND EVALUATE AND ADAPT THE PROGRAM OVER TIME.

THE FEIRO MARINE LIFE CENTER WILL IMPLEMENT THE EXPANDING ACCESS THROUGH DIGITAL LEARNING PROJECT TO INCREASE CAPACITY TO CONDUCT HYBRID ONLINE/IN-PERSON PROGRAMS CREATED USING UNIVERSAL DESIGN PRINCIPLES. THE RESULTING LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES WILL BE ACCESSIBLE TO A WIDE VARIETY OF CLALLAM COUNTY RESIDENTS, INCLUDING THOSE WITH DISABILITIES, CONTRIBUTING TO IMPROVEMENTS IN QUALITY OF LIFE, EDUCATIONAL ATTAINMENT, AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP OUTCOMES. THESE PROGRAMS ADDRESS THE NEED FOR MORE ACCESSIBLE PROGRAMMING THAT WAS DISCOVERED DURING THE SHIFT TO DIGITAL ENGAGEMENT DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

LONG ISLAND CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN NEW YORK WILL EXPAND ITS WESTBURY STEM PARTNERSHIP, A SCHOOL-MUSEUM TEACHING COLLABORATION WITH WESTBURY SCHOOL DISTRICT THAT SERVES FIRST AND SECOND GRADE STUDENTS, TO INCLUDE THIRD GRADE STUDENTS, THEIR TEACHERS, AND THEIR FAMILIES IN STEM LEARNING. THIS EXPANSION WILL MITIGATE THE SIGNIFICANT LEARNING LOSS THAT THESE STUDENTS EXPERIENCED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROGRAM ADDRESSES THE ONGOING NEED FOR HIGH-QUALITY STEM EDUCATION IN A SCHOOL DISTRICT THAT IS LARGELY LOW-INCOME AND NON-WHITE, WITH SIGNIFICANT NUMBERS OF IMMIGRANT STUDENTS. AMONG OTHER ACTIVITIES, THE PROGRAM WILL BUILD STUDENTS' STEM-RELATED SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE BY PROVIDING MULTIPLE OPPORTUNITIES TO ENGAGE IN INQUIRY-BASED ACTIVITIES USING PROBLEM-SOLVING AND CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS.

THE WIREGRASS MUSEUM OF ART IN DOTHAN, ALABAMA, WILL STRENGTHEN AND IMPROVE ITS COLLECTIONS RECORDS AND OBJECT MANAGEMENT. THEY PLAN TO CONDUCT A PHYSICAL INVENTORY OF THE COLLECTION'S APPROXIMATELY 1,100 ITEMS AND HIRE A COLLECTIONS MANAGER/REGISTRAR TO ENSURE THAT THE COLLECTION CAN BE MORE EXTENSIVELY USED TO RESPOND TO COMMUNITY NEEDS IN EDUCATION AND LIFELONG LEARNING. THIS WILL SUPPORT CONTINUED PRESERVATION OF THE OBJECTS AND INCREASE ACCESS TO THEM. THEY ALSO PLAN TO CREATE A PRIORITIZED LIST OF RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SHORT-TERM AND LONG-TERM COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT NEEDS, INCLUDING CONSERVATION NEEDS.

THE CYNTHIANA-HARRISON COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY WILL PARTNER WITH THE LOCAL CHAMBER OF COMMERCE TO CREATE A BUSINESS CENTER WITH ACCESS TO COMPUTERS, INTERNET, AND PRINTING AND FAXING SERVICES TO HELP THE SMALL BUSINESS COMMUNITY AND JOB SEEKERS. A RECENT STRATEGIC PLAN SURVEY IN THE COMMUNITY HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR BETTER ACCESS TO TECHNOLOGY, INTERNET, AND TRAINING. THE LIBRARY WILL ALSO DEVELOP TRAINING ON RESOURCES THAT WILL BE HELPFUL FOR SMALL BUSINESSES AND JOB SEEKERS. THE PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE LIBRARY TO DEVELOP SPACES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES TO CONDUCT THEIR WORK AS WELL AS PROVIDE MORE COMPUTERS AND HOTSPOTS FOR PATRONS TO CHECK OUT FOR USE AT HOME. THE PROJECT WILL HELP THE BUSINESS COMMUNITY RECOVER FROM THE ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE NATIONAL INDO-AMERICAN MUSEUM IN CHICAGO WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, A LEADERSHIP ROLE THAT THE MUSEUM HAD IDENTIFIED AS A NEED BEFORE ITS OPERATIONS WERE IMPACTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM IS DEDICATED TO PRESERVING AND SHARING THE DIVERSE HERITAGE, EXPERIENCES, AND CONTRIBUTIONS OF THE NEARLY FIVE MILLION AMERICAN INDIANS IN THE UNITED STATES AS AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE LARGER AMERICAN NARRATIVE. THE MUSEUM WILL REENGAGE IN AN ACTIVE SEARCH FOR AN INDIVIDUAL WITH THE EXPERIENCE AND QUALIFICATIONS TO TAKE ON ORGANIZATIONAL REOPENING PLANS AND ENSURE CONTINUANCE OF THE MUSEUM'S PRE-PANDEMIC GROWTH TRAJECTORY. THE NEW POSITION WILL BRIDGE THE DIGITAL ENGAGEMENTS THAT DEFINED THE MUSEUM'S WORK DURING COVID-19 WITH IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING THAT WAS PREVALENT PRE-PANDEMIC.

THE MORTON ARBORETUM IN LISLE, ILLINOIS, WILL LEVERAGE TWO OF ITS FLAGSHIP INITIATIVES-THE CHICAGO REGION TREES INITIATIVE AND ARBNET TO ADDRESS NEEDS EXACERBATED BY COVID-19 IN UNDERSERVED CHICAGO-AREA COMMUNITIES. THE PROJECT WILL BUILD RELATIONSHIPS WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF AND ACCESS TO URBAN TREES, WHICH ARE LINKED TO REDUCING THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF THE PANDEMIC. WORKING IN COLLABORATION WITH PARTNERS IN THE TARGETED COMMUNITIES, THE ARBORETUM WILL IDENTIFY LOCATIONS IN NEED OF NEW TREES; ORGANIZE TREE PLANTINGS; AND WORK TO ESTABLISH NEW AND ACCESSIBLE PUBLIC ARBORETA. THE ARBORETUM WILL HIRE A COMMUNITY OUTREACH ASSISTANT TO ENGAGE INDIVIDUALS IN PRIORITY COMMUNITIES, BUILD RELATIONSHIPS, SUPPORT TREE PLANTINGS, AND DEVELOP NEW OUTREACH RESOURCES FOR THE PROGRAM. COMMUNITIES WILL BENEFIT FROM A HEALTHY TREE CANOPY, WHICH REDUCES AIR POLLUTION AND HELPS IMPROVE MENTAL HEALTH.

MAINE AUDUBON IN FALMOUTH, MAINE, WILL COLLABORATE WITH WABANAKI TRIBES, PORTLAND PUBLIC SCHOOLS, AND OTHERS TO EXTEND ENVIRONMENTAL/STEM EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES WHILE ENGAGING LEARNERS OF ALL AGES IN THE HISTORY AND CULTURE OF THE WABANAKI. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HIGHLIGHTED THE PERSISTENT, DISPROPORTIONATE VULNERABILITY AND SEEMING INVISIBILITY OF NATIVE COMMUNITIES. IN THIS PROGRAM, STUDENTS WILL LEARN THE HISTORY OF THE SIGNIFICANT AND NOW ENDANGERED ATLANTIC SALMON AS INDIGENOUS SCIENTISTS, LEADERS, AND ELDERS PRESENT THEIR DEEP KNOWLEDGE, CULTURAL PERSPECTIVES, AND TRADITIONAL WAYS OF SUSTAINING THE FISH VIA FILMED INTERVIEWS. HIGH-QUALITY FILM WILL MEMORIALIZE CONTEMPORARY WABANAKI VOICES AND SHOWCASE LANDS AND RIVERS THAT HAVE SUSTAINED MAINE'S NATIVE COMMUNITIES FOR MORE THAN 600 GENERATIONS. THIS PROGRAM HAS INTERTWINED GOALS OF RAISING AWARENESS OF MAINE'S ENDURING FIRST INHABITANTS AND THEIR TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE AND TEACHING ABOUT SALMON, FISH BIOLOGY, HABITATS, AND CONSERVATION.

THE OREGON MUSEUM OF SCIENCE AND INDUSTRY IN PORTLAND WILL INCREASE THE REACH, IMPACT, AND SUSTAINABILITY OF ITS DIGITAL PROGRAMMING. SUPPORTED BY THREE EXPERIENCED DIGITAL CONTENT CREATORS, MUSEUM STAFF WILL CREATE CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE, DIGITAL STEAM CONTENT THAT SUPPORTS UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES AND ALIGNS WITH COMMUNITY NEEDS. DIGITAL DELIVERY WAS AN ESSENTIAL TOOL DURING THE COVID-19 PUBLIC HEALTH CRISIS, ALLOWING THE MUSEUM TO TAKE CONTENT AND EDUCATION INTO THE COMMUNITY AND SUPPORT TEACHERS, LEARNERS, AND FAMILIES. THIS NEED FOR DIGITAL PROGRAMMING, WHILE PERHAPS NOT AS ACUTE AS AT THE HEIGHT OF THE PANDEMIC, WILL NOT GO AWAY ENTIRELY ANY TIME SOON. THE MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE TO DELIVER INNOVATIVE, EFFECTIVE DIGITAL CONTENT TO INCREASE ACCESS AND BROADEN PARTICIPATION IN ITS PROGRAMS.

THE MUSEUM OF THE ALEUTIANS IN UNALASKA, ALASKA, WILL CATALOGUE AND RE-HOUSE ARCHAEOLOGICAL MATERIALS AND INCLUDE THEM IN THE ALASKA DIGITAL ARCHIVES AND ON THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE. ITEMS TO BE CATALOGUED INCLUDE THE LAUGHLIN COLLECTION, WHICH INCLUDES CULTURAL MATERIAL FROM THE CHALUKA ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE EXCAVATED BY WILLIAM LAUGHLIN AND HIS STUDENTS FROM 1960-1976, AND THREE ADDITIONAL ARCHAEOLOGICAL ASSEMBLAGES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE AN ARCHAEOLOGIST TO WORK WITH STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS TO CATALOG AND RE-HOUSE THE MATERIALS. TO REENGAGE WITH VISITORS AND VOLUNTEERS FOLLOWING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE MUSEUM WILL HOST A LECTURE SERIES FOCUSED ON CAPTURING THE PUBLIC'S INTEREST IN ARCHAEOLOGY AND FOSTERING A SENSE OF STEWARDSHIP REGARDING CULTURAL RESOURCES.

HEARTLAND LIBRARY COOPERATIVE’S “OUTSTRETCHING HANDS” PROJECT IN SEBRING, FL, IS TO BRIDGE THE DIGITAL DIVIDE, ADDRESS ISSUES OF ACCESSIBILITY, AND PROVIDE SERVICES TO THE PATRONS RESIDING IN THE FIVE UNDER-SERVED SURROUNDING COUNTIES. HEARTLAND WILL PURCHASE EQUIPMENT NEEDED TO CREATE A MOBILE LIBRARY, WHICH WILL OVERCOME A RANGE OF BARRIERS ITS PATRONS FACE WHEN TRYING TO ACCESS LIBRARY SERVICES, SUCH AS DISTANCE AND FUEL COSTS. THE BOOKMOBILE WILL BE OUTFITTED WITH IPADS, NOTEBOOK COMPUTERS, INTERNET ACCESS, AND PRINTING CAPABILITIES, AND WILL GIVE PATRONS THE ABILITY TO BORROW LIBRARY MATERIALS, APPLY FOR JOBS AND ASSISTANCE, UPDATE RÉSUMÉS, AND CATCH UP ON THE LOSS OF LEARNING RESULTING FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE MUSEUM OF SCIENCE AND INDUSTRY (MSI), CHICAGO WILL IMPLEMENT A TWO-PART COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROJECT TO BRING DYNAMIC SCIENCE CONTENT BEYOND THE MUSEUM AND INTO CHICAGO COMMUNITIES. BUILDING ON SUCCESSFUL LIVE, ONSITE PROGRAMMING, MSI WILL DEVELOP A NEW OFFSITE PROGRAM. THIS PROGRAM WILL BRING MSI'S GUEST EXPERIENCES TEAM TO SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY SPACES THROUGHOUT CHICAGO WITH FOUR TYPES OF INTERACTIVE EXPERIENCES: LEARNING LAB, SCHOOL ASSEMBLY, WHOLE-SCHOOL TAKEOVER, AND SCIENCE FAIR. IN SUMMER 2022, MSI WILL PARTNER WITH COMMUNITY SERVING ORGANIZATIONS TO DISTRIBUTE SUMMER SCIENCE KITS THAT PROVIDE HANDS-ON LEARNING ACTIVITIES. MSI WILL PARTNER WITH CHICAGO PUBLIC LIBRARY, CHICAGO PARK DISTRICT, LOCAL SCHOOLS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS TO REACH ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL YOUTH ACROSS CHICAGO'S NEIGHBORHOODS. THESE PROGRAMS SEEK TO PROMOTE EDUCATIONAL GROWTH AND EMOTIONAL HEALING FROM THE IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE ORANGE COUNTY LIBRARY SYSTEM IN ORLANDO, FLORIDA, WILL BROADEN COMMUNITY ACCESS TO CULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS THROUGHOUT CENTRAL FLORIDA THAT SUFFERED LOSSES THROUGHOUT THE PANDEMIC. THE LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL PURCHASE PASSES TO EDUCATIONAL VENUES INCLUDING MUSEUMS, THEATERS, AND ZOOS AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE TO RESIDENTS FOR FREE THROUGH THE LIBRARY SYSTEM'S ONLINE EXPERIENTIAL LENDING PLATFORM. THE LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL PROMOTE THE PROGRAM AND PARTICIPATING VENUES TO FAMILIES IN UNDERSERVED AND AT-RISK COMMUNITIES THAT WERE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY THE ECONOMIC FALLOUT OF THE PANDEMIC. PROMOTIONAL EFFORTS WILL INCLUDE A SUSTAINED SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN, PRINT ADVERTISING, AND OUTREACH TO TITLE I SCHOOLS AND NEIGHBORHOOD ASSOCIATIONS.

THE SAN DIEGO COUNTY PUBLIC LAW LIBRARY WILL IMPLEMENT A PROGRAM ADDRESSING THE GAP IN ACCESS TO JUSTICE AMONG COUNTY RESIDENTS THAT NEED HELP WITH THEIR LEGAL PROBLEMS. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC EXACERBATED THIS ISSUE FOR MANY RESIDENTS OF THE COUNTY'S MOST ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED NEIGHBORHOODS, WITH DECREASED LEGAL SERVICES AVAILABLE JUST AS LEGAL PROBLEMS SAW AN UPTICK. AT PUBLIC LIBRARY BRANCHES IN TWO OF THOSE NEIGHBORHOODS, VISITING LAW LIBRARIANS WILL PROVIDE PATRONS WITH LEGAL RESEARCH HELP AND REFERRALS TO LEGAL SERVICES. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL PROVIDE ACCESS TO LEGAL RESEARCH DATABASES. IN ADDITION, THE LIBRARY WILL HIRE THREE PART-TIME REFERENCE LIBRARIANS TO ASSIST PATRONS WITH SPECIFIC LEGAL ISSUES.

THE PIKES PEAK LIBRARY DISTRICT WILL DEVELOP DIGITAL SKILL TRAINING TO MEET A CRITICAL NEED FOR ADULTS, AGES 18 AND OLDER, WHO LACK FOUNDATIONAL DIGITAL LITERACY SKILLS. THE PROJECT, DEVELOPED AS A RESULT OF RECENT COMMUNITY NEEDS ASSESSMENT FINDINGS, WILL HELP PATRONS DEVELOP DIGITAL SKILLS, BUILD CONFIDENCE USING TECHNOLOGY, AND FOSTER DIGITAL RESILIENCE THEREBY EQUIPPING INDIVIDUALS TO PARTICIPATE IN WORK, EDUCATION, AND CIVIC LIFE. THE TRAINING WILL INCLUDE 138 COMPUTER CLASSES AND 76 LEARNING LABS TO BUILD TRANSFERRABLE SKILLS IN ESSENTIAL AREAS AND PROMOTE CONFIDENCE AND RESILIENCE IN USING TECHNOLOGY. THE DIGITAL SKILL TRAINING PROJECT WILL SERVE COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHOSE NEED WAS FURTHER EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY.

THE ALEXANDRIA MUSEUM OF ART IN ALEXANDRIA, LOUISIANA, WILL DEVELOP A FREE ONLINE EDUCATOR'S VAULT ON THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE, EXTENDING ACCESS TO SERVICES INITIALLY DEVELOPED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. IN ONE LOCATION, EDUCATORS, PARENTS OF HOMESCHOOLED CHILDREN, AND OTHER APPROPRIATE PARTIES CAN ACCESS ART LESSONS AND ACTIVITIES, AN EDUCATIONAL VIDEO SERIES RELATING TO THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION, INTERVIEWS WITH ARTISTS, AND PREPARED LESSON PLANS WITH EDUCATIONAL, HISTORICAL, AND PRACTICAL INFORMATION ABOUT FEATURED WORKS OF ART, HELPING TEACHERS RE-ENGAGE WITH STUDENTS RETURNING TO IN-PERSON LEARNING. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL FACILITATE FOCUS GROUPS WITH LOCAL EDUCATORS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE AREA'S SPECIFIC NEEDS, WHICH ARE LIKELY TO HAVE BEEN AFFECTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC'S INTERRUPTION OF IN-PERSON INSTRUCTION. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL ALLOW EDUCATOR'S VAULT USERS TO CONTINUALLY GIVE FEEDBACK ON THE WORK BEING CREATED.

THE LINCOLN LIBRARY IN SPRINGFIELD, ILLINOIS, WILL EXPAND ITS COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT TO BETTER ASSIST THE PUBLIC IN CURRENTLY UNDERSERVED AREAS. THE LIBRARY WILL HIRE AN OUTREACH LIBRARIAN WHO WILL WORK WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO MAKE LIBRARY SERVICE MORE ACCESSIBLE IN THREE UNDERREPRESENTED NEIGHBORHOODS (BASED ON SOCIOECONOMIC DATA, RACIAL DIVERSITY, AND PROXIMITY TO THE MAIN LIBRARY). RESIDENTS OF THESE AREAS EXPERIENCED EXACERBATED DISPARITIES DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THEY NOW WILL HAVE REGULAR ACCESS TO BARRIER-FREE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND LIBRARY SERVICES. TO BETTER SERVE PATRONS, LIBRARY STAFF ALSO WILL RECEIVE ANTI-RACISM TRAINING AND TRAINING ON TRAUMA-INFORMED CARE.

THE MEMPHIS PUBLIC LIBRARIES (MPL) IN TENNESSEE WILL ENHANCE SERVICES FOR VULNERABLE POPULATIONS FACING TRANSPORTATION AND FINANCIAL BARRIERS, THE DISPARITIES OF WHICH WERE WIDENED WITH COVID-19. MPL WILL EXPAND OUTREACH PROGRAMS TO TRADITIONALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS THROUGH THE LIBRARY'S MOBILE TECHNOLOGY VAN, INCLUDING PROVIDING TECHNOLOGY CLASSES FOR MINORITY, FEMALE, LOW-INCOME, AND OTHER AT-RISK YOUTH POPULATIONS. MPL WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER AND TYPES OF PROGRAMS IT OFFERS TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR PATRONS OF ALL AGES AND MEET EVOLVING PATRON NEEDS. IN ADDITION, MPL WILL EXPAND ITS DIGITAL COLLECTIONS TO INCREASE ACCESS FOR PATRONS, WHO CONTINUE TO RELY HEAVILY ON VIRTUAL RESOURCES.

THE HIGH PLAINS LIBRARY DISTRICT (HLPD) WILL HIRE A CREATIVE TECHNOLOGIST AND PURCHASE SKILLS-BASED PROGRAMMING EQUIPMENT TO DEVELOP PROGRAMMING TO SUPPORT WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT. PROGRAMMING WILL TAKE PLACE AT HPLD'S LIBRARY INNOVATION CENTER WHICH WILL SERVE AS A COMMUNITY CATALYST FOR WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT, STEM EDUCATION, AND FUTURE INNOVATION. THE PROJECT WILL INTRODUCE PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS TO WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT SKILLS, PROVIDE ACCESS TO RESOURCES THAT WILL PREPARE PARTICIPANTS TO TAKE CERTIFICATION COURSES WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS, AND TRAIN STAFF IN WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT SKILLS TO INCREASE THEIR PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT. THE PROJECT WILL EMPOWER THE EMERGING WORKFORCE WITH THE TOOLS THEY NEED TO ENTER SKILLS-BASED JOBS THAT ARE RAPIDLY GROWING IN WELD COUNTY. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT COVID-19 RECOVERY AND THE ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY OF WELD COUNTY BY CREATING A SKILLED WORKFORCE.

AMAZEMENT SQUARE, A CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN LYNCHBURG, VIRGINIA, WILL PARTNER WITH LOCAL SCHOOL DIVISIONS AND HOSPITAL CENTRA HEALTH'S AUTISM AND DEVELOPMENTAL SERVICES TO FACILITATE A COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM ADDRESSING SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL AND ACADEMIC LEARNING LOSS FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC FOR CHILDREN WITH AUTISM AND OTHER AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS AND THEIR FAMILIES. THE PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE A COMMUNITY ADVISORY COMMITTEE, IN-CLASS CURRICULUM, EXCLUSIVE QUARTERLY MUSEUM EXPERIENCES, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR MUSEUM STAFF, AND PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE DIGITAL RESOURCES. THE PROGRAM WILL INCREASE THE UNDERSTANDING OF STEAM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ARTS, AND MATH) CONCEPTS AMONG PARTICIPATING CHILDREN, FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS AND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AMONG THE ADVISORY COMMITTEE, EXPAND MUSEUM STAFF KNOWLEDGE OF INCLUSIVITY AND AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER PROGRAMMING, AND HEIGHTEN AWARENESS OF THE MUSEUM'S ACCESSIBILITY RESOURCES.

SCIENCENTER IN ITHACA, NEW YORK, WILL CONDUCT A CAPACITY-BUILDING PROJECT TO IMPROVE THE MUSEUM'S DIGITAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND EXPAND COMMUNITY ACCESS TO PROGRAMMING. COVID-19 EXACERBATED TYPICAL PATTERNS OF LEARNING LOSS, AND THE SCIENCENTER WORKED WITH TEACHERS, LIBRARIES, AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS TO SUPPORT ONLINE LEARNING THROUGHOUT THE PANDEMIC. TO CONTINUE THIS MOMENTUM, THEY PLAN TO UPGRADE THE MUSEUM'S WI-FI CONNECTIVITY, INCREASING ACCESS AND RELIABILITY FOR VISITORS AND SUPPORTING THE DEVELOPMENT OF DIGITAL PROGRAMS FOR TARGET AUDIENCES. WORKING WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS, SCIENCENTER WILL CREATE INTERACTIVE STEM PROGRAMS THAT COMPLEMENT CLASSROOM LEARNING FOR STUDENTS IN GRADES PRE-K THROUGH 6. BY RELATING CONTENT TO STUDENTS' PERSONAL EXPERIENCES AND SURROUNDINGS, THEY WILL FOSTER HIGHER ENGAGEMENT IN ACTIVITIES AND HELP TO ADDRESS THE PANDEMIC'S IMPACT ON STEM LEARNING.

THE NEW ORLEANS MUSEUM OF ART WILL HIRE A DIGITAL ASSETS MANAGER TO PLAY A KEY ROLE IN THE MUSEUM'S ONGOING EFFORTS TO EXPAND PUBLIC ACCESS TO ITS LARGE PERMANENT COLLECTION VIA DIGITAL TOOLS AND RESOURCES. THESE EFFORTS WILL SUPPORT EDUCATORS, STUDENTS, AND OTHERS WHO HAVE BEEN DIRECTLY IMPACTED BY COVID-19. ONE PRIORITY FOR THE DIGITAL ASSETS MANAGER POSITION WILL BE TO SUBSTANTIALLY INCREASE THE NUMBER OF COLLECTION OBJECTS THAT ARE ACCESSIBLE ONLINE. DURING THE PANDEMIC, THE MUSEUM'S DIGITAL EFFORTS WERE REDIRECTED TO CREATING ONLINE PROGRAMMING. NOW, THE MUSEUM IS ONCE AGAIN ABLE TO SUPPORT ONGOING DIGITAL WORK IN THE UPCOMING YEAR. THE DIGITAL ASSETS MANAGER WILL BOTH RESOLVE THE MUSEUM'S BACKLOG OF PRE-PANDEMIC DIGITAL PROCESSING WORK AS WELL AS EXPAND THE AVAILABLE DIGITAL MATERIAL AND CONTENT RESULTING FROM THE PANDEMIC AND GOING FORWARD.

THE KENTUCKY MUSEUM OF ART AND CRAFT WILL INCREASE ITS ABILITY TO GENERATE REVENUE NEEDED FOR THE MUSEUM'S LONG-TERM STABILITY. SINCE THE ONSET OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE MUSEUM HAS REDUCED ITS STAFF BY 50 PERCENT, AND REVENUE HAS DECREASED DRAMATICALLY. THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE OR RE-INSTATE FOUR REVENUE-GENERATING POSITIONS IN ITS MARKETING AND COMMUNICATIONS, EDUCATION, SPECIAL EVENTS, AND VISITOR SERVICES DEPARTMENTS. THE NEW STAFF MEMBERS WILL IMPLEMENT EXPANSIVE MARKETING STRATEGIES, ADDITIONAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND PROGRAMS, SPECIAL EVENTS AND FACILITY RENTALS, AND MORE INTIMATE IN-PERSON VISITS. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL HELP THE MUSEUM TO CONTINUE ENRICHING LOUISVILLE'S ARTS AND CULTURE LANDSCAPE FOR YEARS TO COME.

THE RACINE ART MUSEUM (RAM) IN WISCONSIN WILL IMPLEMENT TWO TARGETED OUTREACH PROGRAMS FOR STUDENTS AND OLDER ADULTS. THE RAM ON THE ROAD PROGRAM DELIVERS FREE, HANDS-ON ART EXPERIENCES TO SCHOOLS VIA A COLORFULLY DECORATED VAN THAT TRANSPORTS INSTRUCTORS, ARTISTS, AND SUPPLIES TO BRING THE MUSEUM DIRECTLY TO K-12 CLASSROOMS. THE HANDS-ON ART PROJECTS ARE TIED TO THE MUSEUM'S EXHIBITIONS AND OFTEN USE MEDIA NOT TYPICALLY INCLUDED IN SCHOOL CURRICULA. THE MUSEUM'S SPARK PROGRAM PROVIDES CULTURAL ACTIVITIES FOR PEOPLE WITH MEMORY LOSS AND THEIR CAREGIVERS. SPARK ACTIVITIES ARE PRESENTED VIRTUALLY AND AT COMMUNITY CENTERS. THESE FREE OUTREACH PROGRAMS WILL ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN A CREATIVE AND POSITIVE WAY TO ALLOW THE COMMUNITY TO REGAIN COMFORT AND NORMALCY AFTER THE IMPACTS CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

NORTHAMPTON COUNTY HISTORICAL AND GENEALOGICAL SOCIETY IN EASTON, PENNSYLVANIA, ON BEHALF OF THE LEHIGH VALLEY PASSPORT TO HISTORY COMMITTEE, WILL COORDINATE AND PROMOTE K-12 LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES. THE SOCIETY WILL HELP THE MEMBERS OF THE COMMITTEE-COMPRISING 41 EDUCATION AND CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS IN PENNSYLVANIA BY WORKING WITH A WEB DEVELOPER TO DESIGN A NEW WEBPAGE FOR THE LEHIGH VALLEY PASSPORT TO HISTORY WEBSITE TO SERVE AS A PORTAL FOR TEACHERS SEEKING HISTORY-RELATED FIELD TRIPS, LESSON PLANS, INSTRUCTIONAL VIDEOS, AND RESOURCES. THE SOCIETY AND COMMITTEE WILL SUPPORT ITS REGION'S SCHOOLS AS EDUCATORS NAVIGATE THE 2021-2022 SCHOOL YEAR AND HELP THEM USE THE EDUCATION DISRUPTION CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AS AN OPPORTUNITY TO ENCOURAGE MORE SCHOOLS AND TEACHERS TO INCORPORATE REGIONAL HISTORY IN THEIR INSTRUCTIONAL PLANS.

PROVIDENCE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM WILL EXPAND A SUCCESSFUL PILOT COLLABORATION FIRST ESTABLISHED IN 2020 WITH THE RHODE ISLAND DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION TO ADVANCE ENGAGING, HANDS-ON, AND PERSONALIZED DIGITAL INCLUSION PROGRAMS FOR CHILDREN K-3. THE MUSEUM IS PROVIDING TRAINING TO TEACHERS TO DEVELOP VIRTUAL OR IN-CLASS LESSON PLANS AND PROGRAMMING AND OFFERING A SERIES OF PLAY-BASED ONLINE ENRICHMENT COURSES. AS CHILDREN RETURN TO SCHOOL AND TEACHERS ADDRESS LEARNING LOSS RESULTING FROM SCHOOL CLOSURES AND REMOTE LEARNING DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THESE PROGRAMS WILL BENEFIT STUDENTS WHO HAVE NOT BEEN IN THE CLASSROOM ROUTINELY AND/OR NEED HIGHLY INTERACTIVE AND ENGAGING LESSONS AND EXPERIENCES FROM REMOTE ENRICHMENT, DISTANCE, OR IN-PERSON LEARNING.

BOSTON CHILDREN'S MUSEUM, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A COALITION OF BOSTON COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS, WILL DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK ACROSS EXHIBITS, DIGITAL APPLICATIONS, AND COMMUNITY-BASED PROGRAMS TO MAKE GOING TO THE MUSEUM A MORE ACCESSIBLE EXPERIENCE. THE PROJECT WILL PRIORITIZE EQUITY, DIVERSITY, AND INCLUSION, AS RESEARCH SHOWS THAT THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC EXACERBATED EXISTING INEQUITIES WITHIN THE U.S. EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM. THE MUSEUM AND ITS PARTNERS WILL USE AN UPCOMING STEAM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, ARTS, AND MATH) PROJECT AS A TEST CASE FOR THE NEW FRAMEWORK AND ACCESSIBILITY INITIATIVE. THROUGH THIS WORK, THE MUSEUM WILL BETTER SUPPORT UNDERSERVED CHILDREN AND FAMILIES IN THE GREATER BOSTON AREA.

IMAGINE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN EVERETT, WASHINGTON, WILL CONTINUE SPONSORING FREE AND REDUCED-ADMISSION PROGRAMS FOR FAMILIES. THE MUSEUM WILL RESUME MONTHLY FREE-OF-CHARGE FRIDAY NIGHTS TO HELP THE COMMUNITY RECONNECT AND RECOVER FROM THE PANDEMIC BY LEARNING TOGETHER THROUGH PLAY. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL EXPAND AND ENRICH ITS MONTHLY SENSORY MORNINGS, WHICH PROVIDE CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES A SAFE AND SUPPORTIVE PLACE TO PLAY AND LEARN. IN ADDITION, THE MUSEUM WILL PROVIDE FREE MEMBERSHIPS TO ENCOURAGE FOSTER CARE FAMILIES TO USE THE MUSEUM AS A PLACE TO STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS AND HELP CHILDREN HEAL.

PENNSYLVANIA ACADEMY OF THE FINE ARTS WILL UPGRADE ITS ONLINE SYSTEMS TO BETTER ENGAGE DIGITALLY WITH STUDENTS, EDUCATORS, AND THE PUBLIC; PROMOTE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTION OF MORE THAN 15,000 WORKS OF AMERICAN ART SPANNING FROM THE EIGHTEENTH CENTURY TO TODAY; AND BUILD UPON ITS 67 PERCENT GROWTH IN ONLINE USERS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. BECAUSE THE MUSEUM CAN SERVE A FAR GREATER PORTION OF SOCIETY THROUGH ITS DIGITAL COLLECTION THAN ITS PHYSICAL COLLECTION, IT IS COMMITTED TO CREATING AN EQUITABLE ENVIRONMENT WHERE IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL EXPERIENCES ARE GIVEN EQUAL WEIGHT. ALLOWING AUDIENCES TO HAVE HIGH-QUALITY EXPERIENCES WITH ART REGARDLESS OF THEIR ABILITY TO PHYSICALLY VISIT THE MUSEUM WILL HELP ACHIEVE THIS GOAL. MORE ROBUST AND STABLE ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION ONLINE IS KEY TO SUPPORTING THIS NEW HYBRID PROGRAMMING MODEL AND FOSTERING IN-DEPTH CONVERSATIONS ABOUT ART.

AS THE STATE LIBRARY AGENCY, ALABAMA PUBLIC LIBRARY SERVICE (APLS), WILL EXPAND AN EXISTING HOTSPOT LENDING PROGRAM TO RURAL COUNTIES MARKED BY HIGH POVERTY AND LOW HOUSEHOLD CONNECTIVITY. ACCORDING TO U.S. CENSUS DATA, ALABAMA LAGS BEHIND THE NATIONAL AVERAGE IN HOUSEHOLD BROADBAND CONNECTIVITY, WHICH IS ESPECIALLY TRUE IN POOR AND RURAL COUNTIES. COVID-19 UNDERSCORED THIS DIVIDE, AND THE PROJECT WILL WORK TO INCREASE RELIABLE INTERNET SERVICE IN BIBB, CHAMBERS, CHEROKEE, CHILTON, CLAY, COOSA, COVINGTON, FAYETTE, FRANKLIN, GENEVA, LAWRENCE, MARION, RANDOLPH, AND WINSTON COUNTIES. IN DOING SO, APLS SEEKS TO IMPROVE PATRON ACCESS TO NEEDED INFORMATION, AND EMPOWER LOCAL LIBRARIES TO PROACTIVELY MAINTAIN A LIFELINE TO ONLINE INFORMATION IN THE EVENT OF ADDITIONAL DISRUPTIONS.

PRINCE GEORGE'S COUNTY MEMORIAL LIBRARY SYSTEM IN LARGO, MARYLAND, WILL EXPAND ACCESS TO COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY AND THE INTERNET FOR PATRONS IN THIS ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITY, WHERE APPROXIMATELY 36 PERCENT OF THE COUNTY'S RESIDENTS DO NOT HAVE BROADBAND INTERNET ACCESS AT HOME. A DIGITAL EQUITY COORDINATOR WILL ADMINISTER A PROGRAM THROUGH WHICH LIBRARY CARDHOLDERS CAN CHECK OUT LAPTOPS CONTAINING INTERNET HOT SPOTS FOR HOME USE. LIBRARY STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAINING TO REMOTELY ASSIST PATRONS WITH THE DEVICES AND HELP THEM NAVIGATE JOB RESOURCES. THE PROGRAM IS BEING PILOTED AT THREE LOCATIONS AND WILL BE EXPANDED TO ALL 19 BRANCHES. IT RESPONDS TO COMMUNITY NEEDS THAT HAVE BEEN EXACERBATED BY COVID-19 BY GIVING PEOPLE ACCESS TO COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET AND HELPING THEM FIND EMPLOYMENT.

THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN MARITIME MUSEUM IN VERGENNES, VERMONT, WILL IMPLEMENT ITS BOAT-BUILDING AND ROWING PROGRAM IN THIS RURAL COMMUNITY. THE MUSEUM WILL PARTNER WITH SCHOOLS, STUDENTS, AND TEACHERS IN TO CONNECT STUDENTS AND ADULTS WITH THE RICH TRADITION OF BOAT BUILDING IN THE CHAMPLAIN VALLEY WHILE BUILDING TEAMWORK, SELF-CONFIDENCE, AND A SENSE OF COMMUNITY. THE MUSEUM WILL HOST 24 STUDENTS SEVERAL DAYS A WEEK (TWO STUDENT GROUPS WILL SPEND 3 HOURS A DAY) AT ITS BOAT SHOP TO BUILD A HISTORICAL REPLICA OF AN 18TH CENTURY WHALEBOAT. IN THE SPRING, AN AFTER-SCHOOL ROWING PROGRAM WILL UTILIZE THE BOATS TO ENGAGE STUDENTS OF ALL EXPERIENCE LEVELS IN A SERIES OF RACES. IN THE SUMMER AND EARLY FALL, THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL SPONSOR AN ADULT ROWING PROGRAM. THIS PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT THE REGION'S COVID-19 RECOVERY EFFORTS BY CREATING SHARED OPPORTUNITIES TO CONNECT WITH EACH OTHER, THE ENVIRONMENT, AND THE COMMUNITY THROUGH BOAT BUILDING AND ROWING.

THE ARKANSAS MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS WILL HIRE A DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT TO INCREASE THE MUSEUM'S CAPACITY TO DELIVER PROGRAMS AND SERVICES TO RESIDENTS OF, AND VISITORS TO, LITTLE ROCK AND CENTRAL ARKANSAS. THIS WORK WILL HELP THE MUSEUM SERVE AND RECONNECT WITH ITS COMMUNITY AS IT MAKES ITS WAY OUT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND A 3-YEAR PERIOD OF CONSTRUCTION AND LIMITED OFFERINGS. THE NEW STAFF MEMBER AND CORRESPONDING TEAM WILL LEAD EFFORTS TO PLAN, DEVELOP, AND IMPLEMENT FULLY FORMED EXPERIENTIAL ARTS EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND SERVICES FOR VISITORS; ENSURE CONTINUITY WITH ESTABLISHED PARTNERS AND CULTIVATE NEW ONES; AND ENSURE THE MUSEUM'S WORK AND ACTIVITIES ARE COMMUNITY-CENTERED AND GUIDED BY AN AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE COMMUNITY'S SHARED EXPERIENCES DURING THE PANDEMIC.

FOLEY PUBLIC LIBRARY IN ALABAMA WILL ADDRESS ITS COMMUNITY'S GROWING NEED FOR INTERNET ACCESS, REMOTE LEARNING RESOURCES, AND DIGITAL SERVICES BY DOUBLING THEIR CURRENT INVENTORY OF HOTSPOTS FOR LOAN AND OFFERING MORE E-BOOKS AND OTHER DIGITAL CONTENT. THE LIBRARY WEATHERED THE EARLY EFFECTS OF THE PANDEMIC THEN SERVED AS A COMMUNITY RECOVERY SITE FOLLOWING HURRICANE SALLY, WHICH MADE LANDFALL IN SEPTEMBER 2020 JUST MILES AWAY. WITH A HOTSPOT WAITING LIST OF OVER 50 PEOPLE, THE LIBRARY WILL PURCHASE AN ADDITIONAL 15 DEVICES TO HELP EXPAND INTERNET ACCESS TO MORE FAMILIES. TO SERVE THE RISING DEMAND FOR DIGITAL CONTENT, THE LIBRARY WILL ALSO INVEST IN E-BOOKS, AUDIOBOOKS, MOVIES, AND OTHER RESOURCES.

THE FARNSWORTH ART MUSEUM IN ROCKLAND, MAINE, WILL EXPAND ITS EDUCATIONAL, INTERPRETIVE, AND EXPERIENTIAL PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITIONS FOR LEARNERS OF ALL AGES. BASED ON EXPERIENCE GAINED DURING THE PANDEMIC WHEN TRADITIONAL PROGRAMS AND SERVICES WERE CURTAILED, THE MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE TO DEVELOP ONLINE PROGRAMMING AND VIRTUAL SERVICES. TO INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO PROGRAMMING, MUSEUM WILL UPGRADE ITS WI-FI CAPABILITIES AND CREATE ADDITIONAL COMPUTER AND TABLET STATIONS THROUGHOUT THE SEVEN BUILDINGS ON THE 3 1/2-ACRE CAMPUS, AS WELL AS IN ITS TWO HISTORIC PROPERTIES. THE MUSEUM WILL INSTALL A DEDICATED SERVER TO PROVIDE OPTIMUM ONLINE ACCESS TO DIGITAL IMAGES IN ITS COLLECTION. TO HELP STAFF CREATE HIGH-QUALITY DIGITAL CONTENT AND PROGRAMMING TO SERVE THE WIDEST AUDIENCES POSSIBLE, THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A DIGITAL MEDIA SPECIALIST.

THE BAKKEN IN MINNEAPOLIS WILL HOST A COVID-19 RESPONSE RACIAL EQUITY TRAINING PROGRAM FOR ITS STAFF TO IMPLEMENT RESEARCH-BASED EQUITY AND INCLUSION PRACTICES. THE MUSEUM BELIEVES THAT ITS STAFF MUST CONFRONT THEIR OWN INTERNAL BIASES AND INHERENT DISCRIMINATORY CULTURE TO BETTER ENGAGE WITH MINNESOTA'S AFRICAN AMERICAN, INDIGENOUS, AND LATINO COMMUNITIES, WHO HAVE BEEN DISPROPORTIONALLY AFFECTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. EVERY MEMBER OF THE BAKKEN WILL RECEIVE TOOLS TO ENGAGE THEIR MUSEUM WORK IN A MORE EQUITABLE, INCLUSIVE MANNER AND BETTER SERVE THEIR COMMUNITY.

THE THOMAS BRANIGAN MEMORIAL LIBRARY IN LAS CRUCES, NEW MEXICO, WILL IMPLEMENT A COMMUNITY ADULT LEARNING INITIATIVE. THE LIBRARY WILL PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE SUITE OF FREE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES, INCLUDING LANGUAGE COURSES, BASIC EDUCATION, AND CIVICS TEST SERVICES FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN LAS CRUCES AND DOA ANA COUNTY. TO BETTER SERVE SPANISH-SPEAKING PATRONS, THE LIBRARY WILL PROVIDE CONVERSATION COURSES FOR ITS STAFF. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL PARTNER WITH RURAL LIBRARIES IN SURROUNDING AREAS TO INCREASE ACCESS TO PROGRAMMING FOR FARMWORKER AND IMMIGRANT COMMUNITIES. FINALLY, THE LIBRARY WILL WORK WITH LOCAL NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO ENSURE UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS ARE AWARE OF THESE PROGRAMS. COVID-19 DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED THE PROJECT'S TARGET POPULATIONS THROUGH ADVERSE HEALTH IMPACTS, HIGHER UNEMPLOYMENT, AND GREATER NEED FOR BENEFITS AND RESOURCES, AND THE LIBRARY'S ACTIVITIES ARE DESIGNED TO ADDRESS THESE DISPARITIES.

THE DURHAM MUSEUM IN OMAHA, NEBRASKA, WILL ADD TWO PART-TIME FACILITATORS TO THE MUSEUM'S EDUCATION TEAM AND NECESSARY EQUIPMENT TO EXPAND AND ENHANCE ONLINE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING, IN PARTICULAR, THE MUSEUM'S VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS AND AWARD-WINNING MUSEUM LIVE! WEEKLY WEBCAST SERIES, DEVELOPED IN RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL RE-LAUNCH ITS FIELD TRIP PROGRAM WITH FREE ADMISSION AND TRANSPORTATION TO MAKE ITS CULTURAL OPPORTUNITIES ACCESSIBLE AND FINANCIALLY FEASIBLE FOR SCHOOLS AND FAMILIES. THESE TWO INITIATIVES WILL SERVE PRIMARILY A K-12 STUDENT AUDIENCE, WITH PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON ELEMENTARY SCHOOL-AGED STUDENTS, AND WILL COMPLEMENT STATE SOCIAL STUDIES EDUCATION STANDARDS. THESE PROGRAMS WILL GREATLY ENHANCE ACCESSIBILITY TO THE MUSEUM FOR DIVERSE AUDIENCES WITHIN THE OMAHA COMMUNITY WHILE SERVING RURAL COMMUNITIES IN GREATER NEBRASKA AND STUDENTS ACROSS THE COUNTRY.

THE CORITA ART CENTER (CAC) IN LOS ANGELES FORMED BY THE IMMACULATE HEART COMMUNITY IN 1997 TO PRESERVE THE ART AND UPHOLD THE LEGACY OF ARTIST, EDUCATOR, AND SOCIAL JUSTICE ADVOCATE CORITA KENT WILL EXPAND ITS OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF ONLINE RESOURCES, INCLUDING BILINGUAL WORKBOOKS IN SPANISH AND ENGLISH, ACTIVITY PACKETS, VIDEOS AND LIVESTREAMED WORKSHOPS AS WELL AS IN PERSON SOCIAL JUSTICE EVENTS VIA CAC'S MOBILE ART TRAILER FOR CHILDREN, YOUTH, FAMILIES, AND INDIVIDUALS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THIS PROGRAM SEEKS TO ADDRESS THREE MAIN ISSUES CAUSED AND EXACERBATED BY THE COIVD-19 PANDEMIC: THE EFFECTS OF SOCIAL ISOLATION ON MENTAL HEALTH, THE LOSS ARTIST LIVELIHOOD, AND THE ISSUE OF SOCIAL JUSTICE.

THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI'S SCHOOL OF INFORMATION SCIENCE AND LEARNING TECHNOLOGIES WILL CONDUCT A NEEDS ASSESSMENT AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCAN OF RURAL, URBAN, AND SUBURBAN PUBLIC LIBRARIES TO DOCUMENT THEIR RESPONSES TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE UNIVERSITY'S RESEARCH TEAM WILL CONSIDER LIBRARIES' RESPONSES TO THE PANDEMIC IN VARIOUS SOCIOECONOMIC CONTEXTS, AS WELL AS IDENTIFY STRENGTHS AND WEAKNESSES OF THOSE RESPONSES. THE ASSESSMENT WILL PROVIDE EVIDENCE-BASED INFORMATION TO SUPPORT PUBLIC LIBRARIES IN DEVELOPING PROGRAMMING AND SERVICES TO MEET THE HEALTH INFORMATION NEEDS OF THEIR USERS. THE RESEARCH TEAM ALSO WILL CREATE TRAINING AND INSTRUCTIONAL MATERIALS AND A WEBINAR TO STRENGTHEN PUBLIC LIBRARIANS' ABILITY TO CONTRIBUTE TO COMMUNITY HEALTH.

DELAWARE'S BRANDYWINE ZOO WILL HIRE A COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT LEADER TO COORDINATE INTERCONNECTED PROGRAMS FOCUSING ON DEVELOPING CONSERVATION AWARENESS AND ENGAGEMENT IN WILMINGTON'S DIVERSE COMMUNITIES, THE NEEDS OF WHICH WERE SPOTLIGHTED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE BOTH A CONSERVATION LEADERSHIP ACADEMY FOCUSED ON ENGAGING LOW-INCOME YOUTH IN ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY TOPICS AND CONSERVATION SERVICE PROJECTS AS WELL AS EARTH AGENTS, A PROGRAM THAT EMPOWERS AND PROVIDES RESOURCES TO UNDERSERVED FAMILIES TO BECOME LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION CHANGE AGENTS BY DEVELOPING COMMUNITY-BASED CONSERVATION PROJECTS. THE ZOO'S NEW COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT LEADER WILL CREATE OTHER OPPORTUNITIES FOR DIVERSE COMMUNITIES TO BECOME INVOLVED IN COMMUNITY SCIENCE PROJECTS IMPACTING THE ENVIRONMENT. THE ZOO WILL PAY FOR GUEST SPEAKERS; UNDERWRITE THE COST OF CONFERENCE ATTENDANCE; AND FACILITATE DIVERSITY, EQUITY, INCLUSION, AND SOCIAL JUSTICE INSTRUCTION AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR STAFF.

THE WEXNER CENTER FOR THE ARTS AT THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY IN COLUMBUS WILL EXPAND ITS FREE ARTS RESILIENCE PROGRAMS TO HELP INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND NEIGHBORHOODS EMERGE FROM THE PANDEMIC WITH A SENSE OF WELLBEING AND HUMAN CONNECTION. THE ARTS RESILIENCE PROGRAMS REDUCE SOCIAL ISOLATION, IMPROVE COGNITION, AND OFFER TECHNIQUES FOR COPING. DEVELOPED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH ARTISTS, SOCIAL WORKERS, MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS, MEDITATION PRACTITIONERS, AND OTHER ADVISORS, THE RESILIENCE PROGRAMS OFFER ART AS THE SUBJECT MATTER FOR GROUP DISCUSSION AND SELF-REFLECTION AND, IN TURN, SERVE AS A CATALYST FOR WELLNESS. A FULL-TIME DIRECTOR OF ART AND RESILIENCE WILL RAMP UP AND RE-ENERGIZE THIS SUITE OF PROGRAMS IN RESPONSE TO STRESSORS CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND SOCIAL UNREST CAUSED BY RACISM. PROGRAMS WILL SERVE THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND SPECIFIC GROUPS, SUCH AS MILITARY VETERANS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS EXPERIENCING ANXIETY.

MINNESOTA CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN ST. PAUL WILL REINVIGORATE ITS FAMILY LEARNING PROGRAMS, WHICH WERE ELIMINATED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE PROGRAMS WILL SUPPORT LOWER INCOME FAMILIES IN RAISING THRIVING CHILDREN BY PROVIDING FREE OR DISCOUNTED ADMISSION. THE MUSEUM WILL WORK WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND PUBLIC SCHOOLS TO ENSURE ACCESS FOR AS MANY FAMILIES AS POSSIBLE. PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE FREE FAMILY NIGHTS, WORKSHOPS TO SUPPORT PLAYFUL LEARNING, AND FREE PLAY KITS DISTRIBUTED THROUGH PARTNERS TO FAMILIES IN NEED. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL HIRE A NEW PARTNER ENGAGEMENT MANAGER TO DEVELOP AND DEEPEN COMMUNITY ALLIANCES AND REACH MORE PARENTS. BY REACTIVATING THESE PROGRAMS, THE MUSEUM WILL ENSURE ACCESS FOR LOWER-INCOME FAMILIES AND PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE ROLE OF PLAY IN CHILDREN'S GROWTH AND LEARNING AS WELL AS COMMUNITY RECOVERY AND HEALING.

THE KATONAH MUSEUM OF ART WILL EXPAND AND ENHANCE ITS IN-SCHOOL ARTIST RESIDENCY PROGRAM FOR STUDENTS GRADES 2-6 AT THOMAS CORNELL ACADEMY, A TITLE I ELEMENTARY SCHOOL IN YONKERS. THROUGH THIS 10-SESSION SEQUENTIAL PROGRAM, STUDENTS WILL BE GUIDED BY TEACHING ARTISTS AND A SCHOOL-BASED ARTS INSTRUCTOR TO CREATE POETRY, VISUAL ARTWORK, AND CHOREOGRAPHED MOVEMENT PIECES IN RESPONSE TO THE MUSEUM'S EXHIBITIONS, CULMINATING IN AN EVENT FOR FAMILIES FEATURING STUDENT PRESENTATIONS OF THEIR WORK. THIS PROGRAM SEEKS TO FILL THE GAP IN ACCESS TO ARTS ENRICHMENT ACTIVITIES, AN ISSUE EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE CLARA WHITE MISSION WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT TO POSITION THE EARTHA M. M. WHITE HISTORICAL MUSEUM TO IMPROVE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT AND RE-ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY WITH PUBLIC PROGRAMMING TO PRESERVE AND INTERPRET THE CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL EXPERIENCES OF AFRICAN AMERICANS IN NORTHEAST FLORIDA. THE MUSEUM HAS BEEN UNABLE TO OFFER PROGRAMMING OR SERVICES SINCE MARCH 2020, WHEN IT SHUT DOWN AND RELEASED ITS STAFF DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MISSION WILL COORDINATE THE HIRING OF A PART-TIME DIRECTOR AND ASSISTANT TO INITIATE AN INVENTORY OF ITS FURNITURE AND MEMORABILIA, INCLUDING ITEMS IN OFF-SITE STORAGE FACILITIES, AND AN UPDATE TO THE MUSEUM'S EXHIBITIONS. THE NEW STAFF WILL ALSO RECRUIT A DOCENT CORPS AND EXPAND PROGRAMMING. MUSEUM INFORMATION WILL BE UPDATED ON THE CLARA WHITE MISSION WEBSITE AND A DEDICATED WEBSITE FOR THE MUSEUM WILL BE DEVELOPED.

THE NORTH CAROLINA ARBORETUM SOCIETY IN ASHEVILLE WILL IMPLEMENT A NEW SOFTWARE SYSTEM TO IMPROVE THE ONLINE EXPERIENCE FOR MEMBERS, STUDENTS, AND VISITORS. IT PLANS TO INSTALL A USER-FRIENDLY SYSTEM TO ENHANCE CUSTOMERS' EXPERIENCES WITH SCHEDULING AND TRANSACTIONS AND PRIORITIZE FLEXIBILITY IN THE EVENT OF CANCELLATIONS AND REFUNDS, WHICH HAVE BEEN EXACERBATED BY THE PANDEMIC. THE ARBORETUM ALSO WILL HIRE A PROJECT MANAGER TO OVERSEE INSTALLATION AND OPERATION OF THE SYSTEM. ONLINE TRANSACTIONS HAVE BECOME INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT DURING THE PANDEMIC AND WILL CONTINUE TO HELP THE ARBORETUM CONNECT WITH THE COMMUNITY. AS RESTRICTIONS SUBSIDE, THERE IS INCREASING DEMAND TO VISIT THE ARBORETUM, AND THIS PROJECT WILL HELP FACILITATE THAT POSITIVE COMMUNITY EXPERIENCE WITH NATURE.

HIALEAH PUBLIC LIBRARY IN FLORIDA WILL COUNTERACT THE PANDEMIC'S EFFECTS ON ITS COMMUNITY BY OFFERING LAPTOP AND HOTSPOT LENDING ALONG WITH DIGITAL LITERACY PROGRAMS. THE CITY OF HIALEAH WAS DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY COVID-19 IN ITS NUMBER OF CORONAVIRUS CASES AND UNEMPLOYMENT RATE, WHICH HAVE INCREASED THE NEED FOR ESSENTIAL LIBRARY SERVICES AND RESOURCES. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, THE LIBRARY WILL OFFER WEEKLY PUBLIC WORKSHOPS AT FIVE LIBRARY BRANCHES THAT SERVE HIGH DENSITY, LOW INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS. THE TRAININGS AND LOANED MATERIALS WILL HELP RESIDENTS OF ALL AGES AND BACKGROUNDS STUDY AND WORK FROM HOME, GAIN NEW SKILLS TO REENTER THE WORKFORCE, FIND JOBS, GROW THEIR BUSINESSES, AND CONTRIBUTE TO HIALEAH'S ECONOMIC RECOVERY.

THE SCHOOL OF INFORMATION AT PRATT INSTITUTE WILL PARTNER WITH THREE NEW INSTITUTIONS, THE LESBIAN, GAY, BISEXUAL & TRANSGENDER COMMUNITY CENTER NATIONAL ARCHIVE; FRANKLIN FURNACE ARCHIVE, INC; AND THE LESBIAN HERSTORY ARCHIVES TO EXPAND ITS GRADUATE FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM FOR EMERGING LAM (LIBRARY, ARCHIVE, AND MUSEUM) PROFESSIONALS TO BETTER SERVE DIVERSE COMMUNITIES AND COLLECTIONS INCLUDING BIPOC AND LGBTQ+ COMMUNITIES IN NYC. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS DIVERSE COMMUNITIES AND COLLECTIONS, PROVIDES PAID INTERNSHIPS TO GRADUATE STUDENTS ACKNOWLEDGING THAT UNPAID INTERNSHIPS ARE A BARRIER TO DIVERSITY AND INCLUSION EFFORTS, AND BRINGS EMERGING LAM EXPERTISE TO COMMUNITIES HARD-HIT BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE PALO ALTO ART CENTER FOUNDATION IN CALIFORNIA WILL STRENGTHEN ITS CAPACITY TO ENGAGE AND SERVE INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WITH DISABILITIES OF ALL KINDS. INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES AND THEIR FAMILIES HAVE BEEN DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED BY THE EFFECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE FOUNDATION WILL PROVIDE A YEAR OF EXHIBITIONS INCLUDING THE ART OF DISABILITY CULTURE IN FALL 2021 AS WELL AS SCHOOL FIELD TRIPS, PARTNER EXHIBITION TOURS, PUBLIC PROGRAMS, EXHIBITION AND PUBLIC PROGRAM INTERPRETATION AND ACCESS FEATURES, NEW STAFFING POSITIONS TO SUPPORT ACCESSIBILITY, AND STAFF TRAINING. THROUGH YEARLONG ENHANCED INTERPRETIVE FEATURES IN ITS FREE-ADMISSION EXHIBITIONS, PUBLIC PROGRAMS, AND EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES, THE PROJECT WILL PRIMARILY SERVE INDIVIDUALS WITH VISUAL, HEARING, AND PHYSICAL DISABILITIES. AN ADVISORY BOARD INCLUDING REPRESENTATIVES FROM LOCAL DISABILITY-RELATED ORGANIZATIONS WILL GUIDE THE FOUNDATION, WITH AN EXTERNAL FIRM EVALUATING THE PROGRAM.

THE AMISTAD RESEARCH CENTER AT TULANE UNIVERSITY IN NEW ORLEANS WILL IMPLEMENT A NEW DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO INCREASE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS. THE CENTER SERVES A DIVERSE CONSTITUENCY OF ACADEMICS, STUDENTS, AND RESEARCHERS, PROVIDING CULTURALLY ENRICHED PROGRAMS AND INFORMATION ABOUT THE AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY AND OTHER ETHNIC COMMUNITIES IN THE UNITED STATES. THE NEED FOR ONLINE PROGRAMMING AND DIGITAL ACCESS HAS GROWN EXPONENTIALLY BECAUSE OF THE PANDEMIC. THE CENTER WILL UPGRADE ITS IN-HOUSE TECHNOLOGY TO FACILITATE RESEARCHERS' ACCESS AND BETTER MEET THEIR NEEDS. THE UPGRADED SYSTEM ALSO WILL ASSIST K-12 EDUCATORS WITH REMOTE LEARNING, MAKING COLLECTION ASSETS MORE WIDELY AVAILABLE FOR CLASSROOM USE.

THE INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY IN NEW YORK CITY WILL REINSTATE ITS LIBRARY-BASED PUBLIC PROGRAMS AT THE WILLIAM RANDOLPH HEARST LIBRARY AND CREATE HYBRID VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON PROGRAMS FOR INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE NOT YET READY OR ABLE TO ATTEND IN PERSON. VIRTUAL PROGRAMS WERE HIGHLY POPULAR DURING THE PANDEMIC AND WILL CONTINUE ALONGSIDE IN-PERSON PROGRAMMING THAT GETS FILMED. PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE BOOK EVENTS, FILM SCREENINGS, A COMMUNITY DAY, AND EXHIBITION-BASED ACTIVITIES. THE CENTER WILL HIRE A PART-TIME VIDEOGRAPHER/AUDIOVISUAL PRODUCER AND A PUBLIC PROGRAMS COORDINATOR TO SUPPORT THIS EXPANDED PROGRAMMING. THROUGH ITS NEW PROGRAMS, THE CENTER WILL CONTINUE DELIVERING ACCESSIBLE RESOURCES AND CONTENT TO MEET THE COMMUNITY'S NEEDS.

THE SEYMOUR LIBRARY PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE DIGITAL DIVIDE BY IMPLEMENTING A MOBILE CLASSROOM TO INCREASE DIGITAL LITERACY AND REDESIGNING THE WEBSITE FOR GREATER EASE-OF-USE, INCREASED ACCESSIBILITY, AND ENHANCED CONTENT BY THE COMMUNITY. DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE COMMUNITY'S NEED FOR TECHNOLOGY, ACCESS, AND DIGITAL SKILLS GREW EXPONENTIALLY AND THIS TRANSITION TO ONLINE SERVICES AND ACTIVITIES WILL CONTINUE EVEN AS THE CRISIS SUBSIDES. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN ACCESSIBLE AND EASY TO USE WEBSITE WITH A VARIETY OF NEW CONTENT INCLUDING STREAMED CLASSES FOR DIGITAL LITERACY AND ENHANCED SHARING OF LIBRARY AND COMMUNITY RESOURCES.

THE NATIONAL WWI MUSEUM AND MEMORIAL, IN KANSAS CITY, MISSOURI, WILL DEVELOP THE GLOBAL EDUCATION INITIATIVE: DIGITIZATION, A DIGITAL EDUCATION INITIATIVE USING PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIALS FROM ITS COLLECTION TO CREATE AND UPDATE CONTENT SUPPORTING ON-SITE AND ONLINE EXHIBITIONS FOR 2022 AND 2023. THIS CONTENT ALSO WILL BE AVAILABLE ON THE MUSEUM'S WEBSITE AND FEATURED WITHIN SUPPORTIVE INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL SCAN, DIGITIZE, AND CATALOGUE AT LEAST 150 OBJECT RECORDS EACH MONTH, WRITE TWO ARTICLES TO ACCOMPANY EACH EXHIBITION, AND PRESENT TWO ONLINE LEARNING RESOURCES THAT INCORPORATE DIGITIZED MATERIALS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE NATIONAL WWI MUSEUM AND MEMORIAL WILL INCREASE ITS CAPABILITIES AS A CENTER FOR LEARNING AND RESEARCH, INCLUDING ENGAGING NEW AND MORE DIVERSE GLOBAL AUDIENCES THROUGH EFFECTIVELY IMPLEMENTING DIGITAL TECHNOLOGY AND PRIMARY SOURCE INTERPRETATION WHILE HELPING THE INSTITUTION OVERCOME THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF CLOSURES DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE ARIZONA HISTORICAL SOCIETY WILL REOPEN ITS SANGUINETTI HOUSE MUSEUM AND GARDENS IN YUMA AND PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL ONSITE PROGRAMMING FOR K-12 STUDENTS. THE HISTORICAL HOME BRINGS TO LIFE THE DEVELOPMENT OF YUMA FROM 1890 TO 1950 THROUGH THE STORIES OF ITALIAN IMMIGRANT E. F. SANGUINETTI, HIS MEXICAN AMERICAN WIFE LILAH, AND THEIR CHILDREN. TO SUPPORT THE REOPENING OF THE SITE, THE SOCIETY WILL HIRE TWO AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT SPECIALISTS. THESE STAFF POSITIONS ARE REQUIRED TO REOPEN AND HAVE BEEN VACANT DUE TO REVENUE LOSSES INCURRED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. ONE POSITION WILL SUPPORT DAILY SITE OPERATIONS. THE OTHER WILL SUPPORT THE CREATION OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS, INCLUDING LESSON PLANS AND MUSEUM TOUR SCRIPTS FOR SCHOOL FIELD TRIPS.

VOLUSIA COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY IN DAYTONA BEACH, FLORIDA, WILL IMPLEMENT A PROGRAM TO SUPPORT MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS BY ENHANCING LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES IN STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH). LIBRARY STAFF WILL CREATE A TECHNOLOGY-BASED CURRICULUM TO BE DELIVERED THROUGH A MOBILE TECHNOLOGY LAB THAT WILL TRAVEL TO SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY CENTERS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY. THE PROGRAM WILL PRIORITIZE LOW-INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS WHERE THE CHILD POVERTY RATE IS GREATER THAN 30 PERCENT. THE MOBILE LAB ALSO WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS IN THOSE AREAS WITH ACCESS TO TABLETS AND INTERNET CONNECTIVITY THROUGH A HOT SPOT. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS COVID-19'S EFFECTS ON STUDENT LEARNING, WHERE EXISTING DIVIDES DEEPENED AND STEM EDUCATION EXPERIENCED DISRUPTION.

THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF TACOMA (CMT) WILL PARTNER WITH COUNTY AND LOCAL LIBRARIES, TRANSITIONAL HOUSING SHELTERS, HOUSING AUTHORITY, AND OTHER SOCIAL SERVICE PROVIDERS TO IMPLEMENT THE FREE PLAY TO LEARN PLUS (P2L+) PROGRAM. BUILDING ON TWO EXISTING SUCCESSFUL COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROGRAMS, PLAY TO LEARN PIERCE COUNTY AND CMT CARES, P2L+ WILL OFFER LIVE VIRTUAL CLASSES, PRERECORDED CLASSES, ACTIVITY KITS, FAMILY STEAM NIGHTS, RESOURCE GUIDES, AND EVENTUAL IN-PERSON CLASSES TO MEET FAMILIES' NEEDS IN ACCESSIBLE WAYS. P2L+ MITIGATES THE IMPACTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC INCLUDING A DECREASE IN PANDEMIC INDUCED SOCIAL ISOLATION FOR CHILDREN AND CAREGIVERS AND AN INCREASE IN PARTICIPANTS' ABILITIES TO EXPRESS COMPLEX EMOTIONS RELATED TO THE EFFECTS OF THE PANDEMIC.

THE CORDOVA PUBLIC LIBRARY IN CORDOVA, ALASKA, WILL SIGNIFICANTLY EXPAND ITS DIGITAL SERVICES FOR PATRONS IN THIS GEOGRAPHICALLY ISOLATED RURAL COMMUNITY. THE LIBRARY WILL HIRE A DIGITAL SERVICES LIBRARIAN TO HELP COMMUNITY MEMBERS NAVIGATE THE LIBRARY'S ONLINE OFFERINGS. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL CONDUCT WORKSHOPS ON BASIC DIGITAL LITERACY AND COMPUTER SKILLS, WHICH ARE BECOMING INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT AS THE COUNTRY EMERGES FROM THE PANDEMIC. THE LIBRARY WILL ORGANIZE SERVICES TO HELP COMMUNITY MEMBERS SET UP TABLETS AND LAPTOPS; WORKSHOPS TO HELP ELDERLY PATRONS ACCESS AND COMPLETE SOCIAL SECURITY AND MEDICAID FORMS ONLINE; AND HOMEWORK HOURS TO SUPPORT STUDENT LEARNING.

THE HARRISON COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY IN MARSHALL, TEXAS, WILL CATALOGUE AND PLACE ONLINE FOR PUBLIC ACCESS TWO SPECIAL COLLECTIONS OF CULTURAL HERITAGE MATERIAL RECEIVED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE BISHOP COLLEGE SPECIAL COLLECTION INCLUDES APPROXIMATELY 600 ORIGINAL DOCUMENTS DATING FROM 1889 TO 1918, A PERIOD WHEN THE COLLEGE PROVIDED HIGHER EDUCATION FOR AFRICAN AMERICANS. THE STARR LAND ABSTRACT PLANT SPECIAL COLLECTION IS MADE UP OF ORIGINAL PROPERTY ABSTRACTS RECORDING HEADRIGHT OWNERSHIP OF LAND AND SUBSEQUENT OWNERSHIP EVENTS BETWEEN 1836 AND 1916. THE SOCIETY WILL HIRE A DIGITAL ARCHIVIST TO PROCESS THE SPECIAL COLLECTIONS AND PURCHASE EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT DIGITIZATION OF THE COLLECTION IMAGES, ALL OF WHICH WILL BE CATALOGUED IN AN ONLINE DATABASE, RESULTING IN IMPROVED ONLINE SERVICES THAT RESPOND TO THE COMMUNITY'S NEED FOR ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS.

THE SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM IN NEW YORK CITY WILL REVITALIZE AND EXPAND ITS EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND RESTORE ACTIVITIES THAT WERE CANCELLED DURING THE PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM'S CORE PROGRAMMING, WHICH WILL SAFELY REOPEN INDOORS IN STAGES, WILL INCLUDE SCHOOL-AGE EDUCATION PROGRAMS, LETTERPRESS PRINTING WORKSHOPS, AND PUBLIC EXHIBITIONS. ALL PROGRAMS, INCLUDING VIRTUAL OFFERINGS PILOTED DURING THE PANDEMIC, WILL ENGAGE PARTICIPANTS TO MAKE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THEIR OWN LIVES AND THE HISTORICAL DEVELOPMENT OF THE SEAPORT. TO INCREASE ACCESS FOR BROADER AUDIENCES, THE MUSEUM WILL MAKE ITS COLLECTIONS AND ARCHIVES AVAILABLE ONLINE. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL CONTINUE TO MAINTAIN AND PRESERVE ITS FLEET OF HISTORICAL SHIPS IN ACCORDANCE WITH HISTORICAL VESSEL PRESERVATION STANDARDS.

THE BALDWIN COUNTY LIBRARY COOPERATIVE, INC. (BCLC) WILL IMPLEMENT A WI-FI HOTSPOT LENDING PROGRAM THROUGH ALL 14 LIBRARIES AS WELL AS A BOOKMOBILE TO SERVE BALDWIN COUNTY, ALABAMA. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS BROUGHT TO LIGHT THE DIGITAL INEQUALITIES ACROSS THE COUNTRY AND IN OUR COUNTY IN PARTICULAR. WITH MANY SERVICES NOW BEING OFFERED ONLINE, THOSE WITHOUT HOME INTERNET SERVICES ARE BEING LEFT BEHIND; THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THIS NEED FOR RELIABLE ACCESS TO BROADBAND INTERNET. MORE SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL ADVANCE DIGITAL INCLUSION IN THE REGION BY IMPROVING DIGITAL PLATFORMS, ONLINE SERVICES, DIGITAL LITERACY PROGRAMS, AND CREATING NEW PROCESSES AND PROCEDURES TO SUSTAIN A ROBUST ONLINE ENVIRONMENT.

ORLANDO SCIENCE CENTER IN FLORIDA WILL PARTNER WITH ORANGE COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS TO PROVIDE SCHOOL FIELD TRIPS FOCUSED ON STEM AND ENGINEERING DESIGN FOR K-5 STUDENTS. THE MUSEUM WILL RECRUIT AT LEAST 120 CLASSROOMS, WITH A FOCUS ON TITLE I SCHOOLS AND THOSE WHO ARE UNDERREPRESENTED AND UNDERSERVED AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THEY WILL ENGAGE APPROXIMATELY 3,000 STUDENTS AND THEIR TEACHERS IN SPARKING LIFELONG STEM LEARNING, CULTIVATING STEM AND 21ST CENTURY SKILLS (COLLABORATION AND CRITICAL THINKING), AND PROVIDING AWARENESS OF A PATH TO FURTHER STEM EDUCATION AND CAREERS, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO GREATER COMMUNITY PROSPERITY BY PREPARING CENTRAL FLORIDA'S FUTURE STEM WORKFORCE.

THE AMERICAN CRAFT COUNCIL LIBRARY IN MINNEAPOLIS WILL INCREASE ITS ABILITY TO SUPPORT PATRONS BOTH IN PERSON AND ONLINE. THE LIBRARY'S COLLECTION IS THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE IN THE NATION ON CONTEMPORARY AMERICAN CRAFT FROM WORLD WAR II TO THE PRESENT. ALTHOUGH THE LIBRARY CLOSED AND HAD TO CANCEL ITS EVENTS DURING THE HEIGHT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, IT SAW A DRAMATIC INCREASE IN REQUESTS FOR REFERENCE SERVICES DURING THAT TIME. WHILE SOME RESOURCES ARE FREELY AVAILABLE ON THE LIBRARY'S WEBSITE, MANY MATERIALS ARE NOT AVAILABLE DIGITALLY. PATRON REQUESTS FOR THOSE MATERIALS STILL REQUIRE A LIBRARIAN TO SEARCH WITHIN THE PHYSICAL ARCHIVES. THE LIBRARY WILL HIRE A PART-TIME ASSISTANT LIBRARIAN TO SUPPORT PATRON REQUESTS AND AID WITH THE LIBRARY'S FURTHER DIGITIZATION EFFORTS.

CENTRAL WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY LIBRARIES IN ELLENSBURG WILL SPONSOR A SERIES OF MULTIFACETED EVENTS TO PROVIDE THE CAMPUS AND WIDER COMMUNITY WITH STRATEGIES AND TOOLS TO MOVE FORWARD IN PRODUCTIVE, POSITIVE WAYS FOLLOWING THE MENTAL HEALTH STRESS CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. ACTIVITIES WILL BE FREE OF CHARGE AND DESIGNED FOR A RANGE OF AGE GROUPS. WORKING WITH CAMPUS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS, THE LIBRARIES WILL OFFER FIVE MONTHLY INTERACTIVE HEALTH ADVOCACY PROGRAMS THAT ADDRESS COPING SKILLS IN TIMES OF STRESS. PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE A PANEL DISCUSSION ON PROCESSING TRAUMATIC EVENTS, A CREATIVE WRITING WORKSHOP, AND A FAMILY WORKSHOP ON GROWING WITH CHANGE. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE COMMUNITY MEMBERS WITH FORUMS TO COME TOGETHER TO DISCUSS THE PSYCHOSOCIAL IMPACTS OF COVID-19.

THE MISSOURI HISTORICAL SOCIETY IN SAINT LOUIS WILL INVENTORY AND INCREASE ONLINE ACCESS TO ITS PHOTOGRAPHS AND PRINTS COLLECTION. IT WILL HIRE AN INVENTORY SPECIALIST TO PROCESS THE COLLECTION'S NEW OR PREVIOUSLY UNPUBLISHED DIGITAL IMAGES AND BACKLOGGED DONATIONS, THEN POST THE IMAGES ONLINE AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE FOR FREE DOWNLOAD. THE PANDEMIC MADE CLEAR HOW VITAL PROVIDING SUCH DIGITAL ACCESS IS IN SERVING LOCAL, STATE, AND EVEN WORLDWIDE AUDIENCES, AND THIS PROJECT WILL DRAMATICALLY INCREASE THE NUMBER OF DIGITIZED IMAGES AND SEARCHABLE COLLECTION-LEVEL DESCRIPTIONS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC.

ECHO, LEAHY CENTER FOR LAKE CHAMPLAIN IN BURLINGTON, VERMONT, WILL ESTABLISH PROGRAMS TO HELP BURLINGTON HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, WHOSE SCHOOL WAS CLOSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND THEN CLOSED AGAIN FOR A MULTI-YEAR BUILDING RENOVATION. THE MUSEUM WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE SCHOOL TO ESTABLISH THE BURLINGTON HIGH SCHOOL SPECIAL ACCESS PROGRAM TO SUPPORT REPEAT VISITATION AND PROJECT-BASED LEARNING. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL DEVELOP THE BURLINGTON HIGH SCHOOL DEVELOPMENT INSTITUTE MUSEUM PARTNERSHIP TRACK AND SERVE AS A BREAKOUT SPACE FOR TEACHERS TO PLAN LESSONS THAT INTEGRATE MUSEUM RESOURCES IN COLLABORATION WITH MUSEUM EDUCATORS. FURTHER, THE MUSEUM WILL ESTABLISH THE HIGH SCHOOL FIELD TRIP ACTIVITY AND EXTENSION LIBRARY BY PAYING TEACHERS TO REUSE THEIR MUSEUM-INTEGRATED LESSONS PLANS. THESE PRODUCTS WILL FORM THE BASIS OF A FIELD TRIP AND EXTENSION LIBRARY THAT OTHER HIGH SCHOOLS VISITING THE MUSEUM CAN USE.

THE AMERICAN WRITERS MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP AN ON-SITE AND ONLINE EXHIBIT AND RELATED PROGRAMS FOR STUDENTS. THE EXHIBIT, DARK TESTAMENT: BLACK WRITERS ON RACIAL JUSTICE, PAST AND PRESENT, WILL FOCUS ON AMERICAN HISTORY FROM THE END OF THE CIVIL WAR TO THE END OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS ERA, AND WILL FEATURE CONVERSATIONS WITH LEADING BLACK CONTEMPORARY WRITERS ABOUT WRITERS OF THE PAST WHO INSPIRE THEM. THE MUSEUM WILL DEVELOP RELATED CURRICULA AND ACTIVITIES FOR MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WHOSE TEACHERS CAN USE THE ONLINE RESOURCES TO SUPPLEMENT CLASSROOM INSTRUCTION. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL IMPLEMENT A TARGETED MARKETING STRATEGY TO PROMOTE THE EXHIBIT TO SCHOOLS NATIONWIDE, ESPECIALLY IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES TWO CHALLENGES EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE NEED FOR CONTINUED EXAMINATION OF RACIAL INJUSTICE AND THE NEED FOR ENGAGING ONLINE RESOURCES FOR MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THAT COMPLIMENT CLASSROOM CURRICULA AND ENCOURAGE MEANINGFUL DIALOGUE.

THE WOODLANDS CHILDREN'S MUSEUM NEAR HOUSTON, TEXAS, WILL PROVIDE NO-COST FIELD TRIPS TO PRE-K AND KINDERGARTEN STUDENTS IN 20 ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS. THESE FIELD TRIPS WILL ADDRESS THE LACK OF ACCESS TO OUT-OF-SCHOOL LEARNING FOR CHILDREN IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS LEARNING LOSS EXPERIENCED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. EXHIBITS AT THE MUSEUM ARE DESIGNED TO FOSTER CREATIVITY, IMAGINATION, CRITICAL THINKING, SOCIAL SKILLS, COOPERATION, ROLE PLAYING, SPATIAL REASONING, MOTOR MOVEMENT, AND OTHER IMPORTANT SKILLS FOR EARLY LEARNERS. WHILE AT THE MUSEUM, STUDENTS ALSO WILL PARTICIPATE IN AN ART PROJECT THAT IS CURATED FOR EACH SPECIFIC CLASS IN COORDINATION WITH THE TEACHERS AND CLASSROOM OBJECTIVES. THE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE TRANSPORTATION TO AND FROM THE MUSEUM TO REMOVE POTENTIAL FUNDING BARRIERS.

CASEY COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY IN LIBERTY, KENTUCKY, WILL IMPLEMENT A HOLISTIC SUITE OF PROGRAMS AND SERVICES TO HELP CLOSE THE DIGITAL DIVIDE FOR PATRONS OF ALL AGES AND ADDRESS POST-COVID EMPLOYMENT. THE LIBRARY WILL INTEGRATE TECHNOLOGY MORE SEAMLESSLY INTO ONGOING PROGRAMS FOR ADULTS AND ORGANIZE WORKSHOPS TO HELP PATRONS NAVIGATE TECHNOLOGY IN DAILY LIFE. PROGRAMS FOR YOUNGER PATRONS WILL EXPOSE THEM TO CODING AND TECHNOLOGY IN NEW AND EXCITING WAYS AND ENCOURAGE ARTISTIC, CREATIVE, AND LOGICAL THINKING, TEAMWORK, AND INNOVATION. THE PROGRAMS WILL PROVIDE PATRONS WITH THE FAMILIARITY AND EXPERIENCE THEY NEED TO THRIVE IN A WORLD WHERE TECHNOLOGY IS INCREASINGLY A PART OF DAILY LIFE.

THE IRISH AMERICAN HERITAGE MUSEUM IN ALBANY, NEW YORK, WILL EXPAND ITS PROGRAMMING, REINVEST IN ITS COLLECTION, AND STRENGTHEN ITS STAFF TO PRESERVE AND TELL THE STORY OF THE CONTRIBUTIONS OF THE IRISH PEOPLE AND THEIR CULTURE IN AMERICA. SHORTLY AFTER RELOCATING IN EARLY 2020, THE MUSEUM CLOSED DUE TO THE PANDEMIC, BUT IT BUILT A SIGNIFICANT ONLINE FOLLOWING DURING THAT TIME AND WILL CONTINUE TO PRIORITIZE ADDITIONAL DIGITAL OFFERINGS. THE MUSEUM WILL BUILD NEW CONNECTIONS IN THE COMMUNITY THROUGH DIVERSE PUBLIC PROGRAMMING. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME CONTENT AND ENGAGEMENT MANAGER, WHO WILL DEVELOP NEW EXHIBITIONS AND PROGRAMS. STORAGE OF AND CARE FOR THE MUSEUM'S PERMANENT COLLECTION WILL BE IMPROVED, WHICH WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO INCREASE THE ROTATION OF OBJECTS ON DISPLAY AND CREATE DIVERSE TEMPORARY EXHIBITIONS.

THE BOSTON PUBLIC LIBRARY WILL EXPAND ITS ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE (ESL) PROGRAMMING TO ALL OF ITS 26 LIBRARY LOCATIONS ACROSS THE CITY. THE PROJECT WILL RESPOND TO THE RISING DEMAND FOR ESL PROGRAMS, WHICH HAS BEEN HEIGHTENED BY THE PANDEMIC AND ULTIMATELY HELPS INDIVIDUALS PARTICIPATE MORE FULLY IN THE WORKFORCE AND ECONOMY. THE LIBRARIES WILL OFFER BEGINNER, INTERMEDIATE, AND ADVANCED ENGLISH-LANGUAGE CLASSES, AS WELL AS TEST PREPARATION CLASSES FOR GENERAL EDUCATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (GED) AND TEST OF ENGLISH AS A FOREIGN LANGUAGE (TOEFL) EXAMS. THE LIBRARIES ALSO WILL PROVIDE SMALL GROUP TUTORING AND VOLUNTEER-LED CONVERSATION GROUPS. THE LIBRARY FUND WILL HIRE AN ADDITIONAL LITERACY INSTRUCTOR AND VOLUNTEER COORDINATOR TO MANAGE AND IMPLEMENT THE EXPANDED PROGRAMMING. THE LIBRARY FUND ALSO WILL IMPLEMENT A ROBUST MARKETING AND COMMUNICATIONS CAMPAIGN IN MULTIPLE LANGUAGES TO PROMOTE THE NEW PROGRAMS.

THE ADIRONDACK EXPERIENCE (ADKX) IN NEW YORK WILL PARTNER WITH THE ADIRONDACK DIVERSITY INITIATIVE, AKWESASNE CULTURAL CENTER, MOUNTAIN LAKE PBS, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY'S ADIRONDACK CHAPTER, AND THE WILD CENTER TO FACILITATE A SERIES OF FREE VIRTUAL PUBLIC PROGRAMS THROUGHOUT 2022 THAT REEXAMINE THE HISTORY OF ADIRONDACK PARK THROUGH THE LENS OF ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE, ESPECIALLY REGIONAL INEQUITIES ESTABLISHED BY POLICIES TO MANAGE LAND AND WATER ACCESS, AS WELL AS CONSERVATION PRINCIPLES. THE COLLABORATIVE WILL FACILITATE A SERIES OF LIVESTREAMED DISCUSSIONS AS A LAUNCHING POINT FOR PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT AND HOST A SYMPOSIUM TO CONVENE INDIGENOUS AND NON-INDIGENOUS HISTORIANS, EDUCATORS, STORYTELLERS, AND SOCIAL SCIENTISTS TO DISCUSS THESE ISSUES. ADKX SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE COMBINED IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND SOCIAL INJUSTICE PROTESTS ON THE REGION THROUGH THESE VIRTUAL PROGRAMS.

THE ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE (AAH) IN STATEN ISLAND, NEW YORK, WILL IMPLEMENT THE EXPANDED DIGITAL ACCESS PROJECT DEVELOPING THREE 3-D VIRTUAL TOURS, ONLINE ARTIST TALKS, AND EXHIBITION CATALOGUES FOR LEARNERS OF ALL AGES TO EXPAND THE MUSEUM'S AUDIENCE GEOGRAPHICALLY, CULTURALLY, AND SOCIOECONOMICALLY. THE VIRTUAL TOURS, TALKS, AND CATALOGUES WILL INCORPORATE THE WORK OF THREE WOMEN, BIPOC, LGBTQ+ ARTISTS WHOSE WORK EXPOSES SOCIETAL INEQUITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL PROMOTE COMMUNITY HEALING FROM THE EFFECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC WHILE EXPANDING THE REACH OF IMPORTANT PHOTOGRAPHIC WORKS TO A NATIONAL AUDIENCE OF ALL AGES AND CREATE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR THE AAH AS WE AWAIT A FULL RESUMPTION OF OUR FINANCIAL SUPPORT THROUGH EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING AND IN-PERSON ATTENDANCE.

THE MASSACHUSETTS AUDUBON SOCIETY (MASS AUDUBON) WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT (PD) TRAINING PROGRAM FOR APPROXIMATELY 50 MASS AUDUBON EDUCATORS WORKING OUT OF 19 NATURE CENTERS AND AN ART MUSEUM TO DELIVER HIGH QUALITY, CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE, ENVIRONMENTAL-FOCUSED STEM AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAMS IN HIGH-NEED SCHOOL DISTRICTS. ONCE TRAINED, THESE EDUCATORS WILL WORK WITH SCHOOLS ACROSS MASSACHUSETTS DELIVERING APPROXIMATELY 54 DIFFERENT AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAM SERIES. THE RESULTING PROGRAMS PROVIDE OUTDOOR NATURE PROGRAMMING FACILITATED BY EDUCATORS WHO HAVE PARTICIPATED IN SPECIAL TRAINING TO HELP WITH THE SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL AND ACADEMIC RECOVERY FOR STUDENTS FROM COMMUNITIES MOST IMPACTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY LIBRARY WILL COLLECT, PRESERVE, MANAGE, AND INTERPRET DOCUMENTARY SOURCES REPRESENTING ALL ASPECTS OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC EXPERIENCE THROUGH A YEARLONG ORAL HISTORY PROJECT. THE LIBRARY'S OKLAHOMA ORAL HISTORY RESEARCH PROGRAM WILL CAPTURE IMPRESSIONS, RECOLLECTIONS, AND ANALYTICAL REFLECTIONS OF PEOPLE IMPACTED BY THE PANDEMIC THROUGH THEIR OFFICIAL EMPLOYMENT OR COMMUNITY ROLES, INCLUDING A DIVERSE REPRESENTATION OF OKLAHOMANS ACROSS RACIAL, ETHNIC, SOCIOECONOMIC, AND JOB-RELATED CATEGORIES. AN ONLINE PORTAL WILL SPOTLIGHT TWENTY-FIVE INTERVIEWS (APPROXIMATING FIFTY HOURS OF DIGITAL AUDIO AND VIDEO) AND TRANSCRIPTS. THESE EFFORTS WILL SUPPORT PANDEMIC RECOVERY AND GENERATE POSITIVE SOCIETAL IMPACT BY SPOTLIGHTING UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES' CONCERNS, HELPING GOVERNMENT LEADERS REFLECT ON THE IMPACTS OF THE RECENT PANDEMIC RESPONSE, BUILDING EMPATHY FOR INDIVIDUALS IN DIFFERENT SITUATIONS, AND GENERATING IMPORTANT PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIAL FOR FUTURE RESEARCHERS.

THE MEMORIAL ART GALLERY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER WILL EXPAND ITS FREE ARTS EDUCATION PROGRAMMING IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FIVE UNDER-RESOURCED ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS IN THE ROCHESTER CITY SCHOOL DISTRICT. STUDENTS WILL VISIT THE MUSEUM ONCE A WEEK OVER A 4-WEEK PERIOD TO ENGAGE IN A SERIES OF CURRICULUM-BASED, HANDS-ON, IN-GALLERY EXPERIENCES THAT REINFORCE CLASSROOM LEARNING. A MUSEUM EDUCATOR WILL LEAD DISCUSSIONS AND ACTIVITIES, AND THE STUDENTS WILL CREATE THEIR OWN ARTWORK UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF A TEACHING ARTIST. THESE PROGRAMS AIM TO HELP PARTICIPANTS HEAL FROM THE TRAUMA OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC WHILE DEVELOPING THE LANGUAGE, SKILLS, AND TOOLS THEY NEED TO UNDERSTAND, INTERPRET, AND DISCUSS ART.

THE OHR-O'KEEFE MUSEUM OF ART IN BILOXI, MISSISSIPPI, WILL HIRE A FULL-TIME DIRECTOR OF ARTS EDUCATION TO MANAGE SEVERAL PROJECTS TO HELP COMMUNITY REVITALIZATION AND INCREASE ARTS ACCESS FOR THEIR UNDERSERVED POPULATION, WITH A SPECIFIC FOCUS ON POSITIVELY ENGAGING LOCAL YOUTH. THE ABILITY TO RE-HIRE STAFF LOST DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC-RELATED FINANCIAL CRISIS WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO HOST EXHIBITIONS, PROGRAMMING, AND SERVICES THAT REENGAGE AUDIENCES AND INCREASE COMMUNITY WELLBEING. THE MUSEUM'S ARTS ENRICHMENT PROGRAM AND SUMMER ART CAMPS PROVIDE LOCAL YOUTH WITH ACCESS TO PROFESSIONAL ARTS INSTRUCTION AND STUDIO SPACE, AS WELL AS A MUCH-NEEDED SENSE OF COMMUNITY - BOTH OF WHICH ARE ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT AFTER A YEAR OF REMOTE LEARNING AND THE ISOLATION OF QUARANTINE.

CEDAR RAPIDS PUBLIC LIBRARY IN IOWA WILL EXPAND ITS INITIATIVES TO PROVIDE TECHNOLOGY ACCESS AND WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS IN LOW-INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS. THE LIBRARY WILL USE ITS NEW VAN, KNOWN AS THE MOBILE TECHNOLOGY LAB, TO PROVIDE PORTABLE LAPTOPS, PRINTERS, AND OTHER SERVICES AT PARKS AND COMMUNITY PARTNER LOCATIONS. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL SUPPORT COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN THEIR JOB SEARCHES BY PROVIDING ASSISTANCE WITH RESUME WRITING, CONVENING WORKSHOPS ON INTERVIEWING SKILLS TO HELP JOB SEEKERS SET THEMSELVES APART IN AN ONLINE ENVIRONMENT, AND GOING TO EMPLOYER-DRIVEN JOB FAIRS THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY TO HELP PEOPLE APPLY ON-SITE. THE FOCUS ON BUILDING SKILL SETS WILL HELP ADDRESS THE COMMUNITY'S UNEMPLOYMENT CHALLENGES AND WORKFORCE SHORTAGES THAT WERE EXACERBATED BY COVID-19.

THE LAKESHORES LIBRARY SYSTEM IN WATERFORD, WISCONSIN, WILL IMPROVE PATRON SERVICES BY ENHANCING THE ONLINE PRESENCE OF ITS MEMBER LIBRARIES TO HELP SHARE RELEVANT INFORMATION WITH THEIR COMMUNITIES. THE SYSTEM CURRENTLY INCLUDES 15 LIBRARIES IN WALWORTH AND RACINE COUNTIES, AND ALSO PROVIDES SERVICES TO THE WATERFORD UNION HIGH SCHOOL LIBRARY AND THE RACINE CORRECTIONAL INSTITUTION. AS LIBRARY SYSTEM STAFF RESPONDED TO THE FLURRY OF CHANGES IN RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THEY REALIZED THAT MANY MEMBER LIBRARIES DID NOT HAVE THE ABILITY TO MAINTAIN AN ONLINE PRESENCE. IN COLLABORATION WITH THE ARROWHEAD LIBRARY SYSTEM, THE LAKESHORES LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL SUPPORT MEMBER LIBRARIES IN UPDATING THEIR WEBSITES, MOBILE APPS, AND SOCIAL MEDIA.

MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY AND ITS PARTNERS (FORT WORTH ZOO, THE NORTH CAROLINA ZOO, AND OMAHA'S HENRY DOORLY ZOO AND AQUARIUM) WILL HIRE AND TRAIN STUDENTS FROM UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES TO TRANSITION INTO THE LEADERSHIP PIPELINE OF FUTURE PROFESSIONALS FOCUSED ON BIOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT. STUDENTS WILL RESEARCH AMPHIBIAN COLLECTIONS AT THE UNIVERSITY'S PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO LEARN ABOUT SUSTAINABLE REPRODUCTION, HUSBANDRY, AND GENETIC MANAGEMENT. THE TEAM WILL SHARE STUDY RESULTS THROUGH A HOST WEBSITE AND ACROSS DIGITAL MEDIA PLATFORMS. IN THE SHORT TERM, HIRING THESE INDIVIDUALS WILL HELP WITH THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC ECONOMIC RECOVERY. OVER THE LONG TERM, THE UNIVERSITY AND ITS PARTNERS WILL PROMOTE A MORE DIVERSE AND INCLUSIVE EMPLOYEE STRUCTURE. SUCCESS INDICATORS WILL INCLUDE NUMBERS OF GRADUATED AND HIRED TRAINEES, NEW DIGITAL PRODUCTS, AND A POSITIVE IMPACT ON THE COLLECTION'S GENETIC MANAGEMENT.

THE BALTIMORE MUSEUM OF ART WILL IMPLEMENT TWO PROGRAMS FOR STUDENTS: CLOSE ENCOUNTERS (A MULTI-VISIT PROGRAM IN PARTNERSHIP WITH BALTIMORE CITY PUBLIC SCHOOLS FOR FOURTH GRADE STUDENTS) AND LITERACY THROUGH THE ARTS (AN EARLY LEARNING PROGRAM FOR BALTIMORE COUNTY PRE-K THROUGH FIRST GRADE STUDENTS AND ADMINISTERED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE COUNTY). BOTH PROGRAMS, HISTORICALLY FACILITATED IN PERSON, WERE ADAPTED TO BE VIRTUAL DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND HAVE REACHED LARGER AUDIENCES THAN EVER BEFORE. GIVEN THE POSITIVE FEEDBACK FROM STUDENTS AND TEACHERS, THE MUSEUM HAS MADE IT A PRIORITY TO PROVIDE HYBRID VERSIONS OF BOTH PROGRAMS AS THE MUSEUM AND SCHOOLS RECOVER FROM THE PANDEMIC.

THE NEW MEXICO MUSEUM OF ART WILL CREATE A DIGITAL PLATFORM ENCOURAGING EDUCATORS TO EXPLORE THE CLOSE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN ART AND THE TRADITIONAL HUMANITIES OF ANTHROPOLOGY, ARCHAEOLOGY, HISTORY, ANCIENT AND MODERN LANGUAGES, LITERATURE, PHILOSOPHY, AND RELIGION. THIS ONLINE PLATFORM WILL NURTURE VISUAL LITERACY, BROADEN THE MUSEUM'S OUTREACH AND INCLUSIVITY, AND IMPROVE ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS. EACH OF THE PROJECT'S 12 ENGLISH-SPANISH MODULES WILL OFFER WAYS TO ENGAGE LEARNERS OF VARYING EDUCATIONAL LEVELS, INCLUDING THROUGH ANIMATIONS; ONLINE GAMES; 3-D MODELING; AND VIDEOS WITH COMMENTARY FROM SCHOLARS, ARTISTS, AND COMMUNITY LEADERS. THE PROJECT'S APPROACH TO DISTANCE LEARNING ENSURES THAT THE MUSEUM WILL CONTINUE CREATING AND OFFERING RESOURCES THAT CONNECT PEOPLE TO THE MUSEUM REGARDLESS OF GEOGRAPHY. THE PROJECT ALSO ENSURES THAT THE MUSEUM'S DIGITAL RESOURCES SUPPORT EDUCATORS AND STUDENTS CHALLENGED BY CIRCUMSTANCES DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

AT HILLSBOROUGH COMMUNITY COLLEGE, ONLINE LEARNING HAS BECOME A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF EDUCATION DURING COVID-19, AS HAS ACCESS TO DIGITAL RESOURCES. HILLSBOROUGH'S PROJECT WILL CONNECT STUDENTS WHO NEED INTERNET CONNECTIVITY AND COMPUTER RESOURCES WITH THOSE ASSETS. THE COLLEGE WILL PROVIDE SIX COMPUTERS FROM A LAPTOP VENDING KIOSK TO STUDENTS WHO DO NOT HAVE ADEQUATE TECHNOLOGY TO ENGAGE IN AND COMPLETE THEIR ONLINE COURSEWORK. IT WILL CONTRACT WITH LAPTOPS ANYTIME, WHICH PROVIDES AUTOMATED COMPUTER LAPTOP DISPENSING SERVICES, TO GET DEVICES INTO THE HANDS OF STUDENTS, MAKING IT POSSIBLE FOR STUDENTS TO ACCESS A COMPUTER WHEN THEY NEED IT. THE PROJECT DIRECTOR WILL WORK WITH STAFF AND THE CAMPUS LIBRARY DEANS TO HOUSE AND OPERATE THE KIOSK.

THE MUSEUM OF RUSSIAN ART IN MINNEAPOLIS, MINNESOTA, WILL HIRE A MUSEUM EDUCATOR TO OFFER A BROAD RANGE OF ON-SITE AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS ON RUSSIAN ART AND CULTURE FOR ALL AGES. THEY WILL AIM TO IMPROVE CHILDREN'S READING LEVELS THAT HAD WORSENED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC IN THE SCHOOL DISTRICTS SERVED BY THE MUSEUM. THE LITERACY PROGRAM WILL SERVE CHILDREN AGES 7 THROUGH 9, WHO WILL LEARN ABOUT ALL ASPECTS OF RUSSIAN ART, CULTURE, FOLK TALES, AND HISTORY THROUGH AGE-APPROPRIATE BOOKS, SUPPLEMENTED BY PRESENTATIONS ON ITEMS FROM THE MUSEUM'S EDUCATION RESEARCH COLLECTION.

THE BURLESQUE HALL OF FAME IN LAS VEGAS WILL DIGITIZE ITS COLLECTION TO CREATE ONLINE PROGRAMMING, WHICH HAS BECOME ESSENTIAL DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, AS PART OF ITS EFFORT TO DEVELOP AN INCLUSIVE ONLINE STRATEGY THAT CAN REACH WIDER AND MORE DIVERSE AUDIENCES AND RESEARCHERS WITH AN INTEREST IN DANCE, THEATER, MOVIES, WORKING-CLASS HISTORY, WOMEN'S HISTORY, AND ETHNIC STUDIES. THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE HIGH-QUALITY SCANS OF ITS COLLECTION ITEMS, CATALOG THEM APPROPRIATELY, AND ADD THEM TO A COLLECTION DATABASE. CURATED SELECTIONS WILL BECOME AVAILABLE THROUGH ONLINE EXHIBITIONS, SOCIAL MEDIA PROJECTS, AND A SEARCHABLE DATABASE. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO DIGITIZE PART OF ITS COLLECTION OF 8 MM, 16 MM, AND 35 MM FILM, AND WILL MAKE AVAILABLE A COLLECTION OF MIDCENTURY FILMS DEMONSTRATING HISTORICAL STYLES OF BURLESQUE AND THE NATURE OF EXPLOITATION FILMS AND OTHER B MOVIES.

THE FLOYD COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY IN CHARLES CITY, IOWA, WILL IMPROVE ITS COLLECTION STEWARDSHIP BY ORGANIZING STORAGE ROOMS AND PROPERLY CATALOGUING ITS ARTIFACTS. MANY OBJECTS IN THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION WERE TAKEN IN AS DONATIONS WITHOUT PROPER DOCUMENTATION AND THEN PLACED IN A STORAGE AREA WITHOUT SUPPORTING PAPERWORK TO EVEN IDENTIFY ITS LOCATION. THIS LACK OF PRIOR INVENTORY CONTROL HAS AFFECTED THE MUSEUM'S PROGRAMMING FOR THE COMMUNITY, WHICH BECAME VERY EVIDENT DURING THE PANDEMIC. MUSEUM STAFF WILL ASSESS THE CONDITION OF EACH ITEM IN THE COLLECTION AND THEN CATALOGUE THEM AND PLACE THEM IN MUSEUM-GRADE, ENVIRONMENTALLY SAFE STORAGE UNITS. AS A FINAL STEP, STAFF WILL ENTER INFORMATION NEEDED TO RETRIEVE ARTIFACTS FOR FUTURE EXHIBITS IN A DATABASE USING AN UPDATED CATALOGUING SOFTWARE.

THE MARSHALL COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY (MCPL) HAS EXPERIENCED INCREASED LEVELS OF STAFFING TURNOVER, WHICH IT ATTRIBUTES TO THE PANDEMIC. TO OFFSET THE DEFICIENCIES FROM THE LOSS OF SKILLS AND EXPERIENCE, MCPL WILL USE GRANT FUNDS TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES THAT FOCUS ON LIBRARY BASICS, CUSTOMER SERVICE, AND DIVERSITY TRAINING. THIS FUNDING WILL HELP ENSURE THAT THE LIBRARY HAS THE TECHNICAL CAPACITY TO SUPPORT ITS PATRONS AS IT CONTINUES ITS POST-PANDEMIC RECOVERY.

THE VERMONT HISTORICAL SOCIETY IN BARRE, VERMONT, WILL CREATE EDUCATIONAL ONLINE CONTENT AND IN-PERSON PROGRAMS TO ENGAGE K-12 STUDENTS IN EXPLORING THEIR HISTORY. CONTENT AND PROGRAMS WILL FEATURE STORIES OF RESILIENCY, DIVERSITY, AND COMMUNITY THAT DEMONSTRATE HOW VERMONTERS FACED CHALLENGES, PERSEVERED, AND SOLVED PROBLEMS. THE SOCIETY WILL PRIORITIZE STORIES THAT HIGHLIGHT THE EXPERIENCES OF VERMONTERS WHO ARE BLACK, INDIGENOUS, AND PEOPLE OF COLOR, AS WELL AS STORIES THAT BUILD A SENSE OF COMMUNITY. THE VERMONT HISTORY EXPLORER WEBSITE, WHICH SAW A SURGE OF NEW USE DURING THE PANDEMIC AND SERVES AS A VALUABLE TOOL FOR REMOTE LEARNING, WILL HOUSE THE NEW CONTENT. IT WILL PROVIDE EDUCATORS WITH EASILY ACCESSIBLE, STANDARDS-BASED RESOURCES TO TEACH VERMONT HISTORY IN A MORE DIVERSE AND INCLUSIVE MANNER, AND SUPPORT CONTINUED FLEXIBILITY IN DELIVERING EDUCATIONAL CONTENT.

THE WICHITA PUBLIC LIBRARY (WPL) WILL DOCUMENT COVID-19 IN WICHITA AND THE SURROUNDING AREA, HIGHLIGHTING THE EXPERIENCES OF HEALTHCARE WORKERS, FRONT LINE WORKERS, STUDENTS, EDUCATORS, AND ITS MINORITY COMMUNITIES. COLLECTING AND SHARING A WIDE VARIETY OF ORAL AND WRITTEN EXPERIENCES, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND OTHER EPHEMERA FROM THE PANDEMIC WILL HELP WICHITANS GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACTS OF COVID-19 ON OUR COMMUNITY AND WILL HELP FOSTER A SHARED EXPERIENCE FOR THOSE WHO FELT THE ISOLATION OF THE PANDEMIC. IN ADDITION, WPL WILL ALSO DIGITIZE AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO CITY OF WICHITA ORDINANCES AND BUILDING CODES FROM THE EARLY 20TH CENTURY. THIS WILL ALLOW THE LIBRARY TO BETTER PRESERVE THE ONLY KNOWN ORIGINAL COPIES OF THESE TITLES, WHILE MAKING THEM AVAILABLE TO A WIDER AUDIENCE.

THE MUSEUM OF INDIAN ARTS AND CULTURE IN SANTA FE, NEW MEXICO, WILL REESTABLISH ITS ON-SITE SCHOOL TOUR PROGRAM AND CONTINUE ITS ONLINE EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES, ALL OF WHICH SERVE ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS FROM ACROSS NEW MEXICO'S 89 SCHOOL DISTRICTS. THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL CONTRACT WITH AN EDUCATION COORDINATOR AND AN EDUCATION ASSISTANT TO DEVELOP THE PROGRAM WE ARE HERE, NOW AND ALWAYS. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC FORCED THE MUSEUM TO DRAMATICALLY REDUCE ITS STAFF, INCLUDING ITS EDUCATIONAL CURATORS. THE PANDEMIC ALSO CREATED THE NEED TO PROVIDE ONLINE EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES AND RESOURCES FOR STUDENTS. THIS NEED IS ESPECIALLY CRITICAL FOR STUDENTS IN REMOTE AREAS AND TRIBAL RESERVATIONS. AS THE MUSEUM REOPENS ITS DOORS, IT WILL RESUME ON-SITE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND CONTINUE TO DEVELOP AND OFFER ONLINE PROGRAMMING TO SUPPLEMENT THE STATE SOCIAL STUDIES CURRICULUM.

ARTSQUEST IN BETHLEHEM, PENNSYLVANIA, WILL EXPAND ITS FREE PROGRAMS AND SERVICES THAT CONTRIBUTE TO WELLBEING BY INCREASING ACCESS TO THE ARTS FOR FAMILIES, GROUPS, AND INDIVIDUALS OF ALL CULTURAL AND SOCIOECONOMIC BACKGROUNDS. THE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION WILL DESIGN A RANGE OF EDUCATIONAL, INTERPRETIVE, AND EXPERIENTIAL PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITIONS TO ENCOURAGE ART APPRECIATION, ART MAKING, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT WITH THE ARTS. THROUGH ITS PROGRAMS, ARTSQUEST ENCOURAGES A LIFELONG LOVE OF THE ARTS, FROM EARLY CHILDHOOD INITIATIVES SUCH AS TODDLER STORYTIME AND STROLLER TOURS TO CREATIVE AGING PROGRAMS FOR OLDER ADULTS. ARTSQUEST WILL ORGANIZE PROGRAMS AT LOCAL VENUES INCLUDING THE ARTSQUEST CENTER, THE BANANA FACTORY ARTS CENTER, AND THE STEELSTACKS CAMPUS. PROGRAMS WILL BE DESIGNED TO PROVIDE STRESS RELIEF, A TEMPORARY ESCAPE FROM THE PANDEMIC, AND THE OPPORTUNITY FOR PARTICIPANTS TO RECONNECT AND ENGAGE WITH ONE ANOTHER.

THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM IN OAK LAWN, ILLINOIS, WILL EXPAND PROGRAMS AND SERVICES THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE WELLBEING OF YOUNG CHILDREN AND FAMILIES AS THEY BEGIN TO RECOVER FROM THE STRESS AND ISOLATION CREATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM'S WEE ONES WEDNESDAY PROGRAM FOR CHILDREN 0-2 AND THEIR PARENTS AND CAREGIVERS, AS WELL AS SENSORY-FRIENDLY SESSIONS FOR CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES, WILL INCLUDE ADDITIONAL SUPPORT FROM PRACTITIONERS IN OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY, PHYSICAL THERAPY, SPEECH PATHOLOGY, AND CHILD PSYCHOLOGY.
