THE MUSEUM ALSO WILL CREATE A SUPPORT GROUP FOR PARENTS WITH CHILDREN 0-3 ADVISED BY CHILD DEVELOPMENT AND CHILD PSYCHOLOGY PROFESSIONALS.

HISTORIC LONDON TOWN AND GARDENS IN EDGEWATER, MARYLAND, WILL RELAUNCH ITS HORTICULTURAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS BY REHIRING A HORTICULTURAL EDUCATOR TO JUMPSTART THE PARK'S NEW GARDENS-BASED CURRICULUM. BEFORE THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC FORCED THE PARK TO REDUCE ITS STAFF, THE PARK HAD A ROBUST EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM FOCUSED ON COLONIAL HISTORY. THE NEWLY REVAMPED GARDENS-BASED PROGRAMS WILL PROVIDE PRE-K AND ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STUDENTS WITH OUTDOOR, IN-PERSON, HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE NATURAL WORLD. THIS WILL FULFILL A CRITICAL CURRICULAR NEED FROM THEIR PARTNER, ANNE ARUNDEL COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS, AND COMBAT THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF REMOTE LEARNING, INCLUDING SOCIAL ISOLATION, DEPRESSION, AND ANXIETY. THE PARK'S HORTICULTURAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS AIM TO SERVE AT LEAST 1,500 PRE-K THROUGH THIRD GRADERS ANNUALLY, LAYING A FOUNDATION FOR ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY.

THE DAYTON METRO LIBRARY IN OHIO WILL SUPPORT LOCAL JOB SEEKERS THOUGH EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING, RESOURCES, AND COMMUNITY-FOCUSED PARTNERSHIPS, AS THEY FACE UNEMPLOYMENT RATES THAT ARE 50% HIGHER THAN THE STATEWIDE RATE AND STILL STRUGGLE IN THE WAKE OF THE PANDEMIC. THE LIBRARY WILL HIRE A WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT LIBRARIAN TO ASSIST COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHOSE EMPLOYMENT AND LIVELIHOODS WERE IMPACTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC IN FINDING FULFILLING CAREERS. THE LIBRARIAN ALSO WILL SUPPORT ONGOING TRAINING OF OTHER STAFF TO ENSURE PATRONS RECEIVE CONSISTENT SUPPORT IN THEIR JOB SEARCHES. IN ADDITION, THE LIBRARY WILL PURCHASE DATABASES THAT EDUCATE AND ASSIST JOB SEEKERS. THE LIBRARY WILL PROMOTE THESE NEW SERVICES THROUGH PRINT AND ELECTRONIC MARKETING MATERIALS.

THE MARSHES OF GLYNN LIBRARIES IN BRUNSWICK, GEORGIA, WILL IMPLEMENT AN EARLY LITERACY FAMILY ENGAGEMENT PROJECT TO ADDRESS COMMUNITY DEFICITS IN EARLY READING PROFICIENCY. IN COOPERATION WITH THE GLYNN COUNTY SCHOOLS' PUBLIC PRE-K PROGRAM, THE LIBRARY WILL SHARE EARLY LITERACY STRATEGIES THAT PROMOTE READING READINESS WITH FAMILIES OF PRESCHOOL STUDENTS. EACH WEEK FOR 5 WEEKS, PRE-K STUDENTS WILL RECEIVE A BAG OF ITEMS FOCUSING ON AN EARLY LITERACY STRATEGY (I.E., TALKING, SINGING, READING, WRITING, AND PLAYING). EACH BAG WILL CONTAIN THREE BOOKS, A LEARNING TOOL OR TOY, AND A HANDOUT WITH ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE STRATEGY AND SUGGESTED ACTIVITIES FOR THE WEEK. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL PROVIDE PARENTS AND CAREGIVERS WITH IDEAS FOR ACTIVITIES THEY CAN DO WITH THEIR CHILDREN TO IMPROVE READING READINESS. THE PROJECT WILL HELP THE LIBRARY REESTABLISH EARLY LITERACY OUTREACH FOLLOWING THE IMPACTS OF COVID-19 ON FAMILY ENGAGEMENT WITH SCHOOLS AND PUBLIC LIBRARIES.

THE JEFFERSON COUNTY LIBRARY COOPERATIVE, A LIBRARY CONSORTIUM OF 40 MUNICIPAL PUBLIC LIBRARIES IN JEFFERSON COUNTY, ALABAMA, WILL INCREASE ITS CAPACITY TO ENGAGE MORE BROADLY WITH AND BETTER SERVE THE COMMUNITY. THE LIBRARIES SHARE A UNIFIED CATALOGUE AND HAVE ACCESS TO CENTRALIZED INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY INFRASTRUCTURE AND SUPPORT. THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC HAS CHANGED THE COMMUNITY'S EXPECTATIONS OF LIBRARY SERVICE FROM PROVIDING CENTRALIZED, IN-PERSON SERVICES TO DECENTRALIZED ACCESS POINTS, MICROSERVICES, AND A SEAMLESS DIGITAL EXPERIENCE. TO BETTER SERVE PATRONS' NEEDS, THE COOPERATIVE WILL HIRE A NEW STAFF MEMBER TO COORDINATE COMMUNICATION BETWEEN MEMBER LIBRARIES. THE STAFF MEMBER ALSO WILL LIAISE WITH THE COOPERATIVE'S LIBRARY SOFTWARE ADMINISTRATOR TO REDUCE WAIT TIMES FOR RESOLVING PATRON ACCESS AND ELIGIBILITY ISSUES AND EXPEDIATE PATRON FULFILLMENT OF INTERLIBRARY REQUESTS.

THE NORMAN ROCKWELL MUSEUM IN STOCKBRIDGE, MASSACHUSETTS, WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE ACADEMY OF ART UNIVERSITY IN SAN FRANCISCO TO BUILD A VIRTUAL GALLERY TEMPLATE THAT WILL BE USED TO PRESENT ENGAGING, INTERACTIVE VIRTUAL EXHIBITIONS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL WORK WITH A TEAM OF STUDENTS AND PROFESSORS FROM THE ACADEMY TO CREATE A TEMPLATE THAT WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO CREATE DIGITAL EXHIBITIONS RELATED TO WHAT IS BEING SHOWN IN THE PHYSICAL GALLERIES AND DIGITAL-ONLY EXHIBITIONS. THE MUSEUM CREATED A ROBUST PRESENCE ONLINE TO SERVE PATRONS DURING THE PANDEMIC. THE VIRTUAL GALLERY WILL PROVIDE A NEW TOOL TO BUILD ON THAT WORK AND IMPROVE THE MUSEUM'S ABILITY TO SERVE A GROWING ONLINE AUDIENCE, A NEED CREATED AND EXACERBATED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

TWIN LAKES LIBRARY SYSTEM RECEIVED THIS GRANT WHICH WAS TRANSFERRED TO MIDDLE GEORGIA REGIONAL LIBRARY SYSTEM (MGRLS). MGRLS WILL CONTINUE TO PARTNER WITH GEORGIA COLLEGE AND STATE UNIVERSITY TO INTENTIONALLY AND SENSITIVELY DOCUMENT THE ORAL HISTORY OF CENTRAL STATE HOSPITAL, WHICH WAS ONCE THE LARGEST MENTAL HEALTH HOSPITAL IN THE WORLD. MGRLS WILL CONTINUE TO ENGAGE THE ADVISORY BOARD OF FORMER HOSPITAL STAFF, PATIENTS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO HELP GUIDE THE COLLECTION OF STORIES FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS AFFILIATED WITH THE HOSPITAL ASSEMBLED BY TWIN LAKES LIBRARY SYSTEM. MGRLS WILL ALSO SPONSOR STATEWIDE HARVEST DAYS TO DIGITIZE CENTRAL STATE HOSPITAL MATERIALS FROM INDIVIDUALS' PERSONAL ARCHIVES. INTERVIEWS AND MATERIALS WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO AN EXHIBIT THAT WILL TRAVEL ACROSS GEORGIA TO EDUCATE INDIVIDUALS ABOUT THIS LITTLE-KNOWN STATE HISTORY AND DESTIGMATIZE MENTAL HEALTH.

TWIN LAKES LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL PARTNER WITH GEORGIA COLLEGE AND STATE UNIVERSITY TO INTENTIONALLY AND SENSITIVELY DOCUMENT THE ORAL HISTORY OF CENTRAL STATE HOSPITAL, WHICH WAS ONCE THE LARGEST MENTAL HEALTH HOSPITAL IN THE WORLD. TWIN LAKES LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL ASSEMBLE AN ADVISORY BOARD OF FORMER HOSPITAL STAFF, PATIENTS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO HELP GUIDE THE COLLECTION OF STORIES FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS AFFILIATED WITH THE HOSPITAL. THE LIBRARY WILL ALSO SPONSOR STATEWIDE HARVEST DAYS TO DIGITIZE CENTRAL STATE HOSPITAL MATERIALS FROM INDIVIDUALS? PERSONAL ARCHIVES. INTERVIEWS AND MATERIALS WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO AN EXHIBIT THAT WILL TRAVEL ACROSS GEORGIA TO EDUCATE INDIVIDUALS ABOUT THIS LITTLE-KNOWN STATE HISTORY AND DESTIGMATIZE MENTAL HEALTH.

BROOKLYN CENTER COMMUNITY SCHOOLS DISTRICT WILL TRANSFORM THE DISTRICT?S ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOL LIBRARIES INTO 21ST CENTURY LEARNING HUBS. LIBRARY STAFF WILL FORM AN ADVISORY GROUP OF STAKEHOLDERS, CONDUCT SURVEYS AND FOCUS GROUPS WITH STUDENTS, TEACHERS, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND VISIT LOCAL LEARNING LABS TO HELP INFORM THE PROJECT. STAFF WILL RECONFIGURE THE SPACE WITH MORE FUNCTIONAL FURNITURE AND A MORE COLLABORATIVE LAYOUT. IN ORDER TO SERVE STUDENTS OUTSIDE OF TRADITIONAL SCHOOL HOURS, LIBRARY STAFF WILL DEVELOP A LAPTOP CHECK-OUT AND WIFI HOTSPOT LENDING PROGRAM, EXTEND LIBRARY HOURS BEFORE AND AFTER SCHOOL, AND HOLD A MONTHLY COMMUNITY EVENT.

THE EDITH MEMORIAL LIBRARY WILL DOCUMENT AND DISSEMINATE THE AGRICULTURAL HISTORY OF THE CRAFT BEVERAGE INDUSTRY IN THE FINGER LAKES REGION OF NEW YORK TO DOCUMENT HOW THE INDUSTRY EMERGED AND TRANSFORMED SENECA AND SCHUYLER COUNTY. THE PROJECT WILL CHRONICLE THE LEGISLATIVE, ECONOMIC, AND AGRICULTURAL HISTORY THROUGH PERSONAL NARRATIVES AND COMMUNITY STORYTELLING TO DOCUMENT THE IMPORTANT ROLE OF THE INDUSTRY PLAYS IN THE COMMUNITY. INTERVIEWS, ROUNDTABLE DISCUSSIONS, EXHIBITIONS, AND PODCASTS WILL BE USED TO CAPTURE AND ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN THE 40 PLUS YEAR HISTORY OF THIS GROWING INDUSTRY. ORAL HISTORIES AND RELATED EPHEMERA WILL BE MADE ACCESSIBLE VIA NEW YORK HERITAGE, A STATE ARCHIVAL PORTAL.

THE INTER AMERICAN UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO PROPOSES TO TRANSFORM THE CDIN LABORATORY SCHOOL LIBRARY INTO TO A LEARNING HUB FOCUSED ON STEM LEARNING. THIS UPDATED CENTER WILL PROVIDE 7TH AND 8TH GRADE STUDENTS WITH LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO GROW THEIR PROBLEM-SOLVING SKILLS, ENGAGE IN CRITICAL THINKING, AND LEARN DIGITAL, INFORMATION, AND MEDIA LITERACIES. THE SCHOOL LIBRARIAN WILL ADD MORE FLEXIBLE, PERSONALIZED, AND STUDENT-CENTERED LEARNING AREAS TO THE LIBRARY SPACE ALONG WITH NEW TECHNOLOGY. THE SCHOOL LIBRARIAN WILL ALSO ESTABLISH PARTNERSHIPS WITH OTHER INFORMATION CENTERS AND STEM BUSINESSES TO DEVELOP WORKSHOPS FOR THE STUDENTS, BRING IN STEM EXPERTS TO TALK TO THE STUDENTS, AND PROVIDE COACHING AND MENTORING FOR THE STUDENTS.

NEUSE REGIONAL LIBRARY SYSTEM WILL DEVELOP THE GATEWAYS TO STEM PROGRAM BY OFFERING STEM PROGRAMMING AFTER SCHOOL AND DURING SUMMER MONTHS TO GRADE SCHOOL CHILDREN IN RURAL AREAS OF THE LIBRARY'S REGION. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF STEM PROGRAMMING LED BY A FULLY QUALIFIED STEM EDUCATOR WITH A FOCUS ON READING AND EARLY LITERACY THAT WILL HELP COMBAT THE "SUMMER SLIDE" OR DETERIORATION IN LITERACY SKILLS OF STUDENTS DURING OFF MONTHS. THE PROGRAM WILL ALSO INCREASE EXPOSURE TO NEW TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS VIRTUAL REALITY, 3D MODELING, AND CODING FOR STUDENTS IN AREAS WHERE OTHER OPPORTUNITIES FOR EXPOSURE TO THESE TECHNOLOGIES ARE NOT PRESENT.

BRIAR CLIFF UNIVERSITY WILL SUPPORT REPURPOSING A SMALL, LOW-USE LOUNGING AREA IN BISHOP MUELLER LIBRARY FOR USE AS A VIDEO RECORDING CENTER FOR FACULTY TO PREPARE TEACHING CONTENT FOR DELIVERY IN ONLINE COURSES AND STUDENTS TO PRODUCE ACADEMIC PROJECTS. THIS PROJECT?S PRIMARY GOAL IS TO ENHANCE LIBRARY SPACES AND TECHNOLOGY INFRASTRUCTURE FOR CONTENT CREATION-BASED LEARNING. THE PHYSICAL DELIVERABLE WILL BE THE DIGITAL MEDIA CREATION STUDIO, A 9 BY 16 FOOT (144 SQ. FT.) ONE BUTTON STUDIO SPACE HOUSED ON LEVEL 1 OF THE BISHOP MUELLER LIBRARY. THIS NEW SPACE WILL ALLOW STUDENTS, FACULTY, AND STAFF TO RECORD A QUALITY HD VIDEO WITH THE TOUCH OF A SINGLE BUTTON, WITHOUT ANY PRIOR PRODUCTION EXPERIENCE.

OSAGE COUNTY INTERLOCAL COOPERATIVE PROPOSES TO TRANSFORM THE HOMINY PUBLIC SCHOOL LIBRARY INTO AN INQUIRY-BASED LEARNING AND RESOURCE HUB TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR THE FUTURE. LIBRARY MEDIA SPECIALISTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES ON INQUIRY-BASED METHODS AND COLLABORATE WITH CLASSROOM TEACHERS, COUNSELORS, AND ADMINISTRATORS TO IDENTIFY OPEN EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES, DEVELOP CROSS-CURRICULAR LESSONS, AND IDENTIFY COURSES FOR CREDIT TO MEET THE ACADEMIC NEEDS OF EVERY STUDENT. THE LIBRARY WILL INCREASE ACCESS AND USE OF INFORMATION BY PURCHASING NEW DIGITAL EQUIPMENT TO REPLACE OUTDATED COMPUTERS, EXTENDING LIBRARY HOURS BEFORE AND AFTER SCHOOL AND DURING THE SUMMER, MAKING COMPUTERS AND HOTSPOTS AVAILABLE FOR STUDENTS TO CHECK OUT, AND HOSTING FAMILY LITERACY NIGHTS. THE LIBRARY WILL ALSO CREATE COLLABORATIVE SPACE WITH NEW FURNISHINGS AND SPACE LAYOUT.

BELFAST FREE LIBRARY WILL FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS THAT ENGAGE A BROADER CROSS-SECTION OF THE COMMUNITY IN ONGOING DISCUSSIONS ABOUT CLIMATE CHANGE TO ENSURE THAT ALL VOICES AND VIEWS ARE HEARD. USING BEST PRACTICES FROM CITIZEN SCIENCE, CLIMATE CHANGE COMMUNICATIONS, AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, BELFAST FREE LIBRARY AND GULF OF MAINE RESEARCH INSTITUTE (GMRI) SEEK TO DOCUMENT AND ARCHIVE DIVERSE IDEAS, PERSPECTIVES, PRIORITIES, AND ASPIRATIONS ON CLIMATE CHANGE FROM BELFAST CITIZENS. THE ARCHIVE WILL BE HOUSED AND MADE ACCESSIBLE ON THE GMRI ECOSYSTEM INVESTIGATION NETWORK THAT SUPPORTS LOCAL CITIZEN SCIENCE EFFORTS. INFORMATION GLEANED FROM THE PROJECT WILL BE USED TO INFORM LOCAL DECISION-MAKING AND PLANNING IN RESPONSE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, AS WELL AS REPRESENT THE COMMUNITY?S COLLECTIVE MEMORY ON A CRITICAL ISSUE.

WAHLUKE SCHOOL DISTRICT WILL DEVELOP A CULTURALLY RELEVANT LEARNING COMMONS FOR WAHLUKE HIGH SCHOOL AND TRANSFORM THE CURRENTLY UNUSED LIBRARY SPACE INTO A LEARNING COMMONS. A RECENT SURVEY INFORMED THE DECISION TO FOCUS ON CULTURALLY RELEVANT TEACHING AND THE DESIGN WILL BE FURTHER HONED THROUGH A SERIES OF FOCUS GROUPS WITH TEACHERS AND STUDENTS. LIBRARIANS WILL PROVIDE INSTRUCTIONAL SUPPORT TO TEACHERS ON INQUIRY-BASED AND CULTURALLY RELEVANT TEACHING METHODS. LIBRARY HOURS WILL ALSO BE EXPANDED TO INCLUDE TIME BEFORE AND AFTER SCHOOL. THE LEARNING COMMONS WILL INCLUDE NEW TECHNOLOGY AND RESOURCES, FLEXIBLE FURNITURE, AND COLLABORATIVE SPACES TO SUPPORT MULTI-MODAL COMMUNICATION, COLLABORATION, AND CREATIVITY.

THE CITY OF ANIAK LIBRARY WILL ENGAGE COMMUNITY MEMBERS AROUND TWO RECENTLY DONATED COLLECTIONS: AN ANIAK HISTORY-GENEALOGY ARCHIVE INFORMED BY U.S. CENSUS RECORDS AND A PHOTO ARCHIVE REFLECTING THE CITY?S HISTORY FROM 1943?1970 TO INCLUDE VOICES THAT WERE NOT OFTEN INCLUDED IN DOCUMENTATION OF THE CITY?S HISTORY. ANIAK, A REMOTE COMMUNITY OF APPROXIMATELY 500 RESIDENTS, HAS BEEN THE SUBJECT OF RESEARCH AND HISTORIES WRITTEN BY OUTSIDERS. THROUGH A SERIES OF PROGRAMS AND DIGITIZATION WORKSHOPS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS? ESPECIALLY ELDERS? WILL BE ENCOURAGED TO SHARE PERSONAL NARRATIVES AND ARTIFACTS RELATED TO THE PERIODS COVERED BY THESE COLLECTIONS. THE INCLUSION OF LOCAL MATERIALS AND STORIES ENSURES THAT NATIVE ALASKAN NARRATIVES ARE REPRESENTED IN THE LOCAL HISTORY.

J. SARGEANT REYNOLDS COMMUNITY COLLEGE PROPOSES TO CREATE A SEMESTER-LONG LAPTOP LOAN PROGRAM FOR FIRST-GENERATION COLLEGE STUDENTS WHO DEMONSTRATE THE GREATEST NEED THROUGH AN APPLICATION PROCESS. FORTY STUDENTS WILL BE SELECTED EACH SPRING AND FALL SEMESTER BEGINNING SPRING 2021. TWENTY STUDENTS ARE EXPECTED DURING SUMMER TERMS. THE GRANT FUNDED PROJECT WILL RECRUIT A FINAL COHORT IN AUGUST 2022. A TOTAL OF 200 FIRST-GENERATION STUDENTS ARE PROJECTED TO BE SERVED. REYNOLDS WILL FURTHER WORK TO CLOSE THE DIGITAL DIVIDE BY PROVIDING THREE TECHNOLOGY WORKSHOPS PER SEMESTER TO EVERY STUDENT WHO BORROWS A LAPTOP. THESE WORKSHOPS WILL DEMONSTRATE THE BASICS OF LAPTOP OPERATION AS WELL AS GIVE A SHORT PRIMER ON THE SOFTWARE THE STUDENTS WILL NEED TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN THEIR COURSES.

LAKEVIEW COMMUNITY LIBRARY WILL IMPLEMENT COMMUNITY DIGITIZATION SERVICES AND RICH PROGRAMMING TO RECONNECT THE COMMUNITY TO ITS VANISHING DAIRY FARM AND AGRICULTURAL HISTORY. LAKEVIEW COMMUNITY LIBRARY WILL PARTNER WITH SEVERAL ORGANIZATIONS AND NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING RANDOM LAKE HISTORICAL SOCIETY, COMMUNITY NEWSPAPER THE SOUNDER, AND RANDOM LAKE HIGH SCHOOL TO TRAIN AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO COLLECT AND DIGITIZE PERSONAL AND COMMUNITY NARRATIVES AND MATERIALS. THE LIBRARY WILL ALSO USE ACTIVITIES SUCH AS DAYTRIPS TO NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES? HISTORICAL SOCIETIES, COMMUNITY SCAN DAYS, AND LECTURES TO BUILD THE CAPACITY OF LIBRARY STAFF AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO CAPTURE AND PRESERVE LOCAL STORIES AND MEMORIES IN THEIR RAPIDLY CHANGING COMMUNITY.

MOORE FREE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION WILL ENGAGE THE NEIGHBORING TOWNS OF NEWFANE AND BROOKLINE TO COLLECT LOCAL RESIDENTS? STORIES IN RESPONSE TO THE COMMUNITY IDENTIFYING THE NEED TO COLLECT AND SHARE COMMUNITY STORIES. THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM THE TWO COMMUNITIES? SHARED NARRATIVE AND BUILD CONNECTIONS AMONG THE 2,100 PLUS INDIVIDUALS THAT RESIDE IN THE TOWNS. STORIES WILL BE ARCHIVED, INDEXED USING OPEN SOURCE TOOL OMEKA, AND MADE ACCESSIBLE THROUGH THE LIBRARY?S NEW WEBSITE. MOORE FREE LIBRARY WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY OF WINDHAM COUNTY, SENIOR SOLUTIONS AND BRATTLEBORO AREA HOSPICE, VERMONT FOLKLIFE CENTER, AND A CORPS OF DEDICATED VOLUNTEERS.

GREAT FALLS PUBLIC SCHOOLS WILL TRANSFORM THE LIBRARY AT NORTH MIDDLE SCHOOL FROM AN UNDERUSED SPACE TO A 21ST CENTURY COLLABORATIVE LEARNING COMMONS. LIBRARY STAFF WILL CONDUCT FOCUS GROUPS WITH STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND ADMINISTRATORS ABOUT THE LIBRARY REDESIGN AND THE REIMAGINED LIBRARY SERVICE MODEL TO HELP CREATE A SENSE OF OWNERSHIP IN THE PROCESS. LIBRARIANS WILL ALSO VISIT OTHER NEWLY RENOVATED LIBRARY SPACES BEFORE RECONFIGURING THEIR SPACE. THE COLLABORATIVE SPACE WILL INCLUDE MORE FUNCTIONAL FURNITURE, NEW TECHNOLOGY, AND A MAKERSPACE. THE LIBRARIANS WILL COORDINATE WITH THE PTA TO HOLD EVENTS FOR PARENTS TO ENSURE THEIR ENGAGEMENT. LIBRARY STAFF WILL ENGAGE IN PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND SHARE THEIR LEARNINGS WITH TEACHERS AND ADMINISTRATION IN ONGOING PROFESSIONAL LEARNING SESSIONS ON INQUIRY-BASED LEARNING AND STANDARDS-BASED TEACHING.

THE PENNSYLVANIA HORTICULTURE SOCIETY MCLEAN LIBRARY WILL SUPPORT THE DOCUMENTATION, PRESERVATION, AND DISSEMINATION OF PHILADELPHIA?S COMMUNITY GARDENS HISTORIES TO CURTAIL THE LOSS OF AN IMPORTANT PART OF CITY HISTORY. AS NEIGHBORHOODS SHIFT AND STEWARDSHIP OF GARDENS CHANGE, HISTORIES AND STORIES THAT REFLECT THE HISTORICAL AND SOCIAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE GARDENS ARE FADING. THE MCLEAN LIBRARY HAS BEEN ENGAGED WITH COMMUNITY GARDENERS FOR NEARLY FOUR DECADES. BUILDING ON THIS LONG-STANDING RELATIONSHIP, IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY GARDENERS, THE LIBRARY WILL DEVELOP A SERIES OF DIGITAL PRESERVATION AND ARCHIVING WORKSHOPS TO SUPPORT LOCAL GARDENERS IN THE PRESERVATION OF GARDEN HISTORIES, ARTIFACTS, AND RELATED NARRATIVES. CONTENT CREATED BY LOCAL GARDENERS WILL BE SHARED VIA THE SMITHSONIAN GARDENS COMMUNITY OF GARDENS DIGITAL ARCHIVE.

THE JIM GATCHELL MEMORIAL MUSEUM FOSTERS A LIFELONG PASSION FOR LEARNING OF ALL PEOPLE, ENRICHES THE LIVES OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS BY BEING A TRUSTED COMMUNITY SPACE, AND HAS RESPONDED TO THE UNPRECEDENTED CHALLENGES OF RECENT YEARS WITH AN INCREASED FOCUS ON ENGAGING THE REGION’S YOUTH. NAMED TO HONOR LOCAL PHARMACIST AND HISTORIAN, JIM GATCHELL, THE MUSEUM IS A VALUABLE RESOURCE AND COMMUNITY ASSET THAT PROUDLY SERVES THE NEEDS OF ITS RURAL AUDIENCES.

THE MUSEUM OF DISCOVERY AND SCIENCE FULFILLS ITS MISSION THROUGH FOUR EDUCATIONAL CONTENT PILLARS: ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY, EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION, HEALTH & WELLNESS, AND PHYSICAL SCIENCE. IN 2022, THE MUSEUM RECEIVED DESIGNATION FROM THE COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF BROWARD AS A HUB FOR RESILIENCE EDUCATION. IN THIS ROLE, THE MUSEUM SERVES AS THE ANCHOR AND CHAMPION OF THEIR COMMUNITY’S CONVERSATION, EDUCATION, AND ACTION REGARDING ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY AND RESILIENCE, POSITIVELY IMPACTING 1.9 MILLION RESIDENTS.

THE RIVERSIDE ART MUSEUM ADHERES TO ITS MISSION TO INTEGRATE ART INTO THE LIVES OF PEOPLE IN A WAY THAT ENGAGES, INSPIRES, AND BUILDS COMMUNITY BY PRESENTING THOUGHT-PROVOKING EXHIBITS AND PROVIDING QUALITY ART CLASSES THAT INSTILL A LIFELONG LOVE OF THE ARTS. THE MUSEUM ADMINISTERS THE RECENTLY OPENED CHEECH MARIN CENTER FOR CHICANO ART & CULTURE, WHICH IS A SPACE FOR DIALOGUE, SCHOLARSHIP, AND EXHIBITION FOCUSING THE IMPORTANCE OF ART ON THE CHICANO MOVEMENT OF THE 19060S, AS WELL AS ITS CONTEMPORARY RESPONSE TO CURRENT SOCIAL CONDITIONS AND GLOBAL ARTISTIC MOVEMENTS. THE MUSEUM IS A GREAT RESOURCE TO THE DIVERSE AUDIENCES THAT MAKE UP SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA.

AS A LEADING CULTURAL INSTITUTION THAT PROVIDES LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR EVERYONE, THE CENTER OF SCIENCE AND INDUSTRY (COSI) HAS MADE AN UNPRECEDENTED GLOBAL IMPACT TO HELP CLOSE THE EDUCATION GAP, EXACERBATED BY THE PANDEMIC, BY FOSTERING DIVERSITY AND EQUITY IN STEAM; INSPIRING SCIENCE AND HUMANITIES EDUCATION; AND PROMOTING SCIENCE LITERACY. IT HAS DONE THIS IMPORTANT WORK THROUGH CRITICAL HUMAN SERVICE-BASED PARTNERSHIPS AND IN COORDINATION WITH OTHER MUSEUMS AND NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS.

THIS ASHEVILLE ART MUSEUM HAS CREATED SIGNIFICANT LOCAL AND REGIONAL IMPACT THROUGH ITS ARTS PROGRAMS AND EXHIBITS. WITH A RECENT EXPANSION INTO A NEW BUILDING, THE MUSEUM HAS BEEN PROPELLED TO A GREATER LEVEL OF CAPACITY AND SERVICE TO THEIR COMMUNITY. THE MUSEUM SERVES AS A COMMUNITY ANCHOR AND VALUABLE RESOURCE FOR THE CITY’S DIVERSE COMMUNITIES.

THE BURKE MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY AND CULTURE BUILT AND OPENED A NEW MUSEUM IN 2019. THIS PHYSICAL TRANSFORMATION HAS BEEN PAIRED WITH A TRANSFORMED VISION OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, PUBLIC SERVICE, AND RELATIONSHIP-BUILDING, CHARACTERIZED BY A NEW “INSIDE-OUT” DESIGN AND INTERPRETIVE APPROACH; A STRENGTHENED, MUSEUM-WIDE COMMITMENT TO DECOLONIZING ITS PRACTICES AND MINDSET; AND EDUCATIONAL OFFERINGS THAT HAVE BEEN REDESIGNED AND REVITALIZED TO BETTER MEET THE NEEDS OF TEACHERS AND STUDENTS ACROSS THE STATE.

THE OAKLAND MUSEUM OF CALIFORNIA’S EDUCATIONAL OFFERINGS ADDRESS CRITICAL NEEDS OF STUDENTS AND TEACHERS AS A LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND STATEWIDE RESOURCE. BEYOND ITS ROLE AS A CENTRAL CULTURAL AND EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE FOR THE BAY AREA, THE MUSEUM IS AN INDISPENSABLE CIVIC ANCHOR FOR OAKLAND, ASPIRING TO CREATE POSITIVE SOCIAL CHANGE IN THEIR CITY AND TO CHAMPION THE VITAL ROLE CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS CAN PLAY IN FOSTERING SOCIAL COHESION.

THE MISSISSIPPI CHILDREN'S MUSEUM EXPRESSES A DEEP
CONNECTION TO THEIR COMMUNITY THROUGH A BROAD BASE OF PROGRAMS AND INITIATIVES,
AND THEY EMBRACE THEIR ROLE AS A COMMUNITY ANCHOR AND A TRUSTED COMMUNITY
SPACE. THE MUSEUM RECENTLY EXPANDED THEIR SERVICES TO ANOTHER LOCATION TO
BETTER MEET THE NEEDS OF A BROADER AUDIENCE IN THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI.

THE MUSEO DE ARTE DE PONCE HAS DONE AN EXCEPTIONAL JOB
RESPONDING TO THE OVERWHELMING CHALLENGES FACING PUERTO RICO THROUGH THE RECENT
HURRICANES, EARTHQUAKES, AND PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM HAS FOUND WAYS TO CREATE
ART-BASED, MISSION-BASED PROGRAMMING THAT ADDRESSES HUMANITARIAN NEEDS AND HAS
TAKEN THESE PROGRAMS TO A WIDE VARIETY OF AUDIENCES.

THE
HIGH DESERT MUSEUM SERVES A LARGE ? THOUGH SPARSELY POPULATED AND RURAL ?
GEOGRAPHIC RANGE IN THE INTERMOUNTAIN WEST.
IT HAS BEEN A CONSISTENT EDUCATIONAL RESOURCE SUPPLYING VIRTUAL LEARNING
OPPORTUNITIES TO ISOLATED SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITIES, A SERVICE MADE EVEN MORE
RELEVANT DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE AQUARIUM OFFERS A VERY IMPRESSIVE PORTFOLIO OF COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND PROGRAMS, WHICH HAVE STATEWIDE IMPACT. THEY HAVE BEEN VERY STRATEGIC IN THEIR APPROACH, AND THEY ARE CLEARLY ADVOCATES FOR THEIR COMMUNITY.

THE MUSEUM IS COMMITTED TO REACHING A BROAD GROUP OF AUDIENCES, AND TO MAINTAINING A RELEVANT PRESENCE WITHIN THEIR COMMUNITY. THE TIMELINESS OF THEIR NOMINATION WAS NOTED, AS THEY INITIATED NEW PROGRAMS IN 2018 IN REMEMBRANCE OF THE 50TH ANNIVERSARY OF MARTIN LUTHER KING JR'S ASSASSINATION.

THIS MUSEUM HAS BEEN DOING INCREDIBLY IMPORTANT WORK WITHIN THEIR COMMUNITY, PARTICULARLY FOLLOWING THE PULSE NIGHTCLUB SHOOTING. THEY HAVE TAKEN THEIR EXPERIENCES FOLLOWING THAT TRAGEDY TO HELP OTHER COMMUNITIES - FROM DALLAS, TO LAS VEGAS, TO PARKLAND - BEGIN THE HEALING PROCESS AFTER THEIR MASS CASUALTY EVENTS.

THE MUSEUM'S BROAD PROGRAMMING COVERS A VARIETY OF AUDIENCES. DUE TO THEIR LOCATION IN SAN DIEGO, THEY HAVE MAINTAINED STRONG RELATIONSHIPS WITH MILITARY FAMILIES THROUGH A NUMBER OF OUTREACH EFFORTS.

THIS TRIBAL MUSEUM HAS EVOLVED FROM ONE FOCUSED PRIMARILY ON THEIR TRIBAL MEMBERS TO AN ORGANIZATION NOW WORKING WITH A BROADER AND MORE DIVERSE GROUP OF AUDIENCES. THEIR ABILITY TO TELL THEIR STORIES AND SHARE THEIR HISTORY WITH NON-NATIVE VISITORS COULD SERVE AS A MODEL FOR OTHER TRIBAL CULTURAL CENTERS.

AS THE STATE'S OFFICIAL REPOSITORY FOR PUBLIC-OWNED COLLECTIONS, THE NEARLY 100-YEAR-OLD MUSEUM OF NATURAL CULTURAL HISTORY (MNCH) IS AN UNPARALLELED RESOURCE FOR LEARNING ABOUT OREGON'S HUMAN HISTORY, CULTURAL HISTORY, AND SCIENCE TOPICS. LOCATED AT THE UNIVERSITY OF OREGON, MNCH PRIMARILY SERVES THE INTERESTS OF STUDENTS IN EUGENE; HOWEVER, IT ALSO RESPONDS TO THE STATEWIDE CONCERNS ABOUT LIMITED ACCESS TO STEM EDUCATION. SINCE 2015, MNCH HAS MADE EXTRAORDINARY STRIDES TOWARDS EXTENDING ITS SERVICES TO STUDENTS, FAMILIES, AND EDUCATORS IN OREGON'S UNDERSERVED RURAL COMMUNITIES. THIS OUTREACH, BORN OUT OF DEEP COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS, PROVIDES RICH LEARNING ADVENTURES FOR SCHOOLS AND LIBRARIES ACROSS THE STATE TO ENCOURAGE MORE STUDENTS TO PURSUE CAREERS IN STEM.

TUCKED AWAY IN THE COMMUNITIES ALONG THE FOX RIVER OF NORTHEAST WISCONSIN IS A SMALL MUSEUM AFFECTIONATELY KNOWN AS THE HISTORY MUSEUM AT THE CASTLE. BY PLACING HISTORIC LESSONS IN A MODERN DAY CONTEXT, THE MUSEUM INSPIRES VISITORS TO DISCOVER AND APPRECIATE FOX CITIES' RICH HISTORY. THE MUSEUM RECENTLY DEVELOPED THREE EXHIBITS FOCUSED ON THE AFRICAN AMERICAN, HOMELESS, AND MENTAL ILLNESS COMMUNITIES. FEATURING TRAVELING, POP-UP, AND STATIC DISPLAYS IN AND AROUND APPLETON, THE EXHIBITS CREATED NEW WAYS FOR CITIZENS TO ENGAGE WITH THE PAST AND PLAN FOR A MORE POSITIVE FUTURE.

THE DETROIT HISTORICAL SOCIETY (DHS) HAS A 100-YEAR LEGACY OF TELLING THE CITY'S STORIES AND WHY THEY MATTER. WITH THE 50-YEAR ANNIVERSARY OF THE TUMULTUOUS DETROIT RIOTS LOOMING, DHS SOUGHT THE BEST WAY TO TELL THE TRAUMATIC AND SENSITIVE STORY THAT STILL RESONATED WITH COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE COUNTRY, WHILE ALSO INCORPORATING ALL DETROITERS IN THE NARRATIVE. RATHER THAN AVOIDING THE SUBJECT OR ADDRESSING IT THROUGH A TRADITIONAL EXHIBITION. THE 50-YEAR ANNIVERSARY BECAME THE CATALYST FOR DETROIT 67: LOOKING BACK TO MOVE FORWARD, A COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PROJECT THAT CHANGED THE WAY DHS DEFINED ITS ROLE IN CIVIC DIALOGUE AND HISTORIC COMMEMORATION.

LOCATED IN THE HEART OF THE CITY'S CULTURAL DISTRICT AND LESS THAN A MILE FROM THE BRIDGE TO MEXICO, THE EL PASO MUSEUM OF ART (EPMA) USES SERVICES, PROGRAMS, AND ART EXHIBITS TO CELEBRATE THE DIVERSITY AND CULTURAL PRIDE OF THE CITY. THROUGH DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL OUTREACH, EPMA BUILDS COMMUNITY COHESION IN BOTH THE UNITED STATES AND MEXICO, DEMONSTRATING THAT CULTURAL UNDERSTANDING AND CELEBRATION ARE PARAMOUNT FOR CHANGE AND GROWTH.

THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF DENVER AT MARSICO CAMPUS IS ONE OF THE MILE HIGH CITY'S GEMS. LOCATED IN THE DENVER METRO AREA, THE MUSEUM HAS GROWN ALONG WITH THE POPULATION IT SERVES, EXPANDING ITS FACILITIES, PROGRAMMING, AND ATTENDANCE. IT OFFERS RICH PLAY EXPERIENCES AND A DYNAMIC LEARNING ENVIRONMENT DESIGNED FOR CHILDREN, NEWBORN THROUGH AGE EIGHT. WITH A FOCUS ON ACCESS, THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF DENVER HAS BECOME A LEADER IN OPERATING AND DESIGNING ACCESSIBLE MUSEUM EXPERIENCES FOR ALL.
NATIONAL AWARD FOR MUSEUM SERVICE

THE KUSKOKWIM CONSORTIUM LIBRARY IS DOING EXTRAORDINARY WORK WITH JUST A SINGLE LOCATION AND VERY FEW RESOURCES. KUSKOKWIM CONSORTIUM LIBRARY’S LEVEL OF EMBEDDEDNESS IN THE COMMUNITY WOULD BE AN ASPIRATION FOR ANY LIBRARY. THEY SERVE BOTH A CAMPUS COMMUNITY AND A LOCAL COMMUNITY THAT IS APPROXIMATELY 65% ALASKA NATIVE IN ONE OF THE MOST ISOLATED RURAL LOCATIONS IN THE COUNTRY. THE LIBRARY DEMONSTRATED ITS INNOVATION, LEADERSHIP, AND IMPACT IN THE COMMUNITY, THROUGH EFFORTS ENCOMPASSING DIGITAL ACCESS, LITERACY, HOMELESSNESS, FOOD INSECURITY, AND CULTURAL PROGRAMS.

LONG BRANCH FREE PUBLIC LIBRARY OFFERS A SIGNIFICANT RANGE OF PROGRAMMING WITH JUST 15 FULL-TIME EQUIVALENT STAFF. TO BETTER SERVE THEIR LARGE IMMIGRANT COMMUNITY, LONG BRANCH FREE PUBLIC LIBRARY CONNECTED WITH THE BRAZILIAN CONSULATE. THEY HAVE A FORMAL PARTNERSHIP WITH BARBERSHOPS TO OFFER LITERACY PROGRAMS AND ALSO WORK WITH HOMELESS, UNEMPLOYED, AND FORMERLY INCARCERATED POPULATIONS. SOME OF THESE PROGRAMS HAVE BECOME MODELS IN OTHER LIBRARIES, HAVE BEEN INCORPORATED BY THE NEW JERSEY STATE LIBRARY.

THE LOS ANGELES COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY, WITH 84 BRANCHES, HAS STEPPED UP TO SUPPORT VARIOUS COMMUNITY NEEDS, PLACING A PRIORITY ON PROGRAMS AND SERVICES THAT ADDRESS SOCIETAL INEQUITIES. THEY ALSO PROVIDED EVIDENCE THAT MANY OF THEIR SERVICES ARE HAVING A TANGIBLE IMPACT ON PEOPLE’S LIVES.

TOLEDO-LUCAS COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY STANDS OUT AS A TRUE CONNECTOR IN THEIR COMMUNITY. WHEN THEIR COMMUNITY PERCEPTION POLL POINTED TO LITERACY AND TECHNOLOGY ACCESS NEEDS, TOLEDO LUCAS COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY EXPANDED PROGRAMS AND SECURED SUPPORT FOR A DIGITAL EQUITY GAP ANALYSIS. INSTEAD OF CREATING NEW OFFERINGS, THEY STROVE TO AMPLIFY THE WORK OF THEIR PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS THROUGHOUT ALL 20 OF THEIR BRANCH LOCATIONS. THEY ALSO EXEMPLIFY INCLUSIVE SERVICES, THROUGH A RECENTLY IMPLEMENTED LANGUAGE ACCESS POLICY, TEXT MAGNIFIER STATIONS, AND ACCESSIBILITY AUDITS.

WILMINGTON PUBLIC LIBRARY SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE LOCAL EPIDEMIC OF ILLITERACY AND SERVE AS AN EQUALIZER FOR FAMILIES OF COLOR WHO SUFFER FROM MULTI-DIMENSIONAL, GENERATIONAL POVERTY. THE LIBRARY IS DEPLOYING VARIOUS STRATEGIES TO BUILD STRONG COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS, RAISE ITS VISIBILITY, AND SHIFT ATTITUDES RELATED TO READING AND LEARNING. THE LIBRARY’S BARBERSHOP BOOKS PROGRAM RECRUITED 20 LOCAL BARBERS AS INFLUENCERS TO PROMOTE READING AMONG YOUNG MALES. THEIR COOL CONVERSATIONS SPEAKER SERIES INCLUDES DIVERSE CELEBRITIES AND CULTURAL LUMINARIES WHO REFLECT THE LOCAL DEMOGRAPHIC.

SERVING THE MOST POPULOUS AND ECONOMICALLY DISPARATE COUNTY IN MISSOURI, ST. LOUIS COUNTY LIBRARY IS MEETING THE CHALLENGES OF A LARGE COUNTY-BASED SYSTEM THROUGH STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AND DYNAMIC OFFERINGS. THE LIBRARY LAUNCHED THE DIGITAL EQUITY INITIATIVE TO CONNECT OVER 40 SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND NEARLY 1,500 SENIORS WITH TECHNOLOGY DURING THE PANDEMIC. THE LIBRARY’S TAP IN CENTER PROVIDES FREE LEGAL ASSISTANCE AND HAS HELPED OVER 250 PATRONS RESOLVE OUTSTANDING ARREST WARRANTS. AN INNOVATIVE DRIVE-THRU SERVICE HAS CONNECTED RESIDENTS TO NEEDED RESOURCES THROUGHOUT THE PANDEMIC, INCLUDING MEALS, DIAPERS, FREE BOOKS TO KEEP, AND MORE.

THE AMISTAD RESEARCH CENTER IS A COMMUNITY-BASED ARCHIVE WITH A FOCUS ON AMERICA’S ETHNIC AND RACIAL HISTORY, THE AFRICAN DIASPORA, AND CIVIL RIGHTS. WITH AN INTERNATIONAL AUDIENCE OF ACADEMICS, EDUCATORS, STUDENTS AND COMMUNITY RESEARCHERS, THE CENTER PROVIDES ACCESS TO HISTORICAL RECORDS AND BRINGS HISTORY TO LIFE. THE CENTER COLLABORATES WITH K-16 INSTITUTIONS, SERVES STUDENTS THROUGH THEIR AMISTAD ON THE GO! PROGRAM, AND SUPPORTS INTERNSHIPS FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS AND UNDERGRADUATES. THEY REFLECT COMMUNITY CONCERNS THROUGH OFFERINGS SUCH AS THE CULTURAL SERIES, CONVERSATIONS IN COLOR, AND DEMONSTRATE THE IMPORTANT ROLE THAT ACADEMIA CAN PLAY IN PUBLIC DIALOGUE.

THE HIGHWOOD PUBLIC LIBRARY CLEARLY ARTICULATES ITS VISION FOR ADDRESSING COMMUNITY NEEDS AND HAS PUT RELATED SERVICE MODELS INTO PRACTICE.  PROGRAMMING HAS ASSISTED LOCAL IMMIGRANT POPULATIONS FACED WITH LAW AND POLICY CHANGES OVER THE YEARS, AS WELL AS SUPPORTING THE ADVANCEMENT OF COMMUNITY LITERACY.

LOCATED IN THE HEART OF APPALACHIA, THE CABELL COUNTY PUBLIC LIBRARY PROVIDES AN INTEGRATED APPROACH TO SOCIAL SERVICES INCLUDING ITS INFORMATION  REFERRAL DEPARTMENT, WHICH IS REGULARLY PROMOTED BY LOCAL MEDIA. THE LIBRARY ALSO ESTABLISHED A DOMESTIC VIOLENCE SHELTER AND FOOD BANK, WHICH ARE NOW SELF-SUSTAINING.

MEMPHIS PUBLIC LIBRARIES HAVE BEEN INTENTIONAL ABOUT CONNECTING TO THEIR COMMUNITY, AND PROGRAMMING GOES BEYOND THE LIBRARY INTO PLACES SUCH AS LAUNDROMATS AND RETAIL CENTERS. THEIR DIVERSE STAFF REFLECTS THE LARGER COMMUNITY DEMOGRAPHICS.

THIS LIBRARY HAS DEMONSTRATED THAT INNOVATIVE, REPLICABLE PROGRAMMING HAS CULTIVATED COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS DURING A TIME OF EXPLOSIVE AREA GROWTH. THEY ARE THE HUB FOR VALUABLE EARLY EDUCATION RESOURCES, EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES, AND EXPANDING OPPORTUNITY TO PEOPLE WITH ALL ABILITIES BEYOND THE BORDERS OF IDAHO.

THE GULFPORT PUBLIC LIBRARY HOSTS MANY IMPACTFUL AND WELL-RUN PROGRAMS, BUT PARTICULARLY NOTABLE IS ITS RECOGNITION OF AND CONTRIBUTION TO THE LARGE LGBTQ+ COMMUNITY THAT CALLS GULFPORT HOME. FROM BUILDING RELEVANT COLLECTIONS TO HOSTING CONSTRUCTIVE CONVERSATIONS AND PROVIDING SUPPORT TO YOUTH, THEY DEMONSTRATE A COMMITMENT TO THEIR RESIDENTS, AS WELL AS OTHER DIVERSE POPULATIONS THEY SERVE, INCLUDING THE ECONOMICALLY UNDERPRIVILEGED AND THE ELDERLY.

IN A COMPLEX AND DIVERSE CITY, THIS LIBRARY IS DEEPLY ENGAGED WITH THE COMMUNITY. THEY RESPOND TO IDENTIFIED NEEDS BY PARTNERING WITH LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO CREATE WIDE-REACHING AND EXCITING PROGRAMS.

THIS CONSORTIUM HAS WORKED SUSTAINABILITY FOR OVER FIFTY YEARS, AND FULFILLS AN IMPORTANT DATA CURATION NEED IN A COLLABORATIVE WAY. THEY HAVE MAINTAINED A STRONG RANGE OF PROGRAMS AND SERVICES AND ARE A RECOGNIZED MODEL IN DIGITAL PRESERVATION AND DIGITAL CURATION.

WITH HAVING ONLY TWO FULL-TIME EMPLOYEES, THIS LIBRARY COMMITS TO CULTURAL PRESERVATION, INCLUSIVE AND RIGOROUS SCHOLARLY WORK, AND CAREFUL CUSTODIANSHIP OF CULTURAL FORMS AND ARTIFACTS. THEY SERVE AS A CRITICAL FIXTURE WITHIN THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY ? AND A BRIDGE TO THE WORLD BEYOND.

FOR THE 50-YEAR-OLD LIBRARY, AN ANCHOR IN THE GEORGETOWN COMMUNITY, BUILDING TRUST IS ESSENTIAL FOR EVERYTHING IT DOES. SEEKING NEW WAYS TO SUPPORT THE COMMUNITY'S DIVERSE NEEDS, THE LIBRARY HIRED THE CITY'S FIRST LICENSED SOCIAL WORKER IN 2016. THE LIBRARY'S COMMUNITY RESOURCE COORDINATOR SERVES AS A SOCIAL ADVOCATE FOR PATRONS IN CRISIS AND ESTABLISHES COLLABORATIONS AND COMMUNICATIONS WITH NONPROFITS THAT STRENGTHEN THE COMMUNITY'S SUPPORT SYSTEMS. BY PLACING A COORDINATOR WITHIN ITS WALLS, THE LIBRARY COULD GO WELL BEYOND THE SCOPE OF A TRADITIONAL SERVICES AND ESTABLISH A HIGH-LEVEL OF TRUST WITH RESIDENTS. NOW SERVING AS THE CITY'S CULTURAL CENTER, THE LIBRARY UNIQUELY EMPLOYS A FINE ARTS LIBRARIAN TO MANAGE FREE CONCERTS, ART EXHIBITS, AND COLLABORATION WITH PARTNERS TO ENHANCE THE CITY'S ART OFFERINGS. THE LIBRARY ALSO SERVES AS A CENTER FOR CIVIC DIALOGUE, USING RESOURCES AND PARTNERSHIPS TO FOSTER DISCUSSIONS ON SUCH DIFFICULT SUBJECTS AS POLITICS, BULLYING, AND RACE.

LOCATED IN THE HEART OF THE CITY, THE READING PUBLIC LIBRARY (RPL) IS PERFECTLY POSITIONED TO ADDRESS THE CITY'S NEEDS. BY CONTINUALLY ASSESSING COMMUNITY NEEDS, THE LIBRARY RESPONDS TO REQUESTS FOR SUPPORT AND SERVES AS AN ALLY FOR READING CITIZENS. RPL EMPLOYS A MULTI-FACETED EARLY CHILDHOOD LITERACY PROGRAM TO ENGAGE ALL YOUNG, GROWING MINDS THAT COME THROUGH ITS DOORS. IT USES POP CULTURE ICONS TO ENTICE CHILDREN INTO READING, AND BECAME A KEY PARTNER IN THE CREATION OF THE SUMMER LEARNING COALITION, BRINGING TOGETHER MULTIPLE COUNTY AGENCIES TO ADDRESS SUMMER READING LOSS. WITH THE LOSS OF MANUFACTURING JOBS, THE CITY HAS MANY PRODUCTION LINE WORKERS LOOKING FOR EMPLOYMENT. RPL'S FREE COMPUTER CLASSES HELP THEM MASTER COMPUTER SKILLS, MANEUVER THROUGH WEBSITES, CREATE RESUMES, AND ULTIMATELY IDENTIFY JOB OPPORTUNITIES. THE LIBRARY ASSISTS WITH SECOND CHANCE CITIZENS TO HELP PEOPLE RECENTLY RELEASED FROM PRISON, THROUGH TEMPORARY LIBRARY JOBS AND SUPPORT SERVICES.

ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA, HOME TO THE WORLD-RENOWNED MAYO CLINIC, IS A CITY WITH A CAN-DO ATTITUDE. WITH A PASSION THAT MIRRORS THAT ATTITUDE, THE ROCHESTER PUBLIC LIBRARY (RPL) STRIVES TO INCREASE EQUITY AND ACCESS BY TARGETING VULNERABLE POPULATIONS. THESE TARGETED POPULATIONS ARE SERVED BY THE LIBRARY'S MANTRA: "WE CARE." THAT CARING CULTURE IS AT THE CENTER OF EVERY DECISION THE LIBRARY MAKES. RPL HAS MADE A CONCERTED EFFORT TO BE A SAFE SPACE WHERE MARGINALIZED YOUTH AND FAMILIES SEEK REFUGE, FIND SERVICES, AND RECEIVE SUPPORT AND UNDERSTANDING. THE LIBRARY HOSTS CLUBS, SUPPORT GROUPS, MONTHLY MEETINGS, AND TEEN PROGRAMMING WITH THE PURPOSE OF CELEBRATING ALL INDIVIDUALS, THEIR IDENTITIES, AND THE COMMUNITY THAT SUPPORTS AND VALUES THEM. RPL CONNECTED WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT ROCHESTER READING CHAMPIONS, A FREE TUTORING PROGRAM THAT TRAINS AND DEPLOYS VOLUNTEERS TO TUTOR LOW-INCOME YOUTH STRUGGLING TO READ AND MEET GRADE-LEVEL READING REQUIREMENTS.

ORANGE COUNTY LIBRARY SYSTEM CREATES AND IMPLEMENTS EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THAT INSPIRE AND ENGAGE STUDENTS, PAVING THE WAY FOR ACADEMIC SUCCESS. THE LIBRARY HOSTS "EXPLORE TECH ENGINEERS," A TRAVELING EXHIBIT WITH ENGINEERING-RELATED DISPLAYS, PRESENTATIONS, AND ACTIVITIES TO GEARED FOR THE COUNTY'S MOST DISADVANTAGED STUDENTS. FAMILY STEM NIGHTS, MAKER MONDAYS, AND STEM CLUB ARE SOME OF THE MANY WAYS FAMILIES CAN INCORPORATE STEM ACTIVITIES INTO THEIR LIBRARY VISIT. THE LIBRARY PARTNERS WITH THE LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICT TO PROVIDE EACH STUDENT A VIRTUAL LIBRARY CARD, GIVING ALL DISTRICT STUDENTS ACCESS TO A SPECIALLY-CURATED SUITE OF ONLINE RESOURCES THAT SUPPORT LANGUAGE SKILLS DEVELOPMENT, EXPLORATION IN SCIENCE, AND DISCOVERY IN RESEARCH. IN RECENT YEARS, ORANGE COUNTY HAS SEEN AN INFLUX OF HAITIAN IMMIGRANTS. RESPONDING TO THIS POPULATION, THE LIBRARY BEGAN TRANSLATING A VARIETY OF MATERIAL INTO THE HAITIAN-CREOLE LANGUAGE AND PROVIDING ESOL CITIZENSHIP CLASSES.

PUEBLO, COLORADO, IS A TOWN AT A CROSSROADS. THIS DIVERSE COMMUNITY OF 165,000 PEOPLE UPHOLDS A WORKING-CLASS TRADITION THAT DATES BACK TO THE DAYS OF THE STEEL MILL. PUEBLO CITY-COUNTY LIBRARY DISTRICT (PCCLD) AIMS TO PROVIDE THE BEST POSSIBLE PUBLIC LIBRARY AND SERVICES FOR ITS RESIDENTS, AND IN THE LAST FIVE YEARS, PUEBLO CITIZENS HAVE BECOME INCREASINGLY COMMITTED TO THEIR PUBLIC LIBRARY. PCCLD FOCUSES A MAJORITY OF ITS ATTENTION ON LITERACY, EMPHASIZING THE WHOLE FAMILY'S LITERACY JOURNEY. EARLY CHILDHOOD LITERACY INITIATIVES ARE ROBUST, SUPPLEMENTED WITH LESSONS GIVEN TO PARENTS AND GUARDIANS TO UNDERSCORE THE IMPORTANCE OF READING TO CHILDREN AND ENCOURAGING A LIFELONG LOVE FOR READING. TO REACH THE 50 PERCENT OF THE POPULATION THAT IS HISPANIC, PCCLD ESTABLISHED THE HISPANIC RESOURCE CENTER, PROVIDING SERVICES, ACTIVITIES, AND FREE RESOURCES IN BOTH ENGLISH AND SPANISH THAT ILLUSTRATE HISPANIC CULTURE AND HISTORY SO IMPORTANT TO THE REGION.
NATIONAL AWARD FOR LIBRARY SERVICE
